content.title: Hang in there!
content.introtext:
Hang in there!
'At just the right time we will reap a harvest of blessing if we don't give up.' Galatians 6:9 NLT
Are you feeling fed up? Had enough? Ready to throw in the towel and quit? Sick of not being appreciated, wanted or valued? Thinking about 'slacking off' school, college, uni, friends or family because you just can't take anymore? Listen, hang in there!
'Let's not get tired of doing what is good...at just the right time we will reap a harvest of blessing if we don't give up.' (Galatians 6:9 NLT) There are no short cuts with God. We can miss out on so much great God stuff-just because we give up too early.
A man named William Wilberforce had been pushing the British Parliament to abolish the slave trade. He was about to give up when his friend John Wesley heard of his campaign. From his deathbed Wesley wrote to Wilberforce, 'Unless God has raised you up for this very thing, you will be worn out by the opposition of men and of devils. But if God be for you, who can be against you? Are all of them stronger than God? O be not weary in well doing! Go on, in the name of God and in the power of His might, till even American slavery shall vanish away before it.'
Wesley died six days later. Wilberforce fought for 42 more years. Three days before his own death, slavery was abolished in Britain. Eventually it was abolished in America too. Hang in there-what God has in store for you is worth any price you have to pay.
SoulFood Reading: Deut 32:29-34:12, Luke 12:1-12, Ps 119:17-24, Pr 17:7-10

content.title: Get real
content.introtext:
Get real
'...your sin will find you out.' Numbers 32:23 NKJ
Heard about a guy called Moses? The man God chose to lead all the Israelite people out from Egypt? It was no easy feat but Moses did it! There were 12 tribes of Israel; it was a tough, gruelling journey and just as they were about to reach their destination, two of the tribes decided they wanted to settle somewhere else. (Read it in Numbers 32.) The thing was, the other ten tribes still needed help so Moses kinda said, 'Get real; don't be so selfish. You can't just stop and look out for yourselves. We've all chipped in to get us this far; you can't give up on the rest of us now!'
So they agreed, and promised they would help and then Moses said: '...if you fail to keep your word, then you will have sinned against the Lord, and you may be sure that your sin will find you out.' (Numbers 32:23 NLT)
We can all have good intentions to do the right thing, but when we mess up or 'sin', as the Bible calls it, we are sinning against God. God knows about it (there's no hiding it from Him) and if we don't put it right, things will only get worse. Today: Get real! Put it right! Ask God to forgive you. Then live, knowing He has! Take action! Ask God to help you stop going against Him and help you stop sinning. Then live, knowing He is!
SoulFood Reading: Deut 30:1-32:28, Luke 11:45-54, Ps 119:9-16, Pr 17:4-6

content.title: Become a soul winner
content.introtext:
Become a soul winner
'...he who wins souls is wise.' Proverbs 11:30 NIV
When was the last time you prayed for your friends and family to become Christians? How often do you pray for that compared with how often you pray for yourself? Are you getting possessive about God and keeping Him to yourself? Everyone needs to know about His love and forgiveness and how amazing it is to be a Christian, not just you. Are you being selfish: God's taking care of me, teaching me, helping me, guiding me? Are your prayers all about you? 'God do this for me, help me with this, get me that, I want, I want, gimme, gimme!'
What about those people who don't know Him yet? Your friends and family who don't yet understand who Jesus is and how much they need Him? What about those people who feel so hurt or vulnerable? Or those who are addicted or abused and who don't yet know about a God who can heal and set them free? What about those don't yet know He's their Saviour?
God's bigger than us; He can handle us all. We don't need to be selfish-there's enough of Him to go around. In fact here's a crazy thing: the more you give God away to others, the more of God you'll get back! That's why Proverbs says, '...he who wins souls is wise.' Want more of God? Then be a Soul Winner! Tell everyone about Him and don't hold back.
SoulFood Reading: Deut 28-29, Luke 11:29-44, Ps 119:1-8, Pr 17:3

content.title: Promises, promises (3)
content.introtext:
Promises, promises (3)
'...The Word of our God stands forever.' Isaiah 40:8 NKJ
God's promises are powerful because '...The Word of our God stands forever.' Nothing and no one can break them, ruin them, stop them or destroy them. God's promises aren't just any old promises, they're 'Power Promises'. They are invincible! Grab your Bible and look up 2 Peter 1:3-11. Discover the power God's promises can bring into your life when you let them get under your skin and live by them:
(1) Nothing can stop you becoming who God intended you to be. 'By His divine power, God has given us everything we need for living a godly life...He has given us great and precious promises.' (v3-4 NLT)
(2) You can become pure. '...These are the promises that enable you to share His divine nature and escape the world's corruption caused by human desires.' (v4 NLT)
(3) You will be successful. '...The more you grow like this, the more productive and useful you will be in your knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.' (v8 NLT)
(4) You will live forever. '...God will give you a grand entrance into the eternal Kingdom of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.' (v11 NLT)
But the responsibility rests with us. We have to choose to make this happen: 'In view of all this, make every effort to respond to God's promises.'(v5 NLT)
(5) Let God's promises do their thing in your life: 'His power at work in us can do far more than we dare ask or imagine.' (Ephesians 3:20 CEV)
SoulFood Reading: Deut 25-27, Luke 11:14-28, Ps 78:65-72, Pr 17:1-2

content.title: Promises, promises (2)
content.introtext:
'...The Word of our God stands forever.' Isaiah 40:8 NKJ
Did you know that there are thousands of promises in the Bible? Why does God give us so many? The answer is so we can get to know the God of the promises. They show us who He is and what He is like. He wants us to not just read them but to soak them up in our hearts and minds. That's so we can really get to know Him and get into His way of thinking and acting.
He wants us to become so familiar with who He is that it becomes second nature to call on His promises, no matter what's going on in our lives. Whatever the situation, God wants us to remember His promises, just like Jesus did when He lived on Earth. Be challenged and encouraged by more of God's promises today. Don't just read them, but see what they tell you about God Himself and what He is like. Get to know the God of the promises:
(1) 'If you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.' (Romans 10:9 NLT)
(2) 'Though your sins are like scarlet, I will make them as white as snow.' (Isaiah 1:18 NLT)
(3) 'The eternal God is our hiding place; He carries us in His arms.' (Deuteronomy 33:27 CEV)
(4) '...I can do everything through Christ, who gives me strength.' (Philippians 4:13 NLT)
SoulFood Reading: Deut 22-24, Luke 11:1-13, Ps 78:56-64, Pr 16:33

content.title: Promises, promises (1)
content.introtext:
Promises, promises (1)
'...The Word of our God stands forever.' Isaiah 40:8 NKJ
Has anyone ever broken their promise to you? It hurts, doesn't it? You begin to look forward to something but then, when they don't come through, your hope is shattered. When that happens a lot, you can stop believing in promises, stop trusting what people tell you and become cynical about life. You can start to believe that no one really cares about you and that you need to look out for number one, coz nobody else will.
The Bible tells us that, '...The Word of our God stands forever.' What God says sticks-forever! The things that God has promised you are true. His Words are utterly dependable, totally trustworthy. When God promises you something you can know for sure that He'll never go back on it, forget about it or pretend He never said it. Get a load of what God promises you today and every day:
(1) 'Weapons made to attack you won't be successful; words spoken against you won't hurt at all.' (Isaiah 54:17 CEV)
(2) 'Don't be afraid...the Lord your God is living among you. He is a mighty Saviour. He will take delight in you... With His love, He will calm all your fears... He will rejoice over you.' (Zephaniah 3:16-17 NLT)
(3) '...Nothing can ever separate us from God's love. Neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither our fears for today nor our worries about tomorrow-not even the powers of hell can separate us from God's love.' (Romans 8:38 NLT)
SoulFood Reading: Deut 18-21, Luke 10:38-42, Ps 78:40-55, Pr 16:32

content.title: Step by step
content.introtext:
Step by step
'The Lord directs the steps of the godly...' Psalm 37:23 NLT
Ever tripped up and fallen flat on your face? Ouch! And how embarrassing if you're in a crowded place at the time! The shame! If we're not careful we can go through life like this. No, I don't mean tripping up every time we leave the house! But blundering along, making serious, stupid or careless mistakes that cause our lives to crash-land. Can we avoid it? Is it possible? God says it is: 'The Lord directs the steps of the godly. He delights in every detail of their lives.' (Psalm 37:23 NLT) This means we are to:
(1) Avoid 'People Pressure'. Never do what others want you to do if it goes against what God says. Live God's way and you'll avoid falling flat on your face.
(2) Tune into God's timing. Not many of us are good at waiting. Whatever it is we want, 'we want it and we want it now!' God isn't going to forget about you or leave you waiting unnecessarily. He is 100% tuned into every part, every detail of your life. Don't let your impatience cause you to run ahead or you'll find yourself on slippery ground and you'll trip up.
(3) Trust God. When God says He'll do something, you can be guaranteed that He will do it. He doesn't change His mind, get sidetracked or decide He can't be bothered! God always has your best interests in mind. Walk step by step with Him.
SoulFood Reading: Lev 24:17-22, Deut 15:7-1, Matt 5:38-48 (An Eye for an Eye/Love)

content.title: The BIG E
content.introtext:
...encourage and strengthen him...

Deuteronomy 3:28 NIV
Paul was bought a car for Christmas by his brother, a seriously generous gift! One day he came out of his office to find a young lad hanging round it. As he got nearer the young lad said, 'This your car Mr?' 'Yeah,' replied Paul '...it is. My brother gave it to me for Christmas'. 'No way,' said the lad, 'that's amazing, you mean your brother gave it to you and it didn't cost you nothing? I wish...' he hesitated. Of course Paul knew what he was going to wish for? He was going to wish to have a brother like that. But what the lad actually said, completely threw him, 'I wish' he said 'that I could be a brother like that'. So often we can live life looking what we can get rather than what we can give. This lad knew the value of being an encourager. God asked Moses to 'encourage and strengthen' Joshua so he could take over as leader. Moses had led the Israelites out of slavery in Egypt. It hadn't been easy, the Israelites were not the best travellers, constantly moaning! This is why it was so important that Moses encouraged Joshua. He understood what the job was about. God wants us to encourage each other to help us through our lives: '...encourage one another daily... so that none of you may be hardened by sin's deceitfulness.' (Hebrews 3:13) So today, GO ENCOURAGE!

content.title: You have the power!
content.introtext:
'"I have given you authority...to overcome all the power of the enemy."'

Luke 10: 19 NIV
You have not been called to defeat Satan, Jesus already did that 2000 years ago. You have been called to enforce his defeat! Paul tells us in Colossians 2: 15 that Jesus disarmed Satan and made a public spectacle of him at the cross.
When General McArthur met the Supreme Commander of the Japanese forces at the end of World War II, he stripped the glittering medals from his chest, took the sword out of his hand, and as the world watched he declared total victory for the allies and enforced the terms of surrender. And that's what Jesus did for you at the cross. When He died and rose again He stripped the devil of his power, took the sword out of his hand and declared: 'All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to Me. Therefore go...' (Matthew 28:18-19 NIV). Go in His power! Go in His name! 'What's in a name?' you ask. 'Therefore God exalted Him to the highest place and gave Him the name that is above every name, that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, in heaven and on earth and under the earth, and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.' (Philippians 2: 9-11 NIV)
Any claim to authority is only as good as the power that backs it up. And for us, the power we need is in the name of Jesus. Whether in heaven, earth or hell: 'Every knee should bow' and 'every tongue confess that Jesus is Lord.' And He has transferred that power to you today. So go out and use it!
SoulFood reading: Deut 1-2, Luke 10:25-37, Ps 78:32-39, Pr 16:31

content.title: Get your act together! (2)
content.introtext:
'...Be an example... in the way you live...'



1 Timothy 4: 12 NLT
Heard of Nanny McPhee? You may have seen the film or maybe it's not your cuppa tea? But this story is able to give us a good picture, which can encourage us to, 'Be an example...in the way you live.' 7 children without a mum are now nannyless for the 17th time, driving their poor dad to despair! But all is about to change as Nanny McPhee walks into their life. She arrives, hunched over, her face disfigured so bad that she's never going to win any beauty competitions. The children do their worst, hoping to send her packing. But she doesn't leave! She stays showing them the right way to live and as time goes on, the children begin to behave. What's so cool about this story is that the more the children do the right thing the more beautiful Nanny McPhee becomes. She straightens up, warts vanish and blotches disappear from her face. Their behaviour affects her beauty. At the end of the film Nanny McPhee looks like a totally different person, certainly more appealing to the eye.
When we don't 'get our act together' as a Christian we make Jesus look ugly. When we act in the wrong way we don't show Jesus in all His beauty; we give people an uglier version of who[a16] He really is. Let Jesus be seen as He really is through 'being an example...in the way you live.'
SoulFood reading: Acts 27-28, Luke 10:13-24, Ps 78:17-31, Pr 16:26-30

content.title: Get your act together! (1)
content.introtext:
'...Be an example... in the way you live...'

1 Timothy 4: 12 NLT
Behind the set, actors get ready preparing for the show that's soon to take place. How they appear back stage is very different to how they will soon behave during their performance. Lights and action! The play begins and all their focus and attention is about what's happening on stage, all they're thinking about is delivering their lines well, in the right place and time. When it ends, they're back to being their normal selves, they dress and act differently and their thoughts are no longer all about the show! That's ok, though! They're actors, that's how it is! If we are not careful, we can find ourselves living life as a Christian like an actor. In church we will be one character, focused on how to live as a Christian. We will speak and behave in a certain way and pray, worship, read the Bible, but then when we come home we live and act in a totally different way. Today God is saying, 'Be an example...in the way you live.' All the time!
So get your act together. Be a good example no matter where you are or who you are with: 'In every way be an example of doing good deeds....speak the truth so that you cannot be criticised. Then those who are against you will be ashamed because there is nothing bad to say about us.' (Titus 2: 7-8 NCV)
SoulFood reading: Acts 24-26, Luke 10:1-12, Ps 78:9-16, Pr 16:25

content.title: You can handle it!
content.introtext:
'You will keep in perfect peace all who trust in you, all whose thoughts are fixed on you!'

Isaiah 26: 3 NLT
Have you been having a tough time recently? Whether you have or not, you'll know what it feels like, right? Because one thing is guaranteed-at some point you will have tough times! The Bible guarantees it! 'We must suffer...' (Romans 8: 17 NCV) So the question to ask is not, 'How do I avoid having a hard time?' instead we should ask, 'What do I do when things get tough?' Our answer would probably be, 'If life is difficult, then we can't possibly enjoy ourselves. We just have to moan and complain and look miserable, until it's over.' But God answers our question with a promise, 'I will keep in perfect peace all who trust in Me, all whose thoughts are fixed on Me.' What a great promise! We just need to do our best and let God do the rest as we look to Him for help. We don't have to worry or panic, we can feel calm and relaxed, because God will fill us with His peace. This way God has the last word. No more running around like a headless chook or getting caught up in your emotions or reacting to what people are saying. You'll know God's in control, you won't even have to look miserable, you could even smile. Imagine that! When things go wrong-and they will-do what God asks of you and then chill. Sit back and watch Him work on your behalf!
SoulFood reading: Acts 22-23, Luke 9:57-62, Ps 78:1-8, Pr 16:23-24

content.title: Say what? (3)
content.introtext:
'...grow in grace...'



2 Peter 3:18 AMP
We're sticking with this verse for one more day because there's one more thing we need to know about growing in God's grace. We have already learned that (a) we need it, and (b) it's free and our choice to accept it. But when we've got it, there's something that God wants us to do with it, He wants us to give it away! That's right-give it away! There is something very unique about God's grace: it never runs out and it grows when you give it away. When we allow God's grace in our lives we receive God's unconditional love, forgiveness, power, faithfulness. And He says, '...Freely you have received, freely give.' (Matthew 10: 8 NIV) If we got it from Him for free, He wants us to give it away for free. Now, this is where it gets tricky. It's easy to accept something you don't deserve for free, but harder to give something away to people whom you think don't deserve it. The means the next time someone does you wrong, God wants you to be gracious and forgive them, not go round and punch their lights out, or moan at them for months on end. In short, however God treats you, He wants you to treat others. Impossible? No! God wouldn't ask you to do something you couldn't handle. He'll help you. Grow in grace! You'll be surprised how much you enjoy it. :)
SoulFood reading: Acts 20-21, Luke 9:46-56, Ps 46, Pr 16:20-22

content.title: Say what? (2)
content.introtext:
'...grow in grace...'

2 Peter 3: 18 AMP
Jesus told stories when He was on earth to help us understand grace! Like the story of a group of guys who worked on a vineyard for the day. Some worked all day, some for just an hour, but the owner of the land chose to give them all the same pay. Why? Because he could and he chose to do it. (Matthew 20: 1-16) Then there's the story of a son whose dad threw him a great big party to welcome him home, even though he had been really selfish and rebellious (Luke 15: 11-32). These are grace stories-about people who received good things that they didn't deserve. God has things He wants to give to you. Even though no-one deserves it, He wants to give to them, and He can, because of His grace! Some people believe that if they try really hard to be good enough they can get themselves to heaven. Some people believe that they are so bad that they can never get to heaven. That's not how grace works. Grace is not about what you've done in the past or about what you can do in the future. It's about what God can do right now. '...God loved the world (that's you too!) so much that He gave his one and only son that whoever (you again!) believes in Him shall not perish but have eternal life.' (based on John 3:16 NLT) Accept God's grace today.
SoulFood reading: Acts 18-19, Luke 9:37-45, Ps 42:6-11, Pr 16:17-19

content.title: SAY WHAT!? (1)
content.introtext:
'...grow in grace...'

2 Peter 3: 18 AMP
What's God on about when He tells us to 'grow in grace?' What is grace? Something you say at mealtimes like... 'God bless this bunch as they munch their lunch'. How do you grow in that? Do we 'grow' by 'saying grace' over our snacks as well? 'Thanx for this sweet, a tasty treat, please give me some dietary tips, to stop this clinging to my hips!' Or is grace something we say to each other in church? Like ...'The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all, Amen!' If it is, how can you 'grow' in that? Do we need to scrap the service altogether and just talk sentences?
GRACE= God's Radically Amazing Choice for Everyone! God's: It belongs to God, from God, He invented it, He gave it! You can't get in anywhere else. Radical: Extreme, there's nothing like it; it blasts beyond boundaries, leaves no-one untouched. Amazing: incredible, unbelievable, stupendous, inconceivable!
Choice: You get to choose whether you want it; whether you want to be transformed by it or not.
Everyone: No-one gets left out. It's for every single person, from the youngest to the oldest.
We all need it, for 'all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, and are justified freely by his grace through the redemption that came by Christ Jesus.' (Romans 3: 23 NKJV)
SoulFood reading: Acts 16-17, Luke 9:28-36, Ps 42:1-5, Pr 16:16

content.title: Stick with it
content.introtext:
'...the testing of your faith produces patience.'


James 1: 3 NKJV
Once upon a time a farmer's donkey fell into a dry well. When the farmer heard the donkey's braying and realised what had happened, he decided that neither the donkey nor the well was worth the trouble of saving. So he went and asked his neighbours to come and help him bury his donkey in the well and put it out of its misery. Initially, the donkey was very upset. You would be too, if you were in a deep hole and people started throwing muck on top of you! But as the dirt rained down on his back, the old donkey had a thought. He decided that every time a shovel of dirt landed on his back, he would shake it off and step up. And that's what he did. As the dirt cascaded down the well, the old donkey kept shaking it off and stepping up. Hours later, the exhausted donkey finally stepped over the wall of the well. What was meant to bury him actually helped him!
When troubles come, don't give up; like the donkey, have patience and persevere, then you too will discover that what you thought was hindering you is actually helping you. '...These troubles test your faith, and this will give you patience. Let your patience show itself perfectly in what you do. Then you will be perfect and complete and have everything you need.' (James 1: 3-5 NCV)
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 5:1-17, Luke 4:16-30

content.title: Your Comfort Blanket
content.introtext:
'...God is our merciful Father and the source of all comfort.'

2 Corinthians 1: 3 NLT
Lots of children have a special blanket or a toy that they take everywhere. Perhaps you remember having one when you were little...you even may have it still! Have you ever been around a child who wants their comfort blanket but it has gone missing; 'AAAAGGHHH' the deafening sound is still ringing in your ears: utter chaos, frantic parents, screaming child, bedlam!
God is described as the 'God of all comfort'. We may grow up and no longer need our comfort blanket, but we never stop needing comfort. We all need to feel safe and secure; loved. There's no situation you can be in, nothing so bad you can experience, where God, the God of all comfort, can't meet your needs. He's like the ultimate comfort blanket, always there, always ready; He never goes missing and is never unavailable.
God promises that He will use all our hard times to help others, so nothing we go through ever goes to waste. Listen: 'Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ...who comforts us in all our troubles so that we can comfort those in any trouble with the comfort we ourselves have received from God.' (2 Corinthians 1: 3-4 NIV)
SoulFood reading: Acts 14-15, Luke 9:18-27, Ps 1, Pr 16:10-15

content.title: Butt out!
content.introtext:
'...Who are you to judge...?'

Romans 14: 4 NKJV
You can just tell by that look on her face she's guilty. And he might not be saying it but you know he's thinking it. We think we've got people sussed, don't we? The way they look or act or just the tone of their voice 'says it all'. If we're not careful we can so easily 'write someone off' because we think 'we know', before we actually find out the facts.
Sometimes we can believe we're 'doing God a favour' by 'sussing that person out' on His behalf. If we're not careful, we can stop talking to certain people about Jesus, because we've 'sussed out' they're not interested, so decide 'not to waste our time' on them. We don't even ask God about it! When someone wrongs us, we believe we have the right to go and 'give 'em a good talking to' making sure everyone knows how great we are and how terrible they are, in the process. We act; we don't ask God about it! If we did we'd hear Him saying this: '...always be willing to listen and slow to speak...' (James 1: 19 NCV), and this 'No-one can know a person's thoughts except that person's own spirit, and no-one can know God's thoughts except God's own Spirit.' (1 Corinthians 2: 11 NLT) So before you go 'writing someone off', ask God about it, only He knows what's best. So butt out and let God in!
SoulFood reading: Acts 12-13, Luke 9:1-17, Ps 65, Pr 16:8-9

content.title: Boss or boring?
content.introtext:
'Because of Christ and our faith in him, we can now come boldly and confidently into God's presence.'

Ephesians 3: 12 NLT
You're told about two events happening in church next week. The first is that youth event you've been waiting for; the second is a new prayer meeting. Your reaction is 'YAY!' & 'Ugh!' You think one is going to be 'amazing', the other is going to be 'boring'! And we both know which we're talking about here! Why is it that when it comes to praying, lots of us think it's BORING?
One of the most sought-after people in the world is Barack Obama. He's made history as the first black American president. This time last year over 2 million people stood in a freezing cold Washington, DC, to watch the ceremony as he took the oath to become the 44th Commander-in-Chief! People travelled from all over the world to be there. But no-one had the privilege of chatting with him in person. But how amazing is this: you can get to speak to the One who is not just in charge of a country but the One who is in charge of the whole planet! The most highly placed person in the entire universe says that you can talk to Him ANYTIME YOU WANT! More than that He says you can go 'boldly and confidently' because He won't turn you away. In fact just the opposite: He's actually waiting for you! How can that be boring? The creator of the Universe is waiting to speak with YOU! So get praying today.
SoulFood reading: Acts 10-11, Luke 8:40-56, Ps 14, Pr 16:6-7

content.title: Don't slouch
content.introtext:
'...she could stand straight...'

Luke 13: 13 NLT
'DON'T SLOUCH!' Have you ever had it said to you by a teacher or parent? 'Stop slouching, sit up straight.' Well guess what? Today God is saying 'DON'T SLOUCH!' Now that doesn't mean God's having a go at you about the way you veg on the couch watching the TV or slump in the chair at your computer. He's saying, 'Know your worth, know your value, and walk tall, because with Me there is no need to slouch!'
If we get criticised, put down, bullied or made the punchline of someone's joke, what can happen is that we start to believe we are worthless. Instead of being able to walk with our head held high, knowing we are, '...fearfully and wonderfully made...' (Psalm 139: 14 NIV) we end up walking stooped over, head down feeling negative about who we are.
Luke tells us about a woman Jesus met who was bent over and couldn't straighten up. She was slouching big time and had done for 18 years; something inside her was crippling her. Then she met Jesus, 'He called her over... He touched her and instantly she could stand straight.' (Luke 13: 12-13 NLT) Jesus made a MASSIVE difference in her life & He can do the same for you. Allow Jesus to touch your life, just ask Him, so you can stand up straight! Hear Him tell you your worth. You are a priceless precious person in God's sight!
SoulFood reading: Acts 8-9, Luke 8:26-39, Ps 146, Pr 16:4-5

content.title: Watch where you're going!
content.introtext:
'The end of all things is near. Therefore be clear minded and self-controlled so that you can pray.'

1 Peter 4: 7 NIV
Walk along the road with your head down looking at the pavement, and it won't be long before you end up walking smack bang into something and it's gonna hurt! We need to look ahead to what God is sending our way, we need to watch out for it and prepare for it. Otherwise we won't see it coming! 'The end of all things is near. Therefore be clear minded and self controlled so that you can pray.' God wants us to talk to Him about what's up ahead and what's going to matter when we get there!
Have you seen the film Slumdog Millionaire? It's about a young guy from a very poor background in India, who wins Who Wants To Be A Millionaire. How does he know the answers? The film takes you on a journey through his life. For each question, he had learnt the answer through events that had happened in his life (often difficult and sad situations). He was not incredibly intelligent; he didn't have a massive knowledge about the world. It just so happened that the questions he was asked, he had learnt the answer through how he had lived his life. As a result he became a millionaire! Amazing!
Now being a Christian isn't about winning Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, but it is about making your life count. Watch where you're going. Talk to God about what's up ahead.
SoulFood reading: Acts 6-7, Luke 8:16-25, Ps 140, Pr 16:3

content.title: Keep Growing.
content.introtext:
'...until Christ is formed in you...'

Galatians 4: 19 NIV
Think for a minute about all the things you've learned since you were born. You can walk, run, and talk! And that's just for starters!! They say you learn the most in the first 5 years of your life than at any other time. And you can see why! You're taking in massive amounts of information, growing and developing new skills. Wow, you're amazing! But we don't often think about that really do we, because it just seems to happen naturally. We expect it!
When you become a Christian, it's the start of a whole new life; it's time to learn and grow all over again. In fact we're actually, '...being transformed into His likeness...' (2 Corinthians 3: 18 NIV) We're becoming Christlike. It's not instant, it happens over time. And, just like growing up naturally, the way to do it is through food and exercise-eating God's Word, the Bible, and doing the things He says. First we have milk: 'Like new born babies, crave pure spiritual milk, so that by it you may grow up in your salvation...' (1 Peter 2: 2 NIV), then solids: '...solid food is for the mature, who by constant use have trained themselves to distinguish good from evil.' (Hebrews 5: 14 NIV) If we're not careful though, we can stay like babies and never grow up. 'I gave you milk not solid food for you were not yet ready for it...' (1 Corinthians 3: 2 NIV) Don't get left behind... keep growing!
SoulFood reading: Acts 3:11 - 5:42, Luke 8:1-15, Ps 133, Pr 16:2

content.title: Need more strength? Wait on God!
content.introtext:
'...but those who hope in the LORD will renew their strength...'



Isaiah 40:31 NIV
When you pray to God, do you get a TXT from Him a few minutes later saying when and how He'll answer your prayer? Not likely! But God does promise that if we wait on Him, He will give us strength. Think of it a bit like papier mache; did you ever make it at primary school? You know, where you stick newspaper to a balloon. Newspaper itself isn't strong; it's well easy to rip. But the more layers you put on, the stronger it gets, until in the end, it's almost impossible to break. You're a bit like that balloon. Every time you wait on the Lord, another layer of paper is added, and you get a bit stronger. So if you're feeling like things are tough and you can't do it yourself, just wait on Him, read your Bible, pray; you will get stronger.
Don't panic; 'waiting' doesn't have to be all about sitting cross legged in silence, meditating. Sometimes it can be proactive too. If you're 'waiting' on someone in a restaurant, you're seeing to their needs; so sometimes, weird as it sounds, waiting on God involves proactively doing God's will, and serving others. Do you need more strength? Well grab hold of this promise that's yours as a child of God: 'Wait on the Lord; be of good courage, and He shall strengthen your heart...' (Psalm 27:14 NKJV).

SoulFood: Deut 18:9-18, Dan 2. Isa 47:5-15, Acts 16:16-34

content.title: Living on the edge
content.introtext:
'But Daniel was determined not to defile himself...'


Daniel 1: 8 NLT
It can be tough being a Christian sometimes, difficult to keep on doing the right thing all the time. Daniel had it really tough. When he was only 14 years old his country was invaded, he was taken away and forced to learn a different language and to work for the foreign government. He had no idea when or if he'd ever return home. You wouldn't blame him for 'slacking off' in a situation like that, would you? But Daniel didn't. He chose to trust God!
Daniel was constantly being tempted to forget about living for God. It's hard to do the right thing when you're at that party with your mates and the alcohol and love interests are in plentiful supply, isn't it? Well, Daniel was tempted every day to forget God's way. Did he say 'stuff it' and join in? No! Every day Daniel was faithful, doing what was right in all things. At one point Daniel was thrown into a den of lions. Did he panic? No! Every day of his life Daniel had chose to obey God, and as a result when a MASSIVE problem came his way, he could handle it!
If you're tempted to think it doesn't matter about getting the little day-to-day things right, remember Daniel. It was only through obeying in all the small things everyday that he was able to get the big things right too.
SoulFood reading: 1 Sam 5:1 - 6:16, Rev 11:15-19

content.title: The BIG E
content.introtext:
'...encourage and strengthen him...'



Deuteronomy 3:28 NIV
Paul was bought a car for Christmas by his brother, a seriously generous gift! One day he came out of his office to find a young bloke hanging round it. As he got nearer the young bloke said, 'This your car Mr?' 'Yeah,' replied Paul '...it is. My brother gave it to me for Christmas'. 'No way,' said the bloke, 'that's amazing, you mean your brother gave it to you and it didn't cost you nothing? I wish...' he hesitated. Of course Paul knew what he was going to wish for? He was going to wish to have a brother like that. But what the bloke actually said, completely threw him, 'I wish' he said 'that I could be a brother like that'. So often we can live life looking what we can get rather than what we can give. This bloke knew the value of being an encourager.
God asked Moses to 'encourage and strengthen' Joshua so he could take over as leader. Moses had led the Israelites out of slavery in Egypt. It hadn't been easy, the Israelites were not the best travellers, constantly moaning! This is why it was so important that Moses encouraged Joshua. He understood what the job was about. God wants us to encourage each other to help us through our lives: '...encourage one another daily... so that none of you may be hardened by sin's deceitfulness.' (Hebrews 3:13) So today, GO ENCOURAGE!

SoulFood: Ezra 1-2, John 7:25-44, Ps 18:20-29, Pr 4:18

content.title: It's NOT about YOU!
content.introtext:
'Don't be selfish; don't try to impress others. Be humble, thinking of others as better than yourselves.'


Philippians 2: 3 NLT
'Hey what about me?', 'I am SO much better than she is!', 'That's the last time I help him!' Ever said or thought something like that? If we're honest, every one of us has thought, said and even acted on words like that some time. We are naturally selfish. 'It's all about ME, right!?' WRONG! We've read today words said by Paul to the Church in Philippi telling us that God doesn't want us to be selfish, that's not His way, that's not what He created you to be! Why not? After all, being the centre of attention and having everyone run round after you doesn't seem a bad idea, does it? James 3:16 (NLT)says, 'For wherever there is jealousy and selfish ambition, there you will find disorder and evil of every kind.' And in verse 15 it says that selfishness is motivated by the devil. WARNING! If you're thinking about being selfish today, THINK AGAIN! God has let you know that living selfishly will bring every kind of evil your way; you don't want that for your life! More importantly, God doesn't want that for your life! And He has promised to help you, '...when you are tempted, He will show you a way out...' (1 Corinthians 10:13 NLT) Talk to Him today, about things you find tough, ask Him to kick out the selfish attitude and fill you with His Spirit instead!
SoulFood reading: Acts 1:1 - 3:10, Luke 7:36-50, Ps 123, Pr 16:1

content.title: Don’t go there!
content.introtext:
'Do not withhold good from those who deserve it when it is in your power to act.'



Proverbs 3:27 NIV
Ever had this experience? Your excited about being a Christian and living for God when, WHAM! The warm fuzzy feelings suddenly fizzle. That's not bad or wrong. Feelings come and go all the time. What's bad is when we let those 'can't be bothered' feelings keep us from doing what is right. That's called apathy and God hates it (Isaiah 32:9; Amos 6:1). Apathy is one step away from a proper bad attitude, it always ends up destructive not productive. When a bad attitude infects our brains it spoils all the fun and poisons friendships. Somehow, even though it's not what you wanted you find yourself in a slanging' match with your best friend. The hurtful words are coming out your mouth faster than you can think to stop them. When did you stop caring about their feelings? Answer; when apathy arrived.
The key to overcoming apathy is not by trying to crank up a bunch of ooey-gooey feelings. You need to say sorry and then start doing the things you did at first. That means doing these three things today and every day:
1) Talk to God in prayer (Ephesians 6:18)
2) Listen to God by reading The Bible (Acts 20:32)
3) Show love by helping others. This is why God says, 'Do not withhold good from those who deserve it when it's in your power to help them'. God doesn't want you to become a-pathetic. So don't go there!

SoulFood: Zeph 1-3, John 7:14-24, Ps 104:24-35, Pr 24:28-29

content.title: LIAR! LIAR! (4)
content.introtext:
'Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.'

John 8: 32 NIV
Julie hadn't been in touch with her parents for a long time, so she wrote them a letter: 'Dear Mum & Dad, it's me! Just letting you know how I'm doing. I've fallen in love with a guy called Blaze. He's a great guy, but he quit Uni a few years ago to get married. That didn't work out, so he got a divorce last year. We've been going out a few weeks now and we're thinking about getting married in November. I decided to move in with Blaze last Friday and have dropped out of Uni. I really needed to get a job to support me and Blaze but will probably go back to Uni after the baby is born. Oh yes, I'm pregnant! Ok, don't panic, everything I've written in this letter so far is a lie. None of it is true. But what is true is that I didn't do very well in my 1st year exams and I really need some money. Could you please send me some? Thanks. Love, Julie.'
Julie was trying to make bad news seem like good news by bringing it from another perspective! When we stray from the truth, we can't make good decisions or know the difference between right and wrong. The good seems bad and the bad seems good. Our view of reality is always a matter of perspective, and the only viewpoint worth trusting is God's. Stay close to Him.
SoulFood reading: Joel 1-3, Luke 7:24-35, Ps 118:19-29, Pr 15:33

content.title: What's going on?
content.introtext:
'You intended to harm me, but God intended it all for good.'



Genesis 50:20 NLT
Yesterday we faced up to the reality that life can be painful, that things in our lives can go horribly wrong. It did for Joseph (read Genesis 37 - 50)! At first you think, will anything ever go right for this poor guy? He gets laughed at, bullied, beat up and left for dead by his brothers before they decide to sell him. As a result he has to live in Egypt as a slave, his boss's wife tells lies about him and he's thrown into prison, where he's forgotten about! Nothing's gone well and it's not even his fault. What's going on?
Listen to what Joseph says to his brothers. He basically says 'you guys planned evil against me but God used those same plans for good'. Rather than get angry, bitter and plot revenge, Joseph put his trust in God. No matter what was happening, Joseph kept on living for God. Later, he recognised how God had worked in His life all along. God used all the mess to enable him to save the lives of thousands, including the lives of his family. He had no reason to be angry but every reason to be thankful.
Romans 8:28 NAS says, 'And we know that God causes everything to work together for the good of those who love God...' Remember today that no disaster, disease or delay is beyond God turning it into something good.

SoulFood: 1 Tim 4-6, John 7:1-13, Ps 104:1-23, Pr 24:26-27

content.title: LIAR! LIAR! (3)
content.introtext:
'Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.'

John 8: 32 NIV
Ok, so this is the third day we've read this verse. But rather than say, 'Give it a rest already!' read it over again and let it really sink in! When we're not living in God's truth, we're living in lies; we're going against God and getting trapped in the stuff we do wrong. So test out how you're doing.Imagine this: You have just found out that for the last two weeks your every movement has been picked up by secretly hidden cameras. Without realising it your life has been the latest Big Brother experiment. Everything that you have done and said over the last two weeks has been broadcast over the internet. The TV cameras and the press are outside waiting with their difficult questions. How are you feeling? Are you thinking back to certain moments hoping that no-one really saw that or heard you say that? Are you feeling confident about the press interview? Or do you want the ground to open up and swallow you? Are you just thankful it was this month it happened and not last month? If you're not feeling totally confident, take time to think where you went wrong and talk to God about it. Ask Him to forgive you and start again. Jesus says, 'If you hold to my teaching, you are really my disciples. Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.' (John 8: 32 NIV)
SoulFood reading: Jer 51-52, Luke 7:11-23, Ps 118:10-18, Pr 15:31-32

content.title: OUCH!
content.introtext:
'The Israelites groaned in their slavery and cried out, and their cry for help because of their slavery went up to God'



Exodus 2:23 NIV
In the short time it takes you to read this, thousands of people will suffer. Death, disaster, disease, loss, trouble, violence, hardship, tragedy, failure are some of the harsh realities of life. They bring with them, grief, heartache, depression, agony, disappointment, sorrow, sadness, pain, misery. The Bible tells us that people on this earth, will always suffer, because of sin. Even Jesus said, 'In this world you will have trouble' (John 16:33 NIV). So the question we should be asking is not, 'will I suffer?', but 'how will I deal with suffering?'
Look what the Israelites did, 'they cried out (to God) for help'. In Exodus 3 we discover that when God's people are hurting: He sees, He Hears, He cares; and He acts. For years the Israelites had been held as slaves in Egypt and God promised to set them free (Genesis 15:16, 46:3-4). They had to wait a long time for that promise to be kept. God rescued them when He knew the time was right. God's rescue doesn't always come the moment we want it.
If you're suffering today, remember that even though God has a different time schedule; He sees, He Hears, He really does cares; and He will act. Do you know someone who is suffering? Ask God to show you how He could use you to help them. God used Moses to set the people free from slavery. God will use you too.

SoulFood: 1 Tim 1-3, John 6:52-71, Ps 114, Pr 24:23-25

content.title: LIAR! LIAR! (2)
content.introtext:
'Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.'

John 8: 32 NIV
Do you know what the most deadly weapon in the world is? More deadly than any nuclear weapon of mass destruction! It's your tongue! The tongue is always right there at the start, the root source of every war that's started, every evil deed that's done, every weapon that's built, every scheme that is plotted to bring about death and destruction. The Bible says, '...our tongues get out of control...they are restless...always spreading deadly poison.' (James 3: 8 CEV) Who would have believed, that little pink muscle we're also encouraged to scrub clean along with our teeth each day (with specially made toothbrushes built to scrape the fuzz off), could be so dangerous? We have to be dead careful how we use it. If not, it will stop you living in God's truth-the 'truth that will set you free'. You wouldn't choose to live as a prisoner, would you? Locked up for your whole life? NO! So how do we tame our tongue and live in God's truth? (1) Trust God's Word more than your own. (2) Remember God's way is the best way. (3) Understand that we need God's help to 'tame our tongue'-never go it alone! (4) Think ahead. Get it right now-it makes it easier in the future. (5) Help others live the same way.
SoulFood reading: Jer 49-50, Luke 7:1-10, Ps 118:1-9, Pr 15:27-30

content.title: Chill!
content.introtext:
'By the seventh day God had finished the work he had been doing; so on the seventh day he rested from all his work.'



Genesis 2:2 NIV
Get this; God doesn't get tired! (Psalm 121:4) So what's He doing taking a rest then eh? Could it be that rest isn't just about stopping when you're tired to 'recharge your batteries'? Could it be that God is telling us something important? When God rested, He was telling us we need to rest too! So how exactly did God do it?
1) He rested after he had worked; sorry if you were thinking 'YAY I can rest all the time God says!' We too need to work first and then rest!
2) He worked 6/7 of the week and rested 1/7; when we come back from holiday, we can want to stay in 'holiday mode', and start dreaming of holidaying all year round. But God's way for our lives is about getting the right balance.
3) He blessed His rest time; He set it apart as something different. He gave a rule to live by (commandment 4 in Exodus 20) that our rest must be a priority, something special, different than any other day.
4) He used it to look back on all His work; we too need to regularly look back at what we've been doing and how we've been living, to avoid making the same mistakes.
God was able to look back and call everything 'very good.' Can you look back on your last week and say the same? Take time to chill!

SoulFood: Habakkuk 1-3, John 6:35-51, Ps 127, Pr 24:19-22

content.title: LIAR! LIAR! (1)
content.introtext:
'Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.'

John 8: 32 NIV
Have you seen the film Liar Liar? Actor Jim Carrey plays a character who is a compulsive liar until his son makes a wish that he will never be able to lie again-and his wish comes true. There are some funny moments as his dad struggles with telling the truth, but in the end he actually discovers that being honest brings out the best in him and his life changes dramatically for the better. Jesus wants us to live a life of truth. He says, 'If you keep on obeying what I've said, you are truly my disciples. You will know the truth and the truth will set you free.' (John 8: 31-32 CEV) Jesus knows that when we lie, it hurts, destroys and traps us. Jesus wants us to live a life of freedom.
No-one can force us to stop lying, but if they could would it make any difference to you? Seriously think about it for a moment, how often do you think it would be a problem for you? We've all got room for improving. We need to focus on living 100% in the truth! Why? Firstly: Because, 'The Lord hates...a lying tongue.' (Proverbs 6: 16-17 NKJV) Secondly: It traps us, 'A witness who lies will not go free, liars will never escape.' (Proverbs 19: 5 NCV) Talk to God today and ask Him to help you to live your life in His truth!
SoulFood reading: Jer 45-48, Luke 6:37-49, Ps 109:16-31, Pr 15:23-26

content.title: Having it all
content.introtext:
'...here is the conclusion of the matter: Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.'



Ecclesiastes 12:13 NIV
If anyone ever 'had it all' Solomon did. Knowledge, power, and the biggest bank account ever! On top of that his house was full of 100's of beautiful women, plus he was a famous writer, a connoisseur of fine wines and his dinner parties resembled 'lifestyles of the rich and famous'. In his spare time he built magnificent palaces, gardens and parks! But here's the amazing thing: Solomon never found fulfilment in his unlimited possessions, power or pleasure (and he really did try... read Ecclesiastes and see for yourself!). That's why he made this statement near the end of his life, 'Here is the conclusion of the matter: Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.'
So there you have it. Solomon, one of the most powerful and people who ever lived - saying, 'Take it from a guy who's tried it all: This world, despite all its glitz and glamour, cannot fill the empty place in your soul. Only a relationship with God will satisfy your deepest longings'. So, what about you? Have you found the ultimate fulfilment that only Jesus Christ can bring? Open your heart to Him. Ask Him to forgive your sins and fill you with His life and love. Then spend your days getting to know Him. That's the smartest move you can ever make. And that's the way to true riches.

SoulFood: Joel 2:12-32, Mk 9:2-27

content.title: God knows best!
content.introtext:
'...He gave them their request, but sent leanness into their soul...'

Psalm 106: 15 NKJV
Have you ever seen a child waving their ice-cream about with mum saying 'hold it still or it will fall on the floor'? After the 4th time mum goes 'fine have it your way'. Then you hear the siren start, the ice-cream is on the floor, the kid is at full noise and mum is going 'I wish you'd listen to me sometimes!' The mum knew best, and was saying 'don't' out of love, but the kid just wouldn't listen!
Sometimes, we can be like that with God-we think we know better than Him, and though He may be stopping us from doing something in His wisdom, if we keep on and on at Him, He may step back and let us have it our way. But that doesn't mean it'll always work for the best, just like the kid with the ice cream.
After God brought His people through the Red Sea, they soon forgot what He'd done, and tested Him-and He gave them what they asked, providing physically but 'sent leanness into their soul'. They were spiritually empty, coz they did things their way. Check out Exodus 2:11-14, when Moses took things in his own hands-he couldn't even keep one soldier that he killed buried in the sand. But doing it God's way later, a whole army was buried in the Red Sea! So today, make up your mind to do it God's way: it's so much better!
SoulFood reading: Jer 41-44, Luke 6:27-36, Ps 109:1-15, Pr 15:22

content.title: Carpe Diem
content.introtext:
'Be thankful in all circumstances, for this is God's will for you who belong to Christ Jesus..'




1 Thessalonians 5:18 NLT
'Carpe diem', that's Latin for 'seize the day'. It means live for today, not tomorrow. We can often spend today looking forward to tomorrow. We decide we don't like the now, so daydream about the later. We find ourselves saying things like: 'I can't wait till the weekend', or 'things will be so great when I finally leave school.' Or 'once I get my license, my life will be perfect!' We focus on the future. If we always live like this - thinking mainly about tomorrow - we'll never be satisfied, because tomorrow never comes does it?
When things go wrong, we often look ahead to better days; try to avoid what's happening now. There's a problem with this futuristic obsession: It shields us from what really is (reality) by filling our minds with what might be (fantasy). The result is sad; we miss out on life, because we never stop to think about what's happening now! God doesn't want you to miss out, which is why he says, Give thanks all the time, 'no matter what is happening'. When you do this you recognise that every moment of every day He is there with you. Nothing is outside His understanding. When life is sad or difficult, taking time to thank God you realise He is there protecting you, loving you, encouraging you, supporting you. If you're always looking ahead you'll miss out on knowing Him. So seize the day; give thanks!

SoulFood: Nahum 1-3, John 6:25-34, Ps 98, Pr 24:15-18

content.title: Copy cat!
content.introtext:
'Be imitators of God... as dearly loved children.'

Ephesians 5: 1 NIV
If you've got a little brother or sister, or have ever seen a child grow up, you'll know how true it is to say that children learn from their parents-from the little things like how they speak (do they say bath so it rhymes with naff or hearth?!) to the bigger things like a work ethic, opinions on money and how they treat people. You may even have had your great aunt Betty say to you, 'ooh, you are like your mum when you do that'! We learn from our parents-but not just them. As you've got a bit older and developed your own friendships, you may have realised that you've picked up habits or phrases from your mates too. The more time you spend with someone, the more you become like them. If we see God as our heavenly Father, and spend time with Him, then it follows that we should become like Him too-which is what we should want. Check out how 'the word on the street' paraphrases Ephesians 5: 1: 'Copy God: imitate him; mimic his mannerisms like kids end up walking and talking like their old man. Love people like the Liberator loved you... And the whiff of it all will float up to heaven where God will inhale and be moved to tears.' Study Jesus, spend time with God, and let that be what influences who you become.
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 20:1-11, Heb 8:7-13

content.title: The 'R' word
content.introtext:
'Do you see a man skilled in his work? He will serve before kings...not...obscure men..'



Proverbs 22:29 NIV
On a list of your favourite words, responsibility is probably propping up the bottom along with exam and dentist. But think how life would be without any responsibilities. Your parents wouldn't have to provide you with a home, there would be no laws against anything at all, you couldn't do anything that involves working together; so no team sports. It's absolutely right to be thankful that God has created you to be responsible, hard working and skilled at what you do best.
Some people think that work, taking responsibility, is something that came after Adam and Eve got chucked out of the Garden of Eden (Genesis 3). Because they messed up, sin entered the world and so now we have to work. Gutted! But this isn't true; God actually designed us to work and be good and skilled at what we do right from the start. God put Adam in the Garden '...to work and take care of it' (Genesis 2:15). He wasn't expecting Adam to stuff it up either! He 'put him in charge'. More importantly we know that God Himself works and rests (John 5:17, Genesis 2:2-3) so there is no way we can excuse ourselves. Work is one of our God-given responsibilities.
Every day has 24 hours filled with opportunities to serve and to become better at what you do. So don't be scared of the 'R' word!

SoulFood: 2 Pet 1-3, John 6:1-24, Ps 85, Pr 24:11-14

content.title: Gossip's not Godly!
content.introtext:
'Praises and curses come from the same mouth...this should not happen.'

James 3: 10 NCV
The Bible says: 'We use our tongues to praise our Lord...but then we curse people whom God made like himself...this should not happen.' (James 3: 9-10 NCV) When we're full on for God, praising Him in church or youth group on a Sunday, but then rip into someone at school or college on Monday, it breaks God's heart. Even if you think you're only saying something that's true, if it hurts someone else, or puts them down, God says it's wrong. Trying to justify our gossip doesn't help, because even if we don't say it to someone's face, what we say about someone affects the way that others see them-they can judge them without even knowing them. A good habit to get into with your mates, is to agree that if one of you starts to say something bad about someone, just say, 'Hang about, but did they hurt you, or put you down? Doesn't God love them too?' If someone has hurt you or upset you, ask your friends to pray about your attitude to them with you, instead of dissing them behind their back. We learn from the Bible that we should 'Be...gentle, and patient, accepting each other in love...' (Ephesians 4: 2-3 NCV) We all get stuff wrong and hurt others, so we all need this-why not start by practicing patience with others today, and loving them instead of gossiping about them?
SoulFood reading: Jer 36:27 - 40:16, Luke 6:17-26, Ps 79, Pr 15:18-21

content.title: Values
content.introtext:
'The tongue that brings healing is a tree of life, but a deceitful tongue crushes the spirit.'



Proverbs 15:4 NIV
Maybe the toughest decisions you face during your teenage years are the ones involving your personal values eg what principles will you live your life by? Childhood means everybody else tells you what to think and how to act. Adulthood means it's your call. Will you take on board the ideals of your parents? That might be a good thing; or it might not! Will you launch out on our own? No-one can live your life for you. You have to decide.
Values aren't just something we think about but stuff we do. Our values cause us to act in a certain way. God unpacks many values in the Bible, teaching us how He wants us to live. Here's just one of them: ‘The tongue that brings healing is a tree of life, but a deceitful tongue crushes the spirit.' Do you ever think from one day to the next about the words you create with your tongue? Do you want your voice to be a voice of healing or a voice of destruction? The answer might seem obvious to you now but would it be obvious to someone on the receiving end of one of your rants!
Don't just think about this verse today. Take some time to write down the values you have about family, money, sex, relationships, friendships, education, work, church. Do your values match what God says? Listen to God's values and live them!

SoulFood: 2 Sam 22:31 - 24:25, John 5:31-47, Ps 126, Pr 24:10

content.title: Go for Gold!
content.introtext:
'Run in such a way as to get the prize..'

1 Corinthians 9: 24 NIV
Today, we're going back in time... Imagine you're at primary school, and it's that day of the year you either love or hate-sports day! You've either been looking forward to it, or dreading it, for the same reason-because you want to win! Whether it's the three-legged, the obstacle, the egg and spoon race or the sprint, you run your heart out to win. And if you don't win, you're determined to try even harder next year. When little kids race, they put so much into it, even if they're unlikely to win, they still run their hardest and try for first place! That's the way we should be in our relationship with God. We should want the best, we should always be trying to get closer to Him. You'd never enter a race expecting or wanting to lose it, would you? No matter what, you try your very best, you want to win. Do you ever look at your mates and think that their relationship with God is so much deeper and better than yours, that theirs is taking off, while you're going round in circles? That's probably because they've committed to pursuing God until His presence is real in their lives; God honours that commitment. You can get that too; so get back that childish enthusiasm you had, and don't take your eyes off the finish line. Go for Gold in your relationship with God!
SoulFood reading: Jer 33:1 - 36:26, Luke 6:1-16, Ps 137, Pr 15:15-17

content.title: Sleep when the wind blows
content.introtext:
'Lazy hands make a man poor, but diligent hands bring wealth.'



Proverbs 10:4 NIV
Years ago a farmer on the Atlantic coast found it really difficult to find workers. No-one wanted to work for him because of the dreadful storms that hit the area. The farmer interviewed yet another man, 'Are you a good farmhand?' This man replied, 'Well, I can sleep when the wind blows.' The farmer didn't understand his answer, but was so desperate for workers, offered him the job. To his astonishment the guy accepted and worked really well. Then one night the farmer woke up to the sound of the wind howling. He jumped out of bed and went to the farmhand's room, 'Get up, Get up! A storms coming, tie things down before they blow away'. The man rolled over and firmly said, 'No Sir! I told you I can sleep when the wind blows.' Enraged the farmer ran out to see to the farm without his help. To his amazement he discovered that all the haystacks had been covered, all the animals were locked away safely, everything was tied down, and nothing could blow away. The farmer then understood what his hired farmhand had meant, and he returned to bed, to also sleep whilst the wind blew.
When you work hard you are prepared and have nothing to fear. Work hard at reading your Bible. Then whatever life throws your way, you can 'sleep when the wind blows' too.

SoulFood: 2 Sam 20:1 - 22:30, John 5:16-30, Ps 5, Pr 24:8-9

content.title: Feelings vs Faith
content.introtext:
'...My soul is overwhelmed with sorrow to the point of death...'

Mark 14: 34 NIV
Have you ever felt one way, but had people tell you that as a Christian you shouldn't? Ever heard 'Don't feel like that. If you trusted God and prayed more...sort it out and get over it!'? You feel like the bottom has fallen out of your world, things couldn't get any worse, then your so-called mate says that, and then you feel worse! They don't say it to make things worse; they really do mean well, but you don't need to hear it then. With friends like those...well, you know the rest of that saying! Are you on your own feeling like that? No! Check out Job's story in the Old Testament to see a bunch of well-meaning friends who didn't really help much!
So if 'encouraging' words don't help, what do we do when we feel we've hit rock-bottom? Firstly, understand that feelings are human emotions: even Jesus had them! He didn't deny or hide them, or beat Himself up for having them, He openly acknowledged them but processed them in a healthy way. He prayed that God would take them away. It's ok to want that! God didn't yell at Him or tell Him to get over it, did He? Secondly, know that feelings don't dictate your options or eliminate your choices. You can still make good choices when you're feeling bad. Follow Jesus' example in Mark 14: 36-choose God's will, whatever you feel, and He'll strengthen you to handle the tough times.
SoulFood reading: Jer 31-32, Luke 5:27-39, Ps 122, Pr 15:10-14

content.title: It's not fair!
content.introtext:
'The wicked man earns deceptive wages, but he who sows righteousness reaps a sure reward.'



Proverbs 11:18 NIV
A man asked for a member of his family to be left unmentioned in a book that was being written about his family history. The reason was that he wanted to hide the awful truth that this relative had been sentenced to death by electric chair for committing murder. 'No need to do that', said the biographer. 'I can report the situation in such a way that there will be no embarrassment to you. I'll just write that his death came as a real shock.' OK, sick joke alert! But seriously, the Bible teaches us that once we've died, there's nothing else that can be done in order to get us ready to meet God (Hebrews 9:27). It won't matter what people write about you or say about you to make you look good. God knows all about you, and you will be judged by Him.
Life can seem so unfair sometimes; some people get away all sorts of bad stuff, others make lots of money from doing wrong things, innocent people suffer. But remember, ultimately God is in control, He will be the judge, and the rewards some dodgy people appear to be getting for doing wrong, God promises, won't last long. 'Evil people get rich for the moment, but the reward of the godly will last.' Concentrate on being the best you can be and let God be the judge of others.

SoulFood: 2 Sam 17:14- 19:43, John 5:1-15, Ps 15, Pr 24:7

content.title: Start a trend!
content.introtext:
'...He poured water into a bowl and began to wash the followers' feet...'

John 13: 5 NCV
Imagine... you're touring London; you've done the museums, the shops and the sights, and you're finishing up with a tour of Buckingham Palace. You're halfway through the tour, being shown the royal bathroom, when the Queen walks in, rolls up her sleeves, runs some water in the bath, then makes you take off your shoes and socks and starts washing your feet. Then she dries them, and moves on to your sister, then your mum and dad! How weird would that be?! Not what you'd expect from the Queen of England at all, is it? Yet Jesus did exactly that to the disciples; He did what they really weren't expecting, He went first, He led the way, in spite of who [a15]He was. He shows us that we have to be willing to put aside our image, put aside people's expectations of us, put aside our own comfort and status and remember that first and foremost, we're here to serve God. Check out John 13: 13-17. Jesus tells us to follow His example, and serve others. So if you want to be blessed, don't focus on making spiritual speeches, or letting everyone know how holy you are and what amazing things you've done-instead, roll up your sleeves and get serving those around you. And don't wait for everyone else to start. Someone needs to set the trend-so why not you?
SoulFood reading: Jer 28-30, Luke 5:12-26, Ps 110, Pr 15:8-9

content.title: Antman
content.introtext:
'Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider its ways and be wise!'



Proverbs 6:6 NLT
Lots of people have dreams about being a superhero like Batman or Spiderman or maybe even the Incredible Hulk! But what about Antman (or Antwoman!)? How does that sound? Yes, Ants, those pesky little things that make us feel seriously grossed out if we find one in our jam sandwich! We instinctively want to squash them if we see them; we don't much care for them being around do we? But God says learn from them. He is thinking about the superhero Antman! Now before you get carried away designing your superhero outfit, listen to what God wants you to learn (proverbs 6:6-8).
1) The ant works hard: No-one has to tell the ant what to do. They have no Boss telling them, but they see the need and get on with their job. 2) The ant prepares for the future: They don't just live for today, but make plans for the year ahead. 3) The ant is focused: The ant knows what it should do, it has purpose.
God wants you to live the same: a) to work hard, not because some teacher or boss or parent is breathing down your neck, but because you want to b) to plan for the future, not just living in the moment, but thinking about where you're going c) to be focused, determined to live your life being all God intended you to be.

SoulFood: 2 Sam 14:21 - 17:13, John 4:39-54, Ps 41, Pr 24: 5-6

content.title: Let it go (4) - Shoulda, woulda, coulda...
content.introtext:
'...I will make up to you for the years that the...locust has eaten...'

Joel 2: 25 NAS
You have to let go of what you failed to do: whether it was not talking to the new geeky kid at school coz you didn't want your mates to laugh, or not telling people about God coz you're scared of what they'll say; for whatever reason, we don't always do what we know is right. Today's verse isn't really about bugs eating stuff, it's more about God saying that even though there's stuff you haven't done, that He would have liked you to do, He can make up for it. God gives you a second chance: He can put you where you would have been if you'd not missed out in the first place. So instead of living your life thinking 'coulda, woulda, shoulda done that' and 'if only', leave behind the things you didn't do, don't beat yourself up about it, and have faith that God will give you a second chance. Remember: say sorry, and it's shredded, forgotten. Focus instead on not missing out on the future opportunities, but grabbing them with both hands. You may feel like you're completely going to miss out on something, some dream, because you didn't do what you should have done. So be outrageous: ask God for a new dream for the future, forgetting what's past, and reaching for the exciting future you know He's got planned for you!
SoulFood reading: Jer 25-27, Luke 5:1-11, Ps 102:18-28, Pr 15:4-7

content.title: Lazy days are over!
content.introtext:
'One who is slack in his work is brother to one who destroys.'



Proverbs 18:9 NIV
Ok so we all like to sit in front of the TV sometimes, or turn off the alarm and go back to sleep. We don't always do things when we should, 'I'll do it later!' we say. Does that make you lazy? The Bible's very clear that being lazy is as bad as vandalizing. Laziness is destructive! So we don't want to fall into that trap! Do we? (The answer is no - you don't!) So let's have a lazy checklist, so we can stop ourselves from hitting the destruct button by falling into the laziness trap.
L is for Lame: Lame excuses that you make up for not doing things! A is for Always: Always being the one other people have to clean up after! Z is for ZZzzz: ZZzzz - Are you spending far too many mornings having another lie-in? Y is for YoYo: YoYo describes your emotions that bounce up and down all the time - and when you're down nothing at all gets done because you 'just don't feel like it!'
So does that sound anything like you? Are you L-A-Z-Y? Make a change today or these lazy habits and attitudes will become a way of life, which means you're headed for a life of destruction. God wants you to value yourself far more than this. He sees your potential. You can do it. From today let's agree lazy days are over!

SoulFood: Ps 103 , Mk 5:24-34

content.title: Let it go (3) - Broad shoulders.
content.introtext:
'...I persecuted the church...'

Galatians 1: 13 NIV
Today you have to let go of what you've done to others. The things we've done to others can weigh us down like a ton of bricks-the guilt can really drag you down, even if they say it's fine now. It's a bit like living in A Christmas Carol, with the ghost of your past not letting you move on in life. How do you live with the things you've done? Take Saul (Paul) as an example, and you'll soon feel better about yourself! You can definitely learn from him, he was someone who had really messed up-he'd torn Christians from their families and dragged them away to be beaten and killed. Then he converted to Christianity himself, and went around preaching to and meeting the widows and kids of the guys he'd done over. How did he deal with that guilt? He had two choices, and so do we-either try to carry it around, and probably collapse in the process, or find someone with shoulders big enough to take it from us. What did Paul do? Enter Jesus, who has the biggest shoulders you could ever hope for. Paul handed it to Him, and thanked God for it. Check out Romans 7:24-25. God showed him mercy, and he let go of the hurts he'd caused, knowing God could heal them. Trust God to do the same for you, and let it go.
SoulFood reading: Jer 22-24, Luke 4:31-44, Ps 102:12-17, Pr 15:3

content.title: Are you approachable? (2)
content.introtext:
'But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control'



Galatians 5:22-23 NAS
Approachable people are like this: 1) Personal warmth; they actually like people. Ok, so some people are a nightmare, but the truth is that people suss out whether you like them or not. And if you're going to be approachable you need to learn to love people! 2) Their moods are consistent. How frustrating are moody people? You never know how they'll be. If you're moody, people will be scared to talk to you. 3) Sensitivity to people's feelings. Although approachable people are emotionally stable, they don't expect everyone to be that way. They recognise that good people have bad days; and act sensitively to that. 4) They understand human weakness, including their own. Don't be down on yourself, but be honest about your own weaknesses. When you're not trying to show people how fantastic you are and admit your struggles other people will be honest too. An old proverb says: 'Blessed are they who can laugh at themselves, for they shall never cease to be amused.' And because they can admit their own faults, they don't have a problem allowing other people to have faults as well. 5) The ability to forgive, and ask for forgiveness. Sometimes you screw up. Fact. We all do. So why do we often find it so hard to admit that? When you've messed up, say sorry. Get over yourself and ask for forgiveness. When you can do this other people will do it too.

content.title: Let it go (2) - Stop picking the scab!
content.introtext:
'...God has made me forget all my trouble...'

Genesis 41: 51 NIV
Ok, more of 'Let it go'. Here's the point in super-simple terms: you have to let go of what other people have done to you. Have you ever had a nasty cut that got a HUGE scab on it, and did you have a little pick at the scab, and make it bleed and hurt again a bit? Well, think of that scab as the healing of bad stuff that other people have done to you-if you let it go, and just leave it alone, eventually it will heal. It may well sting a bit on the way, and you may be left with a little scar, but it shouldn't be too bad. But, if you pick at the scab, keep worrying it, once, twice, even more, it'll take way longer to heal, it may even get infected, and you'll almost definitely have a scar at the end of it. Yes, that person did hurt you and yes that stinks-but it's not going to change. However, the way you deal with the hurt can change. They're responsible for the original cut, but if you keep picking it, that's you, not them making it hurt-and you're not giving it a chance to heal; you're not letting God do His thing. So do yourself a favour-stop picking that scab, and ask God to help you each time you think about it.
SoulFood reading: Ruth 1:3-18, Acts 8:26-40

content.title: Don’t miss your opportunity
content.introtext:
'For a man may do his work with wisdom, knowledge and skill, and then he must leave all he owns to someone who has not worked for it. This too is meaningless and a great misfortune.'



Ecclesiastes 2:21 NIV
We're often told to 'build a good life for ourselves'; to 'look out for number one'. To get good qualifications, a good career, a house, a car, get married, have kids, have holidays abroad, nice clothes, lots of money. But at the end of the day, we're all going to die and then what? What was the point of living like that? It all seems pretty pointless don't you think?
Jesus warns us against living such pointless lives, "Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and rust destroy, and where thieves break in and steal. But store up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where moth and rust do not destroy, and where thieves do not break in and steal. For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also." (Matthew 6: 19-21 NIV)
God doesn't want us to build our lives getting things that we can't take to heaven with us, or doing things that will mean nothing in heaven. He doesn't want you to live a pointless life. So when you're thinking about what to do with your time, your money, your life. Ask yourself this, will it make a difference in the light of eternity?
You only have one life to invest in the eternity to come. Don't miss the opportunity. Today make sure that what will be most important to you five minutes after you die, become the most important to you now.

SoulFood: 2 Sam 12:1 - 14:20, John 4:27-38, Ps 87, Pr 24:1-4

content.title: Let it go (1) - Shred it!
content.introtext:
'Forget what has happened before, and do not think about the past.'

Isaiah 43: 18 NCV
What do you do when your memory drags crud from the past, and makes it seem real now, making it hurt all over again? Today's verse looks at letting go. Unless you decide to let it go, your past can, and will, infect your present, and influence your future. God doesn't want that for you!
First, you need to let go of what God has forgiven! When you confess sin to God and say sorry, He forgives and forgets-instantly! Imagine you write down the wrong stuff you've done, in detail, and every time you look at it you feel bad. When you confess, God takes that paper and shreds it beyond recognition; it's gone, rubbish, it is no more. You don't have it to remind you anymore. But if you don't let go of what God's forgiven, it's like you going through the bin, spending ages picking out all the bits, and painstakingly sticking them all back together. You wouldn't do that in real life, so don't do it with God; He shredded it deliberately, because once you've said sorry, it's gone. And what if you don't feel forgiven? Well, you don't feel oxygen, but you don't use that as a reason to stop breathing, do you? If you don't feel forgiven, just act like you are, and over time, you'll start to feel it too.
SoulFood reading: Jer 18-21, Luke 4:14-30, Ps 102:1-11, Pr 14:35 - 15:2
