content.title: Are you approachable? (1)
content.introtext:
'But the fruit of the Spirit is... kindness, goodness... gentleness,'



Galatians 5:22-23 NKJV
Before we look at whether or not we're approachable, we've got to ask 'do we care?' After all, some of us quite like the idea that people are scared of us, or that we're 'hard'. People like this don't tend to be very approachable, because you never know what response you're going to get! But is this really how you want people to see you? You might feel good thinking people are scared of you, but it's hard to make good friends. Let's take Jesus as an example. He was the ultimate hardman, and talk about scary; He was the Son of God AND could do pretty much anything He liked! Yet people flocked to Him in their thousands, His disciples never left his side. And why? It was because Jesus showed all the fruits of the Spirit. He was no walk over, yet He had so much compassion for people. When people were trying to kill Him, He fought back with love. He was kind, He loved kids, He was gentle and humble but at the same time He knew He was the Son of God. He knew He had the strength of Father God to draw on when He felt weak. Let's think about how we can model ourselves on Jesus today. We've the same Father God watching our back so drop the act and do it, Jesus style!

content.title: Light feet
content.introtext:
'Blessed are those who have learned to...walk in the light of your presence...'

Psalm 89: 15 NIV
Wouldn't it be nice if God just handed you a book of your entire life right now. You could flick through the chapters about your jobs, relationships, money, dreams and ambitions. You could skim read all the outcomes of your life choices. It would save you a whole lot of worrying and stressing in the here-and-now about whether you'll ever find that 'special someone'. Or how you'll ever pay that money you owe. Or do you ever conquer that re-occurring struggle?
It might seem a nice idea, but that's not how God works. The Psalmist said, 'Blessed are those who have learned to...walk in the light of your presence...' (Psalm 89:15 NIV) In ancient European monasteries monks walked dark corridors with candles on the toes of their shoes, giving them just enough light to see the next step. That's how God leads us. Just enough light to see our next steps. We might pray to God over direction in something, and then complain that He's not listening just because He hasn't sent the floodlights on our entire future. With God, it's never the full floodlit laser lightshow, it's more like the small flickers of a candle. There's enough glow to stop us tripping over our own feet, but it's only a little glimmer in order that we keep our hand firmly placed in our Father's hand; in order that we walk in the light of His presence.
SoulFood reading: Jer 14-17, Luke 4:1-13, Ps 98, Pr 14:34

content.title: Are you up for it?
content.introtext:
'Then Isaac sowed in that land, and reaped in the same year a hundredfold; and the LORD blessed him.'



Genesis 26:12 NKJV
Sometimes what God asks us to do, can seem totally ludicrous, absolutely ridiculous! Are you up for that? Isaac was; he was well up for whatever God asked of him. Then he was in a land that was suffering from famine and God told him to stay put. Sensible people don't spend months doing the back-breaking job of planting seeds in a land where there's very little water. Not only is it bad for business, but you and your family are likely to die in the process! Even so, Isaac chooses to obey God, and God kept His promise and business was booming!
Unfortunately this just made the guys living around Isaac (the Philistines) mad with jealousy and they deliberately started to trash all Isaac's hard work. He could have fought back, big time. They were breaking the law! But he chose to be patient, he followed God's way, and as a result he got a bumper harvest and the people were able to live together in peace. What seemed ridiculous turned out better than ever!
We too can find ourselves in situations where it's so hard to give when you have so little, or so hard to be patient with people who are deliberately causing you trouble. Remember God's way won in Isaacs's life, so God's way will win in your life too. Are you up for the absolutely ridiculous today?

SoulFood: 2 Sam 7:18 - 11:27, John 4:13-26, Ps 32, Pr 23:29-35

content.title: Eight principles to live by
content.introtext:
'Whoever pursues righteousness and unfailing love will find life, righteousness, and honour.'

Proverbs 21: 21 NLT
Fact: People who set goals achieve more than people of equal education and ability who don't. With that in mind, build these eight principles into your life.
(1) Decide what the goal is. Do this by consulting God-and not just once! Talk to him about it over and over again. 'Many are the plans in a man's heart, but it is the Lord's purpose that prevails.' (Proverbs 19: 21 NIV) (2) Think on paper. Writing your goals down gives them a sense of permanency, plus it energises you. (3) Establish a deadline. Without a definite beginning and ending it's easy to put it off and get nowhere. (4) Make a list of what you need to do to achieve your goal. (5) Convert your list to a plan. Decide what's most important and you need to do first and what things you can do later. (6) Act immediately. 'Be very careful, then, how you live-not as unwise but as wise, making the most of every opportunity...' (Ephesians 5: 15-16 NIV) Do something! An average plan put into action beats a brilliant one that's not. (7) Do something every day to move you forward. Build it into your diary. (8) Have a goal you're willing to devote your life to. And keep your eye on that goal at all times. 'Teach us to number our days aright, that we may gain a heart of wisdom.' (Psalm 90: 12 NIV)
SoulFood reading: Jer 10-13, Luke 3:21-37, Ps 95, Pr 14:29-33

content.title: Living with a thankful heart!
content.introtext:
'I will bless the Lord at all times...'



Psalm 34:1 NKJV
David said, 'I will bless the Lord at all times: his praise shall continually be in my mouth.' A thankful heart isn't always easy to have but it's much better than being bitter and miserable, in fact it can save your life! When Jonah disobeyed God and ended up inside the whale, he told God, '...I will sacrifice to You with...thanksgiving...' (Jonah 2:9 NKJV). When he did, God made the fish spit him up on dry land. When you're down in the dumps and life's feeling rubbish, that's when you need to open your trap and praise God. Nothing shows trust like thanking God when life's smacking you round the head. This does two things:
1) It builds your faith. David said, '...magnify the Lord with me...' (Psalms 34:3). Picture a giant magnifying glass pointed at God. When you remember just how big God is, the problem becomes so tiny it's ridiculous! Plus, '...faith comes by hearing...the word of God' (Romans 10:17 NKJV). Hearing God's promises coming from your own lips, causes faith to rise in your heart. So start talking!
2) It restores life. Before raising Lazarus from the dead, Jesus looked up to heaven and said, 'Father...thank You that You have heard Me. And I know that You always hear Me...' (John 11:41-42 NKJV). As soon as you thank God for stuff you're faith levels rocket, then the grey can turn to colour.

content.title: Be real with God.
content.introtext:
'Be anxious for nothing, but in everything by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God.'

Philippians 4: 6 NKJV
Have you ever been at a prayer meeting, or youth group when people were praying, and either not prayed out loud coz you didn't think what you wanted to pray about was worthy, or prayed about something you really didn't know much or care about especially, coz you thought it'd sound more spiritual and make you sound more holy? You end up praying about those missionaries in Guatemala (wherever that is!) or world peace, when really your mind keeps wandering back to that coursework you've got to do but really don't understand? We all do that at times, but the solution to the ever-wandering mind is simple, and staring at us in this verse: don't worry! Pray what's in your heart, not what you think should be or wish was there. Don't worry about sounding 'spiritual'-God knows what's in your heart anyway, so why not try being honest with Him, and praying about what's really bothering or exciting you. Whether you think your request is big or small, whether your motives are mixed or pure, whether your thanks are genuine or a bit silly, God can sort it all out, and He'll respond to your prayers wisely. You just need to trust Him with your prayers. If He doesn't answer the way you want Him to, it's for a reason-He knows what He's doing. So don't be afraid; just pray!
SoulFood reading: Jer 7-9, Luke 3:11-20, Ps 64, Pr 14:25-28

content.title: Are you a good actor?
content.introtext:
'But when you give to the needy, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing, so that your giving may be in secret. Then your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will reward you'



Matthew 6:4 NIV
A couple of weeks ago we were looking into what Jesus really meant when he called people 'hypocrites'. We found out that it was all to do with the ancient Greeks and their love of acting and theatre. Let's have another look at this today because there's more for us to discover... In Matthews Gospel Jesus actually mentions four types of Hypocrites:
1) The Poser; the Christian who makes themselves 'look good' by acting like they care about others when really they couldn't give a stuff
2) The Pusher; the Christian who pushes other people into doing what they don't do themselves
3) The Preventer; the Christian who is so obsessed with their own petty issues that they stop other people from experiencing God
4) The Preoccupied: the Christian who is more bothered about how they look on the outside than who they are inside.
So what's all this got to do with today's verse? Well Jesus is letting us know that He wants us to help anyone and everyone around us who's in need, anyway that we can, BUT, with the right motive! He doesn't want you to put on an act and do things to make yourself look good, that's being a hypocrite! Do it because you love Jesus and want to be more like Him. Then you'll find God smiling over you, saying 'that's my kid!' And get this....He'll give you a reward EVERYTIME!

SoulFood: 2 Sam 3:22 - 7:17, John 4:1-12, Ps 100, Pr 23:22-28

content.title: Turning stumbling blocks into stepping stones (2)
content.introtext:
'...none of these things move me...'

Acts 20: 24 NKJV
You don't often hear about famous people before they 'arrive', do you? It's easy to think they never had it hard, never had stuff thrown in their way-but that's because it's part of their job to put up a front in public. Think about some of the most significant leaders in our nation, like Kevin Rudd or John Howard. Do you think they ever got told they wouldn't amount to much? Of course they did; they get criticised all the time in the press and take all sorts of knocks. And what about Barack Obama: did he let the colour of his skin hold him back when everyone thought the idea of a black President was impossible? The common theme is that these leaders have a vision for their life; nothing will stop them. That doesn't mean that things don't come along and get in the way, it doesn't mean everything's easy; but instead of letting the bad stuff knock them down, instead of giving up, they brush themselves off after every fall and see what they can learn from it. Yes, some of the stumbling blocks in life may hurt, but don't let them stop you. Follow Paul's example, and next time something tough comes your way, say to yourself, 'This won't move me.' Ask God to help you use it to grow and learn, and to shape you to be more like Him through your experiences.
SoulFood reading: Jer 4-6, Luke 3:1-10, Ps 59:9-17, Pr 14:23-24

content.title: Always Available
content.introtext:
‘God is our refuge and strength...'



Psalm 46:1 NIV
Yesterday we began to think a bit about the troubled world we live in. Terrorism, wars, hurricanes, tsunamis, crime, disease. Every night the media invades our homes bringing all this stuff to us in glorious Technicolor. The result is that our emotions can take a bit of a battering. Instead of having a true grasp of reality our minds start producing all sorts of worries about the future - what if we're next? In response to that the Bible says three things:
1) ‘God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.' When you're in a tight spot, God is totally available to help you. Read the whole Psalm - there's no catch, it doesn't say that God will help you occasionally or reluctantly. No, He's there for you, always. What more do you need?
2) ‘Therefore we will not fear' (v. 2 NIV). Don't panic, talk defeat, or give in to despair. A songwriter said, ‘He's as close as the mention of his name.' Just say His name in prayer, and He'll be there for you.
3) ‘...waters roar and foam and the mountains quake with their surging' (v. 3 NIV). When everything you once thought to be solid and dependable, is shaken to the core you'll be where you've always been; in the strong and loving arms of God; the One who's always available to help.

content.title: Turning stumbling blocks into stepping stones (1)
content.introtext:
'...we are more than conquerors...'

Romans 8: 37 NKJV
Do you think you have it bad? Life sucks, there's always something stopping you getting where you want to go? There's no way you'll ever succeed with all this stuff holding you back? Everyone else has it better than you; money or fame is all you need for success? Think again! Some of the most famous names we know had a tough time of it before they made it big. Take Beethoven as an example. Now, you may not like his music, and think it's just for old fossils, but you've got to admit the man is pretty well known; most people recognise his name. You may think he must have had a sorted life to make it-but no! His dad was an alcoholic slave driver, who forced him to work to support the family. He spent so much time playing the piano and composing to make money, he had no childhood. But he didn't let that stop him. He used the bad stuff to make a better life for himself, and started thinking positively. What had been stumbling blocks, he turned into stepping stones, which helped make him who he was at the end of his life. So don't stumble on problems and grumble about them; instead, step on them, and use them to help you move forwards in life. It's not easy, but with God, you can conquer the biggest problems and make good from them.
SoulFood reading: Jer 1-3, Luke 2:41-52, Ps 59:1-8, Pr 14:21-22

content.title: Listen & Learn
content.introtext:
'Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.'



Matthew 11:29 NIV
Sometimes teachers get it wrong: The famous French sculptor Rodin was described by teachers as, 'the worst pupil in the school!' Albert Einstein's teacher described him as "mentally slow, unsociable and adrift forever in his foolish dreams." He was expelled! Thomas Edison, the guy who invented the light bulb had a teacher who said, 'he was too stupid to learn anything!' The famous opera singer Enrico's teacher said, 'he had no voice at all and could not sing!' Beethoven's teacher called him 'hopeless' as a composer.
Miss Phillips, a teacher of Peter J Daniel, constantly said, "Peter. J. Daniel you're no good, you're a bad apple and you're never going to amount to anything." Peter was totally illiterate until he was 26. Now he owns the street corners he used to fight on and published a book: Miss Phillips, You Were Wrong!
Jesus is the greatest teacher of all, He never gets it wrong! He knows everything about you, He sees your potential, He never listens to what others say about you, He knows you! Today He is saying, 'Hang out with Me, learn from Me! I'll show you how to get the best out of your life. Don't try and work things out on your own, don't try so hard! Walk with Me, work with Me; watch how I do it. Keep company with Me and I'll teach you the best way to live life!"

SoulFood: 2 Sam 1:1 - 3:21, John 3:22-36, Ps 89:38-52, Pr 23:19-21

content.title: Respect your temple (2)
content.introtext:
'...God bought you with a high price. So...honour God with your body...'

1 Corinthians 6: 20 NLT
Remember yesterday when we learnt that we're made in God's image? Well, today we're going to look at how that should affect the way we treat ourselves. We have three key things to consider: exercise, eating and sleep. Here we go:
Firstly: an hour on the Wii or PS3 doesn't count as exercise! It's easy to get some exercise-especially while you're young. Join a netball or football team, or if you're not really sporty, go for a walk with your mates at lunchtime instead of just sitting around!
Secondly: you need to eat well. Yeah, we all have days when all we want is chocolate and chips, but honestly you've got to get a balanced diet. That doesn't mean you balance a Mars bar with a bag of corn chips, but means you need to eat fruit and veg as well as protein (meat, cheese and nuts) and carbs (bread, pasta and rice etc). If you struggle with this, why not try a smoothie? It's a great way to get loads of goodness in you, and pretty yummy too.
Thirdly: staying up late isn't the be-all and end-all. We need sleep. If you don't get enough sleep, you won't focus properly in school, college, work or uni, and you won't achieve your best. So try and get 8 hours most nights; it really is good for your health! Remember: you're a temple!
SoulFood reading: Ex 17:1-7, John 4:4-42

content.title: Facing the elements
content.introtext:
‘In everything give thanks...'


1 Thessalonians 5:18 NKJV
Some days can be a real drag, can't they. You get up and leave the house in the morning... it's raining. You pack up to go home again later on in the afternoon... it's still raining. And the forecast for the weekend - rain. Yep, there are days when your mood can hit rock bottom and before you know it every other word off your lips is some kind of moan, groan or complaint. Well just be careful, if you let a bit of mouldy weather get you down what will you do when real hardship comes along?
Joseph was people-trafficked by his own shady brothers! He couldn't possibly have known that God would turn their actions inside out and establish him as Prime Minister. Joe just had to take each day as it came ‘making the most of every opportunity...' (Ephesians 5:16 NIV). And Joseph's not the only one, the Bible tells story after story where difficulty actually makes people stronger. Listen, there's a plan unfolding in your life, and it isn't affected by rain or snow or sleet or hail! Around this world there are some places that don't have a lot of God's kingdom happening, war zones, places of poverty, disaster sites. God loves the people in those places as much as he loves you and he needs people prepared to face the environments, that He might be glorified. So see this winter as a practice run!

content.title: Respect your temple (1)
content.introtext:
'...God bought you with a high price. So...honour God with your body...'

1 Corinthians 6: 20 NLT
One of the things the Bible tells you to do is honour God with your body. But what does that mean? And what on earth has it got to do with temples? Ok, time for a quick history lesson: the temple was a place where people went to meet with God, and to worship Him. It was a place of respect, and pretty ornate too: which is a posh way of saying it was nice to look at!
God made you to be like that, He calls your body 'a temple'-how awesome is that?! God wants to live in you, and He wants you to live out Him, so that when people look at your life, they see Him. It says in the Bible that you're made in the image of God, so that basically means there's a bit of God in you. If you think about it, treating your body like a temple kind of makes sense. It's basically all about not abusing your body, but instead, using it to glorify God. So how should that affect the way you treat yourself?
Well, have a think about what you'd do if Jesus came to stay, and you were in charge of His wellbeing. I'm guessing you'd make sure He ate well, got sleep, exercised, and kept generally fit and healthy, wouldn't you? So...if you're made in the image of God, why should you treat yourself any differently?
SoulFood reading: Hosea 11-14, Luke 2:34-40, Ps 21, Pr 14:17-20

content.title: Bad day? Focus on Him.
content.introtext:
'I pray...that your heart may be enlightened...'



Ephesians 1:18 NIV
Imagine - you're having the worst day ever. Your best mate's been killed, and to top it all his body's been nicked from the grave. You're walking along with a mate, wallowing in your sadness, when some bloke comes along and starts chatting. Most people would probably want to tell him to get lost and leave them alone - even if he was trying to be helpful!
That's probably what the disciples were thinking in Luke 24:15 - 16. But how glad to you think they were that they didn't ignore the guy walking by them, when they found out it actually was Jesus! They'd been so focused on how bad they were feeling, they'd not even realised it was Him! When the disciples did actually look to Jesus, and recognise him, suddenly things changed. They went from fear to courage, pain to joy, despair to hope - all because they'd got back their focus on Jesus. And that is the story of Jesus - no matter how bad things may seem to be, how bad your day is going, when you fix your eyes on Jesus and focus on Him, He'll fill you with hope. Don't be so focused on what's going on that you lose sight of what matters - Jesus.
That's why Paul writes ' I pray that your hearts will be flooded with light so that you can understand the confident hope he has given to those he called' (Ephesians 1:18 NIV).

SoulFood: Eph 4:17 - 6:24, John 3:1-21, Ps 89:15-37, Pr 23:15-18

content.title: You must understand the reason
content.introtext:
‘...let grain from the bundles fall purposely for her...'



Ruth 2:16 NKJV
OK, last day on Ruth. Let's keep going where we left off yesterday. Ruth, right in the middle of feeling loss, feeling hungry, feeling homesick, suddenly gets more than she ever needed dropped right into her lap. She didn't deserve it, didn't earn it, and couldn't even understand it. It's called grace; it's how God works!
But here's the health warning: If you're not used to being blessed it might not take long before it starts going to your head! That's why the Bible says: ‘But remember the LORD your God, ...gives you the ability to produce wealth' (Deuteronomy 8:18 NIV). And here's the small print (you should always read the small print!) God doesn't bless you so you can sit back and count your wads, or so you can strut around posing in all your bling. God's gifts are just tools to help you do His will. That's all that matters. At the end of the day what good is that stuff, if it takes you miles away from God? When God gives you something, He wants you to use it to make Him famous. So, when God gives you His blessings, be sure to read the instructions that go with them; only then will you find true fulfilment! So have you got it? God is the source of everything you have; and ever will have!

content.title: What you sow, you reap
content.introtext:
'Let us not become weary in doing good...we will reap a harvest if we do not give up.'

Galatians 6: 9 NIV
You may think you have to be old to make a difference in the world. Sorry. Wrong! You can see and do amazing stuff as a young person, and change the world around you for the better. You may have heard of a Dutch lady called Corrie Ten Boom; she's written books about her life, and is famous for saving Jews from the Nazis in the war. But you may not have heard of her nephew Peter. He made an amazing difference too; and he started young! When he was just 16, he was thrown into prison for his involvement with the Jews, and for defying the Germans. After World War 2, he travelled the world, preaching that forgiveness is the only answer to hatred, and people were changed and saved through him and his words. What he'd done when he was younger came back to help him too; he had a heart attack in Israel and needed surgery. It turned out the surgeon was one of the babies Peter's family had saved all those years ago. 40 years after he'd been saved, the surgeon repaid the debt, by saving Peter's life.
What you sow, good or bad, will come back to you. So make sure it's good stuff you're sowing in your life, and one day, you'll reap the harvest. It'll be in God's time, but it will happen.
SoulFood reading: Hosea 1-5, Luke 2:8-20, Ps 8, Pr 14:9-12

content.title: Get real with Jesus
content.introtext:
'...Go now and leave your life of sin'


John 8:11 NIV
Jesus always told it like it is. He would never put a bandage on an infected wound. He always insisted on getting right down to the root cause of a problem. When a woman who'd been caught having sex with a bloke who wasn't her husband was brought to him he first dealt with her accusers and then told her lovingly but firmly, '"...Go now and leave your life of sin."' (John 8:11 NIV) We come to the same Jesus with the same burden of guilt and shame that woman felt. Listen: 'Since he himself has gone through suffering and temptation, he is able to help us when we are being tempted' (Hebrews 2:18 NLT). Sadly, in our 'Do it yourself' culture, we often try to sort our issues out everywhere else before coming to Jesus. Why? Because He's the only person we can't fake it to - we have to be 100% real with him and that's scary! But it's worth it! Job writes, '...prepare your heart and lift up your hands to Him in prayer. Get rid of your sins, and leave all iniquity behind you. Then your face will brighten in innocence. You will be strong and free of fear. You will forget your misery. It will all be gone like water under the bridge... you will have courage because you will have hope. You will be protected and will rest in safety. You will lie down unafraid, and many will look to you for help' (Job 11:13-19 NLT). Jesus invites you to step into the river of God's mercy today. Let it flow over you setting you free. Whether it's the guilt of something you have done, or the pain for something that was done to you - get real with Jesus!

SoulFood: Eph 1:1 - 4:16, John 2:12-25, Ps 89: 1-14, Pr 23:10-14

content.title: Mustn't grumble
content.introtext:
'Do all things without complaining...'

Philippians 2:14 NKJV
So, we might not have won the World Cup or trounced the poms at cricket, but if you had to pay a dollar every time you complained and you got a dollar every time you showed gratitude would you be rich or poor? So you reckon you're hard done by and you warrant a whinge? Actually, no. Not in the face of a few hard facts.
Fact 1: Life expectancy in this country is 81 years. Life expectancy in the developing world is half that.
Fact 2: It would take $12 billion to provide safe water world-wide and $17 billion to provide basic health care and nutrition globally. However, we spend way more than that every year shopping in the suburbs!
Fact 3: 21 children die every minute from poverty related causes in the developing world. The point is if you're going to moan: moan about something worth moaning about. By all means nag about the injustice of this world. Complain about the poverty which destroys life. Make a noise about the West's indifference to the rest of the planet. But be thankful for what you've got. A final thought: if somebody gave you a buck every time you complained and collected one every time you were thankful; would you be loaded or stony broke?
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 24-25, Luke 2:1-7, Ps 144:9-15, Pr 14:5-8

content.title: ‘Finding yourself’
content.introtext:
‘...she found herself working in a field belonging to Boaz...'



Ruth 2:3 NIV
Ruth had made a brave decision to travel with her mother-in-law to a place she didn't know. But now life was spiralling downward. Her husband was gone. Home was a long way away; there was no money in the bank. She was in survival mode which meant hanging around the fields picking up off-cuts from the harvest. Not a good look, ladies.
Then God started turning things around. The guys cutting the harvest started dropping handfuls of barley in her path; undeserved blessings. Why? Because the boss (Boaz) saw Ruth hanging around and told his workers, ‘leave them for her to pick up' (Ruth 2:16 NIV). Ruth had no idea that word had been spoken, she just started getting blessed! And you don't know what God will speak over your life. Suddenly everything can change! Doors can be opened, mountains can be moved. What's happening? Your steps are being ordered by the Lord (Psalm 37:23). And you don't even have to worry about somebody else getting what's yours, because nobody can pick it up except you; the boss says so!
The minute the boss started showing favour to her, Ruth's downward spiral was over. She came from the fringes to the foreground. Instead of only looking forward to off-cuts she got the cream of the crop. When God speaks, that can happen very quickly. So be ready!

content.title: Moving mountains
content.introtext:
'...whoever says to this mountain, 'Be removed...'

Mark 11: 23 NKJV
Crack open the carbs and glug down those protein-shakes, you're going to need a whole lot of muscle to shift these mountains! Alright, so it'll take more than perfect pecs and well adjusted abs to shift the Himalayas in our lives. Here are three handy hints in mountain moving:
(1) Bench-press God's Word: Textbook example: When Satan tempts Jesus to jump off the temple without so much as a bungee rope, Jesus sees the lie and fights back with 'It is written...' (Read it for yourself in Matthew 4: 1 -11.) Your first mountain moving muscle is God's Word; learn to use it!
(2) Flex some forgiveness: After speaking about mountain-moving faith, Jesus said, '...Whenever you stand praying, if you have anything against anyone, forgive him, that your Father in heaven may also forgive you your trespasses.' (Mark 11: 25 NKJV) Your mountain can't be moved (or your prayers answered) if you're tapped into un-forgiveness. So if you want to experience power, get busy with forgiveness.
(3) Keep up the reps: Jeremiah said that God's Word is '...like a hammer that breaks a rock in pieces.' (Jeremiah 23: 29 NKJV) Ever wonder how a hammer can hit a rock ninety-nine times, but on the one-hundredth blow it shatters? That's because all the previous blows kept weakening it. Live in God's Word; keep speaking it over your situation and soon mountains may move.
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 21-23, Luke 1:67-80, Ps 144:1-8, Pr 14:1-4

content.title: Seeing others through God's eyes!
content.introtext:
'...while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.'



Romans 5:8 NIV
The old Bible sat in the bargain basket amongst hundreds of tattered books. A lot of people had picked it up and thumbed through its faded pages. It wasn't in very good shape - certainly not worth the $2 on the sticker. So it was thrown aside. But then a man picked it up and gasped in shock. He rushed to the counter and paid the puny amount for the old book. It was an original Gutenberg, 500 years old and one of the first books ever printed! It was worth more than $2,000,000! The world cast it aside, unaware of its value.
And we do the same thing, don't we? Seeds of greatness often lie buried within unpromising people that amazingly spring to life when they are watered and nurtured.
In truth, we were all overlooked until Jesus saw something of value in us. But rather than paying a bargain price He paid the highest price. Listen: '...While we were still sinners, Christ died for us' (Romans 5.8.NIV).
A different world would appear before our eyes if we could begin to see every man, woman, boy and girl as a precious treasure that God could not live without, that Christ died to redeem. Look at Matthew: when Jesus found him he was a dodgy tax collector, a wheeler-dealer working for the Romans. But Jesus said, '"Follow" Me' (Matthew 9:9 NIV). Matthew did and never looked back. Aren't you glad that God found you!

SoulFood: Ezek 37:1-14, Matt 27:50-53, 1 Thess 4:13-18

content.title: Those who can: Teach
content.introtext:
'...we who teach will be judged more strictly.'

James 3:1 NIV
You know those adverts on TV, where good clean wholesome pupils (not like the tearaways you've grown accustomed to at your school) swoon at the feet of a drop-dead gorgeous teacher (as opposed to old Mr Cod-face who bores his way through your double geography lessons), hanging onto his every word as the on-screen caption spells out, 'those who can: teach'. Well, have you ever stopped to think about that? Could you teach? Not as in school teacher, but could you teach your peers, your family or your friends the way of Jesus?
There's an old saying: 'sometimes you're the only Bible some people will ever read'. What does that mean? Simple. For a lot of people, the closest they'll ever get to understanding anything the Bible goes on about is by what they observe in your life. If you're the only Christian they know, then you're their definition of what a Christian does. You may even be their only definition of what Jesus is like.
So, what lessons will people learn from your life? Will they see that a Christian is somebody who spouts on about love but then backstabs? Will they learn that it's ok for Christians to play the field? Will they see any difference in how you live your life, and how they live theirs? Can you live as an example of Christ? Those who can: teach.
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 18:17-20:21, Luke 1:57-66, Ps 139:13-24, Pr 13:25

content.title: Who belongs in your life?
content.introtext:
‘...Where you go I will go...'



Ruth 1:16 NIV
Ruth told Naomi, ‘Where you go I will go.' Relationships are weird. Suddenly you can meet someone and ‘tzzzzt' - there's an electric connection between you. It's what made Elisha quit farming and follow Elijah, a prophet with self-esteem issues; it's why Timothy hung out with Paul, an old man with a habit of getting into fights. You know instantly, ‘I won't reach my destiny without you in my life.' Looking back you realise if you hadn't met that certain person, you wouldn't be where you are today.
On the other hand, ‘Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye' (Ruth 1:14 NIV). Now Orpah's leaving didn't make her a bad person; it just meant her part in the story was over. Listen, you need to learn to recognise when somebody's part in your story is over, otherwise you'll just drive each other nuts. Yep, it can be hard to admit something is over, especially a relationship. Look, if God wants that for you He'll make it work. But if it blatantly ain't working then accept His will in the matter. Get up, go outside, put one foot in front of the other and start living again! Never beg a friend to stay with you against their will. Their leaving is no accident; it just means God has something better in store for you (and possibly them too), so trust Him and move on!

content.title: Trusting God when there are no answers
content.introtext:
'The secret things belong to the Lord...'

Deuteronomy 29: 29 NIV
Sometimes we treat life as if it's a Maths lesson. We're faced with a problem, and if we look long enough we eventually find the solution. But life isn't all algebra and percentages. Life has a sneaky habit of raising questions we can't seem to answer: innocent children born with HIV; cancer robbing a young mum of her life; a tsunami devastating an island. Where are the answers to these sorts of questions? We try and make sense of it, we search for clues in the suffering, we blame ourselves, we blame others, and yet we're still no further down the line in understanding suffering's million dollar question, 'Why, God, why?'
The book of Job turns the spotlight on the question, 'Why?' It's about one good man's struggle against suffering. But it could just as easily be about the Holocaust, or 9/11, or you! It asks why God heals one person's illness but not another. Are we somehow to blame for our own misery? Is it right to question God? Will we ever get the answers we crave? The answers page seems to have been torn from the back of the text book. We find that suffering isn't a sum to be solved. We find that God has His ways and they're higher than ours. We're confronted with a hard truth: are we willing to trust God despite the uncertainty? The question is: are you?
SoulFood reading: Josh 6:1-25, Luke 7:36-50

content.title: Thank God !
content.introtext:
'...God...reconciled us to Himself through Jesus Christ...'



2 Corinthians 5:18 NKJV
We see the golden arches of McDonald's and we think 'Big Mac'. We see a swoosh on a pair of trainers and think 'Nike': but what about the cross? What does that symbolise? A bling item we hang round our necks? A religious shape hung outside a church? Or a death penalty of its day?
How can we make sense of this picture of Jesus hanging from a death penalty? Firstly, we now know where God is to be found; He's on a cross. When we face raw suffering in a hurting world and we ask that million dollar question, 'where is God in all of this?' or our soul cries, 'where is God when I need Him most' the answer is hanging from the cross. Hanging from that same pain we are feeling.
Secondly, we see a crucified God who takes responsibility for our mess. An exchange is made as the ultimate price is paid for our ransom; blood money. In order to be restored to the Father, the Son stretches His arms across a large cross-beam, and we are able to walk across this bridge into the Father's arms.
Thirdly, we see God is staying with us to the very end of our wounded road. A miraculous exchange brings about change as we are released to grow into our God destinies. Thank Jesus today.

SoulFood: 1 Sam 27-31, John 2:1-11, Ps 110, Pr 23:6-9

content.title: Anger management (5)
content.introtext:
'...for man's anger does not bring about the righteous life that God desires.'

James 1: 20 NIV
So what do you do, when you know all the theory (yeah, sure, it's better to forgive and forget than spray paint, ‘you messed up my life, loser' all over their front door) but you're still struggling to apply it? Well, we need to check in with the black-belt of forgiveness, the man Himself: Jesus Christ.
He's the man who didn't wait for us to come crawling back, tail between our legs, before He started to think about putting things right. He took the initiative. Listen: ‘When we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son...' (Romans 5: 10 NKJV) Did you get that? Even when we were off doing our own thing, totally ignoring God, He'd put the plan in place to fix the relationship back together. He's the ‘forgiveness' master. He paid the price before we've even said the ‘sorry'.
So, you might not have even started to sort this whole mess out. They might still see you as the enemy, even though you've done nothing wrong. What an opportunity for you to practice forgiveness by God's standards. Try forgiving them right now, even if they don't seem sorry. Erase those fantasies involving their falling in front of huge dump trucks from your mind. Picture all the steps you could do to make this relationship work. Become an expert in forgiveness and a thicko in hatred. Take the forgiveness initiative.
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 16:1-18:16, Luke 1:39-56, Ps 139:7-12, Pr 13:24

content.title: You gain through your pain
content.introtext:
‘...Naomi was left without her two sons and her husband.'



Ruth 1:5 NIV
When hers sons died, Naomi experienced a unique bonding process with her daughters-in-law, Ruth and Orpah, who (obviously) had lost their husbands. Unless you've been through something like it, it's hard to understand that kind of bond. Tragedy can bring together the oddest people. When you're hurting, don't look for support from people based on what they look like or where they live. All you want is someone who's been there themselves, someone who really knows what you're going through. People can't give you what they don't have.
The old preacher Charles Spurgeon gets at this issue using the image of soldiers returning from battle, ‘Just as old soldiers compare stories and scars, when we arrive at our heavenly home we'll tell of the faithfulness of God Who brought us through. I wouldn't like to be pointed out as the only one who never experienced sorrow, or feel like a stranger in the midst of that sacred fellowship. Therefore be content to share in the battle, for soon we will wear the crown.'
So if you're fighting just to get through another day, remind yourself that you aren't the first and you won't be the last to do so. Like Naomi, God sees what you're going through and has plans for your life yet to be revealed. Be encouraged. You will gain through your pain. Hold on to His hand; He'll bring you through this!

content.title: Anger management (4)
content.introtext:
‘...For if you forgive men when they sin against you, your heavenly Father will also forgive you.'

Matthew 6: 14 NIV
God made you with a capacity for anger because when handled the right way it's the fuel that brings needed change and the medicine that heals. So what are this medicine's active ingredients? (a) reality. You don't have to focus on how you've been ‘disrespected, man'. The sooner you can get over yourself, the sooner you can get around to making sure it doesn't happen again. (b) humility. You're no goody-two-shoes either, own up to your share of the mess. Admitting you've been a grouch sometimes makes it easier for someone else to admit that they've been one too. (c) forgiveness. Forgive and forget, it's a bit of greeting card cheese, isn't it? But, actually, it's the only way. If we truly forgive, we need to make sure that we're not bringing it up every 5 minutes. Even if our minds can't forget that easily, we need to act like we've chosen to forget. Jesus was dead serious about this forgiveness stuff; just listen: '...if you forgive men when they sin against you, your heavenly Father will also forgive you. But if you do not forgive men their sins, your Father will not forgive your sins.' (Matthew 6: 14-15 NIV) Hey, if Jesus can forgive the very people who wanted Him dead, surely we can forgive the person who winds us up.
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 13-15, Luke 1:26-38, Ps 139:1-6, Pr 13:21-23

content.title: Learn to be content (2)
content.introtext:
'I have learned the secret of being content...'



Philippians 4:12 NIV
Michael Drosnin wrote a book about a man who wanted more. More wealth, so he built a huge financial empire. More pleasure, so he paid for the best women money could buy. More adventure, so he set air speed records, built and piloted the world's most unique aircraft. More power, so he got political clout that was the envy of senators. More glamour, so he owned film studios and hung out with stars. Drosnin tells how this man's life ended: 'He was a figure of ... power, ready for the grave. Emaciated ... thin scraggly beard ... sunken chest, hideously long fingernails in grotesque yellow corkscrews ... Many of his teeth were black, rotting stumps. A tumour was beginning to emerge from the side of his head...there were innumerable needle marks. Howard Hughes was an addict. A billionaire junkie.' All that, and he still wasn't content. So here's the question: If he'd pulled off another deal, made another million and tasted another thrill, would it have been enough? No. We think we'll be more grateful if we get more, but it's not always the case.
The same man who wrote, 'I have learned the secret of being content' also wrote, 'In everything give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you' (1 Thessalonians 5:18 NKJV). You cannot make yourself a more grateful or content person, but you can pray for it and open your heart to what God will do.

SoulFood: 1 Sam 24-26, John 1:43-51, Ps 23, Pr 23:4-5

content.title: Anger Management (3)
content.introtext:
‘...Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God. '

Matthew 5: 9 NIV
Jesus said, ‘The good man brings good things out of the good stored up in his heart, and the evil man brings evil things out of the evil stored up in his heart. For out of the overflow of his heart his mouth speaks.' (Luke 6: 45 NIV) Notice that word, ‘stored'. When we store something as dangerous as anger, we give it room to fester and breed more danger.
If we leave a toothache untreated, the pain seems to grow and grow, until one day you can't even sleep because the pain has spread from one tooth to your entire face. If we leave anger untreated, the pain preoccupies us, it saps our energy, it drowns out our love, it controls our thoughts, it spreads right across our life until one day you realise it has hindered your progress in life, damaged your relationship with God, and your whole outlook is off centre.
Ask God for the humility and courage to deal with today's problems-today! When your head hits the pillow tonight, know you've exercised these words, ‘Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God.' (Matthew 5: 9 NKJV)
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 10-12, Luke 1:11-25, Ps 73:17-28, Pr 13:20

content.title: Be grateful for your blessings
content.introtext:
‘I went away full, but the Lord has brought me back empty...'



Ruth 1:21 NIV
When it comes to valuable life-lessons, the book of Ruth is right up there. For the next few days we're gonna dig into it...
When famine came to Bethlehem, Naomi, her husband and two sons moved to Moab where the economy was thriving. What they hoped would be a short stay turned into ten years. The lads married two local girls, Ruth and Orpah. Then the unthinkable happened; Naomi's husband and both sons died! As you might expect she was absolutely gutted. She heard that things were back on the up in Bethlehem so she decided to go home. After arriving back safely she said, ‘I went out full, and the Lord has brought me home again empty' (NKJV). She was choking on the irony that she'd left a land of nothing for a land of plenty and come back with even less than she set out with.
The truth is, you can be blessed and not know it. You never miss the water till the tap runs dry! Only as you look back do you realise that what you have is much more important than the things you don't have. Have you been saying, ‘I'll be happy when...'? Forget it, happiness doesn't come from getting what you want, it comes from appreciating what God's given you. So take a few minutes today to put down that wish list and just say some simple thank yous.

content.title: Anger management (2)
content.introtext:
‘...don't sin by letting anger control you...'

Ephesians 4: 26 NLT
Uncontrolled anger is like jumping into a Ferrari, gunning the engine, then discovering the brakes don't work. The Bible says: ‘Don't sin by letting anger...control...you...anger gives a...foothold to the Devil.' Did you get that? Uncontrolled anger opens the door to Satan, and then it's all downhill from there! So before you say something you'll regret or can't take back, ask yourself: (1) Is my anger appropriate? Some anger is. You can't love roses and not hate weeds. But it's easy to let small stuff like thoughtless comments and insensitive friends make you overreact. For anger to have a healthy result it needs to be measured and constructive. This is a control issue! Listen: '...the mind controlled by the Spirit is life and peace.' (Romans 8:6 NIV) A controlled response and a gracious response is a Christ-like response. It always wins! (2) Is it really worth dragging other people into? Anger invariably affects those around you because it's only human to take sides, even if not personally involved. Dragging others in is usually a way to feed our own ego and justify our bad behaviour. (3) Is the relief I'll get from venting worth the aftermath? The Bible says: ‘A gentle answer deflects anger but harsh words make tempers flare.' (Proverbs 15: 1 NLT) By sounding off, you usually end up making the finest speech you'll ever regret! By its very nature, anger encourages exaggeration. It makes you say things you can't take back. Long after you've moved on, angry words retain the power to wound and divide.
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 7-9, Luke 1:1-10, Ps 73:1-16, Pr 13:17-19

content.title: Learn to be content (1)
content.introtext:
‘I have learned the secret of being content...'



Philippians 4:12 NIV
So, what's the secret of being content? Here are three things that may help you on your way...
1) Learn to be happy with less. Happiness isn't about getting what you want, but about enjoying what God's given you. Make a list of good things in your life, and thank God for them today. Paul said he had learned to be content, ‘whether well fed or hungry, whether living in plenty or want. I can do everything through him who gives me strength.'
2) Remind yourself things could be worse. Snoopy was lying in his kennel one Thanksgiving Day, mumbling about being stuck with dog food while all those humans got to be inside with the turkey and gravy and pumpkin pie. ‘Of course, it could have been worse,' he finally reflected, ‘I could have been born a turkey.' Reminding yourself ‘It could be worse' can really help you to develop contentment.
3) Know that you're going for spiritual contentment, not just stuff. We may want more stuff, but underneath that is what we really want; God, the perfection of heaven - and that's to come. You're unlikely to feel totally content, as this world isn't your ultimate home; heaven is.
Today, try flipping your discontent on its head, and using it to pray ‘Your Kingdom come, Your will be done on earth as it is in heaven' (Matthew 6:10 NIV).

SoulFood: 1 Sam 20:30 - 23:29, John 1:29-42, Ps 131, Pr 23:1-3

content.title: Anger management (1)
content.introtext:
‘...don't sin by letting anger control you...'

Ephesians 4: 26 NLT
So, you want to be a ‘good Christian'. You want to love other people. It's just that sometimes other people can be so frustrating, so annoying, so downright unlovable. In fact, with some people, you suspect that the kindest way to show them love is by slapping them severely with a freshly filleted mackerel (or whatever punishment your raging emotions dream up). If only you could find permission for that in the Sermon on the Mount! So, here's today's question: how can we manage our anger healthily?
Tip for today is ‘honesty is the best policy'. ‘...don't sin by letting anger control you...' (Ephesians 4: 25-26 NLT) When you're angry, don't deny it-acknowledge it. We're right to feel angry when innocent people are mistreated. We're wrong to feel like smashing a brick into someone's head just because they push in front of us in the dinner queue. Now, we don't have to be Christian doormats that let everyone walk over us, but neither do we want to walk around like ticking time bombs about to explode. So start controlling your feelings before they control you. And when you have to take someone to task, keep it truthful, not hurtful. It's one thing to tell a person why you're angry with them, another to start dissing their very existence. ‘Words can bring death or life! Talk too much, and you will eat everything you say.' (Proverbs 18: 21 CEV)
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 4:18 - 6:33, Mark 16:1-20, Ps 80:12-19, Pr 13:13-16

content.title: Inside Outside
content.introtext:
‘I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full..'



John 10:10 (NIV)
Living your fullest life needs help from two places: the inside and the outside.
1) The Inside: You need to be able to dig deep and to how to go the extra mile. Yep, that means extra effort and extra time. Mega business dude Andrew Carnegie had this sussed and was fond of saying, ‘There's no use in trying to help people who won't help themselves. You cannot push anyone up a ladder unless he or she is first willing to climb it.' The apostle Paul puts it like this: ‘each one should carry his own load' (Galatians 6:5).
2) The Outside: You need to be teachable, open to other people whom God brings along to input into your development. This isn't just a good idea, it's a God idea; called discipleship, or basically, mentoring. Good mentors lead by example; they know that to have influence they first need your respect. They treat you as an individual understanding your strengths and weaknesses. They notice whether you're right-brained (creative) or left-brained (methodical). They find out whether you learn visually or verbally. They know when you need a pat on the back or a kick in the butt! They're someone who, like the apostle Paul, can say ‘Follow my example, as I follow the example of Christ.' (1 Corinthians 11:1 NIV) If you can get a mentor you'll be well blessed. So don't hang about, ask God to bring you one!

content.title: Happiness isn’t found on a hanger
content.introtext:
‘Happy is he...whose hope is in the Lord...'

Psalm 146: 5 NKJV
Whoever said money can't buy happiness, just didn't know where to shop, right? The Bible doesn't include the verse ‘Happy is the girl with her Dad's credit card in Sportsgirl' or ‘Blessed is the boy spendin' his birthday cash in EB Games'. It might seem that way at times, but if time has taught Aussies anything, it's that however much you blow, you're always left wanting more; you're always left feeling curiously empty. That's how this credit crunch got started, isn't it? People spending cash they never had in the first place in order to purchase ‘happiness'.
Happiness isn't found on a hanger in a dress shop, girls. Nor can it be downloaded on to your Shuffle, boys. ‘Happy is he (or she)...whose hope is in the Lord', the psalmist sang. Dead right. Clothes go out of season; this year's must-have fashions are next year's shoulder pads (ask your Mum). Technology evolves; today's Apple Mac is tomorrow's Commodore 64 (ask your Dad). The only constant we have in life is God. He's never old fashioned or out of touch. His hard-drive never fails you. He never rusts, busts or burns out. God is the same yesterday, today and forever. So if you think happiness is only your next purchase away, you're always going to be left feeling bankrupt inside. Isn't it time you started to cash all your cheques in the Bank of God?
SoulFood reading: 2 Kings 1:1 - 4:17, Mark 15:33-47, Ps 80:1-11, Pr 13:11-12

content.title: Spirit signals
content.introtext:
‘The man without the Spirit does not accept the things that come from the Spirit...'



1 Corinthians 2:14 NIV
Pastor Jon Walker writes: ‘Spirit warnings alert you to impending danger. A friend of mine was driving towards a green light when he was strongly prompted to hit his brakes. As he did so a truck ran a red light. Had it not been for my friend's instant obedience he'd probably have been killed. Spirit ‘stop signs' red-flag you not to go somewhere. A dog I owned...was used to being on a lead and when I took him to a neighbour's field to run, I'd simply say "No" when he approached a place he shouldn't go. He'd done nothing wrong, and my warning wasn't a rebuke; it was a caution for his own protection. Spirit timing is God telling you the time is not right. In university I planned to buy a computer through a discount programme... however, they told me it had been discontinued. I was very angry at God. Two months later the university reopened the programme offering upgraded models bundled with software that cost extra two months ago; the whole package was cheaper than the previous one...Turns out God knows what he's doing!'
Be sensitive to Spirit signals. Trust God's Spirit to guide you in the decisions and details of your life. Keep a list of the times He has prompted you; it'll remind you to obey in the future. Remember, God's promptings always line up with His Word; even when they don't line up with your ideas!

SoulFood: 1 Sam 18:1 - 20:29, John 1:14-28, Ps 29, Pr 22:26-29

content.title: Grow up (2)
content.introtext:
‘Train up a child in the way he should go...'

Proverbs 22: 6 NIV
‘Growing older' and ‘growing up' is not the same thing. You can be forty and still wobble about in spiritual nappies. ‘Growing up' isn't just something that happens. It takes work. You must want to grow, choose to grow, make an effort to grow. When you first decided to follow Jesus, something in you was drawn to His invitation. That's great, that's all you need to get started. But where do you go from there? How do you ‘follow' Jesus? Do you simply put your feet up until Judgment Day, thinking: ‘well, that's my ticket sorted for the afterlife.' Well, you could, but you'd miss out on the full ride that God has planned for you. Following Jesus means trying to make Jesus-like choices and then asking his Spirit to help you stick with it.
The Jesus blueprint for choices always focuses on putting others first, not yourself. This kind of thinking is alien to our culture, where we are told ‘chase OUR dreams', or ‘make a name for OURSELVES'; it comes unnaturally to us. But it's the core of a Jesus lifestyle, it sums up his ‘love God; love people' attitude. So where are you at with your thinking? Ask yourself now: where do I need to stop wanting my way and start wanting God's way? Where can I grow up? Now ask the Holy Spirit to help you stick with it.
SoulFood reading: Ex 34:27-35, Col 2:9-15

content.title: The J word
content.introtext:
‘...I coveted them and took them...'



Joshua 7:21 NIV
You know how it is, all of a sudden those trainers you thought were the bomb when you bought them 2 months back feel pretty sad compared to the new style that's just been released. Or what about that new mobile you mithered for months about? Yeah, you were well happy with it until first day back when you found out she had one too! If that sounds a bit like you then you need to pay attention today because it sounds like ‘stuff' has got a hold of you.
There's a story from the book of Joshua about the time when things started going wrong for Israel; they started losing battles. Joshua asked God why and God said it was because there was sin in the camp. When Joshua started doing a bit of detective work one of his soldiers, confessed, ‘While we were in Jericho, I saw a beautiful Babylonian robe... and a gold bar... I wanted them for myself, so I took them.' At the end of the story it cost the guy his life and the lives of his family.
When you get jealous about stuff you're basically putting something else in the place of God. If you think you really do need (not just want) something, pray about it and trust God to give it to you! In the meantime be grateful for what He's already given you.

content.title: Grow up (1)
content.introtext:
‘Through wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established.'

Proverbs 24: 3 NKJV
Annoying, aren't they? Those brats you see on Supernanny. All that kicking and screaming and those award-winning temper tantrums make you want to wrap the kid in its soiled nappy and send it for recycling. Thank God we're so over the ‘spitting the dummy out of the pram' phase, eh? Or are we?
We can all have our moments of dragging our feet because we feel like God isn't playing fair or because we're so stubborn in wanting our own way. But get this: God wants us to ‘grow up in all things into Christ...' (Ephesians 4:15 NKJV) You see, a Dad may love a screaming brat but he's not likely to be a fan of the outburst; well, it's the same with our Heavenly Dad. That's where the discipline comes into play. Supernanny's legendary ‘naughty step' isn't designed to torture a child, it's there to get the child to change how they think. Well, guess what: '...we are no longer to be as children...' (Ephesians 4:14 NAS) To change our spoilt-brat ways, we must change the way we think. In fact, we are urged to ‘...think the same way that Jesus Christ thought...' (Philippians 2: 5 CEV) Imagine Jesus pulling a strop because He didn't feel like healing a leper today. Doesn't add up, does it? Little kids, by nature, think only of themselves, because they're immature. Don't just think of yourself-think like Christ. Grow up!
SoulFood reading: Rev 19-22, Mark 15:21-32, Ps 143, Pr 13:9-10

content.title: It’s time to get away
content.introtext:
‘..."Come aside...and rest a while."'



Mark 6:31 NKJV
Check out Jesus' life in the Gospels; Matthew, Mark, Luke and John; and you'll see He sets us an amazing example. He was so controlled, even under extreme criticism. He never wavered from following God's plan.
The good things in life aren't always the right things, and that's hard. You might be chasing after something that God wants you to leave, or vice versa. So how do you know what God wants? Follow Jesus' example, and get away! (Luke 4:42). Go to a deserted place, and meet with the Lord. Now, that doesn't mean you have to go and sit in your little brother's sandpit in a heatwave; it just means a quiet place to think, pray, refuel and listen to God.
It's easy in the busyness of life to get carried away doing everything at 200 kph. We treat our brains like a Ferrari, thinking they're at their best when they're fastest. Everyone around you might tell you that time is money; and the devil loves that. If he can keep us so busy with life, surrounded by crowds and noise with no time to think, we won't be spending that quality time with God, which is what he wants.
Jesus turns the tables on the rest of the world, and says ‘come to me'. So will you? Will you stop, get away from it all, and check that you have been saying yes to the right things, according to God?

SoulFood: 1 Sam 16-17, John 1:1-13, Ps 92, Pr 22:24-25

content.title: God is with you
content.introtext:
‘The Lord turn His face toward you and give you peace.'

Numbers 6: 26 NIV
allas Willard writes about a little boy whose mum died. Every night he toddled into his dad's room to ask if he could sleep with him. Only when his father promised to sleep with his face turned towards him, did the little guy feel safe enough to doze off.
Moses prayed, ‘The Lord turn His face toward you and give you peace.' God watches over us, guides and protects us 24/7! In fact, the most common promise in Scripture isn't about salvation or heaven. No, the most frequent promise in the Bible is, ‘...I will be with you...' (Josh 1:5 NKJV) It's the promise God made to Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Sarah, Jacob, Joseph, Moses, Mary and Paul. And it's the one that kept them going! David said, ‘Even when I walk through the darkest valley, I will not be afraid, for You are close beside me...' (Ps 23:4 NLT)
Do you believe it? Do you believe that God is looking you full in the face and smiling at the very thought of you? Well, whatever you choose to believe doesn't alter the truth. God is looking out for you. Just like He's reminding you today, ‘...Do not be afraid or discouraged...the Lord...is with you...' (Josh 1:9 NLT) Be at peace today, God is looking out for you!
SoulFood reading: Rev 15-18, Mark 15:1-20, Ps 132:11-18, Pr 13:7-8

content.title: Control your anger (2)
content.introtext:
‘Stop being angry! Turn from your rage'



Psalm 37:8 NIV
A bad temper is not something to be proud of, but prayed over. When you blow your top, you just reveal your contents. And which of us hasn't done that, and regretted it? Here's three ways to get your lid firmly back on!
1) Less is more: By cramming too much stuff into too little time, you wind yourself up! Like guitar strings that are pulled too tight, you end up snapping, then feeling guilty because you're not ‘spiritual' enough. ‘Do not think of yourself more highly than you ought, but rather think of yourself with sober judgment, in accordance with the measure of faith God has given you.' (Romans 12:3-4 NIV).
2) Don't be a hammer: If you want to get on in life you'll need to tackle different problems in different ways. People whose only tool is a hammer have got no choice but to treat every problem like a nail. Before long they've got holes all over the house, so put the hammer (anger) down! You know, the Bible describes 9 different fruit of the Spirit but not one of them is anger. (see Galatians 5:22)
3) What's the point: Sometimes ‘enough is enough' and you need to speak up. When Jesus got angry in the temple he had a point because poor people were being ripped off and he was drawing attention to it. In this case, ‘If you don't do what you know is right, you have sinned.' (James 4:17 CEV).

content.title: Band of brothers
content.introtext:
‘Then he consecrated Jesse and his sons...'

1 Samuel 16: 5 NKJV
Not yet shaving; voice barely broken; knee-high to a grasshopper. Yet, it was David, not his hairier, tenor-bass voiced, older brothers that had the guts to battle Goliath. Why? Because:
(1) His brothers weren't up for it. When Goliath started ranting, soldiers shook in their sandals. David's brothers saw a big noise rather than a big God. A lesson for us all, do we see big problems that will grind us down, or do we see a big God that will build us up?
(2) His brothers had no previous battles. There's nothing insignificant on our ‘God CV'. Our little battles equip us for big battles. The lion David killed as a boy was big; the bear was bigger; Goliath bigger yet. But David wasn't about to bail over this latest overgrown grizzly. Listen: ‘The Lord, who delivered me from the paw of the lion and...the bear...will deliver me from the hand of this Philistine.' (1 Samuel 17: 37 NKJV) His past was shaping his destiny.
(3) His brothers had beauty not bravery. ‘...the Lord does not see as man sees; for man looks at the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart.' (1 Samuel 16: 7 NKJV) Even today, we're still impressed with muscle or make-up, but real history-makers have it sorted in their core. The lives of frail old Mother Teresa or Nelson Mandela prove it. (Google them and see!)
SoulFood reading: Rev 10-14, Mark 14:66-72, Ps 132:1-10, Pr 13:4-6

content.title: Don’t be scabby!
content.introtext:
‘Physician, heal yourself!...'



Luke 4:23 NKJV
In the Old Testament, a priest couldn't serve in God's house if he had a scab. Why? Because when you've a scab you're a health risk. We all have ‘scabs'. It could be some pain in your life or an issue you haven't dealt with that still hurts.
If you went to the doctors, and he tried to see to you while he had a huge gaping, bleeding, oozy cut on his head, you wouldn't really listen to what he was saying, would you? You'd think he needed to sort himself out first, before he sorted you. It's the same with you when you're witnessing to your friends, and working for God. It's hard to help your mates sort out emotional issues, when you've still got unresolved issues from the past. It's hard to talk about victory, and complete forgiveness to others, when you feel defeated by an old issue. Now, that doesn't mean you can't work for God if you have issues - completely the opposite in fact - often the broken become the best at mending. But you do need to be at least dealing with your issues not ignoring them. It's not wrong to have a wounded heart, but it is wrong not to deal with it. So spend some time with God and let Him heal you and make you whole, so you can be more effective in your mission to others.

SoulFood: 1 Sam 14-15, Luke 24:45-53, Ps 63, Pr 22:17-23

content.title: Star Quality
content.introtext:
‘Those who turn many to righteousness [will shine] like the stars forever...'

Daniel 12: 3 NKJV
Why is it we all love to show off-whether it's guys talking about AFL as if they personally taught Jonathan Brown everything he knows, or girls posing in their new gear as if they're on a catwalk? Could it be that somewhere built within our biology God has placed a desire for significance?
What does every talent show wannabe crave? A record deal? Partly. A millionaire lifestyle? Probably. To make a name for themselves? Definitely. We all want to be a legend in our own lunchtime because God has built us for great things. He doesn't want us to settle for an average existence. He made us to make our own mark on eternity. So, what does that mean? Are we all to place ourselves up for public humiliation in Red Symon's firing line? Well, no. To really place your own personal print on history, you need to explore all that God has placed inside you. Has He given you the gift of the gab? Maybe you're a born evangelist. Do you hate it when people hate each other? Maybe you're destined to be a star peace-maker. Do people seem to look up to you? Maybe you're here to role-model a Godly life-style to others. The point is: whatever weird and wonderful concoction of gifts and talents bubble inside of you, they bubble for a reason. That reason is to shine like God's star in your generation.
SoulFood reading: Rev 5-9, Mark 14:53-65, Ps 48, Pr 13:2-3

content.title: Control your anger (1)
content.introtext:
‘In your anger do not sin.'



Ephesians 4:26 NIV
Everyone, except the emotionally disturbed, likes to think of themselves as deep-down basically an OK person. And most people are, until they get angry. You see, anger dissolves personality. Anger is that it brews and festers invisibly waiting for its moment and then - KABOOM! The nicest, sweetest people can explode in a ball of rage. It ain't pretty!
So what if that's you? Or maybe you've not exploded yet but you can feel your fuse burning shorter and shorter. Listen to what Paul says: ‘In your anger do not sin.' (NIV). Does that mean it's always bad to get mad? No, Paul is making the point that we can't help things happening that stir us to feeling angry, but we have a choice not to let that anger lead to sin. You can scream something really hurtful and nasty at your sister / brother / mum / dad (or whoever) or you can let off steam in your bedroom by screaming into your pillow! One of those things is OK by God and the other isn't!
Sometimes we're angry because we think people don't appreciate us, or take advantage of us. Again Paul writes: ‘Get rid of all...anger...forgiving each other...as...God forgave you' (Ephesians 4:31-32 NIV). So, if you're inclined to be hot-tempered, ask God now to remind you of all the times He's forgiven you. It's a great way to cool off ;-)

content.title: Boxing clever
content.introtext:
‘Be self-controlled and alert. Your enemy the devil prowls around like a roaring lion looking for someone to devour.'

1 Peter 5: 8 NIV
You'd have to be pretty clueless to eat a picnic in a minefield, or to try telling Russell Crowe that the Rabbitohs are rubbish without expecting to get an earful back. It's the same with your faith-life. You're acting pretty naïve if you think the devil isn't looking for the right moment to give you a slap or worse still blow you sky-high. The Bible gives us plenty of warning, ‘Be self-controlled and alert. Your enemy the devil prowls around like a roaring lion looking for someone to devour.' (1 Peter 5: 8 NIV) So, how do you keep your guard up against a dirty fighter? First, jab him with the Word. God's Word is like a weapon. If your opponent comes at you with lies, you need truth to sort your head out. Second, use the rabbit punch of prayer. Pray hard and long. Pray for a Godly perspective. Pray for God's strength. Pray for God's perseverance. Pray. Pray. Pray. Third, upper cut with praise. God loves it when we can say, ‘Life might be a female dog, BUT God is still good.' Satan hates that. You see, his plan is to take your eyes off God. But if he only succeeds in drawing you closer, he ends up on the canvas. And for the knockout hook? Easy: ‘Resist the devil and he will flee...' (James 4: 7 NIV)
SoulFood reading: Rev 1-4, Mark 14:43-52, Ps 1, Pr 13:1

content.title: The right place; the right people
content.introtext:
‘...for...a time like this.'



Esther 4:14 NIV
Did you know the Bible has a beauty queen in it? Not only that, but Esther also married a king, uncovered a plot to kill all the Jewish people, and saved them. Quite a life! Her story shows us how important it is to be in the right place, and let the right people influence you. Remember these two things:
1) Where you are today is no accident. If you think of your life as a swimming race, there's no time for you to just tread water - you should always be going forwards. Don't think that there's gonna be a better time, or more important opportunity - you don't choose your time, God does. He's got you where you are for a reason, so that when He calls you to do something, you're either in the right place to do it already, or on your way there.
2) God sends special people to guide us. Mordecai was Esther's mentor, her accountability guy. Without him, she may not have ever realised what her calling was. He helped her actually get stuck in and do what God wanted. Who is your Mordecai? Who helps you understand where you are, knows you well enough to give you a gentle kick up the bum if you go off on one? Who will encourage you when you feel ready to quit? None of us are perfect - that's why God sends friends, we really need them!

SoulFood: Esther 4:9 - 5:3 ,Heb 4:7-16

content.title: Who’s first?
content.introtext:
‘...If anyone wants to be first...'

Mark 9: 35 NIV
Sacrifice. A bit of an ugly word. We often associate it with gory death scenes from B grade horror movies. But the reality of the word couldn't be further away from that! Sacrifice is something beautiful. Think of the everyday heroes who bring beauty to the word: the single mum who works two jobs to give her child a better future; the soldier on the frontline risking his life for the security of his country; the young person volunteering her time to clean up the local park. Beautiful heroic acts centred on this beautiful word: sacrifice. You see, when we put other people's needs before our own we end up connected to some very wise words first said over 2000 years ago, ‘If anyone wants to be first, he must be the very last.' (Mark 9: 35 NIV) In God's kingdom, things are different. The least are considered the greatest (Luke 9: 48). Jesus knew if you want to turn the world kingdom side up, it begins with a revolution of the self. When we're able to help others rather than help ourselves, we begin to grasp the beauty of sacrifice. Jesus washed His disciples' feet before His own were cleaned. Sacrifice: Jesus gave up the five star luxuries of Heaven to live in poverty. Sacrifice: Jesus laid down his life so that others would gain theirs. Sacrifice: so, go on, do something beautiful today.
SoulFood reading: 1 Kings 21-22, Mark 14:27-42, Ps 129, Pr 12:27-28

content.title: From God’s perspective
content.introtext:
‘He made known his ways to Moses, his deeds to the people of Isarel.'

PSALM 103:7
Have you ever known someone to do something that made absolutely no sense until they explained it to you? God can be just like that. Sometimes He does things we don't get, sometimes he doesn't do things we think He should. Like when He told Noah to build a boat, Abraham to sacrifice his only son, and Moses to cross the sea on foot. None of those things make any sense until you look at the whole story, from God's perspective. Then we can see He totally knew what he was doing!
When we are able to stop looking at things through our own eyes and see God's perspective it changes the way we see everything. When we understand Him better we learn to love Him more. When we see why He has asked us not to do certain things we naturally find quite appealing, it's much easier to do as He asks. ‘There is a way that seems right to man, but in the end it leads to death' (Proverbs 14:12 NIV). Just because something feels right, it doesn't mean it is. If it's not God's plan, it's a dead end!
Understanding God's point of view keeps us on track. We live in a world that has come to the conclusion that there is no truth and everyone's opinion is valid. The problem isn't that our culture doesn't believe anything, it's that it believes everything. Many say ‘It doesn't matter what you believe as long as you're sincere.' Rubbish! Hitler was sincere; and that definitely mattered. Seeing life from God's perspective keeps us stable, focussed and stops us being fooled by the latest fads!

content.title: Coming clean with God
content.introtext:
‘When I kept silent about my sin...Your hand was heavy upon me....'

Psalm 32: 3-4 NAS
A woman who completed a walk around the world confessed she travelled part-way in a support truck. ‘I shouldn't be remembered as the first woman to walk round the world when I cheated,' she said. How many of us would even have admitted our deception?
The Psalmist said, ‘When I kept silent about my sin...Your hand was heavy upon me.' Confessing your sins: (1) lets you experience God's forgiveness: He already knows about them anyway, but how can He forgive you while you're busy making excuses and blame-shifting? John says, ‘...if we confess...he will forgive our sins...' (1 John 1: 9 NCV) The first move is up to you. (2) restores your emotional and physical energy: Nothing's more draining than denial and nothing gives you energy and enthusiasm like having a clean slate. David said, ‘I am weak from sin...' (Psalm 31:10 CEV) Reflecting on his affair with Bathsheba, he said, ‘When I kept silent... my vitality was drained...I acknowledged my sin...and You forgave the guilt.' (Psalm 32: 3-5 NAS) (3) allows you to move on: Confession allows you to hit the ‘reset' button and start again. It draws a line between the past and future. (4) lets you grow: Thomas Edison said failure taught him over a thousand ways not to make a light bulb! Your mistakes work for you instead of against you when you start confessing them to God and accepting His forgiveness.
SoulFood reading: Philip 4:4-13, Gen 11:1-9

content.title: Jump overboard for the Lord!
content.introtext:
‘...Peter heard him say, ‘It is the Lord'...and jumped into the water.'



John 21:7 NIV
Imagine: you've been up all night, sat in a stinky boat in the middle if the lake, fishing; that's your job, it's what you do. And what have you caught? Diddly squat! Then some bloke, who isn't a fisherman, tells you to throw your nets the other side of the boat. You'd be a bit reluctant, thinking ‘who does He think He is, telling me my job', but you do it anyway; and wow - not only one, but 153 fish leap into your nets! Just one question: Who is this man? One word from Him, and things change for the better. Answer: It was Jesus.
Peter's so excited that he leaves the fish he's been slaving all night for without a second thought, leaps off the boat, and runs through the water to Jesus. For Peter, even though his nets were full, he'd achieved his goal, he didn't stay and guard his blessings. He went overboard and committed himself fully to God. Could you do that? It's a challenge for you today. When you've got what you want in life, don't just watch over it, but be willing to leave it for Jesus.
Peter felt like he was giving up everything when he left his boat, his mates, his fish and jumped in to see Jesus; but when he got there, Jesus was cooking...fish! God knows what you need, He has it, and He'll give you it. So go on; jump out of that boat.

SoulFood: Lev 23: 33-44, Jn 7:1-40. Zech 14:16-21, Heb11:8-16
