content.title: Strengthen your mind
content.introtext:
‘Do your best to present yourself to God as one ... who correctly handles the word of truth'

2 Timothy 2:15 NIV
Ever go back upstairs to remind yourself of why you originally went downstairs? Well, just like our bodies don't work too well without proper exercise; neither do our minds! Doctors say that all those hours in front of the TV, avoiding mental stimulation, result in the shrinking of our mind's capacity, including our memory. ‘Brain fitness' experts assure us that our brains don't grow old from working too hard, but from hardly working at all! When you just let your mind ‘vegetate' and don't stretch it with deep reading, creative thinking or challenging conversation, it can become old-even when it's young! On the other hand, if you challenge your mind regularly, your brain stays young even as you get older.
Here's a great way to strengthen your mind: ‘Do your best to present yourself to God as one ... who correctly handles the word of truth.' Paul is telling Timothy to push his mind by studying God's Word. Paul didn't want Timothy's mind to turn into a vegetable! He knew that God promises those who feed on His Word daily will become ‘...like a tree planted by streams of water...which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither.' (Psalm 1:3 NIV) Don't let your mind ‘wither'; exercise and strengthen it by studying the Scriptures today!
SoulFood reading: Josh 1, Acts 3:1-21

content.title: Romans road
content.introtext:
'...The gift of God is eternal life...'



Romans 6:23 NIV
Ever feel 'there must be more to life than this?' Ever wondered what happens after you die? Do you long to get right with God? Your soul is hungry for the life Jesus can give you. Follow this:
Step 1: We've compiled a very long and sorry record as sinners and have proved that we are utterly incapable of living the glorious lives God wills for us. (see Romans 3:23). Face it, we need help from God to live right.
Step 2: If you sin your whole life then your pension payout is death. But God's gift is real life, eternal life, delivered by Jesus (see Romans 6:23). Jesus has bought you a ticket to life before and after death. He's paid for it by giving his life for you on the cross.
Step 3: God put His love on the line for us by offering his only Son in sacrificial death, even while we were still of no use whatever to him (see Romans 5:8). You can't buy the ticket off Him, all you need to do is accept the ticket as a gift from one friend to another.
Step 4: '"...if you confess with your mouth, "Jesus is Lord," and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved' (Romans 10:9 NIV).
Now pray these words: 'Lord Jesus, I'm sorry for trying to go it alone. I place You in charge now. By faith I receive Your ticket to life now and forever. Thank You for setting everything right between You and me, amen.'

SoulFood: Num 29:1-6, Matt 24, Rev 11:15-19, 1Cor 15:50-58

content.title: Picture language
content.introtext:
‘I looked, and I saw...'

Ezekiel 1:4 NIV
God gave Ezekiel some of the maddest visions any human eyes have ever seen. His book in the Old Testament (in between Lamentations and Daniel) is bursting with vision after vision-for 48 chapters! If you're serious about getting to know God through His Word, sooner or later you'll need to tackle books like this. The understanding won't come all at once-and you'll probably need quite a bit of help from Christian friends further down on the journey than you-but God wants to speak to you from every single page of His Word. None of it is just padding!
One of the special things about Ezekiel, like many of the ‘prophetic books' (including Revelation too), is that it is full of picture language-pictures that have meanings deeper than just the surface. Let's look at an example. In his first vision Ezekiel is shown four heavenly creatures: with four faces each! The face of a lion, the face of an eagle, the face of a man and the face of an ox. Can you guess what these faces might represent? Pause for a minute and think about it. If you can, then you're on your way to understanding the Bible on an even deeper level.
So what did you get? Well, the lion is a generally a sign of kingship, the eagle of vision, the man of intelligence and the ox symbolises strength in service. Still scared of those ‘prophetic books'? Nah!
SoulFood reading: Num 11-13, Mark 7:1-13, Ps 37:32-40, Pr 11:7-8

content.title: In the waiting room
content.introtext:
‘...look not only to your own interests, but also to the interests of others'



Philippians 2:3-4 NIV
People will often say that relationships are more important to them than anything else, but their actions don't show it. How about you? Relationships are living things and like any living thing if you don't feed and protect them, they will die. While things are going well we can take the people close to us for granted, then a crisis comes along to remind us how valuable the people in our lives are.
One author writes: ‘The Intensive Care waiting room is different from any other place in the world. And the people who wait are different. They can't do enough for each other. No one is rude. The distinctions of race and class melt away. The truckie loves his wife as much as the university professor loves his, and everyone understands this. Each person pulls for everyone else. In the Intensive Care waiting room the world changes. vanity and pretence vanish. The universe is focused on the doctor's next report. If only it will show improvement. Everyone knows that loving someone else is what life is all about. Could we learn to love like that, if we realised that every day of life, is like a day in the Intensive Care waiting room?'
The apostle Paul says, ‘...if I have a faith that can move mountains, but have not love, I am nothing' (1 Corinthians 13:2 NIV). He's absolutely right isn't he?!

content.title: Tell someone about Jesus
content.introtext:
‘...a Samaritan woman came to draw water...'

John 4:7 NIV
John tells us that, ‘When a Samaritan woman came to draw water, Jesus said to her, ‘Will you give me a drink?" After five failed marriages her trust levels are demolished so she approaches Jesus cautiously. Brick by brick, Jesus takes down the wall she's hiding behind. When He gets through, she leaves transformed. There are (at least!) two big lessons in this story for us today:
(1) Christ sees potential in you when others don't. Jesus was forever winding up a bunch of religious people called ‘The Pharisees' who complained, saying, ‘This Man receives sinners and eats with them.' (Luke 15:2 NKJV) They were right! That's exactly the category this woman fitted into and yet she was the first person Jesus introduced Himself to as the Messiah. Why didn't He do that when He called His 12 disciples, baptised John, cleansed the temple, performed His first miracle or chatted to Nicodemus? Because Jesus doesn't measure you by your past, He measures you by your potential.
(2) Christ will change you, then use you to change others. She didn't mess about, they very same day she went off and started sharing about Jesus. She was the first person to ever preach the gospel in town! And ‘Many of the Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the woman's testimony...' (John 4:39 NIV)
Why don't you take a leaf out of her book and tell someone about Jesus today?
SoulFood reading: Num 8-10, Mark 6:45-56, Ps 37:25-31, Pr 11: 5-6

content.title: Our survey says...
content.introtext:
'I have put my words in your mouth and covered you with the shadow of my hand...'



Isaiah 51:16 NIV
The radio announcer says "Call now if you can tell me..." Next thing you know there's some bloke on the line who hasn't got a clue. The announcer is saying 'I'm sorry, but I'm gonna have to hurry you for an answer' and he's going "can you tell me the question again?" Do you ever come across pushy people who pressure you for an answer, but you've not got no idea what to say? What about when your mate at school says "How come if God is all loving and all powerful, so many people are starving in Africa?' Now, you know you've heard some really clever way you could answer this at Church once, but you'll be blowed if you can put it into words now, what do you say? Do you stand there like a stunned mullet with your mouth opening and shutting and no words or do you babble for the sake of saying something? Sometimes it's wise to wait, to say, 'I don't have the answer right now but I'll look into it'.
If you ask Him, God will tell you what to say and when to say it. His promise is: 'I have put my words in your mouth and covered you with the shadow of my hand...' (Isaiah 51:16 NIV). Your mate might yell 'Don't just stand there, say something' but Wisdom says, 'Don't just say something, stand there!'

SoulFood: Ezek 46-48, Luke 22:54-62, Ps 3, Pr 21:4-8

content.title: Drawing the line
content.introtext:
‘...take up the whole armour of God...'

Ephesians 6:13 NKJV
Simon the Sorcerer was doing good business. The people ‘...followed him because he had amazed them for a long time with his magic.' (Acts 8:11 NIV) But to everyone's astonishment he chose to accept Paul's Gospel message and got baptised. Sadly though, before long, traces of his old ways emerged: he offered Paul money to buy the gift of the Holy Spirit! How did the apostle handle this? Simple! He confronted this flaky guy with the truth in Jesus name, saying: ‘Repent of this wickedness and pray to the Lord.' (Acts 8:22 NIV) You see, Paul knew something that every good pastor knows: when a new Christian starts turning back to their old ways you must quickly crack on and deal with it or they'll end up hurting themselves and other people too. Being fuzzy and soft in those moments helps no-one.
For all of us, whether disciples for 10 minutes or 10 years, the forces of evil around us are real; we can't just ignore them and hope they'll play nice or maybe just go away. To fight and win you must know what you are up against. There'll be times when you have to be decisive and draw a line saying, ‘That's it, the other side of this line is out of bounds for me now that I follow Jesus.' Do you need to draw or re-draw some lines around your life today?
SoulFood reading: Num 7, Mark 6:30-44, Ps 37:16-24, Pr 11:4

content.title: Have a dream
content.introtext:
‘...ABLE TO DO IMMEASURABLY MORE THAN ALL WE ASK OR IMAGINE...'

EPHESIANS 3:20 NIV
How big is your vision? Do you even have a vision? Martin Luther King Jr famously declared in one of the best known speeches in history: ‘I have a dream'. Martin Luther King's dream was to see a future where blacks and whites would live together in harmony as equals. But Luther King's dream wasn't just a dream; a distant thought of ‘wouldn't it be nice if'. He devoted his whole life to promoting nonviolence and equal rights for everyone and as a result he did more to advance the cause of Black Americans than anyone else has ever done.
Martin Luther King's dream was a God-given dream. In a time where black people were not much better than slaves with hardly any legal rights, poor access to education, no right to be in authority, and no opportunity to have a normal job and provide for their families, surely Martin Luther King's dream was impossible? Well, he knew that the Bible says that God is able to do ‘more than we can ask or imagine'. But the verse doesn't stop there, here's the key part: ‘according to his great power which is at work in us.' This verse tells us that:
1) No matter how big we dream, God can do way more than the greatest thing we can even imagine
2) He won't just do it, he does it through us! Can you imagine what the world would look like if Martin Luther King woke up one day having had his dream and thought ‘that's nice, it'll never happen though' - turned over and went back to sleep?! If you don't have a dream or a vision, ask God for one today.

content.title: Let your light shine
content.introtext:
‘Let your light shine before men...'

Matthew 5:16 NIV
Driving down the road a man is being tailgated by a woman who's in a hurry. He comes to an intersection and, as the light is turning yellow, he hits the brakes. The woman behind him goes ballistic. She blasts her horn, shouts out of the window and gestures with her finger. As she's ranting and raving someone taps on her window. To her horror she looks up and sees a policeman. He's not impressed and takes her to the station where she's searched, fingerprinted and put in a cell. After a couple of hours she's released and the arresting officer gives her her personal effects and says, ‘I'm very sorry for the mistake. I pulled up behind your car while you were blowing your horn and using ugly gestures and foul language. I noticed the "What Would Jesus Do?" sticker and the little fish sign stuck on the boot, so I naturally assumed you had stolen the car.' Obviously he was following a Christian who wasn't doing a very good job at following Christ.
The world is sick of people who wear WWJD wristbands, read fat Bibles in the canteen, sing along to worship songs on their iPods, but don't have the love of Jesus in their hearts. What's the answer? ‘Let your light shine before men, that they may see your good deeds and praise your Father in heaven.'
SoulFood reading: Num 4:34 - 6:27, Mark 6:14-29, Ps 37:8-15, Pr 11:3

content.title: Amazing grace
content.introtext:
'To me...grace was given, to preach...the unfathomable riches of Christ.'



Ephesians 3:8 NAS
If it's not, 'Kum-by-ya' it's 'Amazing Grace'. Anyone who can barely tune a guitar and strum a chord has probably tackled it. A song so famous, it must've just always existed, right? It fell from the sky one day and landed on a worship leader's fretboard, right? Actually, no.
John Newton showed no early signs for musical masterpieces. A rough sailor, in trouble with law, at odds with authority, and always the first to diss a Christian, he cared only for himself. One night, however, he woke to find his PJ's soaked with salt water, his boat was sinking fast, his life moments from ending, when he turned to the Lord, asking for forgiveness and new life in Christ.
The rest is musical history. The song Newton wrote about this episode in his life went a little like this: 'Amazing grace! How sweet the sound that saved a wretch like me! I once was lost but now am found, was blind but now I see. Through many dangers, toils and snares I have already come; 'tis grace hath brought me safe thus far and grace will lead me home.' How amazing is grace! How amazing is Jesus! Maybe, you feel a little like John, perhaps circumstances are drowning you at this moment. Take a note from Newton, remember, God's amazing grace is just a prayer away from rescuing you.

SoulFood: Ezek 43-45, Luke 22:39-53, Ps 19, Pr 21:3

content.title: S-T-R-E-S-S!
content.introtext:
‘...when they were alone, He explained all things to His disciples.'

Mark 4:34 NKJV
S-T-R-E-S-S! Unless you're one of those one-in-a-million people who just breeze through life as if nothing at all is a problem you probably get hit by the ‘S' word every single day. You scuff your new shoes, the bus goes past and doesn't stop, the battery on your phone dies, next door's stupid dog starts barking in the night and wakes you up... nnnNNNGGG!!!
So if stress is part of our day how do we handle it? Mark's Gospel says, ‘When they were alone, [Jesus] explained all things to His disciples.' Just like He did with His disciples, there are things Jesus will reveal to you only when you get one-to-one with Him. He's not interested in shouting them at you over your busy schedule. No, you need to take responsibility for yourself and set aside time to study His Word and to pray. Jesus explained things to His disciples when they were alone, away from the busyness of ‘doing' ministry and the crowds and He'll do the same for you.
A minute of silence with God is more powerful than a whole week of words without Him. Bottom line: you need one-on-one time with God! Take some time out today to just be silent with Him; see how long you can listen for ;-)
SoulFood reading: Num 3:1 - 4:33, Mark 6:1-13, Ps 37:1-7, Pr 11:1-2

content.title: Shiny Green Triangles
content.introtext:
‘All Scripture is... profitable...'



2 Timothy 3:16 NKJV
By December 29th all that's left of that massive tin of lollies your Gran brought round for Christmas are about a dozen of ‘nobody's favourite'; they're just sitting there in their wrappers. Who put them in there? They don't even have chocolate on! We all have our favourites; Minties, Strawberry Creams, Jelly Beans those crunchy ones in the blue wrapper. But be careful; don't go treating the Bible like a tin of lollies. You can't just pick the bits you like and leave out all the rest. To grow in your faith you need to take in all the different tastes of God's Word because ‘all Scripture is... profitable...' (2 Timothy 3:16 NKJV). To make a profit in business you have to know your business inside out, otherwise you'll soon be out of business. To get on in your Christian life, make it your business to know your Bible.
There's nothing like just setting aside half an hour to get into your Bible. Without it you won't be able to hear what God is saying to you. You'll always have to depend on somebody else. Imagine dealing with your mates on that basis, never bothering to listen to a word they say? How long do you think your friendships would last? The same is true with God, so put down your Word4U2day and open your Bible... now.

content.title: Impressive?
content.introtext:
‘Am I now trying to win the approval of men, or of God?...'

Galatians 1:10 NIV
How much energy and emotion do you use up trying to change somebody else's opinion of you? Would you really feel so much better if they suddenly woke up tomorrow morning and decided you actually are ‘good looking / funny / intelligent / whatever' after all? Why base your worth on the opinions of those who are committed to putting you down? Let's face it, most of the people you've spent all that effort trying to impress, may never, ever, be impressed. So, why don't you make an agreement with God today to only see yourself the way He sees you: loved, unique, precious, forgiven, full of potential, destined for life in all its fullness.
If you're not willing to do that then really you're walking into a prison of your own making. Until you quit agreeing with those who've mistreated you or bowing to the events that crippled you emotionally, you'll stay stuck. This is what the apostle Paul was banging on about when he said, ‘Am I now trying to win the approval of men, or of God? ... If I were still trying to please men, I would not be a servant of Christ.' He knew that to get on in life you have to interact with people without allowing yourself to be controlled by their moods or dominated by their opinions. All you need to know is that Jesus loves you unconditionally. So what else matters?
SoulFood reading: Num 1-2, Mark 5:31-43, Ps 2, Pr 10:30-32

content.title: Eat the Word (3)
content.introtext:
'..."All that the Lord has said will we do..."'


Exodus 24:7 NKJV
So you've bought your new recipe book. You're going to make the world's greatest 'Super-double-whipped-cream-marshmallow-chocolate delight'. You read the recipe five times over, you memorise it, discuss it with friends, you copy it out in a journal. What more do you need to do? The cake will bake itself, right? Of course not! It's no good merely studying the recipe! In order for the cake to rise, you need to act on the words on the page, apply what it says to reality. It's the same with God's Word. We can study it at church, we can memorise favourite verses, we can create amazing pictures in our journals, but at some point don't we need to act upon it? It's not theory, it's practical. 'Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says...the man who looks intently into the perfect law...not forgetting what he has heard, but doing it - he will be blessed in what he does' (James 1:22-25 NIV). If we think reading, knowing, and even believing God's Word is all there is to it, we end up with cake on our faces. God wants us to get the most out of life, He's not interested in us being 'Bible nerds' who can quote every scripture, He's interested in seeing His Word come to life in our lives.

SoulFood: Ezek 40:10 - 42:20, Luke 22:24-38, Ps 24, Pr 21:1-2

content.title: Sort it out!
content.introtext:
‘...The Lord has taken away your sin...'



2 Samuel 12:13 NIV

Look, there's no point asking God for blessing when you're carrying around a sack full of unforgiveness you're not willing to let go of, or a sack full of arrogance you need to repent of. Jesus said, ‘...when you offer your gift to God at the altar, and you remember that your brother or sister has something against you, leave your gift there at the altar. Go and make peace with that person, and then come and offer your gift.' (Matthew 5:23-24 NCV) Get it sorted! Make things right with that person you need to forgive. Ask forgiveness from that person you've wounded. And what if the person isn't around any more? Then Bible says, ‘...confess your sins to each other and pray for each other so that you may be healed...' (James 5:16 NIV) Share the issue with someone trustworthy. You'll be surprised how amazing peace of mind can be found through the prayer and the presence of a godly friend. After King David committed a terrible sin he tried to cover his tracks with even greater crimes, but God wouldn't let David carry the guilt in private. He sent a prophet who cleverly cornered David into breaking his silence. Broken, he finally sought forgiveness, pouring out his heart. He then wrote Psalm 51 as his heartfelt prayer. If you have sin to sort out today, you really should take a look at it.
SoulFood reading: Isa 51:1-16, Mark 5:1-20

content.title: W8
content.introtext:
'Be still before the LORD and wait patiently for him'

Psalm 37:7 ESV
Waiting! Not many of us enjoy waiting do we? Waiting for the bus to come, school to finish, or even for the microwave to warm up our leftover pizza. We don't want to wait do we? It's hard. When we want something we want it NOW!!!. ‘Hurry up!' we shout at our friend who's late or the traffic lights. Just hurry up!!
It's Christmas Eve and everyone's waiting for Christmas Day. Are you one of those people who can't wait to see their presents so has already found them and even opened a few? It can be hard to wait. But the Bible tells us to ‘Be still before the LORD and wait patiently for Him'. Waiting for God patiently, not screaming at Him to hurry up but patiently waiting, being still; listening for God, not rushing ahead of Him.
It can be hard to wait! When we want something to happen and nothing is changing, it can be so tempting for us to try and make that change ourselves.
A major cause of car crashes here in Australia is people running red lights. They are in too much of a hurry to wait for the next green.
It's important to wait. Sometimes it's a matter of life and death. Ask God, today, to give you the patience to wait when you need to. To do things in His time not yours.

content.title: Eat the Word (2)
content.introtext:
'...My words will by no means pass away.'



Mark 13:31 NKJV
Some recipes just can't be improved upon. You don't melt a mars bar on top of fish and chips. You don't add curry sauce to a Big Mac. You don't do an ice cream any favours by dipping it in salt. They're all recipes that need no updating. The Word of God is the same. 'Heaven and earth will pass away, but My Words will by no means pass away.' When we eat the Word we get tried and tested, 100% pure perfection. No added preservatives or any of that junk. We get a diet that we know will do us good.
Joshua says: '"Do not let this Book of the Law depart from your mouth; meditate on it day and night...do everything written in it. Then you will be prosperous and successful"' (Joshua 1:8 NIV). In other words: Eat, drink and be merry. Note how he says 'meditate' on it. Meditation is when we allow our brains to have a good chew on God's word. Watch how your Alsatian can get the most out of his chewed up little bone, how much more can we get when we chew over God's wisdom. Note, also, the word, 'success'. Any athlete wishing for Olympic glory watches what they push through their face. Grant Hackett wouldn't get far on a kebab, and neither will you. To stay the distance you need regular helpings of the Word.

SoulFood: Ezek 37:1 - 40:9, Luke 22:14-23, Ps 78:65-72,Pr 20:26- 30

content.title: One Word
content.introtext:
‘Lord, if it's you...tell me...'



Matthew 14:28 NIV
One of the most famous Jesus-stories is the one when He walked on the water to His disciples in the boat. His mate Pete shouts out, ‘Lord, if it's you...tell me...' (Matthew 14:28 NIV). Jesus gave him one word, ‘Come,' and with that Pete hops over the side of the boat and starts walking! Was he scared? Wouldn't you be? Ice skating is hard enough but how the heck do you stand up when the water's still wet and wobbly! But Peter's desire was greater than his fear. And that's all you need to get started, a desire for God that's bigger than your doubts.
There's another detail in this story we should note: The disciples didn't exactly back Peter up in his surfing-without-a-surfboard experiment! So bear in mind that when God gives you a Word and you step out in response to it, not everybody will cheer and shout out encouragements. It's normal for you to want people to see what you see and believe what you believe. But if you're not careful, people's opinions will short-circuit your faith and make you doubt what God has said. God says: ‘I'm not going to confirm what I've told you through them. In fact, I don't even need them to agree with what I've spoken concerning you.' Relax. You may want your mates to back you up, but the truth is, Jesus is all you need!

content.title: Eat the Word (1)
content.introtext:
'...open your ears to the words of his mouth...'



Jeremiah 9:20 NIV
It may have been a sad day in the school tuck shop the day the Board decided 'healthy' was in and cream donuts were out...but here's the thing, it was done for your own benefit. We need to be careful what we digest. It's not just our stomachs either, we need to watch what we feed our brains. Our favourite mags may give us the lowdown on what's hot and what's not, but there's not enough substance there to sustain us. Our spiritual lives need a good dose of iron and all the right ingredients. We need to tuck into our Bibles for a healthy feed. It's a diet of a) POWER. Read Luke 4 to understand the power of Jesus' Word. It's a healthy tale of forces submitting to God's Word b) FORCE. '...by God's word the heavens existed and the earth was formed...' (2 Peter 3:5 NIV). God didn't call in the builders when He made the world, His Word alone was enough to create all that exists c) LIFE. 'The words I have spoken to you are spirit and they are life' (John 6:63 NIV). When you eat the Word of God, it can't just sit there and do nothing, it comes to life. It gets to work in you and starts to produce results. So don't just sit there drooling, tuck in, feed your face with the Word.

SoulFood: Ezek 34-36, Luke 22:1-13, Ps 78:56-64, Pr 20:25

content.title: What are you talking about? (2)
content.introtext:
‘He who guards his lips guards his life...'

Proverbs 13:3 NIV
Paul Galvin's business had gone bust. He went to the auction of his own company, and with his last $750 he bought back the department which later became Motorola! He was ‘down' but definitely not ‘out!' ‘When times are good, be happy; but when times are bad, consider: God has made the one as well as the other. Therefore, a man cannot discover anything about his future.' (Ecclesiastes 7:14 NIV)
‘Good times' can be less helpful than ‘tough times'; and the ‘hard times' can be better for you than the ‘easy times'. Whatever changes and challenges come your way; whether planned or unexpected, whether you feel like you're going forward or sliding backwards - God is waiting for you to turn to him and know him. ‘If any of you lacks wisdom, he should ask God, who gives generously...' (James 1:5 NIV) ‘Ask and it will be given to you...' (Matthew 7:7 NIV). And there's more; God can make you a new creation (2 Corinthians 5:17), give you strength (Isaiah 40:31), guide and comfort you (Psalm 23). ‘You will have to live with the consequences of everything you say'. Proverbs 18:20 reminds us that, for better or for worse, repeated actions create behaviours, behaviours create character and character creates a destiny. So make sure you are careful, with an attitude like the Israelites of Deuteronomy 11:18, and protect your life!

content.title: Credit crunch
content.introtext:
'Give, and it will be given to you.'


Luke 6:38 NIV
Three reasons to hang on to your purse strings: 1) with the credit crunch in full bloom you'll need every penny you can get 2) it's a tight month you can always give a little next month 3) wait til you've landed that dream job with that dream salary, then give!
If you're not going to give, feel free to choose any of the above as your reason. For those of us, who want to give, feel free to choose one of the following:
1) When we give - we get! Jesus said, 'Give and it will be given to you...the measure you use...will be measured to you' (Luke 6:38 NIV). Test Jesus in this, put your money where his mouth is, see what happens. 2) We get back more than we give. If a bank lends you money, they whack a load of interest on top - so in effect, you always pay back way more than you borrowed. The Bible says when we give to the poor we lend to God (Proverbs 19:17). Imagine that- loaning to God! What kind of interest does God pay back?
3) We get into good habits. Giving is not just how the church raises its budget, it's how God raises His children. Parents want to raise their children to cultivate beautiful qualities such as: generosity. Our heavenly parent is no different. So, pick a reason!

SoulFood: Jn 2:1-11, Job 36:22 - 37:13

content.title: Are you a ‘grafter’ (1)
content.introtext:
‘...receive...the engrafted word...'



James 1:21 KJV
Have you ever turned on the TV and caught a few minutes of any of those gardening programmes? Yes, it is a bit baffling how people can get so excited about borders and rockeries. But if you're going to understand some of the things in the Bible you'll need to know a bit about gardening; Eden, home of the first people is a pretty big clue that God is into gardens.
Today's verse is a gardening image. In some translations of the Bible the word ‘planted' is used but the original word is actually ‘grafted' or ‘engrafted' which is when a gardener carefully slices a branch off one tree and then transplants it into a hole he's made in a branch of another tree. From then on the branch that's been relocated starts receiving all its water and life from the new tree.
Now let's get creative, picture yourself reading your Bible, and as you do, those words from God are becoming attached to you, they start growing in you and producing fruit in your life. That's how God's Word works, and that's why you need to read it every day. As God's Word actually becomes part of who you are, you will find that it frees you from fear, lifts you when you're low, directs you the way to go, and gives you the strength to fight and win.
So, how do you feel about gardening now?

content.title: Criminal records
content.introtext:
'He cancelled the record...against us...by nailing it to [Christ's] cross.'



Colossians 2:14 NLT
So what do you think of when you hear the words, 'criminal record'? Your Dad's 'Phil Collins' Greatest Hits collection'? A special certificate awarded to those who break the law? Or a long list of sins committed by your good self?
However good we may think we are, we're never good enough by 'holy' standards. So you might not be on par with some when it comes to dodgy dealings, but can you honestly say, 'I've never told a lie', 'I've never dissed someone behind their back', 'I've never in my darker moments wished someone would get run over by a bus'? The Bible says we've all fallen short of God's standards. We've all created our own list of sins, our own catalogue of wrongs, our own criminal record. So what is the sentence for all this rubbish? Community service? Probation? Life imprisonment? Actually, there's no way we could ever serve our sentence. How can imperfect creatures like us satisfy the holy perfect standards of God? The answer is we can't. But we know a Man who can! We know a Man who did. He's served our sentence for us. He's paid our bail. He's got us off the hook. His name is Jesus. When Jesus hung on the cross, a penalty was being paid. A death penalty. Our death penalty. Our criminal record was being wiped clean by the blood of the lamb. Er...praise to Jesus, anyone?

SoulFood: Ezek 31-33, Luke 21:25-38, Ps 78:40-55, Pr 20:22-24

content.title: What are you talking about? (1)
content.introtext:
‘...he who invokes a blessing on himself...shall do so by saying, May the God of truth...bless me...'

Isaiah 65:16 AMP
Words are powerful things. From ‘God said' in creation, to God's Word being a sword in Ephesians 6:17. Words can change things big time. When Wally Lewis was being tackled as a five year old, or when Stephanie Rice was struggling down the swimming pool lane for the first time, did they give up? No! Read Isaiah 65:15, and you'll see that: a) you must rise above what others might say to you (in words or actions) b) there is power in what you say to yourself.
In a way, rising above what others say is the easier of those two points. Follow Lewis' and Rice's example, and filter those put downs from others. And then get tough on what about what you're saying to yourself; don't ever run yourself down. Instead read the Bible out loud to yourself and pray God's promises into your life. Go on; start now! The more time you spend hanging out with God and reading His love-letter to you, the more it'll change how you see the people and situations around you, and even how you view yourself.
Your mouth, your body and your brain are precious to God - so take care of them (check out 1 Corinthian 3:16 and Ephesians 4:29) and let God use them to take care of you.

content.title: Cornflakes and God
content.introtext:
'...in the morning I lay my requests before you and wait in expectation.'



Psalm 5:3 NIV
Start your day off smacking the snooze button on your alarm for the umpteenth time. When it doesn't stop buzzing in your brain, throw the wretched thing at the wall. Shout obscenities at your poor old Mum, when she does her best to wrestle the duvet off you. Burn your toast and spill juice down your school uniform as you scribble down bits of unfinished homework in between watching the telly and TXTing your mates. Start your day off like that and is it any wonder you're fit for a panic attack before you've even caught the school bus? The way we get up can set the mood for the rest of the day.
What if, tomorrow, you were to set your alarm 20 minutes earlier? What if, the first thing you did was say, 'Morning God, thanks for the night's sleep and thanks for a new day, help me find the beauty in this morning, and help me not embarrass myself or your name by my attitude today. Amen'. Try it. Note down any differences about your day. See if your worries are put into perspective. Can starting your day with God alter the way you close your day with God?
Tomorrow morning, sprinkle this Scripture on your cornflakes: ‘Satisfy us in the morning with your unfailing love, that we may sing for joy and be glad all our days (Psalm 90:14 NIV).

SoulFood: Ezek 27:25 - 30:26, Luke 21:12-24, Ps 78:32-39, Pr 20:20-21

content.title: When Jesus comes!
content.introtext:
‘During the fourth watch of the night Jesus went out to them.'



Matthew 14:25 NIV
Night time is when God does some of His best work! It's mentioned in loads of Bible stories, like when the Israelites faced the Red Sea, ‘...all that night the LORD drove the sea back' (Exodus 14:21 NIV), also, during ‘the middle watch' of the night, Gideon defeated the Midianites (Judges 7:19-24), and let's not forget, Jesus rose from the dead before ‘daybreak' (Matthew 28:1).
Matthew says: ‘...in the fourth watch of the night He came to them, walking on the sea. When the disciples saw Him ...they were terrified...immediately Jesus spoke..."Take courage, it is I; do not be afraid"' (Matthew 14:25-27 NAS). The ‘fourth watch' mentioned here is from 3:00 am ‘til 6:00 am. Check these two things out: 1) Jesus waited until the storm was so bad that the disciples had lost all hope. That's because God decides the timetable for our rescue, and He's never late 2) the disciples didn't recognise Jesus until He shouted to them. Often the answer you need is right beside you, but you can't hear it because of all the other chaos you're paying attention to.
So now we know this what should we do with it? The answer is simply this: to know that in life there are dark times, guaranteed, but that doesn't matter one bit to God, ‘...to you; the night will shine like the day...' (Psalm 139:12 NIV). He's always ready and able to save.

content.title: Give peace a chance
content.introtext:
'...the wisdom that is from above is...peaceable...'



James 3:17 NKJV
Peace, man, peace! When we think of 'peace', our heads might jump to a picture of a hippie as if the they copyrighted the word. But the Bible had a lot to say about peace long before those hemp wearing tree-huggers got a whiff of it. James 3:18 tells us that God's Word is 'sown in peace'. Colossians 3:15 tells us ‘Let the peace of Christ rule in your hearts, since as members of one body you were called to peace.' Even Jesus, himself, promises us, 'My peace I leave with you'. So, why the big deal? Because it's God's way. And what happens when we live God's way? We develop care and concern for others. We gain a kick in our step. We get passion and compassion for those in need. We want to bring peace to the places where there's destruction.
The world's way is to 'look after number one', God's way is to 'discover the beauty in everyone'. Do you know someone who seriously tests your patience? You know the type, they could turn Ghandi into the Karate Kid, they just have that knack of winding people up. Well, next time they're testing your peace, rather than hit back in retaliation, ask God to reveal their beauty to you, ask God to show to you how He sees them. Exercise self-control and keep your peace!

SoulFood: Ezek 24:1 - 27:24, Luke 21:1-11, Ps 78:17-31,Pr 20:15-19

content.title: Love yourself
content.introtext:
‘Love others as much as you love yourself.'

Matthew 22:39 (CEV)
Do you ever look around at everyone, and think they're so much better than you? Your mates have the looks of the cast of High School Musical, the charisma of Rove and are as funny as The Umbilical Brothers; whereas you feel like you have the looks of Shrek and the personality of a broom handle? Don't be so down on yourself! Not only are you being unfair to yourself, but with an attitude like that, you can't love others as God wants you to. You're the one person you can never get away from, so unless you learn to love and accept yourself, you'll probably end up miserable; which no-one wants. The devil loves any opportunities to ‘prowl[] around...looking for someone to devour' (1 Peter 5:8 NIV), so don't give him that pleasure by sitting around moping. Stamp on his head and tell him to get lost, and start to think positively about yourself! Read about what God has to say about you (Isaiah 43:4 is a good place to start). When you can see good stuff in you, that's evidence that God is at work in you. Yes, the Bible cautions us about having an over inflated opinion of ourselves - but don't go to the other extreme! Check out 2 Corinthians 4:7. Recognise God's treasure in you, and the potential you have, and run with it. Go on; love yourself!

content.title: Happy shopper
content.introtext:
‘...whoever sows generously will also reap generously.'



2 Corinthians 9:6 NIV
So it's Saturday afternoon, you're in town and ready to throw some serious money at a shopping spree. You're within sight of the inviting mall entrance when you spy a Salvo between you and the door. You pause for a second, and then you decide to do the right thing. You boldly approach, open up your wallet to find, horror of horrors, the smallest thing you have is a 20! What do you do? a) tell him, you'll come back later, once you have change from your latest purchase b) laugh and say sorry mate, I've only got a 20 and I don't want to give you that much, I'll have to make a donation another time c) sow generously. Pull out your 20 and without hesitating put it into the tin and say ‘God bless the Salvos'.
When we sow generously, there is always a cost; if you were to part with your hard earned cash (like in option c, above), it may mean not being able to afford those 'to-die-for' jeans, but as we ditch one purchase we end up with the better buy. We buy the happiness of others and in return bless ourselves, because if we believe the word of God, 'whoever sows generously will also reap generously'

SoulFood: Ezek 22-23, Luke 20:41-47, Ps 78:9-16,Pr 20:11-14

content.title: Rules or relationship?
content.introtext:
‘...I will put my laws in their hearts...'



Hebrews 10:16 NIV
Take a survey in the street and you will not find anyone who likes being called a dog. Yes, you might find plenty of pooch lovers but they won't appreciate you saying they might be a bit canine themselves! One of the amazing things about dogs is that they can understand human language; but only in a very limited way: Sit! Fetch! Heel! So if we're so much smarter than Rover and Fido why do so many of us have that sort of Christian life? Following Jesus gets reduced to: ‘Stop that; come back here; don't do that,' and don't forget the classics: ‘Read your Bible; pray; go to church; pay your tithes; witness.' Now, this is all stuff we should be doing, but God never meant us to do them at the end of a lead!
Let's listen to what the Bible says on the matter: ‘But now we have been released from the law, for we died to it and are no longer captive to its power. Now we can serve God, not in the old way of obeying the letter of the law, but in the new way of living in the Spirit.' (Rom 7:6 NLT) and repeats this again elsewhere saying: ‘...I will put my laws in their hearts...' (Heb 10:16 NIV). The point is quite clear: living life as a Christian is about changing first on the inside, the heart, so that works its way outside in your behaviour. Trying to keep to an external system of rules is a dog's life!

content.title: Church needs you!
content.introtext:
'The...many parts...form one body'




1 Corinthians 12:12 NIV
 Have you ever tried painting with your eyes closed, swimming without your legs, or having a conversation without opening your mouth? They're all possible, but really difficult! It's much easier to use your eyes, legs and mouth. But what does that have to do with 'church'?
Well, there may be people in your church that you struggle with, that you never speak to - maybe even avoid. Sometimes, you may think it's better if you don't even go to church, 'cos everyone's so different to you'.
This passage is saying that's not the way to go about it at all. Just like you work better, when your body is working together, and you don't isolate one bit, 'church' is the same. The Bible talks about us as all being different parts of the same body - and all the parts are important, and help things to be done better. So rather than trying to go it alone, you'll find life easier if you've got the other bits of the body to help you through it. You'll be helping others too - 'cos if you're not there, that means there's a bit missing for other people! Just as much as you need them, they need you - so don't be disheartened, but encouraged by church, and embrace all the differences that people have. God made us all that way for a reason, so that together we can do stuff well.

SoulFood: Ezek 20-21, Luke 20:27-40, Ps 78:1-8, Pr 20:7-10

content.title: Get changed!
content.introtext:
‘...you have taken off your old self...and have put on the new self...'

Colossians 3:9-10 NIV
Have you ever spent ages getting ready in the morning; slapping on that makeup, or spiking up your hair? Making sure you look the best you can, so you can impress that guy or girl that you fancy? I bet you wouldn't dream of letting them see you not looking your best; so why should it be any different with God? Don't settle for letting Him see you looking second best. Look in the mirror at the reflection of your heart and your mind and see what God sees. Ask yourself, are your attitudes and behaviours what you want God to be seeing? If not, then you need to think about changing them. How? By taking off the old, chucking it away, and putting on the new. Your focus each day must be to ‘Clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ, and do not think about how to gratify the desires of the sinful nature' (Romans 13:14 NIV). It's your choice, and only you can make that change. He's not going to force you to.
The devil ain't gonna like you making that change, and he's gonna do what he can to stop you; so expect it to be tough, but stick with it. That's why you need to get on your knees and ask God to help you keep off those old ‘clothes', and stick with the new.

content.title: Shine on
content.introtext:
'...shine like stars in the universe'



Philippians 2:15 NIV
Have you ever had a really bad day? All you want to do is have a go at everyone, to make them feel as bad as you do?
Here, Paul says 'DON'T!' Don't try to drag others down just because you're feeling manky. Instead, build them up. Even though it's really hard, try and be positive. Remember, no matter how bad your day is, you've got a message of life; eternal life. That message isn't just for you, you know; it's for everyone. And it's your job to help share that message, to make sure that everyone gets a chance to hear it and choose how they're going to respond to it. You can't get away with thinking that it's your mates' job, or expecting your youth leader to tell everyone. Not even your pastor will do it for you. It's your job. Yours. And what's one of the best ways to do that, to show others what God can do for them? By standing out from the crowd. Not for being grumpy, but for being positive. By shining like a star, being the light in the darkness. The message of God is a message of hope. Today, why don't you try and be positive to those around you, and share with them the best news in the world! No-one else can make you shine; only you can do it, with God helping you.

SoulFood: Ezek 16:53 - 19:14, Luke 20:20-26, Ps 27, Pr 20:5-6

content.title: The joy of giving
content.introtext:
‘Each of you must bring a gift in proportion to the way the LORD your God has blessed you.'

Deuteronomy 16:17 (NIV)
The award-winning film Schindler's List, is the story of one man's efforts to bring hope in a desperate situation. As the boss of a factory in Germany, Oskar Schindler decides to use his position to save lives. By employing Jews from the concentration camp in his factory, Oskar rescues them from the gas chambers. But it's expensive, so he starts selling his personal possessions in order to keep the business afloat.
At the end of the story the Nazis are defeated and the full impact of Oskar's effort is revealed as the dead are counted and the living stagger back to freedom. But kneeling by the railway tracks that carried thousands of Jews to their death, Oskar realises he could have saved more. Overwhelmed with regret, he thinks of the few goods still remaining in his possession; what else could he have sold to save a life? But it was too late. Yes, Schindler was a hero. But interestingly, all he could think about was what he didn't do. He wished he had done more.
We learn a powerful lesson about giving from this man; if even generous givers look back on their lives and wish they'd done more what about those who never gave at all, or gave less than they could, what will say when they stand before God?

content.title: Your Father’s watching you!
content.introtext:
'The Lord turn his face toward you and give you peace.'


Numbers 6:26 NIV
There's a story of a little boy whose mum died. Every night he toddled into his dad's room to ask if he could sleep with him. Only when his father promised to sleep with his face turned towards him, did the little guy feel safe enough to doze off. He needed to know his dad was looking out for him. When we're struggling, we need to remember that God is looking out for us, His face is towards us. It's not just when we're struggling either, but God watches over us, guides and protects us 24:7. How awesome is that?!
The most common promise in the Bible is, '...I will be with you...' (Joshua 1:5 NKJV). God made that promise to Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Sarah, Jacob, Joseph, Moses, Mary and Paul; quite a list! And that promise kept them going through the stickiest of situations! David said, 'Even though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for you are with me...' (Psalm 23:4 NIV). God used all sorts of ways to remind His people He was with them constantly; from the manna in the wilderness to the pillar of cloud and fire that went before them. How is God reminding you He's with you today? Remember, 'Do not be terrified; do not be discouraged...the Lord...will be with you' (Joshua 1:9 NIV). Be at peace; your Heavenly Father is looking out for you!

SoulFood: Judges 16:23-31, John 15:1-17

content.title: Get into good habits
content.introtext:
‘Bring...(the whole tenth of your income)...'

Malachi 3:10 AMP
Before you skip today's reading thinking it's not for you, just stop and think. Do you get pocket money or an allowance, ever get paid to babysit your little sister, do odd jobs around the house, or have a Saturday job? Yes? Then this IS for you. No? Read it anyway, ‘cos one day soon it will be!
‘Tithing' means giving God back some of your money. How's that fair, ‘cos it's your money isn't it? Well, no, not really! Everything we have is ours thanks to God. He gives us everything we need. The Bible says we should give back at least 10%; which may seem a lot, but just remember, it was His to start with! We're also told to give the first 10%; that means before anything else, not after you've got that new top or DVD you've been wanting for ages!
Giving God the first tenth of whatever ‘income' you have shows Him that He's first in your life. God promises two things to those who tithe: His blessing and His protection. By tithing, you're partnering with God. He'll bless you back more than you could ever bless Him, and He'll protect you when the devil tries to attack you financially.
So get into good habits now; it'll make it much easier to stick to in the future.

content.title: The truth about David’s brothers
content.introtext:
'Then he consecrated Jesse and his sons...'



1 Samuel 16:5 NKJV
Back in the good old days of Bible times, the people of Israel were always scrapping with the neighbouring nations. David's seven brothers were all in the army but none of them would fight Goliath; why? Three reasons:
1) They let the fear of others get to them. Fear is more contagious than the 'flu. If you listen to it long enough you'll get infected. Listening to Goliath and his scare tactics wore down David's brothers. Who are you listening to? Get God's opinion, build your life around it and let His Word to settle every issue.
2) They didn't have a personal track record with God to rely on. David's little battles prepared him for the big ones. He killed a big lion as a boy, a bigger bear later, and Goliath was massive. Was he freaked out by it? No. Listen: 'The Lord, who delivered me from the paw of the lion and...the bear...will deliver me from the hand of this Philistine' (1 Samuel 17:37 NKJV). He relied on his ‘God moments' from the past, and you can do the same.
3) They may have been fit, but they weren't going for God. You've heard the phrase 'don't judge a book by its cover' - well, people might, but God doesn't. He goes straight to the heart (1 Samuel 16:7 NKJV). David's heart was moulded by years of spending time with God. Can you say that too?

SoulFood: Ezek 14:1 -16:52, Luke 20:9-19, Ps 112, Pr 20:1-4

content.title: Peace
content.introtext:
‘When you enter a house, first say, "Peace to this house."'

Luke 10:5 NIV
The neighbours are holding big party, the music's pumping, (some tune from the last century) and it starting to sound like the maddest night of the year. People are going nuts; and probably sadly going to end up in a right state. But what are those people like the morning after? (If you're reading this and it's still before 10 o'clock you might want to sneak out and have a look) It is deathly quiet. There's hardly anyone around. It's probably the most peaceful morning you've enjoyed all year.
When Jesus sent out 72 of His followers to go and take the good news of salvation to the towns of Galilee He told them to find a ‘person of peace' and stay at their house, saying ‘Peace to this house'. But what did He mean? Did He just want the disciples to have a nice, quiet place to stay? Well, to understand what He meant we need a deeper understanding of the word ‘peace'. In Hebrew it is ‘shalom' which is a deep emotional word meaning ‘Nothing missing, nothing broken'. It is about wholeness, completeness, wellbeing. That's what Jesus was all about; bringing God's shalom to a broken and hurting world.
And just like He sent out the 72, He wants to send you too. Will you be one of His shalom-bringers this year?

content.title: Go for gold!
content.introtext:
'I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.'



Philippians 3:14NIV
Did you watch any of last Olympics? Thousands of people meeting together, trying desperately to be the best and win the gold medal. Now, do you think that any of the people who actually won gold just turned up on the day with no planning? Did they just wake up and decide they fancied winning a medal that day? Of course not! Your relationship with God is a bit like a race, so follow these key tips to help you get it right:
1) Be prepared. Make sure you know your race, and know your prize.
2) Good foundations lead to good results. You won't get there without training, and doing your homework on what obstacles you might come across.
3) Being 100% fit gives you the best head start. No athlete would go into a race without being fit for it, so exercise in your bible reading and praying.
4) Keep your eye on the goal. Focus on your prize; an eternity with Jesus. Watch a sprint race on TV; all the athletes are so focused on the finish line that nothing distracts them from getting there.
It might feel like those around you are running a different route, or following a different training programme. You may even feel you're in the wrong race sometimes. Don't let that distract you from God's plan for you. Stay close to Him, know your race, focus on the prize; and you'll get the gold.

SoulFood: Ezek 10-13, Luke 20:1-8, Ps 20, Pr 19:24-29

content.title: When God makes up His mind
content.introtext:
But I the LORD will speak what I will, ...I will fulfil whatever I say

Ezekiel 12:25 NIV
It was either the most astounding coincidence, or an act of God; literally. The small Methodist Church needed a new building, so when somebody donated a piece of land they accepted. It was low-lying land so they constructed a wooden church and put it up on brick pilings. Days later a storm lashed the town and the locals witnessed something amazing. The church building, still intact, was afloat! The flood had lifted it off its pilings and sent it down the road. At the town centre, as dozens of people watched helplessly, it made a sharp, inexplicable right turn and continued on. Finally, in the same decisive manner it veered off the road, it headed straight for a vacant lot and stopped dead in the centre! The flood waters eventually receded but the building is still there. In fact, 130 years have passed since the church, now called Providence Methodist Church, floated itself to the most desirable location in town. What’s amazing is this: The lot where it settled had originally been the congregation’s first choice for their building, but landowner Sam Sadler turned them down. The morning after the flood, he presented the pastor with the deeds to the land! ‘For I am the Lord. I speak, and the word which I speak will come to pass’. No doubt about it; when God makes up His mind, nothing gets in His way!

content.title: Prepared, planted, placed, pruned, prospered (1)
content.introtext:
…God planted a garden…there He put the man whom He had formed.

Genesis 2:8 NKJV
Before God put Adam into the garden, He ‘formed’ him.God knows where he wants you (remember yesterday?) and how he wants to use you. Maybe He’s told you about it, but now you’re frustrated because it’s not happening yet. There’s a process of preparation God takes us through, but preparation takes time. God must deal with our inconsistencies, personality defects, areas of distrust, and a sackful of other stuff. How long does it take? Only God knows. The Bible says the Lord ‘formed man out of the dust of the ground’ (Genesis 2:7 NKJV). What is God working with? Dirt! And the tools He uses to form you are the experiences you go through in life. They shape and alter you. And the more you keep trying to have it your way, the longer the process takes. It may take you five years to learn to stop people-pleasing, or ten years to stop feeling sorry for yourself, or twenty years to stop going back and reliving your childhood. All the while God is telling you, ‘Stop it,’ and you’re saying, ‘Yeah, I know. I’m gonna do better.’ Then finally a crisis happens and the truth hits you. You need to change. At that point you say, ‘You know what? I’m going to forget those things which are behind and start reaching for those things which are before’ (Philippians 3:13). Why wait?

content.title: Prepared, planted, placed, pruned, prospered (2)
content.introtext:
God planted a garden…there He put the man whom He had formed.

Genesis 2:8 NKJV
It’s pretty likely that gardening programmes aren’t filling up your sky+ hard-drive so let’s deal with the basics: what does it mean to plant? Technically it is ‘To bury seeds beyond human view so that they germinate and eventually produce fruit.’ (you did know that, right?) Now think of the Creator of the universe, as He stoops down and plants blessings and opportunities to grow in your life. Can’t see the blessings or opportunities? If you walk out into a field (ok, you might not do that often but use your imagination) and don’t see a crop, it doesn’t mean the seeds aren’t there; God has planted things in your life that will spring out of the dirt at different times. Everything God has for you hasn’t come up yet, so don’t give up, or walk away and say, ‘That’s all there is’. There are talents in you that haven’t been discovered and dreams that haven’t been fulfilled. That’s what the battle is about! The Devil is fighting you over your destiny. He knows good stuff is planted in you and he’s trying to kill the seed. Don’t let him. You’re not the person you’ll be six months or six years from now, because there’s a time factor; everything doesn’t come to harvest at the same time. You have to have faith and patience; otherwise you’ll miss what God has for you.

content.title: Prepared, planted, placed, pruned, prospered (3)
content.introtext:
God planted a garden…there He put the man whom He had formed.

Genesis 2:8 NKJV
Do your parents ever watch ‘Location Location Location’ on TV? In the programme, people talk about moving to find their perfect home in the perfect location! Notice in the verse, God placed the man in the garden, ‘eastward in Eden’ (Genesis 2:8 NKJV). It’s not enough to be in the garden, you’ve got to be in the right location. That doesn’t have to mean the school you go to or the house you live in (those things might be out of your control) but it might mean what group of mates you hang out with, or if you join the worship team at church, or if sign up for that mission week. God has a plan so ask Him to place you in the locations, relationships and opportunities that are perfect for you. Remember, God doesn’t want to dump you, drop you or shove you somewhere, He wants to place you. Ever played chess with someone who spends ages thinking about his or her next move? They pick up the queen slowly place it on a square, keep their finger on for a moment and then finally sit back. It was thought through- it was placed! God knows what He is doing! It’s easy to drift into your future but instead go to God, who will place you. If He places you somewhere you know it’s in the plan.

content.title: Prepared, planted, placed, pruned, prospered (4)
content.introtext:
God planted a garden…there He put the man whom He had formed.

Genesis 2:8 NKJV
Some restaurants and hotels buy plastic plants; you know, a few flowers on a table or a tree in a lobby, and they never need watering or pruning! Yes, plastic plants are hassle free but they’re fake; they have no life! God doesn’t want your relationship with Him to just LOOK like the real thing, He’s not into plastic Christianity, but if you don’t want a fake life with God it will take a bit of work. The Bible says: ‘God took the man and put him in the Garden of Eden to work it and take care of it’ (Genesis 2:15 NIV). Today God may be saying to you, ‘I’ve prepared you, placed you where you need to be, planted blessings in your life that are scheduled to come up at different times, but now you’ve got to work it.’ God may have placed you in a church or group of people; that doesn’t mean they won’t wind you up. God might have planted opportunities in your life; that doesn’t mean making the most of them isn’t hard work. No one likes being formed and prepared, especially if that means we have to change! It takes time, but it’s worth it. In our comfort obsessed culture we can forget that what is easiest isn’t always best. Don’t expect God to do things He’s expecting you to do- Get to work!

content.title: Learn to make better decisions
content.introtext:
...a prudent man gives thought to his steps.

Proverbs 14:15 NIV
If you’re still making the same mistakes you were last year, you need to ask God for wisdom. ‘Everyone with good sense wants to learn’ (Proverbs 18:15 CEV). Think about it- you are where you are today because of decisions you’ve made in the past. Both good and bad. If you want to change your future, learn to make better decisions: a) never make permanent decisions based on temporary circumstances. If you do, you’ll regret it b) don’t let your emotions take over. Pray, weigh things carefully looking at all the fact not just feelings c) surround yourself with People who will tell you the truth; even when you don’t want to hear it d) take the time to consider all options. What looks good to you today, may not look so good tomorrow e) consider the consequences of each action. Ask yourself, ‘Am I ready to handle this right now?’ f) be realistic. If you can’t count, don’t apply for a job in the finance office. If you can’t sing, don’t record an album. Focus on what God gifted you to do. That’s where you’ll succeed g) time is your most limited and valuable resource. Don’t waste it h) allow yourself a 10% risk of being wrong, a 50% likelihood of betrayal, and a 100% commitment to trust God, go forward and survive it all.

content.title: Get up and run!
content.introtext:
For though a righteous man falls…he rises again...

Proverbs 24:16 NIV
An unfit but determined 40-year-old schoolteacher decided to become a jogger and eventually entered a Marathon; a full 26 miler! It’s a gruelling test of heart, mind and body. She knew she wasn’t going get an amazing time she just wanted to finish the race; to say she did it! And it wasn’t easy! As she ran huge blisters developed on her feet. She was hit and injured by a bicycle. Several miles short of the finish line she was utterly exhausted, yet she kept going. Then within a few hundred yards of her goal, late at night when most other runners had finished or dropped out, she fell and lay flat on her face too tired to get up. But her friends put a bit of tape across the finish line and began to cheer her on. She lifted her head, saw the tape and realised her goal was within sight. With supreme effort she got back up, and with a burst of energy dredged up from deep within her, ran the last few metres.’

content.title: Don’t just pray, listen!
content.introtext:
I judge only as I hear….

John 5:30 NIV
Ever wonder why Jesus was always on form and knew what to do? He tells us: Jesus gave them this answer: ‘I tell you the truth, the Son can do nothing by himself; he can do only what he sees his Father doing, because whatever the Father does the Son also does. For the Father loves the Son and shows him all he does.’ (John 5:19-20 NIV) and ‘By myself I can do nothing; I judge only as I hear, and my judgment is just, for I seek not to please myself but him who sent me.’ (John 5:30 NIV). Here’s the secret, Jesus didn’t just talk to His Dad, He took time to listen and get instructions. Your parents might say that you never listen to them and they are chatting away right in your ear; so how do you do when it comes to listening to your heavenly Dad? It’s not easy, but when the Bible says, ‘Pray without ceasing’ (1 Thessalonians 5:17), it means we are to stay in touch with God at all times, to be spiritually sensitive and attuned to the still small voice of His Spirit within us. That calls for having an uncluttered mind and heart. It’s easy to tell God what we want but what does He want? God designed the plan for your life; so today, why not get quiet before Him, so that He can tell you about it?

content.title: 3 By’s
content.introtext:
…the blood…cleanses us from all sin.

1 John 1:7 NKJV
John writes: ‘But if we live in the light, as God does, we share in life with each other. And the blood of his Son Jesus washes all our sins away.’ He gives us three ways to shine!
1) By living in the light. Live life bright! If you are hiding stuff or hoping your Mum doesn’t find out, then you are living in the shadows not the light!
2) By sharing life with each other. Other people can inspire you to reach higher, tell you when you’re out of line and help you when stuff is tough. Make sure you have people who are a bit older and a bit wiser who you are 100% honest with and will be 100% honest with you even when you don’t what to hear it!
3) By dealing with your sin right away the moment you know you’ve messed up then make sure you ‘fess up. Jesus died to deal with that sin, sort it with God and hold on to the forgiveness He gives you. Get it sorted then get up and go on with God; don’t wallow in self-condemnation.
God has put everything in you to blaze brightly in like a star. He’s given you friends, family and leaders to draw out the best in you and the blood of Jesus to cleanse your heart. So what’s stopping you! LIVE IN THE LIGHT!

content.title: Serve, don’t strive!
content.introtext:
…Jesus…made Himself nothing...

Philippians 2:5-7 NIV
The story is told of an ambitious student at a top notch uni. Just before entering his final year he met an old hippy who said, ‘Your idea of happiness is to work around the clock, to study so you can get a better grade than the next guy. That’s not how you’re supposed to live. Come discover peace, man.’ Before you know it the student had called his parents and told them he was dropping out of uni to live in a hippy commune. Six months later they received a letter: ‘Dear Mum and Dad, I know you were upset about my decision. But I’ve changed! I have peace. Here there’s no competing, no trying to get ahead of anyone. This way of life is so in harmony with my inner self, that in only six months I’ve become the number two disciple in the entire commune. And I think I can be number one by June.’ Hello! Listen, competition hardly ever leads to serving but often leads to striving!
The disciples had started arguing about who would be the greatest in His kingdom. Jesus listened, then He picked up a towel and a basin of water and began to wash their feet. When He finished they were speechless, their hearts exposed, their attitudes corrected. ‘Your attitude should be the same as that of Christ Jesus (who) made himself nothing.’ Bottom line: serve, don’t strive!

content.title: Make that your attitude, too!
content.introtext:
…Think on these things.

Philippians 4:8 KJV
Your ability to succeed in life often comes down to a single choice: how you react to what has been done to you in the past, or is being done to you right now. Dr Viktor Frankl endured the Holocaust by this principle. The Nazis killed his family, placed him in a concentration camp, starved and beat him. When the war ended Frankl was neither broken nor bitter. When asked how he endured such treatment with a positive outlook he said, ‘Everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of human freedoms, to choose one’s attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose one’s own way.’
Listen to the attitude God’s Word calls us to adopt: ‘I'd say you'll do best by filling your minds and meditating on things true, noble, reputable, authentic, compelling, gracious; the best, not the worst; the beautiful, not the ugly; things to praise, not things to curse’ (Philippians 4:8)
Every day you choose the clothes you wear, the food you eat, and the attitude you adopt. And there are only two kinds of attitudes; good ones and bad ones. A good attitude is the one the Psalmist adopted when he woke up each morning: ‘This is the day the Lord has made; we will rejoice and be glad in it’ (Psalms 118:24 NKJV). Make that your attitude too!

content.title: Ransomed, redeemed, rescued!
content.introtext:
He provided redemption for his people...

Psalm 111:9 NIV
You’ve seen it in the movies; the kidnappers trap the billionaire’s son, and send a ransom note: ‘give us 10 million or never see your son again’. The word redeemed, which gets used in church in songs and stuff means this: TO BUY BACK. If the billionaire paid up, he has redeemed his child. He has paid the price to get back what was his in the first place. In the movies the hero normally crashes through a window and rescues the kid, but the in the Bible the hero is also the redeemer. The hero pays the price to get us back to God. Have you ever thought of yourself as somebody who needs to be redeemed or bought back? The Bible says our selfishness and sin caused us to fall into ‘…the trap of the devil…held captive to do his will’ (2 Timothy 2:26 NIV). Getting back to God, your rightful owner, could only come through redemption and that’s exactly what God did! ‘For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life’ (John 3:16 NIV). Christ’s death on the cross was the price of your redemption, your ransom; that’s how much God values you! A Christian simply is someone knows they needed rescuing. If you’ve never asked God to rescue you, you can do it today; what’s stopping you?

content.title: Got enough credit???
content.introtext:
…Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him…

James 2:23 NIV
Old Abe; He lived about 4000 years ago and was pretty comfy with his well-to-do family in a big buzzing city. One day he heard God calling him to pack his tent and sleeping bag and head off somewhere new. Cool! Except God didn’t say where! But Abraham wasn’t thick, he knew that searching for God’s ‘somewhere’ was better than settling for the world’s ‘anywhere’. Abraham is an example of faith at its finest. The Bible calls believing what God says ‘FAITH’ and says Abraham’s faith was so great that; it was credited to him’. Just like you need credit to make your mobile phone work, God accepted Abraham’s faith as credit to make his life work.
Are you feeling today as if your life is low on credit? Have you started accepting the world’s ‘anywhere’ rather than God’s ‘somewhere’? Choose to believe God and take the example of Abe; his faith had to stand many tests: a) when he left his family and country, he didn’t have a clue where God was taking him b) he wasn’t a real hard nut but he fought the enemy to save his family c) he believed for a son, even when he and his wife were well too old for all that making babies stuff!
So keep believing God and don’t run out of credit.

content.title: Carry each other’s burdens
content.introtext:
Carry each other’s burdens…

Galatians 6:2 NIV
The Bible says we’re a body with different parts doing different jobs. Instead of gazing at our own belly-buttons we should be looking at how we can help each other, just like the soldier in this story...‘I noticed a guy out of sync. A big, raw-boned redhead named Sanderson. His legs were pumping but he was out of step with the rest of us. His head began to loll from side to side. He was close to losing it. Without missing a step the ranger on Sanderson’s right reached over and took his rifle. Now one of the rangers was packing two weapons. The big redhead did better for a time. But then, while the platoon kept moving, his jaw became slack, his eyes glazed and his legs pushed like pistons. Soon his head began to sway again. This time the ranger on the left reached over, removed Sanderson’s helmet, tucked it under his own arm and continued to run. Our boots thudded along the dirt trail in heavy unison. Thud, thud, thud! But Sanderson was hurting ; really hurting. He was buckling, going down. But no, two soldiers behind him lifted the pack off his back, each taking a shoulder strap in his free hand. Sanderson gathered his remaining strength, squared his shoulders and the platoon continued to run; all the way to the finish line.’ Whose load can you help to carry today?

content.title: Allow God to shape you
content.introtext:
'…we are the clay, and You our potter…'

Isaiah 64:8 NKJV
Imagine a beautiful china teacup saying: ‘I wasn’t always like this. There was a time when I was just a cold, hard lump of clay. One day the potter picked me up and said, “I could do something with this.” Then he started to put pressure on me and change my shape. I said, “What are you doing? That hurts. Stop!” But he said, “Not yet.” Then he put me on a wheel and began to spin me around and around until I shouted, “Let me off.” He replied, “Not yet.” Then he shaped me into a cup and put me in a hot oven. I cried, “Let me out of here, I’m suffocating.” But he looked at me and said, “Not yet.” When he took me out, I thought his work on me was over, but then he started to paint me, then I was back in the oven, it was so hot! Then I he put me on shelf till I thought he’d forgotten me. Eventually I saw what had happened; I had become a beautiful teacup.’ There are things going on in your life today that you don’t understand. When you finally get to the place God wants you to be, you’ll realise that He has been making you into a vessel He can use, bless, and use to bless others. So, allow God to shape you!

content.title: Let God heal your wounds!
content.introtext:
‘...I will...heal your wounds...'

Jeremiah 30:17 NIV

Addressing students at Virginia Tech after a shooting rampage that left 32 of their fellow students dead, Philip Yancey said: ‘You've heard, "Things will get better, you'll get past this." Those who offer such comfort mean well, and what you feel now you won't always feel...Yet you're a different person because of that day. When three of my friends died I came across these lines: "Grief melts away like snow in May,"... It did melt away, but like snow it came back in fierce, unexpected ways, triggered by a sound, a smell, a fragment of memory.'
Yancey, who was recovering at the time from a car crash continued, ‘Pain is a sign of life and love. I'm wearing a neck brace because I broke my neck in an accident. The doctor kept asking, "Does this hurt? Can you feel that?" The answer he desperately wanted was, "Yes, it hurts, I can feel it"; proof that my spinal cord hadn't been severed. Pain offers proof of life, of connection. In deep wounds two kinds of tissue must heal: connective tissue, plus the outer protective tissue. If the outer protective tissue heals too quickly the inner connective tissue won't heal properly, leading to complications later.'
Real healing takes time; it takes place where God's presence, God's peace, and God's people are. Are you hurting today? Turn to God. His promise to you is ‘I will...heal your wounds.'

content.title: Why bother with church!
content.introtext:
‘...Let us go into the house of the Lord.'

Psalm 122:1 NIV

What's your reason for not going to church? Before you answer, read Ten Reasons Why I Never Wash!
1) I was forced to wash as a child 2) people who wash are all hypocrites; they think they are cleaner than everyone else 3) there are so many different kinds of soap; I just can't decide which one is best for me 4) I used to wash, but I got bored and stopped doing it 5) I only wash on special occasions like Christmas and Easter 6) none of my friends wash 7) I'll start washing when I get older and dirtier 8) I don't have time to wash 9) the bathroom is never warm enough in winter or cool enough in summer 10) the people who make soap are only after your money! Sound familiar?
Watchman Nee, who went to prison for going to church in China says, ‘Alone I cannot serve the Lord effectively, and he will spare no pains to teach me this. He will bring things to an end, allowing doors to close and leaving me effectively knocking my head against a wall until I realise that I need the help of the body, as well as of the Lord.' We need church; you'll find a spiritual family to belong to, a faith to live by, and a focus that gets your eyes where they should be; on Jesus!

content.title: Save yourself the embarrassment!
content.introtext:
‘...you will forget the shame of your youth...'


Isaiah 54:4 NKJV
Parents have 1001 ways of embarrassing their teenagers. It just comes naturally to them! The worst of them all is reserved for that special occasion when you bring your boyfriend or girlfriend round for the first time. It's all going really nicely and then it happens: ‘Ooh, I bet you'd like to see some old pictures of...' ...and you can insert your name at the end of that sentence. The family photo album comes out and you wish the ground would swallow you up.
The scary thing is, you've now entered a stage of life when for lots and lots of people, really big mistakes are made, really bad choices leading to all sorts of mess. Are you going to be a casualty or will you get through to adulthood with mind, body and spirit in good shape? Imagine 10 years from now looking back at a video of your teenage years - will it be embarrassing or will you be happy to let it be seen? Is today's Bible verse going to be something you need to reach for in the future or will you make sure that it doesn't apply to you?
One thing's for sure, if you commit each day to God then the chances of you stuffing up are seriously reduced. So what are you waiting for; ask Him to show you which direction to go in today.

SoulFood: Deut 3-4, Luke 10:38-42, Ps 78:40-55, Pr 16:32
