content.title: The ultimate self-esteem!
content.introtext:
‘...perfect love casts out fear...'

1 John 4:18 NKJV

What are you afraid of? ‘A real love for others will chase those worries away. The thought of being punished is what makes us afraid. It shows that we have not really learned to love.' (1 John 4:18 CEV). Today, ask God to give you a fresh understanding of how much He loves you, for who He loves He prizes, protects, and provides for.
Paul writes:[I pray that you] ‘may have power, together with all the saints, to grasp how wide and long and high and deep is the love of Christ' (Ephesians 3:18 NIV). That's extravagant love! God's love is MASSIVE, He couldn't love you any more than He does right now! You say, ‘What does God's love look like?' Look at the cross. If you had been the only person who ever lived, Jesus would have died just for you. Even if you're thinking ‘yeah but you don't know how I've messed up' He never stops loving you! You didn't do anything to deserve it, so when you fail you don't lose it. The Bible says: Nothing in all creation can separate us from God's love' (Romans 8:39 CEV).
Don't even be afraid of your weaknesses. As you get your head round it and you're more secure in God's love you can begin to acknowledge your weaknesses, seek His help, grow strong, and use the gifts He's given you. When you know God loves you, not despite but because of who you are, you have the ultimate self-esteem; and it comes from God's esteem for you.

content.title: No Pain No Gain
content.introtext:
‘...those who were scattered went everywhere preaching the word.'




Acts 8:4 NKJV
As we read through the New Testament we see the young church exploding with growth. They were obviously doing something right. Did they have great worship leaders that played guitars? Did they have nice buildings with comfy seats? Did they podcast their sermons around the world on iTunes? Actually, no to all those. The crazy thing is that the Bible shows us how it was in times of persecution (agro, intimidation, prejudice and violence) that the church grew most quickly. It's a powerful reminder that the bad times, not just the good ones, cause us to grow.
Some of the people who give you a hard time for being a Christian can actually help you out without them even knowing it. As you stand your ground your faith-muscle gets stronger. Like Joseph, you can look back years later and say, ‘...you meant evil against me; but God meant it for good...' (Genesis 50:20 NKJV).
If God lets you to go through a tough time then it must be for your good or for the good of others through your example. Understanding this takes you deeper in your walk with God. So, whether the battle is over your family, your education, your health, or your friendships, expect three things:
1) the closer you get to victory the more intense the battle; 2) what matters isn't your comfort but your calling; 3) God is totally on your side, so keep fighting!

SoulFood: Esther 4:13 - 5:3, Matt 6:16-21, Mark 2:18-22

content.title: Dead sticks don’t flower – do they?
content.introtext:
‘...the rod of Aaron...sprouted and...produced blossoms...'

Numbers 17:8 NKJV

New leadership was urgently needed in Israel. So God ordered an elder from each of the twelve tribes to bring a wooden staff with his name on it, and leave it overnight in the tabernacle - the big tent that they used as a portable temple. He said, ‘the staff belonging to the man I choose will sprout...' (Numbers 17:5 NIV). Next morning Aaron's rod ‘sprouted and...produced blossoms.' Notice:
1) Whose staff grew blossom; Aaron's! Obviously God doesn't pick His leaders because they're perfect. Aaron's CV included making a golden calf for Israel to worship, then defending himself by saying, ‘That cow just walked out of the fire all by itself.' Would you pick somebody like that? God did. That's because He sees in us potential qualities He can use to fulfil His purposes. Keep that in mind, next time a leader disappoints you. And remember it, should God call you to lead.
2) Where it blossomed; in the presence of the Lord. Certain things only happen in God's presence. In Aaron's case a walking stick came to life in ‘...the tabernacle of meeting...where I meet with you' (Numbers 17:4 NKJV). So, sort out your priorities, set time to meet with God each day, and keep it.
3) When it blossomed; during the darkness. Remember your faith grows when you are going through hard and dark times rather than when everything is cool.

content.title: Up and Down the Mountain (1)
content.introtext:
‘...Jesus took...Peter, James and John...up a high mountain...'




Matthew 17:1 NIV
There're five things to look at in this story - we'll look at three today and two tomorrow:
1) Not everybody gets to go up the mountain. Jesus didn't take everybody and He didn't explain or apologise to those disciples who stayed behind. He loves us all equally but He doesn't give us all the same experiences with Him. He knows what He's doing, so trust Him.
2) Those who go up the mountain aren't more spiritual. After seeing Jesus glowing with God's glory, Peter blurted out, ‘Let's build three tents and stay here.' Peter was keen, but a bit daft too. Learn from his mistake and keep quiet so you can listen what God has to say, then take steps to make sure you build your life on His Word.
3) God's plan is to make Jesus famous, not you. ‘While he was still speaking, a bright cloud enveloped them, and a voice from the cloud said, "This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him"...When they looked up, they saw no one except Jesus' (Matthew 17: 5-8 NIV). The number one challenge in your life is getting to the place where you focus on ‘no one except Jesus.' The most important relationship you have is with Him and the only plan that will work out right is the one He gives you.

SoulFood: Deut 5-7, Luke 11:1-13, Ps 78:56-64, Pr 16:33

content.title: The Interpreter
content.introtext:
‘We do not know what we ought to pray for, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us...'

Romans 8:26 NIV

When you go to a foreign country you can feel uncomfortable and a bit lost, because you don't speak the language. The language of the spiritual world is prayer and since the spiritual world is the source of our power; victory, peace, joy, and everything else we need; it's essential that we learn to speak it. The good news is, we have the perfect teacher and interpreter; the Holy Spirit Himself. One of His jobs is to teach us the language of prayer and guide us when it comes to addressing God and He's good at this job! The Bible says the Holy Spirit can interpret our prayers to God even when we don't know what to say. ‘In certain ways we are weak, but the Spirit is here to help us. For example, when we don't know what to pray for, the Spirit prays for us in ways that cannot be put into words.' (Romans 8:26 CEV). Isn't that cool?
Prayer is the link between the physical and the spiritual world; remember Jesus listened to His Dad. He looked into heaven and copied it on earth. The Spirit also shows us what God is saying. That's why prayer cannot be rushed. It's also why taking time to be still before God is so important. It allows the Holy Spirit to share God's thoughts with us, so that we begin thinking His way and be like Him on earth?

content.title: Up and Down the Mountain (2)
content.introtext:
'...if you have faith...'




Matthew 17:20 NIV
When the disciples came down from the mountain they encountered an epileptic boy who kept having fits. His dad was totally desperate. What happened next was a valuable lesson for them, and for us...
4) Do what you've always done, get what you've always got. It takes more than personality and religious catch-phrases to set people free from illness; and this was a biggie! Sadly the disciples were powerless because they were prayerless. Jesus said: '...this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting' (Matthew 17:21 NAS). Persistent prayer is the price we have to pay if we want to walk in power.
5) Rise above the attitudes you see around you. Jesus confronted the core problem: '..."O faithless...generation"' (Matthew 17:17 NKJV). Now before you say 'That's a bit heavy!' just think, why should we act all wishy-washy in the face of a faithless generation moulded by godless media? If we let it, it will pull us down and wear us out. So we need to get tough. That day Jesus said, '"If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, 'Move'"...and it will move"' (Matthew 17:20-21 NIV). Here're two final thoughts: a) ‘If you have faith.' Everybody around you doesn't have to have faith in order for you to see miracles b) you don't have to be a spiritual giant; just use your tiny mustard-seed faith and God will move stuff for you.

SoulFood: Deut 8-10, Luke 11:14-28, Ps 78:65-72, Pr 17:1-2

content.title: A love letter from Jesus (1)
content.introtext:
‘You...are a letter from Christ...'

2 Corinthians 3:3 NIV

‘This is how much God loved the world: He gave his Son, his one and only Son...by believing in him, anyone can have a whole and lasting life' (John 3:16) God sent Jesus to demonstrate His love and He sends us to tell people ‘You...are a letter from Christ...written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God.'
When a letter arrives two questions immediately spring up in our mind:
1) Who is it for? John's answer is ‘ANYONE'! For every person you meet, you will have something they need. Friends, enemies, relatives, neighbours and strangers need the message you have and the hope you bring.
2) Who is it from? A letter from someone you fancy is more interesting than some junk mail! Remember, you are a letter from Christ, about Christ. ‘For we do not preach ourselves, but Jesus Christ as Lord...' (2 Corinthians 4:5 NIV). Our message is not about us; it's about Jesus. ‘But are people really interested in Jesus?' you ask. In His lifetime Jesus was a national celebrity who could draw big crowds. Statistics say 1 billion people across the world are Christians today. Jesus isn't junk mail. ‘But I, when I am lifted up...will draw all men to myself' (John 12:32 NIV). Today nothing is more needed than a living portrait of Jesus Christ, so deliver your love letter to ‘anyone' who crosses your path!

content.title: Back at square one
content.introtext:
'..."Throw your net on the right side..."'



John 21:6 NIV
Have you ever had an amazing day, a day when everything went right, when you were totally in the zone, a day you hoped would never end? And then you woke up the next morning and everything was plain and ordinary and boring again. Why is life like that?
The four gospels all give us a different angle on the life of Jesus and, especially when it comes to the events after His resurrection, they all pick out different details we have to stitch together. We know this: Jesus rose from the dead, met Mary Magdalene first and later that day appeared to the 11 disciples. But then, maybe a week or so after that, they went back to what they were doing before they met Him: fishing. After something massive has happened we can crave the simplicity and security of what we know, we end up like the disciples: back at square one.
But there's good news: If God called you, you're still called. Jesus shouts to the guys from the shore giving them identical instructions to the very first day He met them (Luke 5). Once again an ordinary day is touched with the extraordinary as Jesus steps into the scene. That morning Jesus ate breakfast with them, chatted with them, encouraged them and reminded them that they should always be ready to be interrupted by a visit from the Master.

SoulFood: Deut 11-13, Luke 11:29-44, Ps 119:1-8, Pr 17:3

content.title: A love letter from Jesus (2)
content.introtext:
‘You...are a letter from Christ.'

2 Corinthians 3:3 NIV

The Bible says your life is a love letter from Jesus, ‘known and read by everybody.' But a letter is only effective, if it is easily read and understood. Adults moan because they can't understand text language, ‘what's "C U L8R M8" mean?' They don't get it; which isn't a problem when you txt your mate but might cause difficulties when you txt your mum! People must understand your message.
How can you make sure your love letter from Jesus gets through to the people He's sending it to? Here are things that some common things can confuse your message: a) a begrudging, resentful attitude when a friend, teacher, or parent asks you to go the extra mile and help at an inconvenient time b) not giving your best to the things you've committed to c) being unreliable, not keeping promises d) touchiness, like when you wear your feelings on your sleeve, are easily upset and overreact to unintended offences e) temper tantrums or sulking, where you're moody and grumpy because things don't go your way f) compromising, where you go with the flow and don't take a stand or have the guts to stand out.
Instead of Jesus they see moody or unreliable or compromising Christians. How we live says something; we can give people the wrong message. Jesus has a letter of love. Make sure people can get it.

content.title: ‘Freeze!’
content.introtext:
'...take captive every thought...'



2 Corinthians 10:5 NIV
Nineteen-year-old Liu Shih-Kun was an amazing pianist in China until the 1966 Cultural Revolution banned all things of Western influence. Refusing to renounce his beloved music, Liu was branded an enemy of the state and thrown into a tiny jail cell with no friends, no books, and even worse; no piano. Six years later, for political reasons, he was asked to play in Beijing with the Philadelphia Orchestra. After years without an instrument to practice on, he performed brilliantly. Eighteen months later when he was finally released, he again played flawlessly. His secret? Stripped of everything musical, for seven and a half years Liu disciplined himself to shut out negative thoughts and practice hour after hour on an imaginary piano.
What if you were in that position; all alone, the things you love taken away, would you find a positive focus or would you freak out and think of the worst thing that could happen? Police shout 'Freeze!' when they want to stop a suspect and protect themselves. And you can freeze out harmful thinking by capturing every thought and making it 'obedient to Christ.' Paul says: 'For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against... the spiritual forces' (Ephesians 6:12 NIV). Your thoughts have power. To win over them, you must totally surrender to Jesus and control what you allow your mind to dwell on.

SoulFood: Deut 14-17, Luke 11:45-54, Ps 119:9-16, Pr 17:4-6

content.title: A love letter from Jesus (3)
content.introtext:
‘You...are a letter from Christ.'

2 Corinthians 3:3 NIV

‘...if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone, the new has come!' (2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV). The message in our letter should make it clear that we're not the people we used to be, because:
1) Christ has changed us mentally. Being ‘...transformed by the renewing of [our] mind' (Romans 12:2 NIV) we now look at life, ourselves, others, our challenges and options in light of God's thoughts, not ours. We see opportunities where we saw only obstacles, and possibilities where we saw only problems. Minds that were frazzled with worry, are now filled with confidence and peace.
2) Christ has changed us morally. 1 Corinthians 6:9-10 says ‘...evil people won't have a share in the blessings of God's Kingdom?' then it lists: immoral, worships idols, unfaithful in marriage, a pervert, thief, a greedy person, drunkard, or anyone who curses and cheats others.' and then we're hit with verse 11: ‘Some of you used to be like that. But now the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and the power of God's Spirit have washed you and made you holy and acceptable to God' (CEV). He has transformed our character.
3) Christ has changed us spiritually. That's why only someone who has God's Spirit can understand spiritual blessings. Anyone who doesn't have God's Spirit thinks these blessings are foolish (1 Corinthians 2:14)! Your letter should read: ‘Jesus changed my life, and if you let Him, He will change yours too!' So, today, deliver your love letter to everyone you meet.

content.title: God will provide!
content.introtext:
'...do not worry...'



Matthew 6:31 NIV
King David writes, 'I was young and now I am old, yet I have never seen the righteous forsaken or their children begging bread' (Psalm 37:25 NIV). Nobody can say that King David lived a 'sheltered life'! He lived on the front line, and so when as an old man he shares his reflections about the way the world works we need to pay attention. His advice to the next generation is to learn how to lean on God: 'Trust in the LORD and do good; dwell in the land and enjoy safe pasture. Delight yourself in the LORD and he will give you the desires of your heart. Commit your way to the LORD; trust in him and he will do this;' (Psalm 37:3-5 NLT). The sad thing is, even though David, Israel's greatest King, took the time to write down this advice, and even though it was taught year in year out in the schools and the synagogues of the land, the people just didn't follow it. When Jesus began to minister He had to deal with the same issue saying: 'Do not worry, saying, "What shall we eat?" or "What shall we drink?" or "What shall we wear?"...your heavenly Father knows that you need them. But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well' (Matthew 6:31-33 NIV). So today, relax, no really, chill, trust, God will provide!

SoulFood: Deut 18-21, Luke 12:1-12, Ps 119:17-24, Pr 17:7-10

content.title: Go ‘a little farther’
content.introtext:
‘He went a little farther...and prayed...'

Mark 14:35 NKJV

Throughout history God has looked for men and women to passionately pray on behalf of a lost world. More often than not, He's been disappointed. ‘...I sought for a man...who would...stand in the gap before Me on behalf of the land, that I should not destroy it; but I found no one' (Ezekiel 22:30 NKJV).
The disciples were willing to go with Jesus into the garden of Gethsemane but they didn't get how important it was to pray that night and all fell asleep. Even Peter, James and John, the guys in the inner circle, didn't ‘get it,' so in the end Jesus went ‘a little farther' and prayed alone. Prayer can be a lonely business and you have to stick at it. You can go for months and years before seeing some of the changes that you've prayed so hard about. On the other hand, when you go deeper with God, you get to share things that the disciples missed and only angels got to see to that night in the garden.
Why not get your youth group to set up a 24/7 prayer room for a week, or turn your bedroom into your own garden of Gethsemane and give up some sleep to go deeper with God? You could even join the grannies at your church for the early morning prayer meeting! How about it, is God calling you to go ‘a little farther?'

content.title: Passion plus…
content.introtext:
'Love the Lord your God with all your heart...'



Deuteronomy 6:5 NIV
There's an interesting sequence of events leading up to Peter's denial of Christ. First, Jesus warned Simon Peter that he was a target: '"...Satan has asked to sift you as wheat. But I have prayed for you, Simon, that your faith may not fail..."' (Luke 22:31-32 NIV). Next we read that when the guards had arrested Jesus, Peter '...followed at a distance' (Luke 22:54 NIV). Later that same night Peter, the man who swore he'd die for Jesus, denied knowing Him. Then the cockerel crowed, Peter realised what he'd done, and he '...went outside and wept bitterly' (Luke 22:55-62 NIV).
Can you see the three steps? 1) you don't pay attention to the warnings about the enemy's attack 2) you allow situations to get between you and Jesus; you start to follow 'at a distance' 3) you end up denying Jesus by your words or actions. It's a classic process that happens to lots of people, so don't say, 'That will never happen to me.' That's what Peter said! Instead make sure you stay on your guard, and stay passionate. That red-hot fire inside you to make Jesus known is like your fuel for the race. Craig Lowndes wouldn't win many V8 Supercar races without fuel, but he also has to stay focused too, as every lap contains new dangers. So there's the word4U2day, keep your passion alive and stay focused, then you'll withstand any attacks.

SoulFood: Deut 22-24, Luke 12:13-21, Ps 119:25-32, Pr 17:11-15

content.title: Taking personal responsibility (1)
content.introtext:
‘If you are wise, your wisdom will reward you...'

Proverbs 9:12 NIV

We all love the idea of a better world, city or school. Maybe you've even been praying for God to DO SOMETHING, what if he has done something - sent you!
In a graduation speech he was giving to a whole load of uni students, Chief Judge Alexander Saunders said, ‘As responsibility is passed to your hands it will not do to assume that someone else will bear the major burdens, that someone else will demonstrate the key convictions, that someone else will be elected Member of Parliament, take care of the poor, visit the sick, protect civil rights, enforce the law, transmit value, and defend freedom. What you do not value will not be valued, what you do not remember will not be remembered, what you do not change will not be changed, what you do not do will not be done. You can, if you will, craft a society whose leaders...are less obsessed with the need for money. It's not a question of what to do, but simply the will to do it.'
Paul writes: ‘...each one should carry his own load' (Galatians 6:5 NIV). Don't leave it to someone else! You've got a job to do! Sometimes we don't take responsibility because we believe others are more qualified. No, people who make a difference in life, only do so because they decided to try. Plus: God doesn't call the qualified, He qualifies the called!

content.title: Nothing is more important than love
content.introtext:
'...live a life of love...'



Ephesians 5:2 NIV
The great Scottish writer Thomas Carlyle married his secretary, Jane Welsh. She kept working for him but when she got ill, Carlyle, who was devoted to his work, didn't really notice. But she had cancer and was eventually confined to bed. Although Carlyle loved her, he found that he didn't have much time to give attention to give to her. Then she died. After the funeral Carlyle found Jane's diary and began to read it. On one page she'd written a single line: 'Yesterday he spent an hour with me and it was like heaven: I love him so much.' A reality he'd somehow been too blind to see now revealed itself with crushing clarity. He'd been too busy to notice how much he meant to Jane. He thought of all the times he'd been preoccupied with his work and failed to notice her. He hadn't seen her suffering. He hadn't seen her love. Turning the page, he read words he'd never forget: 'I've listened all day to hear his steps in the hall, but now it's late, he won't come today.' Thomas was devastated. Later, friends found him at the side of her grave, covered with mud. His eyes were red from weeping, 'If only I'd known, if only I'd known,' he cried. After Jane's death, Carlyle made little attempt to write again.
Nothing is more important than love. Is there anyone you need to spend time with today?

SoulFood: Ezek 47:1-12, Rev 21: 22 - 22:5

content.title: Taking personal responsibility (2)
content.introtext:
‘Each one should use whatever gift he has received to serve others...'

1 Peter 4:10 NIV

When someone tells you to be more ‘responsible', it's usually the last thing you'd ever want to do. After all, isn't that for people who are old and boring, and people who never have any fun? In fact the opposite is true; as you grow up the more responsible you are, the more freedom you're going to have to have fun, because things are far less likely to turn to custard! It's not about being old or boring or mature, it's about realising you're responsible for your own life and making good choices instead of doing something stupid and regretting it for the rest of your life. Here are three ways in which we can be more responsible.
1) Following through. If you're a quitter; someone who never finishes what they start, try giving yourself smaller things to finish. Do stuff that really matters to you, and when you start to finish those, think about tackling some other areas.
2) Taking care of the small stuff. How often do you forget small things; that are big things to others? Like forgetting anniversaries and birthdays, not taking the bins out or not calling someone back. Start sorting out the small things first, they matter to other people!
3) Do it yourself. Too many people expect others to do things for them, especially if you're used to your parents doing things. So start doing things by yourself!

content.title: Will you be one of them?
content.introtext:
'If My people who are called by My name...'



2 Chronicles 7:14 NKJV
This time last year nobody was thinking about saving money; it was 'business as usual', spend, spend, spend. Wow, haven't times change? Job security is more important than climbing the corporate ladder. Other people were talking about 'climbing the property ladder'; now they're struggling to pay their mortgage. And what about the weather... storms, floods! It feels like our security blanket has been ripped away and our comfort zone shaken to its core.
But there is an ancient Word for these crazy days; it's an old message for a new generation. 'If My people who are called by My name will humble themselves, and pray and seek My face, and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin and heal their land' (2 Chronicles 7:14). Have you heard those words before? Can you sense God speaking from eternity? Those words are a reminder that every action brings a reaction. If we spend money we haven't got, if we treat the planet like it's disposable, trouble will definitely come our way.
Listen, we need to turn things around and someone needs to set an example. Even within a pampered church that majors on 'what God will do for you, and how to get Him to do it', God has people willing to be humble and get praying. The question is, will you be one of them?

SoulFood: Deut 25-27, Luke 12:22-34, Ps 119:33-40, Pr 17:16

content.title: I don’t want to be a Christian! (1)
content.introtext:
‘I have been crucified with Christ...'

Galatians 2:20 NIV

When you became a Christian, did you really look at the label and read the small print? Did you think through what you were buying into? Our churches and youth groups are full of ‘Christians', but how many of them can really be called ‘followers of Christ'? It's all too easy to miss-sell Christianity as a free ticket to heaven and cushy life with ready-made mates. But this is not what it means to be a true follower of Jesus.
Paul writes: ‘I am crucified with Christ.' To our selfish lives those words are about as appealing as having a tooth out; yet that's exactly what we're supposed to be as Christians! In theory we should have laid down our own lives, given up our plans, our relationships, our gifts, our possessions; put them before Jesus and said ‘You have them, I'll do whatever You want me to do'. But how many of us have really done this? We can all probably remember the odd moment in an incredible time of worship and intimacy with Jesus when we gently whispered ‘You can have it all'. But the sad truth is most of us walk out of that place and within 24 hours we've picked everything back up again for ourselves and carried on as normal. Think today, do I want to be a Christian; or a follower of Jesus?

content.title: Giving up ‘centre stage’
content.introtext:
'Let each of you look out...for the interests of others.'


Philippians 2:4 NKJV
You see one of your mates and shout, 'How's it going?' Thinking you're actually interested, they come over to tell you something cool that happened to them yesterday. But you're not really interested are you so you jump in as fast as you can saying, 'Think that's cool? Let me tell you about...' You're off and running, making every effort to outdo them and prove that your life is way more interesting that theirs! Meanwhile, your mate's wishing they'd just kept walking when they first saw you. They'd hoped to hear something like, 'That's awesome, tell me more.' Instead they just get an earful of your ego.
The Bible says, 'Let each of you look out not only for his own interests, but also for the interests of others.' In other words, give up 'centre stage.' That's easier said than done when we tend to only be bothered with one person - me! Whatever happened to 'Rejoice with those who rejoice...?' (Romans 12:15 NIV)? Those simple words remind us that life is not supposed to be a competition - it's supposed to be a celebration! So next time you feel the urge to interrupt, practice saying, 'Enough about me. How are things with you?' Then listen! Listen with your ears, your eyes, your mind and your spirit. Try to understand the feelings coming through. Then you can 'Rejoice with those who rejoice; mourn with those who mourn.' (Romans 12:15 NIV)

SoulFood: Deut 28-29, Luke 12:35-48, Ps 119:41-48, Pr 17:17

content.title: I don’t want to be a Christian! (2)
content.introtext:
‘Selling their possessions and goods they gave to anyone as he had need.'

Acts 2:45 NIV

The Bible says that God wants to bless us. There's an understanding amongst lots of Christians that says God's blessing means if we give $10 we'll get back $100; but it's interesting that nowhere in the whole Bible is this the case! In fact, if you read about the start of the church in Acts you'll see just the opposite. Back then, anyone who had ANYTHING they didn't need, whether it was a building, a camel or a PS3(!) sold it. They then put all the money into a big pot and gave it to the poor. That way no one had too much but everyone had enough, they simply shared what God had given them. How amazing is that? Of course as Christians we all read our Bible and think ‘ahh, that's really great. Maybe I should put an extra $10 in the offering this week'. But maybe as followers of Jesus, it's time for an eBay revolution! After all, why is it we pick and choose what bits of the Bible we like and ignore the rest (telling ourselves that bit's not relevant for today)? Maybe as Christians we spend too much time trying to interpret the Bible to make it fit with what we want it to say. After all, Jesus never owned a thing. So why does the stack of DVDs in the corner keep getting higher?

content.title: The ‘water test’
content.introtext:
'...bring them down to the water, and I will test them...'



Judges 7:4 NKJV
Are you a nurturer by nature, somebody who will spend hour after hour, day after day, week after week trying to help your mates overcome their issues? If so you'll know that it can be frustrating, very often one step forwards two steps back! God loves that kind of faithfulness but be careful; He doesn't need you to do His job for Him, you need to know where your work ends and His work starts!
Gideon was surrounded by too many people and lots of them were in the 'high maintenance' category! Through a series of tests God showed Gideon who he should keep with him and who he should send home. During the first test, the 'fear test' Gideon lost 22,000 men, leaving only 10,000. Next was the 'water test' to 'Separate those who lap the water with their tongues like a dog from those who kneel down to drink' (v5). Only 300 soldiers passed the test! We learn two lessons from this story: 1) you need to be able to see your enemy approaching. Those who got down to drink like dogs, sacrificed their vision to satisfy their immediate need 2) when God reduces your support, it's in order to give you a miraculous victory. So when the people around you can't pass God's 'water test,' let them go and trust God. He has something better in mind.

SoulFood: Deut 30:1 - 32:28, Luke 12:49-59, Ps 119:49-56, Pr 17:18-21

content.title: Your faith gets God’s attention
content.introtext:
‘...your faith has healed you.'

Luke 8:48 NIV

Read Luke 8:43-48. In this story a woman who'd been bleeding for 12 years crept through a crowd to touch the edge of Jesus cloak. After she was instantly healed, Jesus knew something had happened because He ‘felt the power go out of Him'. The woman confessed it was her and Jesus blessed her.
Notice three important things in this story:
1) She did something she'd never done before. She decided to try Jesus. Smart move! Faith means stepping into the unknown and taking a risk you've never taken before.
2) She recognised her moment. She knew that Jesus was visiting her town, and might not be back. There are ‘God-moments' in life when you've got to get over your fear and move out in faith. If you don't, you'll miss them.
3) She started a new thing. Until then no one had been healed by touching His cloak but her act of faith was a new day. ‘People brought all their sick to him and begged him to let the sick just touch the edge of his cloak, and all who touched him were healed' (Matthew 14:35-36 NIV). God is looking for people who are willing to break with tradition. When He finds them, He uses them to open doors and show new ways of how He can work. So don't be scared to step out and take a risk, it might just start a new thing!

content.title: Extreme refreshment
content.introtext:
'...I die of thirst...'



Judges 15:18 NKJV
Samson was an extreme character who swung from massive highs to major lows, listen: 'The Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon him; and...his bonds broke loose...He found a fresh jawbone...took it, and killed a thousand men...Then he...cried out to the Lord and said, "You have given this great deliverance...now shall I die of thirst?"' (Judges 15:14-18 NKJV). Check out these three things:
1) Samson allowed the enemy to bind him. What has you tied up today? What's holding you back? Even super-macho Samson couldn't win every battle in his own strength. It took God's Spirit to set Samson free and that's what it's going to take to set you free too. 2) Samson needed to use what had already been given him. Just the jawbone of a donkey, but with God's help it was enough to win the day. The answer you're looking for may be right under your nose. Ask God to help you recognise what He's given you, and use it. 3) Samson was victorious, yet dying of thirst. It happens, particularly to those who work for God but don't spend enough time with Him. Jesus promises '...whoever drinks the water I give him will never thirst.' (John 4:14 NIV). It's hard to celebrate a victory when you feel dry and tired, so jump into the refreshing river of God today. The One who gives you victory, can also quench your thirst.

SoulFood: Deut 32:29 - 34:12, Luke 13:1-17, Ps 119:57-64, Pr 17:22

content.title: Consult God!
content.introtext:
‘A man's heart plans his way, But the LORD directs his steps...'

Proverbs 16:9 NKJV

George dreamed of joining the Navy, but his mother, who was a widow raising her children alone, didn't like the idea. Nevertheless she put on a brave face and agreed to let him go. The day he was due to sail he hugged her good-bye but to everyone's surprise she started to cry. After going through so much heartbreak she just couldn't take any more. George must not board that ship; instead he must stay and be strong for the rest of the family. The boy in the midshipman's uniform wanted a Navy career, but not if it meant adding to his mother's grief. So reluctantly he returned his uniform and ordered his belongings ashore. Of all the young men who might have left home in search of adventure and didn't, he was just one more. Yet his decision had profound influence on the Revolutionary War. A mother's upset stopped her fifteen-year-old from ascending the ranks of the British Navy and embarking on an adventure very different from the one for which he eventually became famous. That's because the boy's name was George Washington, first president of the United States of America.
‘We make...plans, but the Lord decides where we will go.' ‘A man's steps are directed by the LORD. How then can anyone understand his own way?' (Proverbs 20:24 NIV). God knows where he wants you, so don't be afraid if your plans don't quite work out!

content.title: ‘Two kinds of givers
content.introtext:
'...God loves a cheerful giver.'



2 Corinthians 9:7 NIV
There are two kinds of givers: those who give what's left over, and those who give off the top. The first group isn't necessarily greedy, they just live a different way. They see themselves as being responsible for meeting their own needs, so whatever's left over goes to God's work. The problem with giving leftovers is that you will never give what you think you can't afford. As soon as you feel a bit tight, you decide not to give. The other problem is that you buy the new phone which you've convinced yourself you absolutely need and have no money left over anyway! God says he wants you to be a 'cheerful giver'. But if your heart is more desperate for those new shoes, how can you ever be generous the way God wants?
On the other hand, those who give 'off the top' understand that God owns and controls all the blessings in their life anyway, so they feel free to give to Him first and themselves second. Leftover givers always struggle in this area. They know all the stuff about God providing but there are clothes to buy, nights out to fund and friends' birthdays coming up, so they hold back, afraid they can't do all this and give to God.
Fear has the power to make you act the opposite to what you believe. Basically fear makes you irrational. Doesn't it make more sense to trust God with your money since it's all His anyway?
SoulFood: 1 Pet 1-5, Luke 13:18-35, Ps 119:65-72, Pr 17:23-26

content.title: LBA?
content.introtext:
‘Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see'

Hebrews 11:1 NIV

Did you see the movie, Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull? If you're an Indy fan you will have no doubt seen one of the earlier films, Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade. In this film Indy sets out to find the treasure with the help of his father. Along the path Indy reaches what looks to be a massive canyon, a sheer drop, making it impossible to get to the other side. Indy trusts his father's words, figures out the clues, takes a leap of faith and finds his feet are safely on solid rock. Indy doesn't fall to his death! There was a bridge there all the time, he just couldn't see it. Only when he steps out does he find it. If Indy had only believed in what he could see at that moment he would never have reached the treasure. It took faith. He needed to trust his father's words and walk on the bridge, even though he couldn't see it. Very scary!
We need to have faith in God. Faith is spelt: LBA; Listening to what God says, Believing it's true and finally Acting on it. Faith is living our lives by what we believe to be true about God; even if it doesn't seem to make sense. It's about believing God is right and trusting him to do what He says, and guess what? He is and He will!

content.title: Dealing with disappointment (1)
content.introtext:
'...Samuel grew, and the Lord was with him...'



1 Samuel 3:19 NKJV
Welcome to life; disappointment guaranteed! So here are some examples to help you when:
1) You're disappointed with those you look up to. Think of Samuel and Eli (1 Samuel 1-4). Sam's mum, Hannah, entrusted her child to Eli the Priest, confident he'd be a great mentor to the young boy. But Eli turned out to be a weak parent who stood by while his sons abused their priestly privileges, bringing shame to the ministry. Who'd have blamed young Samuel for taking a nose dive when the man he looked up to failed so badly? But somehow Samuel looked beyond his disappointment and kept his eyes on God: 'Samuel grew, and the Lord was with him.' As a result God turned him into one of Israel's greatest prophets.
2) You're disappointed in those you live with. Surely your family won't let you down. Right? Wrong! Ask young Joseph. When God gave him a big dream he thought his brothers would celebrate. Instead they were so jealous and angry that they sold him to human traffickers! What an open door to a life of bitterness - surely that kind of disappointment would leave Joseph emotionally paralysed? But no, even though many years of his life were very, very tough Joseph lived for God in every situation. Finally, many years later the breakthrough came, he became Egypt's Prime Minister and was re-united with his family. So don't let disappointment get you down today.

SoulFood: Obadiah, Luke 14:1-14, Ps 119:73-80, Pr 17:27-28

content.title: It’s not fair! Is it?
content.introtext:
‘Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see’

Hebrews 11:1 NIV
Ever felt disappointed? It’s not a nice feeling is it? It’s that feeling you get when things just don’t turn out like you’d hoped they would. It stinks! Life feels so unfair doesn’t it? Ever felt disappointed in God?

Sometimes, when we hear what God has done for other people, we can hope that God will do the same for us. We begin to put our faith in God to do these things for us. We may want God to make us into a fantastic worship leader or preacher or help us get that job, or get that girl/guy to go out with us, just like He did for those other people. Or maybe we want God to do amazing miracles through us like we read about in books. ‘If God has done it for them’ you say, ‘then I believe God will do it for me. I have faith!’ But sometimes that thing we hoped for doesn’t happen and we can get really disappointed. :(

If this has happened to you, ask yourself this, ‘Did I hear God promise to do that for me, or did I just tell God I wanted it?’ Remember what you read yesterday? The first part of faith is listening. What God promises to one person he may not promise to you. Listen to what God is saying to you and put your faith in that; He won’t disappoint you!

content.title: Dealing with disappointment (2)
content.introtext:
'Now go, lead the people...'



Exodus 32:34 NIV
Here are two more types of disappointment you'll deal with in life:
1) Disappointment in those you work with. In life you need people, going it alone sometimes sounds attractive but the reality is pretty harsh, that's why we choose to work together. But when the people in your team fail you it hurts. Imagine Moses' disappointment. He left his brother Aaron in charge while he went to meet with God. When he came back Aaron had totally lost the plot and made the people a fake God; a golden cow! But watch Moses; his true leadership shines in the face of this disappointment. He confronts Aaron, takes it to God for resolution, and prays forgiveness for Israel. With God on his side Moses makes some great decisions and the horrible mess gets sorted out.
2) Disappointment in those you've poured your life into. Let's check in again with Moses, Pastor of the ‘Church of the Ungrateful'. This congregation of former slaves were on their way to the Promised Land, but how did show their thanks to the man who put everything on the line to make it possible? By moaning and groaning and blaming him for everything bad that happened (Exodus 14). Was Moses disappointed and hurt? Yes. But each time he wanted to quit he'd come to God and offload. You know you can do that too, right?

SoulFood: 1 Sam 25:2-42, 1 Peter 3:1-7

content.title: I AM Confident
content.introtext:
‘Now faith is being sure of what we hope for and certain of what we do not see'

Hebrews 11:1 NIV

Seven times in the Gospel of John Jesus describes himself as ‘I AM...'. I AM: bread, light, gate, good shepherd, the resurrection and the life, the way, truth and life, and the true vine. He never said ‘I might be', ‘I could be' or ‘I want to be'. He said ‘I AM'. He was definite, positive, confident, absolutely sure whom He was. Every time He said ‘I AM' He told us an amazing truth about himself. Chew over these:
1) ‘..."I am the bread of life. He who comes to me will never be hungry again..."' (John 6:35 NIV)
2) ‘..."I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life"' (John 8:12 NIV)
3) ‘I am the gate; whoever enters through me will be saved' (John 10:9 NIV)
4) ‘I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.' (John 10:11 NIV)
5) ‘...I am the resurrection and the life. He who believes in me will live, even though he dies' (John 11:25 NIV)
6) ‘I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me' (John 14:6 NIV)
7) ‘I am the true vine, and my Father is the gardener' (John 15:1 NIV)
Today be confident in the faith you have in Jesus. Be confident in I AM - I AM CONFIDENT!

content.title: Dealing with disappointment (3)
content.introtext:
'But we have this treasure in jars of clay.'


2 Corinthians 4:7 NIV
Finally there's the biggie: Disappointment in ourselves. This kind of disappointment can throw you into a downward spiral that's hard to stop or recover from; so watch out!
Peter had sworn undying love to Jesus. 'Even if all fall away on account of you, I never will' (Matthew 26:33-75), and he meant every word of it. But under the pressures surrounding the crucifixion he crumbles and three times denies knowing Jesus. Heartbroken by his own dismal failure, '...went outside and wept bitterly' (Luke 22:62 NIV). Have you ever asked, 'God, how can you possibly use someone as messed up as me?' Welcome to Peter's world. Peter became overwhelmed by feelings of failure and went on a major downer. But Jesus wasn't shocked. He was well aware that Peter was a work-in-progress. He knew that this impulsive, outspoken disciple had a tender heart, so He extended extra grace to him. After his resurrection He took time out to restore the failed disciple. For Peter the years after his biggest failure were more spectacular than he could've ever imagined.
So, when (not if!) you fail: a) don't drown in disappointment b) come to Jesus honestly and say sorry. Confess your sin; don't make excuses, or blame circumstances or people c) receive God's grace by faith, not by feelings. You are never beyond grace d) get whatever help you need to get back on track; sooner, not later.

SoulFood: Ruth 1-4, Luke 14:15-24, Ps 119:81-88, Pr 18:1-5

content.title: God knows best
content.introtext:
‘With all your heart you must trust the LORD and not your own judgment.'

Proverbs 3:5 CEV
‘I told you so! I knew it! I'm right!' We all enjoy saying words like that don't we? We all want to be right and hate being wrong. But we need to get used to being wrong if we want to live the Christian life. 1 Corinthians 1:25 says: ‘For the foolishness of God is wiser than man's wisdom...' That means that even the cleverest thing we could ever say sounds so not clever to God.
A guy in the Bible called Job, had to go through some really rotten stuff in his life and one day he was moaning on to God about it and asked God if He really knew what He was doing? Job thought he was being clever! But God put him in his place saying things like, ‘Right Job, did you put the stars in place? No, you didn't! So until you can do stuff like that, don't even think about questioning me, because I obviously know well more than you. Just trust me!' (for the full version of this chat, read the last few chapters of the book of Job). It silenced Job good and proper. How can you possibly answer that? Well that's just the thing...you can't...no-one can. We were never meant to figure everything out by ourselves, we were meant to ask God and learn from Him. So go on ask...and keep asking. He'll tell you everything you need to know.

content.title: 3 kinds of Belonging
content.introtext:
'...you are...fellow citizens...members of God's household... a holy temple...'



Ephesians 2:19-21 NIV
Do you know that you can enjoy God's presence at any time? You are 'No longer strangers...but fellow citizens...of the household of God...a holy temple' (NKJV). Let's unpack what that means:
1) as 'fellow citizens' we represent God on the earth. We're His 'ambassadors' (2 Corinthians 5:20). 'What does an ambassador do?' Well it's a lot more than putting on posh parties where people eat chocolate! The ambassador lives in a foreign country showing everyone who lives there how amazing his home country is. He doesn't belong there permanently, he could be called home at a moment's notice. Getting the idea?
2) because we belong to the 'household of God' we can open the door to God at any time, with any need, and know that we'll be met with love. God is the father you always hoped for and you are the child He always wanted. If you have any doubts, look at the cross; that's how much God loves you.
3) we are 'a holy temple.' In the Old Testament God had a temple for His people, but now God has a people for His temple. What's the difference? Well are you made of stone?! The Bible says, 'Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God?' (1 Corinthians 6:19-20 NIV). Just like the temple of old your life now displays the awesome greatness of God!

SoulFood: Judges 1-3, Luke 14:25-35, Ps 119:89-96, Pr 18:6-8

content.title: Street wise
content.introtext:
‘Fools think they know what is best, but a sensible person listens to advice'

Proverbs 12:15: (CEV)
You probably know some loud mouth who thinks they're always right and everyone around them is wrong. You know the type they never listen properly to what other people say, they shout and force their (usually uneducated) opinion at anyone within earshot. No-one can tell them anything.
Then there is the person who listens, hears what others say and adds that to their knowledge bucket. Thomas Edison (the light bulb inventor guy from your science class) once said "about the only invention I can claim as absolutely original, is the phonograph. I'm an awfully good sponge. I absorb ideas wherever I can and put them to practical use. Then I improve them until they become of some value. My ideas are mostly the ideas of other people who didn't develop them themselves." Edison stayed open, hungry for knowledge and teachable throughout his life. And to succeed, you must too.
God says ‘Fools think they know what is best, but a sensible person listens to advice'. Sometimes we get things wrong. Sometimes it's easier for people around us to see where we are going wrong than it is to see it ourselves. Listen to what is being said about you. Listen to what God has to say about it. Is it time for you to change? Be wise!

content.title: No turning back
content.introtext:
'Not that we are sufficient of ourselves...but our sufficiency is from God'



2 Corinthians 3:5 NKJV
The Israelites were slaves in Egypt, tortured and beaten and desperate for freedom. So Moses turns up, bugs and bugs the Pharaoh to set the Israelites free (he even uses real bugs!) and finally they've got freedom and the promise of a new life in a new land. Sorted. Well until lunchtime! In the wilderness, God gave them food every day, called Manna, but it wasn't long before they were whingeing like toddlers...'If only we had meat to eat! We remember the fish we ate in Egypt at no cost; also the cucumbers, melons, leeks, onions and garlic. But now we have lost our appetite; we never see anything but this manna!' (Numbers 11:4-6 NIV) They'd forgotten all about the whips and beatings now all they remembered was the cucumbers! That might make Jamie Oliver happy but not God! He had promised them a land where they could grow their own cucumbers with the added bonus of NOT being slaves. But before they enter the land and grow veggies, they need to grow up and that meant learning to depend on Him.
Remember your first week at High School, it might be scary but you can't go back to primary! Growing with God isn't always easy, but we can't go back, we have to learn to trust Him. God has great plans for you to grow. When it's tough don't look back just look to Him!

SoulFood: Judges 4-6, Luke 15:1-10, Ps 119:97-104, Pr 18:9

content.introtext:
‘He will call upon me, and I will answer him; I will be with him in trouble, I will deliver him and honour him.'

Psalm 91:15 NIV
A child picks up the phone and dials 000 and asks ‘is Santa there?' Why? Because he had been annoying his Mum!. Did you know that every day people call 000 when they shouldn't. Calls that say ‘I've stubbed my toe' ‘There's a dead cat in the road' ‘I've lost my keys' ‘there's a spider in my bath' ‘There's a rat in my kitchen' ‘I've ran out of credit!' sound funny at first. But when you see posters about town saying ‘Call an ambulance for the wrong reason and someone might die' and you realize the seriousness of the situation.
What's so great about God is that He can always cope with the amount of emergency calls He gets. He doesn't even mind if they're trivial or not. He just wants you to call. He wants you to know He's always there to help you. Whatever is bothering you bothers Him. You are so important to Him, you matter so much.
‘The Lord says, "I will rescue those who love me. I will protect those who trust in my name."' (Psalm 91:14 NLT). Or as it says in the CEV ‘I will rescue you and keep you safe.'

content.title: Look for the honey!
content.introtext:
'In it was a swarm of bees and some honey, which he scooped out...'



Judges 14:8-9
There's a story in the Bible that talks about Samson. You remember Samson right, the guy with superhuman strength and no hairdresser? One day Samson is really peckish, he spots some bees making some honey and just sticks his hand in and grabs some (the hive was in a dead lion but I don't think he was that bothered about health and hygiene regulations!). Fresh, golden, delicious!
How often do we miss out on something sweet because we're scared of getting stung? Maybe someone is scared to go out with someone they fancy in case they get hurt. Or someone else doesn't take up the opportunity of a role in the school production in case they fail or look stupid. Most times in life we have to get past the bees to get the honey. If your life feels boring don't blame God. Neither bees nor honey are boring! God has dreamt up some great opportunities for you but they don't come gift-wrapped (remember the lion!). In fact a lot of the time they look impossible; but that's the idea. Think about David standing in front of Goliath or Peter stepping out of the boat to walk towards Jesus riding the waves without a surf board. These guys became giant-killers and water-walkers but they had to get past it being scary or even looking impossible. They had to get past the bees and so do you!

SoulFood: Judges 7:1 - 9:33, Luke 15:11-31, Ps 119:105-112, Pr 18:10-12

content.title: To boldly go…
content.introtext:
‘...approach the throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need.'

Hebrews 4:16 NIV
To boldly go where no man has gone before! Recognise the phrase from Star Trek? The space ship, reaching places that had never been seen before! Of course it's just Sci-Fi fantasy; we've not mastered travelling through space in that way just yet! But because of Jesus we are all able to boldly go where no man or woman could go before; directly to God. Before Jesus came to earth not everyone was able to talk directly to God. Animal sacrifices had to be made and certain people were chosen, priests, to go into a place in the centre of the temple and talk to God on behalf of all the people. Often they would tie a long rope around one ankle, so they could be dragged out in case they died in there! Can you imagine having to pray like that? Those guys didn't walk in there with confidence to enjoy Gods' company. They went in scared stiff wondering if they'd be coming out alive! Crazy huh?
But because God loves us so much, He chose to send His only Son, Jesus, to the earth, to die the ultimate sacrifice, so through believing in Jesus, we can talk with God whenever we want to, we can be forever with God (John 3:16) It's amazingly fantastic! Go confidently, boldly, to God; He's waiting.

content.title: Use what God gave you!
content.introtext:
'...with the ability...God supplies...'



1 Peter 4:11 NKJV
When God gives you an assignment He gives you all that's needed to fulfil it. In fact, by working out what you're really good at helps you figure out your calling. Winston Churchill said, 'To each there comes in his or her lifetime a special moment when they are tapped on the shoulder and offered the chance to do a very special thing, unique to them and fitted to their talent. What a tragedy if that moment finds them unprepared or unqualified for that which could have been their finest hour.'
You can't always be what you want to be (see X-factor!), but you can be everything God wants you to be. That's because He assigns us '...each according to his own ability' (Matthew 25:15 NKJV). What do you love doing and do consistently well? Is music your thing? What about computers or maybe helping with little kids? Paul says, 'Now to each one the manifestation of the Spirit is given for the common good.' (1 Corinthians 12:7 NIV). That means some of the things other people find boring, will give you a buzz. That's not an excuse to ONLY do the stuff you love-not many people feel gifted to be pick up rubbish or stack the chairs-we can ALL do that! But stop apologising for the skills you don't have and discover the gifts God has given you and put them to work for His kingdom.

SoulFood: Judges 9:34- 11:40, Luke 16:1-18, Ps 119:113-120, Pr 20:25, Ecc 5:4-6

content.title: Tell all
content.introtext:
‘If I had cherished sin in my heart, the Lord would not have listened.'

Psalm 66:18 NIV
Have you seen that programme on UKTV ‘How Clean Is Your House'? If you have you may have found yourself screaming at the TV, ‘Uggh!! How can they live like that?' as you look in horror at the amount of dirt and rubbish that's inside. Thankfully by the end of the programme you're feeling relieved, as the house is how it should be; nice and clean! But it only got clean because those brave souls asked for help. They decided that it was better to deal with the humiliation of having their dirty houses shown on TV than for them to live that way any way longer. And even though they are named and shamed in front of thousands watching, by the end of the programme they are looking happy, relieved. Their houses look completely different and their lives have changed for the better.
When we do things wrong and go against God, it's like we are messing our lives up as much as those people messed up their houses. If we don't ask for help it stays there. Our lives get messier and messier, dirtier and smellier. Carrying this around all day can make us feel, ashamed, guilty, angry, unloved, useless, hopeless, all negative feelings. That's why God says, ‘Talk to Me, tell Me all about it; ask for My help, My love, My forgiveness. Just ask and it's yours'. Hide nothing, tell God everything and keep clean!

content.title: Lessons from Lystra (1)
content.introtext:
'When the crowd saw what Paul had done...'



Acts 14:11 NIV
Ever had an adult ask: "what do you what to be when you grow up?" Currently a common answer young people give is "I want to be famous". They might not know what they want to be famous for DOING, as long as they get to be famous. Celebs are like gods in our culture. People worship and adore them. Let's look at what happened to Paul, in a town called Lystra, after he prayed for a disabled man who then started walking for the first time; 'When the crowd saw what Paul had done, they shouted..."These men are gods!"... But when... Paul heard what was happening, they [shouted] "... we are merely human beings-just like you!"' (Acts 14:11-15 NLT). God used Paul to do something awesome but instead of focusing on God the people start to big up Paul. This is so easy for US to do in a celeb-crazed culture.
1) Don't get giddy about "famous Christians": Festivals and events are full of young people who "worship" the bands, preachers or even the worship leaders. They are just doing God's stuff so get excited about HIM not THEM.
2) If God uses YOU don't let it go to your head: The next day in Lystra, the same people who were cheering were chucking rocks at Paul (v19) It was a good job Paul was doing it for God and not for the cheers!

SoulFood: Judges 12-15, Luke 16:19-31, Ps 119:121-128, Pr 18:13-20

content.title: Get Real!
content.introtext:
‘We are certain that God will hear our prayers when we ask for what pleases him.'

1 John 5:14 CEV
You know it would be pointless to keep asking your school's Principal to let you play sports or computer games all day, don't you? You know it would be pointless to walk into a bank and ask them to give you as much money as you wanted whenever you wanted it, don't you? Why? Because these things will never happen will they? If the teacher and the bank manager agreed to your request they wouldn't be doing their job properly would they?
Be careful you don't keep asking God for pointless things! Just like the teacher and the bank manager, God has got a plan of how best to do things. And get this; He knows what's best! So if you come along with a stupid request like, ‘make me invisible so I can go and spy on everyone in school', you should know it's not going to happen! And that's not because God isn't listening or doesn't care. It's because you are asking Him to go against what He knows is right and He will never do that! Even if your reason for wanting to be invisible is valid; like you want to find out what the school bullies are planning, so you can stop it before it happens; God won't do it! So get real! Tap into God's agenda and know with confidence He is listening and will act!

content.title: Lessons from Lystra (2)
content.introtext:
'He has shown kindness by giving you rain from heaven...'



Acts 14:17 NIV
Yesterday we read about Paul preaching to the villagers of Lystra. They weren't like the boffins in Athens, or religious Jews that Paul would end up talking to. These guys didn't know a lot about philosophy or religion but they did know about farming. Check out Paul's sermon:
"We are bringing you good news, telling you...turn to the living God who made heaven and earth and sea and everything in them... Yet he has not left himself without testimony: He has shown kindness by giving you rain from heaven and crops in their seasons; he provides you with plenty of food and fills your hearts with joy." (Acts 14:15-17 NIV)
In other sermons Paul bangs on about Jewish history or the words of Greek poets but to the farmers he talks about rain, crops and lunch. Why? Because he wants them to get it, so he talks about the stuff THEY understand. Today, words like 'born again', 'sin', 'redeemed', 'house of God' often make it into our talks and songs yet don't make much sense to non-Christians. So when we talk to our mates, we need to think about HOW we talk about God. Here's a challenge: write down what a Christian is without using church words; if you're into skating or hip-hop use the words from your culture, just make sure it makes sense. Then tell your mates.

SoulFood: Acts 20:7-12, Jer 29:4-14

content.title: What are you doing that for?
content.introtext:
‘When you ask, you do not receive, because you ask with wrong motives, that you may spend what you get on your pleasures.'

James 4:3 NIV
‘What am I doing this for?' It's a good question to ask yourself often; especially when you're praying! Sometimes we can seem to be doing something good and right but the reason behind what we're doing is all wrong. You might look good making a cup of tea for your dad and buying him his favourite chocolate bar, but if you're doing this because you've just had your mobile phone bill and want him to pay for it; then your reason for being kind is all wrong. The Bible says in 1 Samuel 16:7 ‘People judge by outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart'. You might be able to fool people that you are doing things because you are such a lovely person, but you can't fool God; He looks right through you and sees the reasons behind your actions.
Always check your reason for praying is a good one not a selfish one. Why are you praying for this person or situation? Is it just to make your life easier? God wants our reason for doing things to be because we love Him and because we love people. Being selfish, revengeful or manipulative, will get you nowhere with God. In fact He says if we ask Him for good stuff but our motive is wrong, then forget it. He's not interested, we won't get it! So, why are you doing that?

content.title: On your side:)
content.introtext:
'[Jesus] understands our weaknesses, for he faced all of the same testing we do'



Hebrews 4:15 NLT
Ever found yourself saying, "You don't understand what I'm going through" or "Isn't there anyone who understands how I feel"? If you have then like most, you probably have experienced times when you're struggling with what's happening in your life, or you're finding living a Christian life difficult, because the temptation to do the opposite is so strong. You could even be experiencing this today? At times like this we can long for someone to 'be there' for us, someone to just 'get' what we're going through. But sometimes rather than feeling supported we can feel misunderstood, ignored, alone.
Well today there is some great news coming your way. Never again do you have to feel like no-one understands what you're going through. NEVER! The Bible tells us that, 'Jesus understands everything you're going through!' and that means EVERYTHING!
Now before you start thinking, "Don't be daft, how can Jesus possibly understand EVERYTHING about me and my life? How can Jesus know what I'm going through, he never even did anything wrong." - GET THIS: The Bible tells us that 'because Jesus lived on this earth He was tempted in every way and experienced the same feelings that we go through' AND because of this he 'talks to God about you, asking Him to help you.' How good is that?! Today whatever you're going through, know Jesus does understand and is, 'for you not against you!'

SoulFood: Judges 16:1 - 19:15, Luke 17:1-10, Ps 119:129-136, Pr 18:21

content.title: Who are ya?
content.introtext:
‘...I am fearfully and wonderfully made...'

Psalm 139:14 NIV

Your true identity is found only in Jesus. Listen to whom the Bible says you are: You are ‘a child of God' (John 1:12), You are ‘Christ's friend' (John 15:15) You are ‘a new creation' (2 Corinthians 5:17) You are ‘God's workmanship - His handiwork - born anew in Christ to do His work' (Ephesians 2:10) You are ‘a saint' ( Ephesians 1:1) You are ‘righteous and holy' (Ephesians 4:24) You are ‘a citizen of Heaven' (Philippians 3:20 ) You are ‘hidden with Christ in God' (Colossians 3:3) You are an ‘expression of the life of Christ because He is your life' (Colossians 3:4) You are ‘chosen of God, holy and dearly loved' (Colossians 3:12) You are a ‘child of light and not of darkness' (1Thessalonians 5:5) You are a ‘member of a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for God's own possession' (1 Peter 2:9-10) You are an ‘alien and stranger to this world in which you temporarily live' (1 Peter 2;11) You are an ‘enemy of the devil' (1Peter 5:8) You are a ‘child of God and you will resemble Jesus when He returns' (1 John 3:1-2) You are ‘born of God - and the evil one cannot touch you' (1 John 5:18) You are ‘fearfully and wonderfully made' and that's just the start! Know your worth, know your value. It's found in Jesus

content.title: How to fight so everybody wins (1)
content.introtext:
'...watch out or you will be destroyed by each other.'



Galatians 5:15 NIV
Mates sometimes fall out. After all, being friends doesn't mean you have to act like Wiggles characters, hold hands or constantly grin, but how you deal with disagreement makes or breaks friendships. Ever felt like you've won the argument but lost a friend? Here are three ways to that people handle conflict.
1) Avoid them: These are the people who hate to rock the boat, they fear confrontation and don't what to upset everyone; even if THEY have been upset. So they bury their feelings. But like the bad guy in a cheesy action movie, just when you think you've killed off those feelings, they spring back to life. If you try to clam up, the feelings build up and then you blow up - often at the wrong person!
2) Attack them: These are the 'get them before they get you' people; who use words, gossip and maybe fists to wound each other. The Bible says, 'If you keep on biting and devouring each other, watch out or you will be destroyed by each other.' Attack leads to counterattack, both sides 'dig in' and nothing gets resolved
3) Approach them. These people are sensitive to the feelings of others, yet talk about their feelings to God and their friend. They try to deal with the issues without blaming or scoring points and will try to be the first to say sorry.
Which are you?

SoulFood: Judges 19:16 -21:25, Luke 17:11-19, Ps 119:137-144, Pr 18:22-24

content.title: Fame or faith?
content.introtext:
‘Good people are remembered long after they are gone, but the wicked are soon forgotten. '

Proverbs 10:7 CEV
A cheerful thought for you today; one day, you'll die! When you do, what will people remember you for; fame, or faith?
Barnabas isn't the most famous guy in the Bible, but he's called ‘...a good man...full of...faith...' (Acts 11:24 NIV) He wasn't a ‘Paul', doing the kinds of things that made him stand out, and he's only mentioned three times in Acts: for selling his land to help finance God's works; vouching for Paul's character; and giving John Mark a second chance. Barnabas didn't earn much fame, but he was known for his faith! The Bible says: ‘A good and honest life is blessed'; in God's eyes it's not what society considers important that counts, but faith.
Check out the story of the rich man and Lazarus (Luke 16:19-31). For starters, we know Lazarus' name, but we don't have a clue who the rich man was? He may have been famous when he was alive, but where did that get him with God? Precisely nowhere! He had no faith on earth, and now he's only remembered as a nameless ‘how not to do it' example! Lazarus may not have had the best life, or been known for anything special when he was alive, but his memory is much more blessed than the rich man's.
So how will you be remembered when you're gone; for fame, or faith? Start living that good and honest faith-filled life today.

content.title: How to fight so everybody wins (2)
content.introtext:
'Speaking the truth in love, we will...grow up.'



Ephesians 4:15 NIV
The Bible talks about 'Speaking the truth in love'; yeah but how? Suppose a couple fall out with each other because he's always late. She could give him a piece of her mind and list off all of his faults, or give him the silent treatment, or give them both a chance to find a solution and try something like this:
'I feel frustrated....' No blame, no attack; just an honest expression of her own emotion. 'When you are late...' No judging, name-calling or labelling; just a concrete description of his action. 'It feels like the other things you are doing are more important than me...' No moralising; just honestly sharing her feelings. 'Please try to be on time, or call and let me know when you'll be here...' Instead of focusing on past actions he can't change, she's telling him what she'd like him to do differently next time.
'Do you mind doing that for me?' No demanding or taking for granted; just asking for consideration and cooperation. You might not have a "late boyfriend" it might be your parents, mates or people at work who keep doing stuff that winds you up. How can you go further than just speaking your mind but be honest without blaming and look for a solution not just a fight? Think about that and you will be closer speaking truth in love.

SoulFood: Gal 1-3, Luke 17:20-37, Ps 119:145-160, Pr 19:1-2

content.title: Show your parents how it’s done!
content.introtext:
‘...another generation arose after them who did not know the Lord...'

Judges 2:10 NKJV
When Joshua was almost ready to kick the bucket, he called the nation's big bosses together for a bit of a business meeting. The leaders could remember being supernaturally fed for forty years, seeing the Red Sea sliced in two and the walls of Jericho crumbling. Knowing this, our mate Josh asks them who they're gonna serve. What's the response? ‘Israel served the Lord all the days of Joshua...' (Joshua 24:31 NKJV). Sounds great so far! But it's not all as rosy as it looks. They served God partly, and only when it suited them. The one thing they had to do after Josh was dead and gone, was to vacuum up the last pockets of pagan worship. But Israel ‘...did not drive out the inhabitants...' (Judges 1:27 NKJV).
While Joshua had been fully committed to God, the others were only partly committed. So what were the consequences? Their kids messed up big time (Read how in Judges 2:10-19). What shaped the spiritual values of these children? The compromise of their parents! Parents don't always get it right; but unlike these guys here, you can get it right. You don't have to follow the path that everyone else around you is taking; instead, follow God's path, and do things His way. Flip it on its head and be an example to your parents, showing them that if you can live God's way, so can they.

content.title: Night vision (1)
content.introtext:
'Let him who walks in the dark, who has no light, trust in the name of the LORD and rely on his God.'


Isaiah 50:10 NIV
Yes, God promises us peace, but we also know that bad things can happen to good people. Isaiah makes it clear that there will be times when darkness will even surround people who love God. Check your Bible, there's plenty of examples. What about Job who was well blessed before suddenly losing everything? He cried out, 'He has blocked my way...he has shrouded my paths in darkness' (Job 19:8 NIV) But is darkness our enemy? Maybe not. Think about this: Faith is like film - you remember that stuff - the stuff you used to put into cameras before everything went digital! Well the thing about film is that has to be 'developed' in the dark - the tiniest bit of light will ruin the photograph. Our dark days make us lean on God in ways we normally wouldn't. The truth is, if our faith was never tested we wouldn't be motivated to draw closer to God. It's like the old song: 'When darkness seems to hide His face, I rest on His unchanging grace. When all around my soul gives way, He then is all my hope and stay. On Christ the solid rock I stand, all other ground is sinking sand.' Anyone can praise God when life is good. It's when darkness falls that we find out what our faith is made of. It's in those times that we start to develop night vision!

SoulFood: Gal 4-6, Luke 18:1-17, Ps 119:161-168, Pr 19:3-8

content.title: Your new wardrobe
content.introtext:
‘...no one pours new wine into old wineskins.'

Mark 2:22 NIV
Imagine it's your lucky day - you've been given $2,000 to get yourself a whole new wardrobe. You jump on the bus and hit the shops, grabbing yourself some amazing outfits for every occasion. When you get home, the first thing you do is try everything on again, and do a little fashion show in front of the mirror. After a shopping trip like that, you proudly wear your new clothes every day, showing the world just how mighty fine you look.
You wouldn't get home, throw your clothes all over the floor, chuck food on them to cover them in stains, get out the scissors and cut a few holes in them, roll them about in some mud and get the dog to use them as his bed for a week, and only then would you put them on and wear them. If you did, that would be crazy, right?
So if that's the case, why would you even think about doing that with your spiritual clothes? When you become a Christian, it's like God gives you that whole new-life-wardrobe. He gets rid of the old rough edges. So, don't go jumping straight into the old scabby clothes of your life before. Be proud of the changes in you, and show love instead of hate, humility instead of conceit, and worship of God instead of idolatry. Why bother with rags when God's given you riches?

content.title: Night vision (2)
content.introtext:
'Even though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil'



Psalm 23:4 NIV
Psalm 23 is amazing in all sorts of ways, one of which is this: David goes from talking about God, 'The Lord is my Shepherd,' to talking with Him, 'You are with me.' What happened in between? David learned that no matter how dark the way is, God is there to guide us by the hand. He realised that it's better to walk through the dark valley with God than stand on the mountaintop alone.
God doesn't always send you places where the sun is shining, but He promises, 'When you pass through the waters, I will be with you; and when you pass through the rivers, they will not sweep over you.' (Isaiah 43:2 NIV). When you feel like you're out of your depth or in over your head, claim that promise! When you can't find the reason, trust the relationship. God won't fail you.
It's amazing just how many of the important steps forward taken by people in the bible happened in the darkness. Another one of the famous Psalms gets this point across really poetically, '...the night will shine like the day, for darkness is as light to you.' (Psalm 139:12 NIV). So instead of running from the darkness today, ask God to develop your night vision, to show you 'the treasures of darkness, riches stored in secret places' (NIV).

SoulFood: Lam 1:1 - 3:39, Luke 18:18-30, Ps 119:169-176, Pr 19: 9-10

content.title: Choose life!
content.introtext:
‘..."Do you want to be made well?"'

John 5:6 NKJV
He hasn't walked for 38 years, the pool didn't have lifeguards to help, and there are no stair lifts like oldies have to help them up and down the stairs. So when Jesus rocks up and asks this dude ‘..."Do you want to be made well?"' it may seem like a bit of a ‘well duuh' moment! But actually, He asked it to make the guy think. He obviously wanted to be well, but had he thought about what that would mean to his life; would he take responsibility for himself, look after others as well as himself, what job would he get to earn a living?
When we ask God for stuff, we need to be prepared for His answer; it might come with an instruction to change. Sometimes, God's solution is a challenge to us. You're stuck for money? God says ‘Ok, here's a paper round!'. He solves the problem, but we have to change too; you can't just sit on your butt and treat God like a free vending machine!
The good news is, solving bigger problems brings bigger rewards. So ask God to stretch you today by helping you ‘...take up your bed and walk' (John 5:8 NKJV). Throw away that dependency and helplessness and move on to bigger and better things. Be prepared to do what God asks, and you'll see a change. Choose life; God's way.
