content.title: Night vision (3)
content.introtext:
'all you who... walk in the light of your fires... will lie down in torment'


Isaiah 50:11 NIV
When the darkness around you is part of God's plan don't try to create your own light: 'You who live in your own light...will soon fall down in great torment.' Abraham tried that when he sensed the light of God's promise of son going dim over time. Tired of waiting, he decided to go get it on with his maid instead of his wife - errr - big mistake Abe! And what about Peter who promised to follow Jesus to prison and to death (Luke 22:33)? When darkness fell he didn't wait for instructions and ended up chopping off an innocent man's ear!
Let's get one really important point clear: when you're in darkness by divine design you don't have to be scared, God will bring you through, night always gives way to morning! The Bible gives us great promises: '...weeping may remain for a night, but rejoicing comes in the morning' (Psalm 30:5 NIV). The forty dark days Moses spent alone on the mountain, the same time spent by Jesus in the wilderness being tempted, they were essential to God's plans. Jesus said, 'What I tell you in the dark, speak in the daylight...' (Matthew 10:27 NIV). So remember, 1) It may be in a really dark moment that God gives you an amazing revelation. 2) People will listen to you because you've 'earned the right to speak' - you've been there. So you never need to be scared of the dark!

SoulFood: Lam 3:40 - 5:17, Luke 18:31-43, Ps 84, Pr 19:11

content.title: From God’s perspective
content.introtext:
‘He made known his ways to Moses, his deeds to the people of Isarel.'

PSALM 103:7
Have you ever known someone to do something that made absolutely no sense until they explained it to you? God can be just like that. Sometimes He does things we don't get, sometimes he doesn't do things we think He should. Like when He told Noah to build a boat, Abraham to sacrifice his only son, and Moses to cross the sea on foot. None of those things make any sense until you look at the whole story, from God's perspective. Then we can see He totally knew what he was doing!
When we are able to stop looking at things through our own eyes and see God's perspective it changes the way we see everything. When we understand Him better we learn to love Him more. When we see why He has asked us not to do certain things we naturally find quite appealing, it's much easier to do as He asks. ‘There is a way that seems right to man, but in the end it leads to death' (Proverbs 14:12 NIV). Just because something feels right, it doesn't mean it is. If it's not God's plan, it's a dead end!
Understanding God's point of view keeps us on track. We live in a world that has come to the conclusion that there is no truth and everyone's opinion is valid. The problem isn't that our culture doesn't believe anything, it's that it believes everything. Many say ‘It doesn't matter what you believe as long as you're sincere.' Rubbish! Hitler was sincere; and that definitely mattered. Seeing life from God's perspective keeps us stable, focussed and stops us being fooled by the latest fads!

content.title: The pruning process!
content.introtext:
'...HE PRUNES THE BRANCHES THAT DO BEAR FRUIT SO THEY WILL PRODUCE EVEN MORE'.



JOHN 15.2 NLT
Listen: 'He cuts off every branch that doesn't bear fruit and he prunes the branches that do bear fruit so they will produce even more' (John 15:2NLT). There's a time for planting and a time for pruning. Maybe God is at work in your life today taking away branches that don't belong, and pruning ones that do. What kind of things does God take away? Things that have served their purpose. Things that refuse to change. Things that will give you trouble later on. Things that are standing in the way of greater fruitfulness. Things that are holding you back. Things He has not chosen for you.
Have you ever seen a freshly pruned tree? Doesn't look too good, does it? And when God starts to cut back certain things in your life in order to re-direct your energies, you won't look too good either. Sometimes this means: a) having less nice stuff for a while b) letting go of things you depended on, c) being unable to explain to your mates why you are even going through the pruning process.
God knows what needs to be cut back in your life; He also knows what needs to be cut off. Trust Him. Even though you can't understand what He's doing, just pray, 'Lord, if I needed it You would let me keep it, so I open my hand to You today. Send whoever You will and take away whoever You will. I'll praise You when they come and I'll praise You when they go, because Your approval is my reward, and Your purpose is my reason to live.'

SoulFood: Gen 6:9 - 8:4, Matt 24:37-51

content.title: Getting through family breakup
content.introtext:
‘When you walk through the fire, you will not be burned...'

Isaiah 43:2 NIV
You may be in the middle of your parents' splitting up, and nothing feels worse than being stuck in the middle. It may feel like you're being torn in half. So, can you really ‘walk through this fire' without being burned? The Bible says yes, but first you must:
1) Forgive yourself and your parents. Realise it's not your fault. You're not responsible for your parents' relationship, but it's easy to blame yourself. If you do feel responsible, read Isaiah 43:25. God forgives and forgets, and He'll give you the grace to forgive yourself, too. Forgiveness is the one power you always have over anybody who hurts you. So keep on forgiving your parents no matter what; every day. Only by forgiving will you be able to move on.
2) Take your time and stick with God. Don't expect it to all be sorted instantly. You've been hurt, and it will take time to heal. You may be on an emotional roller coaster, flitting between wanting them back together, and wanting them to suffer. Healthy people make healthy choices, so spend time reading God's Word, praying, asking advice, and letting God love you. ‘...your God is gracious and compassionate. He will not turn his face from you if you return to him' (2 Chronicles 30:9 NIV). It won't be easy, but realising God hasn't turned His back on you will help you through this.

content.title: You can start again!
content.introtext:
'WITH YOU THERE IS FORGIVENESS...'



PSALM 130:4 NIV
Some people grow through failure; others never recover from it. They talk about the past all the time because they can't get beyond it. What's the answer? See your mistakes as stepping-stones rather than stumbling blocks! 'How do I do that?' By doing three things.
1) You must push! You've got to push through emotions like Regret: 'If only I hadn't failed.' Frustration: 'I thought my idea was great, why didn't they?' Self-pity: 'They hurt me so I will just sit here and lick my wounds.' Paralysis: 'I will never get beyond this.' When it comes to emotions, the only way out is pushing through!
2) You must bounce! Solomon says, 'Though a righteous man falls seven times, he rises again...' (Proverbs 24:16 NIV). You must be like the lady who said, 'I'm never down, I'm either up or I'm getting up!' So, if you fall, will you bounce back up and try again?
3) You must remember! There's only one way - God's way! Samson blew it by getting too close to the wrong woman (see Judges 16). Jonah blew it by trying to run from God's call (see Jonah 1:3). Peter blew it by denying his Lord (See Matthew 26:74) But God used all of them eventually - when they were willing to do it God's way. So remember, don't blow it by thinking your way is better than God's.
The Psalmist writes: 'With You there is forgiveness...' God's forgiveness is received by faith - and it involves forgiving yourself! 'But what about my past?' The moment you accept God's forgiveness you don't have a past, you only have a future. You're free to get on with your life!

SoulFood: Amos 1:1 - 5:17, Luke 19:1-10, Ps 103:1-12, Pr 19:12-16

content.title: In the fire
content.introtext:
‘Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego...'

Daniel 3:30 NIV
We can learn a few things from those guys in the fiery furnace:
1) Obeying God doesn't mean you'll never have trouble. Don't expect the world to always get you - sometimes, it'll be hard work for you 2) You're not alone, God is with you in your trouble. If you've ever seen the Veggietales ‘Rack, Shack and Benny', you'll remember that when King Neb threw them in the fire, suddenly there were ‘four men, and one was reeeaaal shiny!' (check out the whole story in Daniel 3:19 - 27). The fire didn't kill them, ‘cos Jesus was there too. So be encouraged. It may feel like you're stuck in the flames, but God is with you - He'll bring you out of this victorious. 3) Your trouble will become your testimony. Your mates are watching. When what they're trusting in doesn't work, they'll look to see if what you're trusting in does. Your faithfulness to God and His to you, will challenge them in ways nothing else can. Everybody in Babylon knew what Rack, Shack and Benny believed, but they wanted to know if it worked when the heat was on (literally!). It did, and lives changed! 4) On the other side of your trouble, there's great blessing. Our word for today is a Scriptural principle: when you're faithful in a tough place, God can trust you in a high place.

content.title: On guard!
content.introtext:
'...His peace will guard your hearts and minds...'



Philippians 4:7 NLT
Jesus said, '"Can all your worries add a single moment to your life? Of course not"' (Matthew 6:27 NLT). Worry changes nothing. When was the last time you solved a problem by worrying about it? Imagine somebody saying, 'I got behind on my bills so I decided to worry my way out of debt. And you know, it worked! You can't add one day to your life or one bit of life to your day by worrying; all worry will do is bring you wrinkles and grey hairs!
Listen to these two Scriptures: 'Those who trust in the Lord are like Mount Zion, which cannot be shaken but endures forever' (Psalm 125:1 NIV); 'You will keep in perfect peace him whose mind is steadfast, because he trusts in You' (Isaiah 26:3 NIV). We don't get up in the morning and decide 'Today I'm going to doubt God' yet when we worry that's what we do.
Paul writes, '...His peace will guard your hearts and minds...' Paul uses a military word here - guard. The Philippians lived under Roman occupation and were used to seeing the Centurions guarding their town. What security! Before an enemy could get to them they first had to get past the rock-hard Roman guards. And you know what? God gives you the same guarantee! His peace is not wishy washy - it is solid. Your heart and mind are completely safe if you'll let His peace stand guard. Why don't you ask Him for His peace right now?

SoulFood: Amos 5:18 - 9:15, Luke 19:11-27, Ps 103:13-22, Pr 19:17

content.title: That’s grace!
content.introtext:
‘...grace was given me...'

Ephesians 3:8 NIV
If you were asked to describe yourself in two words, what would you choose? I'm guessing you probably wouldn't get what God would say about you; He says ‘pure joy'. Maybe not the first two words that spring to mind! But that is what grace is all about. It means ‘pure joy' - although you don't deserve it, God considers it a pure joy to save you. What do you make of that?!? This ‘grace' stuff can be a bit hard to get your head around.
In John 8, a woman is caught committing adultery. The law makes no bones about her punishment; the Pharisees are eager to stone her. Jesus, being righteous, surely must agree? Without a lawyer to defend her, or even a character witness, things aren't looking good. But suddenly Jesus starts to write in the sand. We're not told what, but some have suggested maybe a list of their sins, complete with times and places. Ouch! When He's done, her accusers are gone. He says, ‘..."neither do I condemn you...Go now and leave your life of sin"' (John 8:11 NIV). Jesus lifted her from a position of undeniable guilt to one of unconditional pardon. She didn't deserve it, and didn't know it was possible. And that's your story too, isn't it? We all mess up, and don't deserve God's love; but by His grace, we get it. How awesome is that!

content.title: No time off!!!
content.introtext:
'Be ready in season and out of season.'


2 Timothy 4:2 NKJV
Have you thought about what job or career you're aiming for? Or what university or college you're going to go to? Whatever your options are you're probably not expecting to be doing it 24-7-365 - you need some time off in between all that work! Right?? Holiday time's great isn't it? Taking time off from the humdrum routine of school, college, uni or work - we love it!! But God is quite clear that there's one thing that we should never take time off from and that's being a Christian. What!! No time off? - EXACTLY!
Living as a child of God is 24/7 - no time off included. God wants us to always be ready - not only speak to anyone who'll listen about Him, but also to show His love through what we do and what we say.
That means being a Christian not just on a Sunday, but when you're at home....yes even when your little brother has just robbed your diary and blabbed it to mum, yes even at College when you discover someone's been spreading nasty rumours about you, yes even when you're stuck behind that doddery old man in the queue at the shop. God wants you always to be ready to let people know by your words and actions how much Jesus loves them.
Remember being a Christian isn't a Sunday only commitment with the rest of the week off - it's every moment of every day.

SoulFood: Ezek 1-4, Luke 19: 28-40, Ps 111, Pr 19:18-20

content.title: New you!
content.introtext:
‘...I no longer live but Christ lives in me...'

Galatians 2:20 NIV

Do you make New Year's resolutions! Have you ever wondered why we do that? Is it to impress friends? To try and be a better, nicer person? Because you think people expect you to? And do you ever actually manage to keep them all?!? How long is it before you broke you last set?
Hebrews 12 urges us to keep striving, while Romans 3:23 reminds us that we're all going to slip up; so why bother?! Which one do we pay attention to? Our word for today, Galatians 2:20, goes on to say that God loves you and gave Himself for you. Think about that for a minute - it's a pretty huge thing! Verse 21 says that we can never get to a point of supreme goodness by effort. So that means no matter how many resolutions we keep, we'll never reach perfection. But that is why Jesus died for you - so that unreachable goal is brought right to us.
So although resolutions aren't the be-all and end-all at New Year, if you remember how amazing it is that God gave Himself for us, and that we have Christ in us to help us, you might find it easier to do the right thing, for the right reasons, whatever your resolutions. And when you find it hard going, you know on whom you can call for help!

content.title: Give your best, and do it with a smile!
content.introtext:
'Every man shall give as he is able.'



Deuteronomy 16:17
There are over 2,000 Scriptures in the Bible on money and giving. Check out Deuteronomy 16:17 and 2 Corinthians 9:7 as just two examples of passages that are relevant to all Christians - even you!
Now, you may be thinking "but I don't have much money - only my pocket money, allowance, or a bit from my Saturday job". That may be true, but no matter how much money you have - or haven't - got, these passages are still important.
Firstly, you need to recognise that whatever you have, God still asks you to cheerfully give with it. That doesn't mean you have to give every penny away - it just means don't be selfish with it and keep it all for yourself. Think about putting a bit in the collection at church, or giving to a charity who you think do good work, because you want to help.
Secondly, these passages aren't just talking about money. Think about all the other things God has given you - gifts, talents, skills - and think about the ways you could use those ‘as you are able', and how you can give of those gifts cheerfully. That may mean offering to help with the Sunday school or kids' church, if you're good with kids, or singing in the band if God's given you a good voice, or helping serve tea if you've got a gift of hospitality.
So have a think today - how can you give with a smile on your face?

SoulFood: Ezek 5-9, Luke 19:41-48, Ps 142, Pr 19:21-23

content.title: Life isn’t a stage show
content.introtext:
‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart...'

Deuteronomy 6:5 NIV
Sometimes it may seem that life is just one big stage show. You may act like one person at home, another at school and yet another at church, and you choose which personality and character traits you want people to see. Your life is like a chest of drawers, and each drawer has a costume and mask in that you put on for different occasions. You could become an impressionist you have that many different personas! You probably do it without even thinking. But just stop and think now; which mask do you put on when you're with God? Because whatever it is, it's pretty pointless. God doesn't see us as a chest of drawers or a collection of separate performances, He sees us as a whole person. When no one is looking, He sees; when you're at school, He sees; when you're in church, He sees. God made us with one will, one mind, one heart, and one spirit. It's the devil's lie that we can ‘have it both ways,' being who we want, when we want; but that just leaves us mentally and emotionally frazzled, and worse; distant from God! God wants us to be the same all the time; no masks, no costumes. How can we do that? By living with integrity, and striving to ‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart and all your soul and all your strength'.

content.title: The ultimate source of wisdom
content.introtext:
The ultimate source of wisdom

'...the wisdom that is from above is...' James 3:17 KJV

A young executive told his secretary he had an important meeting and didn't want to be interrupted. A few minutes later his boss came to his office needing to see him urgently so, without knocking, he just swung the executive's door open and walked in. There in front of his desk, kneeling on the floor, was the young executive, praying. Totally shocked he stepped right back out again and asked the secretary, 'Is this usual?' 'Yes,' she replied, 'he does it every morning.' 'No wonder I come to him for advice!' said his boss.

Everyone needs wisdom; from the businesswoman high up in the glass-fronted office block to the single dad wondering how he can hold down his job and look after his kids. You see, God's wisdom isn't just a bunch of airy-fairy ideas that bear no relevance to life; God's wisdom is all about how to live life, the way He designed it to be lived! So how do you get wisdom? You ask God to give it to you: 'For the Lord gives wisdom; from His mouth come knowledge and understanding.' (Proverbs 2:6 NKJ) 'If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all liberally...and it will be given to him.' (James 1:5 NKJ) So what's going on in your life today? What choices are laid out before you? Ask God for wisdom to take the right path.

SoulFood: Heb 1-4, Mark 9:14-29, Ps 18:1-29, Pr 11:19-21

content.title: God's incredible love for us
content.introtext:
God's incredible love for us

'...love of Christ... surpasses knowledge...' Ephesians 3:18-19 NIV

George Matheson was told by his doctor that he was going blind. Still, he studied hard and despite deteriorating vision graduated from Glasgow University in 1861 at the age of 19. Just a few years later he lost his sight for good. To make matters worse, his fianc‚e returned her engagement ring to him with a note that said, 'I cannot go through life bound by the chains of marriage to a blind man.' George never married and never recovered from his broken heart. Through all this though, he became a successful pastor and led a fulfilled life. But just occasionally the pain of loneliness flared up, like at his sister's wedding. The ceremony brought back memories of the love he'd lost. In response, he turned to the incredible love of God for comfort and wrote an amazing hymn of praise! Here's how it begins: O love that will not let me go, I rest my weary soul in thee; I give thee back the life I owe, that in thine ocean depth its flow may richer, fuller be.

That's what worship is all about; praising God no matter what, because He's more than worth it!

SoulFood: Heb 5-8, Mark 9:30-37, Ps 18:30-50, Pr 11:22

content.title: Information overload! (1)
content.introtext:
Information overload! (1)

'...many shall run to and fro, and knowledge shall increase.' Daniel 12:4 NKJ

Are you reading this copy of word4U2day on paper? Or are you reading it online? Or on your phone? Technology is everywhere these days and it lets us do things we've never been able to do before, and to do several things all at the same time. But you can become tied to technology in ways that end up becoming unhealthy and unhelpful. Here are a few signs for you to watch out for:

(1) if you chat with people all day by texts, tweets, MSN, Facebook or whatever, but you still feel horrendously lonely, then the chances are the technology isn't helping. You need to go back to more old-fashioned ways of communicating-like having a face-to-face talk!

(2) if you find yourself lying in bed feeling pleased that you've got 10 more online 'friends' today than yesterday, go to the bathroom and splash some cold water on your face! The whole point of friendship is quality not quantity!

(3) if you use technology to have fun and organise your social life but never to develop your relationship with God, then you aren't getting the most out of it. Change your surfing habits so that you spend time listening to some of the great worship and teaching podcasts, bookmark some blogs that explain the Bible in language you can understand. Make technology serve you; don't be its slave!

SoulFood: Ex 17:1-7, John 4:1-42

content.title: Information overload! (2)
content.introtext:
Information overload! (2)

'...the...servant is not greater than his master.' John 13:16 NKJ

A respected researcher says we've trained our brains 'to constantly flit around the universe of messages and information, seeking brief hits of excitement. Grazing ceaselessly, we never dig too deeply before moving on to the next distraction'. As a member of the 21st century tech-generation, you get more information in three days than your parents received in a whole month when they were your age. But when information overload starts to happen important things get forgotten in the battle for your attention. How often do you find yourself apologising to people for really simple things you just never got round to doing because your mind was on something else?

So, let's get down to it, when was the last time you enjoyed some relaxed, uninterrupted time without tech? When was the last time you walked in the park without your iPod, and listened to the birds instead? Can you remember? The fact is you need time away from the never-ending waves of information so you can reflect and recharge. Jesus had places to go, people to minister to, disciples depending on Him; even so, 'He...withdrew...into the wilderness, and prayed.' (Luke 5:16 NKJ) Now, since '...the...servant is not greater than his master', do you think you're above all that? Jesus said, 'Come with Me by yourselves to a quiet place and get some rest.' (Mark 6:31 NIV) Make it your number one priority today to take Him up on that offer!

SoulFood: Heb 9:1-11:16, Mark 9:38-50, Ps 75, Pr 11:23

content.title: Receive His peace
content.introtext:
Receive His peace

'...My peace I give you...Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid.' John 14:27 NIV

Jesus says to us: 'My peace I give you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid.' The peace Jesus gives is like a miraculous blanket that wraps around you silencing every unkind word, soothing every out-of-joint emotion. This peace comes from knowing you're God's child-that's right, the God who controls the universe loves you and always has your best interests at heart. That's why people who've lost everything will often tell you they wouldn't want it all back because of how precious that peace has become to them.

Joni Eareckson Tada discovered this supernatural peace when an accident paralysed her from the neck down, and Corrie Ten Boom found it in a Nazi death camp. Missionary Elisabeth Elliot found it ministering to the primitive Amazon tribe who'd killed her husband. She wrote, 'Only in acceptance lies peace...not in resignation.' There's a big difference between those two words! Writer Creath Davis points out that: 'Resignation is surrender to fate; Acceptance is surrender to God. Resignation lies down quietly in an empty universe; Acceptance rises up to meet the God who fills that universe with purpose and destiny. Resignation says, 'I can't'; Acceptance says, 'God can.' Resignation says, 'It's all over for me'; Acceptance says, 'Now that I'm here, what's next, Lord?' Resignation says, 'I'm alone'; Acceptance says, 'I belong to you, Lord.''

SoulFood: Heb 11:17-13:25, Mark 10:1-12, Ps 88:1-9a, Pr 11:24-26

content.title: Glorious living!
content.introtext:
Glorious living!

'God always does what He plans, and that's why He appointed Christ to choose us.' Ephesians 1:11 CEV

Most of us spend our lives focusing on what we have... until we realise that we're running out of time, then we begin to focus on what we've done. Understand this: when you leave this world your material possessions will be forgotten. The only thing that will stay is your life's impact! During your lifetime you will directly or indirectly impact the lives of approximately 10 000 other people. The question is: how will you impact them? Money, or the lack of it, does not necessarily determine your life's impact. People with fat fortunes have lived, died and made little or no difference. Other people, totally broke but full of vision, have done what Jesus said when He prayed, 'Your will be done, on earth, as it is in Heaven.'

At the end of a life well lived the Apostle Paul wrote, '...I have finished my course...' (2 Timothy 4:7 KJV) Having said that he handed the ministry over to Timothy, walked to the executioner's chopping block and was relieved of his duties. Yet his impact is greater now than ever. He writes: ' God always does what He plans, and that's why He appointed Christ to choose us.' What kind of plans? Not just making a living but making a difference! In the movie Forrest Gump, Tom Hanks plays a character with disabilities, both physical and mental. By following wise advice he goes on to achieve some incredible things. You know what? You have within you huge potential for achieving incredible things. God's given you a gift. Believe it. Discover it. Develop it. Cherish it. Use it. Give it. That's glorious living!

SoulFood: 1 Kings 1-2, Mark 10:13-22, Ps 88: 9b-18, Pr 11:27-29

content.title: Time out, not burn-out
content.introtext:
Time out, not burn-out

'...Come to Me, all of you who are tired and have heavy loads... learn from Me... and you will find rest for your lives.' Matthew 11:28-29 NCV

God doesn't want you to get frazzled by the hectic pace of life. He created you to have a balance of work, rest and play; so make sure you do. It's easy to let life get so busy with school, work, mates, sport, exams, church stuff...the list goes on. You're busy, you may even be enjoying it, and you definitely don't want to miss out on anything. But, before you know it, you're exhausted, you've not had time alone with God for weeks, and you feel like you're going to fall apart. Not good. So-learn early how to get the balance right. Learn to say no. Don't be afraid of time by yourself-in fact, make sure you have time for yourself. When you've had proper rest, you'll have way more energy for all the other stuff; and probably find you enjoy it even more! Don't let yourself get so caught up in doing 'stuff'-including helping other people-if it means you forget to think about yourself and how you're doing. It's easy to forget about your own problems when you're so immersed in other stuff-but Jesus wants to help you deal with it, not file it away

So take time out every now and then-even put it in your diary or on your phone as 'you time'. Spend some quality time with the Big Guy, and make sure you're getting your balance right.

SoulFood: 1 Kings 3-5, Mark 10:23-34, Ps 93, Pr 11:30-31

content.title: God's cedars (1)
content.introtext:
God's cedars (1)

'...The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it...' Isaiah 35:2 NKJ

When Solomon built God a temple, he used different types of cedars-that's trees, to you and me! When the job was finished, they held a ceremony and God turned up in an awesome way. We're going to take four days to look at four types of trees God still uses now to build His church.

First, little cedars: these trees made fence posts for sheep pens, and if you chuck them in a truck driving down a bendy, pot-holed road, they won't fall out. They're consistent, and stick to the job. People who are God's 'little cedars' have what it takes to survive the potholes life throws at them, and its twists and turns.

It's said that people don't control their future, only their habits; and their habits control their future. 'Little cedars' have good habits, like: (a) praying; that's talking AND listening to God. '...He teaches me to listen like a student.' (Isaiah 50:4 NCV) (b) Bible reading; but not just reading-being prepared to hear, learn and live it, like Ezra did. '...Ezra had devoted himself to the study and observance of the Law of the LORD...' (Ezra 7:10 NIV) (c) sharing; having a credible testimony (that's your story of what God's done for you) to tell others. (d) giving; offering God the first bits of whatever money you have.

Put God first, and His blessings will overflow into all areas of your life.

SoulFood: 1 Kings 6-7, Mark 10:35-52, Ps 97, Pr 12:1-3

content.title: God's cedars (2)
content.introtext:
God's cedars (2)

'...The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it...' Isaiah 35:2 NKJ

Secondly, Solomon used fire cedars (which shepherds used to make fires at night, because they ignited easily and burned for ages).

At Pentecost, God gathered 120 'fire cedars' in the upper room. 'Suddenly a sound like the blowing of a violent wind came from heaven and filled the whole house where they were sitting. They saw what seemed to be tongues of fire that separated and came to rest on each of them. All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages as the Spirit enabled them.' (Acts 2:2-4 NIV) That day 3000 people became Christians; wow! The church as we know it was born through fire, and is sustained by fire; we can't let the fire go out.
God's fire leads to revival. We need to be spiritually hungry to be 'fire cedars' for the future revival. But be aware that you'll be a target for attack from the enemy when you are-revival is the devil's worst nightmare. To be sure your fire always stays hot ask yourself these four questions regularly: (1) Am I living life the way the Bible reveals? (Isaiah 8:20) (2) Do my words and actions reveal Christ? (John 3:30) (3) Do I offer other people God's love, acceptance and forgiveness? (Colossians 3:13) (4) Do I win souls and make disciples? (John 15:8)

Pentecost/Whitsunday SoulFood: Acts 1:4-8, Rom 12:1-8, 1 Cor 12:1-13

content.title: God's cedars (3)
content.introtext:
God's cedars (3)

'...The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it...' Isaiah 35:2 NKJ

Thirdly, God uses humming cedars to build strong churches. When the wind blows through them, they hum-and the bigger the storm, the better the song!

In Acts, you can read about a couple of 'humming cedars' who were chucked in prison in Philippi, locked in stocks and beaten. How did they respond? '...at midnight Paul and Silas were...singing hymns to God...Suddenly there was a great earthquake...the foundations of the prison were shaken; and immediately all the doors were opened and everyone's chains were loosed.' (Acts 16:25-26 NKJ) A preacher once said that 'God got so caught up in their praises that He began to tap His foot. And when God taps His foot, you get earthquakes!'

Praising God through bad times breaks chains and opens doors; it's the way to victory. But Satan will do everything he can to stop you, because he knows (a) the importance of praise; 'Great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised...' (Psalm 48:1 NKJ) (b) the healing effects of praise; God's answer to 'the spirit of heaviness' is 'the garment of praise' (Isaiah 61:3 NKJ) and (c) the power of praise; '...when they began...to praise, the Lord set ambushes against the [enemy]...' (2 Chronicles 20:22 NKJ) Don't let Satan rob you of that 'garment of praise'. Choose to put it on, praise God, and watch Him turn your situation around.

SoulFood: 1 Kings 8-9, Mark 11:1-11, Ps 47, Pr 12:4-6

content.title: Men are from Mars, women are from Venus!
content.introtext:
Men are from Mars, women are from Venus!

'...male and female He created them.' Genesis 1:27 NIV

Sometimes it feels like that, doesn't it? Maybe you've had a row with your brother, or your girlfriend's in a mood with you and you've no idea why. It feels like they're on another planet! But they're not. God created guys and girls differently; our brains work in different ways. Whereas a guy may have school, home, mates and hobbies all in different boxes in his brain, where one doesn't affect the others, a girl has all the same things, but the boxes are all joined and they affect each other. Something happening at home can affect all the other boxes. So your brother may forget your argument by the time you get home, and be all cheery when you're fuming with him, because he left that box behind hours ago and has done so much since then, and only when he gets back in the 'family' box will he be ready to deal with it. Or your girlfriend may be in a mood with you because of something going on in a completely different part of her life and, until that's sorted, she won't be happy.

It's unlikely that guys will ever completely understand girls, and vice versa, but by understanding some of the differences, we can learn to get on with each other so much better, and give each other the space to be who God created us to be, whether that's male or female!

SoulFood: Lev 23:15-22, Acts 2:1-18

content.title: God's cedars (4)
content.introtext:
God's cedars (4)

'...The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it...' Isaiah 35:2 NKJ

Fourthly, tall cedars. Their strength wasn't in their height, but in their roots; they could bend almost to the ground without breaking, and come back stronger. God uses 'tall cedars' to build great churches. Don't think that just deciding to be a Christian is enough; that's only 5% of it really, like the bit of the tree you see above the ground. The other 95% is all about growing your spiritual roots. Without roots, the tall cedars would have been useless, and would have toppled in the slightest storm. You must strive to be mature and fully grown, becoming more and more like Jesus. How? '...though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you the elementary truths of God's Word all over again. You need milk, not solid food! Anyone who lives on milk, being still an infant, is not acquainted with the teaching about righteousness. But solid food is for the mature, who by constant use have trained themselves to distinguish good from evil. Therefore let us leave the elementary teachings about Christ and go on to maturity...' (Hebrews 5:12-6:1 NIV) You need to constantly train yourself in the word of God. So study your Bible, listen to good teaching on it, but more than that, think about it yourself, about what it means to you, what God's saying to you through it. And little by little, your roots will grow.

SoulFood: 1 Kings 10-11, Mark 11:12-26, Ps 45, Pr 12:7-9

content.title: Lukewarm or boiling over?
content.introtext:
Lukewarm or boiling over?

'Don't sin by letting anger control you...' Ephesians 4:26 NLT

Anger! It affects everyone! There's the story of the guy who stalled his car at a green light, bringing on loads of honking horns from other drivers. He got out, went to the car behind and calmly said, 'Sorry mate, I can't get it started. Feel free to give it a go, and I'll sit here and honk your horn-anyone can do that.' Nice one!

You need to know how to handle anger properly, or one of two things will happen: (1) You stay angry. You're permanently boiling over, and that's not healthy. Be realistic; not every problem will be resolved the way you want it to be. Sometimes, you just have to give it to God and move on. (2) You don't get angry even when it's appropriate. You're always lukewarm, you show no emotion, and people start to wonder if you're actually human!

If you lack the courage to confront someone, you're more likely to explode at home, and that's not good for anyone. Jesus said, 'If your fellow believer sins against you, go and tell him in private what he did wrong...' (Matthew18:15 NCV) Sometimes we're supposed to get angry; but in the right way. Be angry with the problem, not the person. So, say what you have to say, but in kindness, and not in front of others. That's called speaking the truth in love, and it's not boiling over, but not lukewarm.

SoulFood: 1 Kings 12-13, Mark 11:27-33, Ps 128, Pr 12:10-11

content.title: Stop it!
content.introtext:
Stop it!

'...He has made perfect forever those who are being made holy.' Hebrews 10:14 NIV

'I'm too fat!' 'I'm ugly!' 'I'm always getting it wrong!' 'I'm no good!' 'They don't like me'. How many times do you say those things to yourself? Well, what you need to do is STOP IT! Focus on what's right with you, not what's wrong, or you'll end up so negative you can't appreciate the gift of life. If you're always putting yourself down, or beating yourself up, you're setting a bad example to others-which no-one wants. We've all got bits of ourselves we want to improve, none of us will ever be perfect- but being negative isn't the answer. Look at the verse chosen for today. Slowly read what it says. And again. That's you it's talking about!
Max Lucado writes: 'Underline the word perfect. Note, the word isn't better. Not improving... God doesn't improve; He perfects. He doesn't enhance; He completes... I realise there's a sense in which we're imperfect... We still stumble. We still do exactly what we don't want to do...that part of us is 'being made holy'. But when it comes to our position before God, we're perfect. When He sees each of us, He sees someone who has been made perfect through the One who is perfect; Jesus Christ.'

It's ok to want to improve yourself, but take it easy! Stop and remind yourself that you're '...being made new...becoming like the One who made you...' (Colossians 3:10 NCV)

SoulFood: 1 Kings 14-15, Mark 12:1-12, Ps 101, Pr 12:12-13

content.title: Got what it takes?
content.introtext:
Got what it takes?

'...I said, "Here I am, send me!"' Isaiah 6:8 NLT

Are you one of those people who's always sticking their hand in the air, volunteering, saying, 'pick me, pick me,' a bit like the donkey in Shrek? Are you saying to God, 'Send me'? Before you do, check out these three key 'Cs' for leading and succeeding for God:

(1) Commitment: Real leaders don't quit even if they want to. Have you ever started tidying your room, and it gets messier before it gets better? It'd be easy to give up halfway through, thinking you'd failed, but that'd be a disaster! Just like leadership, you have to see it through to the end to get good results, to see the tidy room. You can't quit halfway through, even if it gets tough. With God's strength, you'll be able to handle the demands of people, pressures and problems that come your way

(2) Creativity: Just before the birth of Jesus, a Roman poet called Horace wrote: 'Adversity has the effect of eliciting talents which in prosperous circumstances would have lain dormant'-which can be put simply as: problems unlock creativity. Wise leaders look for a solution to every problem, then act on it.

(3) Compassion: What moves you? What gets you excited? If you're going to lead, you need to love-and you can't always pick and choose who you'll be leading. So before you say, 'Lord, send me,' ask yourself: Am I ready? Do I have what it takes?

SoulFood: 1 Kings 16:1-18:15, Mark 12:13-27, Ps 108, Pr 12:14

content.title: Lessons from Lazarus (1)-back from the dead
content.introtext:
Lessons from Lazarus (1)-back from the dead

'But even now I know...' John 11:22 NKJ

Lazarus; the second most famous guy to die and come back to life! Not surprisingly, we can learn loads of stuff from his story, and we're going to look at that over the next two days.

Lesson one: Jesus knows how you feel. He knows what it's like to lose someone you care about (read John 11:35-36). God isn't a holy power-pack who raises the dead, He totally sympathises with us too.

Lesson two: Jesus can give you back what life's taken from you. Claim the promise of Joel 2:25. Martha (Lazarus' sister) realised that with God, it's never too late. She said, 'Lord, if You had been here, my brother would not have died. But even now I know that whatever You ask of God, God will give You.' (John 11:21-22 NKJ) Don't pray 'if only', but pray 'even now I know' with faith that God can do it.

Lesson three: Jesus can set you free. Read the story in John 11 for yourself, and see how God's Word was greater than the grave clothes that bound Lazarus. It's greater than whatever it is that binds or limits you too.

You may not completely understand it, but if you trust that He knows what you're going through, He can restore what you've lost. And He will set you free! Pray that your faith will grow and you'll be amazed that things that seem impossible will be changed by God.

SoulFood: 1 Kings 18:16-20:43, Mark 12:28-44, Ps 113, Pr 12:15-17

content.title: Lessons from Lazarus (2)-the bigger picture
content.introtext:
Lessons from Lazarus (2)-the bigger picture

'...that the Son of God may be glorified through it.' John 11:4 NKJ

The next three lessons today:

Lesson four: God has a bigger and better plan in mind. You may wonder why Jesus waited four days before sorting Lazarus out. Here are two reasons: (a) so there would be no doubt about the miracle. In those days lots of Jews believed the spirit only left the dead body when four days had past. So if Jesus had stepped in earlier, they'd have claimed that Lazarus wasn't really dead (b) so that our faith is strengthened. Jesus said, 'I am glad for your sakes that I was not there, that you may believe...' (John 11:15 NKJ) In life, crises will come and go, and be different each time. What must always stay strong is your faith.

Lesson five: God will ask you to face the facts and deal with the stench. Martha wanted Lazarus to be alive, but didn't want the stink of death when the stone moved. When you're praying and God tells you to do something, it's for a reason; until you do it, you can't win! So move your stone and face that stink!

Lesson six: God wants to make you a living testimony. Everywhere Lazarus went afterwards, he didn't even have to open his mouth to proclaim that Jesus was his Lord; his life spoke loud and clear. God's saved you and raised you up to do the same. Don't just talk the talk, but walk the walk too. Is your life a living testimony today?

SoulFood: Ex 16:1-35, Jn 6:30-40

content.title: You're in it together
content.introtext:
You're in it together

'...whatever you do, whether in word or deed, do it all in the name of the Lord Jesus...' Colossians 3:17 NIV

Every one of us has to work in some way, whether it's at school, college, uni, job or home. But most of us 'work' by ourselves which we're not meant to do. We're told to do everything in the name of Jesus, not just some things. So today, why not make the decision, whatever you're doing, to do it together with Jesus? Tell Him now that you want to go through the day with Him. John Ortberg says: '...when you have a tough problem, ask Him for help. When you have a difficult decision to make, ask Him for wisdom, then listen and be really open. When you find your energy flagging, ask Him for renewed strength. When you find your attitude turning negative, ask Him to re-focus your heart...Every few hours... pause for two or three minutes. Thank Him for His help. Hand Him your worries. Ask for His energy. Every moment is an opportunity to be with Jesus. When you forget, and you will, when you mess up, and you will, remember this really important rule: there's to be no beating yourself up! Every moment is another chance. God just keeps sending them. That's grace. Every moment ... is a new chance for you to be with Him.' Remember, Jesus wants you and Him to be in it together-so why not make that your mission today, and give it a go.'

SoulFood: 1 Kings 21-22, Mark 13:1-11, Ps 82, Pr 12:18-19

content.title: From scabs to salvation!
content.introtext:
From scabs to salvation!
'As He was going into a village, ten men with leprosy came toward Him...' Luke 17:12 CEV

Imagine...your fingers so numb and damaged you can't work, next your toes, and you can't walk. Now your internal organs are failing. You're all scabby, and every day you lose a bit more life-then a guy speaks to you, and suddenly you're not dying a slow, painful death anymore... you're completely restored! Read all about it in Luke 17:11-19.
Ok, so things may not be nearly that bad for you, but here are five helpful hints if you feel like you're losing more bits of yourself every day: (1) Turn to Jesus-make the choice to let Him help, and He'll give you back your peace and joy. (2) Shout to Him! -if you want something desperately, act like it! Lift up your voice to God, and He will hear. (3) Do it! Just do what He tells you; faith doesn't demand a reason! Don't try and bargain with God; it doesn't work! Your experience won't be the same as everyone else's. Some Jesus spoke to, some He touched, some He told to go; and they were all healed. You've got to walk it out (Luke 17:14). Each step brings you closer-but nothing happens 'til you take that first step of faith. (4) Praise Him! Only one of the ten came back and said thanks to Jesus; and He noticed. So don't forget your manners; it's much easier to ask for help next time if you've said thanks this time.
SoulFood: Rev 1-4, Mark 13:12-23, Ps 117, Pr 12: 20-22

content.title: Self-controlled, not a control freak!
content.introtext:
Self-controlled, not a control freak!
'...the fruit of the spirit is...self-control...' Galatians 5:22-23 NIV

Everyone knows a control-freak; you know the type. Everything has to be done their way, but if anything goes wrong, it's something or someone else's fault-the weather, the devil, the in-laws! These blame games are just the surface of a need to manipulate every situation. But people don't like being manipulated, so a control-freak's relationships end up turning into power struggles. The more they try to control, the worse they feel; the worse they feel, the more they try to control. No-one wins. Don't let yourself be a control freak.
Instead, be self controlled. Understand that the devil can't do anything without your co-operation; and you don't have to give it! Listen, other people's actions and attitudes aren't your problem, but how you deal with them is. Remind yourself that: (a) the one person you need to control is you (b) sometimes you just have to hand people to God to let Him deal with them (c) you must ask daily for the Holy Spirit's power to help you control your reactions (check out 2 Timothy 1:7).
If you do that, you'll avoid becoming a blamer. You won't turn relationships into war zones. Knowing that 'the fruit of the spirit is...self-control' means understanding that the spirit won't control you, or help you control others-but will empower you to control yourself. Being self-controlled helps you to leave behind the problem to become part of the solution that God is bringing about.

SoulFood: Rev 5-9, Mark 13:24-37, Ps 121, Pr 12: 23-24

content.title: Gotta get through this!
content.introtext:
Gotta get through this!
'...keep your mind on Jesus... then you won't get discouraged and give up.' Hebrews 12:3 CEV

Tough times suck! Especially when you don't know why everything is so pear-shaped. It's easy to be left with questions or doubts when you don't get a quick-fix answer through prayer, reading your Bible, or asking your leaders. But don't worry; you're in good company! David constantly asked 'Why?' in the Psalms and God didn't give up on him. God knew he would stick at it and get through it (Acts 13:22). Endurance isn't just about coping in tough times, but also about growing through them, and using your experience for God's glory.
When you feel like you're not getting answers to 'why?', start thinking, 'I gotta get through this,' and ask how you can. Today's Bible verse says: 'keep your mind on Jesus'. Keep looking forwards. Jesus endured '...the shame of being nailed to a cross, because He knew...later on He would be glad...' (Hebrews 12:2 CEV) Why would He be glad later? Because He was looking ahead, to the result of His perseverance: pleasing His Father, building His church and saving a lost world.
Have the same end result in focus: to please God your Father, to build the church, and to play your part in saving a lost world! So get yourself a 'Gotta get through this' mentality. Keep your eyes fixed on Jesus and He'll give you the strength to last it out, and fight on through to victory.

SoulFood: Rev 10-14, Mark 14:1-11, Ps 4, Pr 12:25

content.title: From dreams to reality...
content.introtext:
From dreams to reality...
'Those who sow in tears will reap with...joy.' Psalm 126:5 NIV

Do you want the good news or bad news first? Well whatever, we're going to start with the not-so-good news. When God gives you a dream to fulfil, your mates might help you on the way and cheer you on, but to see it through to the end, you'll probably have to water that dream with some tears too. Friendship can't lower the price tag of personal sacrifice that comes with God-given dreams. Sorry, there's no mid-season sale there!
But, the better-than-great news is that God promises when you water with your tears, there will be an awesome harvest. Read on from today's verse and you'll see!
It's important to recognise which part of the dream you're at. Is it time to weep or to reap? If you're in the time for tears, that's not an excuse to listen to emo music all night, turn passive and complain that life's not fair. It's about getting passionate about the stuff God's put on your heart, and crying out to Him to sort it out.
To know when it's time to pick all that lovely juicy fruit, you need to understand that everything in life has a season. Fruit won't grow before its time, and there's no point picking it too early or out of season; it'll just be like a watery strawberry or a rock hard pear. So get crying, and grow yourself some fruit!

SoulFood: Rev 15-18, Mark 14:12-26, Ps 124, Pr 12:26

content.title: Triple A and you're on your way!
content.introtext:
Triple A and you're on your way!
'...like newborn babies, long for the pure milk of the Word, so that...you may grow...' 1 Peter 2:2 NAS

Authors Howard & William Hendricks point out three 'A's' we need get sorted when it comes to reading our Bibles:
(1) Attitude: a baby grabs a bottle with a smile and we should grab our Bibles with a smile too. Just like babies need milk to live physically, we need God's Word to live spiritually.
(2) Appetite: you know when you're really hungry, you just can't wait for dinner, and you'd do anything to eat right now? That's what we should be like with the Bible! Psalm 19:10 says that it's 'sweeter than honey' but looking at our enthusiasm (or lack of it) for Bible study, half the time you'd think it was more like grim medicine-it tastes like sour milk but good for you in some weird way. We should think of reading God's Word like tucking into our favourite food; can't wait to eat it and can't get enough of it! Get hungry for God's word!
(3) Aim: the aim of Bible study is to grow, to help us be more like Jesus, to live transformed lives. It wasn't written just to satisfy curiosity, make you smarter or so you could learn geeky facts!
So don't just read it-study it, and see how much you change in the process.

SoulFood: Rev 19-22, Mark 14:27-42, Ps 129, Pr 12: 27-28

content.title: The best trip ever!
content.introtext:
The best trip ever!
'...they were waiting for a better country-a heavenly country...' Hebrews 11:16 NCV

Think about the best holiday you've been on. Or maybe you've not yet had the opportunity to go on the holiday of a lifetime, so where would it be? Somewhere full of action, like Disneyland? Maybe exploring a historic European city? Or would adventure be your thing? White-water rafting, surfing or skiing? The Bible tells us in Ecclesiastes 3:11 NLT that 'He [God] has planted eternity in the human heart', that is, each one of us hopes for a special kind of trip, the best trip ever! All of us, at some point, think about life after death and the opportunity of spending eternity in a better place-Heaven.
The Bible tells us that Heaven is the best destination ever! You don't have to save up for it, or worry about extra baggage charges; it's completely free! No struggling with your suitcase, coz everything you need and more will be provided there for you! It will never disappoint nor will it end.
How do you get to go? Listen: '...if you confess with your mouth, "Jesus is Lord", and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved.' (Romans 10:9 NIV) Why is it so important to believe Jesus is risen? Because if He isn't, then you can't be either. That's right-when God makes all things new (see Revelation 21) you'll get a Jesus-style resurrected body to enjoy it! Now isn't that a sweet deal!

SoulFood: 2 Kings 5:1- 14, John 5:1-15

content.title: Alien invasion
content.introtext:
Alien invasion
'...they were waiting for a better country-a heavenly country...' Hebrews 11:16 NCV

Have you ever wondered 'Is there anybody out there? Do aliens exist?' Well you're not on your own. Even the media captures our imaginations with films and TV programmes about alien life and space. Scientists experiment to 'boldly go where no man has gone before'! Did you know that the Bible talks about aliens? And get this; the aliens are us! Now before you go running to the mirror to check you've not just turned green and grown an extra head, check out what alien actually means: a foreigner, a stranger.
Today find time to read Hebrews 11. You'll hear about great men and women of faith like Noah, Abraham, Joseph, and Rahab:
* because of their faith in God they did incredible things; they were 'powerful in battle and routed foreign armies...received back their dead, raised to life again.'
* because of their faith in God they suffered, they 'faced jeers and flogging... others were... put in prison. They were... put to death... went about... destitute, persecuted and mistreated.'
They all had one thing in common: 'living by faith when they died... admitted that they were aliens and strangers on earth...' They knew that 'God had planned something better.' Each one of them was 'waiting for a better country-a heavenly one.' What about you? Do you know that God has got something better for you? Well, He does!

SoulFood: 2 Kings 1:1-4:17, Mark 14:43-52, Ps 1, Pr 13:1

content.title: OUCH!
content.introtext:
OUCH!
'Careless words stab like a sword, but wise words bring healing.' Proverbs 12:18 NCV

Have you heard the saying, 'sticks and stones may break my bones but words will never hurt me'? It's not true, is it? Words can really hurt! And God knows: 'Careless words stab like a sword!' Ouch! They can be extremely destructive; check out these two situations:
Scene 1: an altar boy in a small country church. One day he accidentally dropped the communion wine. The priest slapped him and shouted, 'Leave, and don't come back!' That boy grew up to be General Tito, the brutal communist dictator who ruled the people of Yugoslavia for years.
Scene 2: an altar boy in a big city cathedral. One day he accidentally dropped the communion wine. His bishop turned to him and whispered reassuringly, 'It's ok, some day you'll be a great priest.' That boy grew up to be Archbishop Fulton Sheen, whose sermons touched the hearts of millions on national television.
Words either build people up or tear them down. YOUR words either build people up or tear people down. When you speak, make sure no-one says, 'OUCH!' You must do these things to enjoy life and have many happy days. You must not say evil things (see 1 Peter 3:10). Feeling hurt by someone's words? Then let God's Word build you up: You are '...fearfully and wonderfully made...' (Psalm 139:14 NIV), '...My unfailing love for you will not be shaken...' (Isaiah 54:10 NIV)

SoulFood: 2 Kings 4:18-6:33, Mark 14:53-65, Ps 48, Pr 13:2-3

content.title: Sleeping habits
content.introtext:
Sleeping habits
'...The Lord gives sleep to those He loves.' Psalm 127:2 NCV

Catching Zeds. Land of nod. Catnap. Dreamland. Dozing. SLEEP: we all need it! And your sleeping habits are important to God!
SLEEP: do you try to avoid it by living off energy drinks? Miss out on two or three days because you do too much of it? Messed up or missed out because of lack of it? You know what? It's hard to think, feel and act like Jesus when you're tired and lacking sleep. That's why God is concerned about your sleeping habits. He wants to 'give sleep to those he loves'. That's you! Here's how to rest and get the best sleeping habits.
Stressed? : Jesus says, 'Come to Me...you who are tired and have heavy loads... learn from Me... and you will find rest for your lives.' (Matthew 11:28-29 NCV)
Lethargic? : 'He gives strength to those who are tired and more power to those who are weak.' (Isaiah 40:29 NCV)
Everything will be ok! : 'He lets me rest... He leads me on paths that are right... I will not be afraid.' (Psalm 23:2-4 NCV)
Every week! : 'Anyone who enters God's rest will rest from his work as God did.' (Hebrews 4:10 NCV)
Promise! : 'God has left us the promise that we may enter His rest, let us be very careful so none... fail to enter.' (Hebrews 4:1 NCV)
Stressed? Lethargic? Everything will be ok, Every week, Promise! SLEEP WELL :)

SoulFood: 2 Kings 7-9, Mark 14:66-72, Ps 132:1-10, Pr 13:4-6

content.title: Love letters (1)
content.introtext:
Love letters (1)
'...You have left the love you had in the beginning.' Revelation 2:4 NCV

Imagine getting a letter from Jesus! How amazing would that be?
There you are, sitting in Church. It's just like any other Sunday until there's an announcement; your Church has received a letter directly from the Name Above All Names Himself. Wow! It starts off great. Jesus obviously knows what's happening and He seems pretty chuffed with it all. Then the letter continues, 'But I have this against you: You have left the love you had in the beginning.' Your heart sinks! Your Church has been so busy doing stuff, forgetting who they're doing it for! They've stopped loving Jesus!
Your immediate reaction is: What? You look around the congregation to see who's responsible; after all it couldn't possibly be your fault, right? But the letter continues: Jesus is holding you all responsible! He's disappointed with you all. Gutted! You think it's all over. But then you realise that Jesus is telling you how to fix the problem and there is hope.
That's pretty much what happened to the Church in Ephesus (read all about it in Revelation 2!) but every day the same thing is happening in churches all over the world. We need to stop, listen and then ask Jesus to help us put right what we're doing wrong. We need to fix our eyes on Him once again and rediscover our first love for Him. After all, He promises: '...I will build My Church...' (Matthew 16:18 NCV)

SoulFood: 2 Kings 10-12, Mark 15:1-20, Ps 132:11-18, Pr 13:7-8

content.title: Love letters (2)
content.introtext:
Love letters (2)
'...You have left the love you had in the beginning.' Revelation 2:4 NCV

If you've ever fallen in love you'll recognise the symptoms: Your mind is consumed with thoughts of the other person, you can't stop talking to them, texting, emailing. You chat online, over the phone and can't wait for the moment when you are in each other's company for that special one-to-one time! You want to know everything about them-what they like, what they don't like-you laugh with them, you cry with them, you want to share everything about you with them. Being in love affects how you act, what you choose to do or not do. Being in love is wonderful... but then comes that awful moment when you realise that person isn't quite so interested in you anymore. They seem a bit distant, they don't talk to you as much, there's no more silly texts or loving gifts... until there's... no more... they have left you... and your heart breaks!
When Jesus said to the Church in Ephesus, 'You have left the love you had in the beginning,' He was talking about Himself. They had left Him! He was still there, but they had left Him, alone, heartbroken. They didn't love Him anymore!
When love is gone you miss out on all the benefits that person brought into your life. If you're like the Church in Ephesus and have walked away from Jesus and stopped loving Him, then you need to bring that love back, so you don't miss out.

SoulFood: 2 Kings 13-15, Mark 15:21-32, Ps 143, Pr 13:9-10

content.title: Love letters (3)
content.introtext:
Love letters (3)
'...You have left the love you had in the beginning.' Revelation 2:4 NCV

Your computer crashes so you ring the helpline to try to get it sorted out. Your mobile dies so take it to the shop, hoping they'll swap it for a new one. But how can you fix a relationship that's gone horribly wrong?
What if, just like the Church in Ephesus, you've stopped loving Jesus? How do you fix that? Can you fix it? Should you fix it? YES! All you need to do is remember!
Remember the best times you had with Jesus: Jesus said, '...I came to give life-life in all its fullness.' (John 10:10 NCV) Remember what Jesus has done: 'In Christ we are set free... we have forgiveness of sins.' (Ephesians 1:7 NCV) Remember what you did then, that you don't do now: '...give yourselves completely to God. Stand against the devil and he will run from you.' (James 4:7 NCV) Remember what you would be missing out on: 'When people's steps follow the Lord, God is pleased with their ways. If they stumble, they will not fall, because the Lord holds their hand.' (Psalm 37:23-24 NCV) Remember, whatever is troubling you, Jesus can help: Jesus said, 'Don't let your hearts be troubled...trust in Me.' (John 14:1 NCV) Remember that Jesus has never stopped loving you: 'Nothing...in the whole world will ever be able to separate us from the love of God that is in ...Jesus...' (Romans 8:39 NCV)
'Come near to God and God will come near to you...' (James 4:8 NCV)

SoulFood: 2 Kings 16:1-18:16, Mark 15:33-47, Ps 80:1-11, Pr 13:11-12

content.title: Keep the good stuff
content.introtext:
Keep the good stuff
'We have this treasure from God, but we are like clay jars that hold the treasure...'
2 Corinthians 4:7 NCV

Chocolate! Practically everyone enjoys munching on a morsel of a tasty tantalising treat of chocoliciousness! Chocolate's everywhere, tantalising shoppers with their bright wrappers and foil linings... Ok this isn't a commercial break; you get the picture!
Anyway the point is, as soon as you're out of the shop with your chocolate bar, are you interested in the wrapper? Er, no; it's what's inside that matters. You're after the chocolate! That shiny wrapper is no longer of interest; it's just rubbish! So if you were to throw the chocolate away and eat the wrapper, everyone would think you'd gone crazy, right? After all, why throw away the best bit and leave yourself with the rubbish? Madness! The wrapper is only attractive when it's got the chocolate inside.
In a similar way, our lives become attractive to others when they are filled with Jesus. We only find our true purpose when we put Jesus at the centre of our lives. That's why Paul says, 'We have this treasure from God, but we are like clay jars that hold the treasure.' Treasure in clay pots; chocolate in plastic wrappers; same difference. Keep your ego in check. Paul says: 'We have this treasure,' he didn't say we are the treasure!

SoulFood: Gen 11:1-9, Phil 2:1-11

content.title: FAITH ATTACK!
content.introtext:
FAITH ATTACK!
'...use the shield of faith...' Ephesians 6:16 NCV

Today let's have a 'faith attack' by answering the question 'what is true faith?'
Believing: Believing Jesus is who He says He is (John 8:24). Trusting: Trusting Jesus will do what He's said (John 6:40). Only found in Jesus: Not another religion or well-meaning people (Acts 20:21). Confident in God: Being certain what God has said will happen, will happen! (Hebrews11:1). Grow: Helping you to be useful and productive (2 Peter 1:5-8). Used: If you don't use it, you lose it! (James 2:14). Powerful: A little can do much! (Luke17:5-6) Given by God: It's a free gift that saves us (Ephesians 2:8-9).
The Bible tells us in Ephesians 6, that true faith is often revealed in us when we're under attack from the enemy. And when you see what it does, you can understand why! But we need never worry, because God gives us all we need to protect ourselves. We have spiritual armour, but don't just read about it-use it!
A Roman soldier's shield protected him from head to toe. It was made of iron, upholstered in thick layers of fabric, and saturated in water when going to battle. Consequently the flaming arrows of the enemy fizzled on contact. Today '...put on the full armour of God...take up the shield of faith, with which you can extinguish all the flaming arrows of the evil one.' (Ephesians 6:13-16 NIV)

SoulFood: 2 Kings 18:17-20:21, Mark 16:1-20, Ps 80:12-19, Pr 13:13-16

content.title: Happy Days :)
content.introtext:
Happy Days :)
'...when you have many... troubles, you should be full of joy.' James 1:2 NCV

You stand in front of the mirror scrutinising every inch of your face. Agonising that your nose is too big and you're getting another spot; right on the end of it. That boiled egg you made isn't runny, your toast's gone soggy and the milk's run out! You're washing up your breakfast dishes and you drop your phone in the sink. You wipe it dry but the screen is blank. And now you can't find your keys and the dog's taken your wallet and gone off to bury it. It's only 8 am and already you're thinking (delete as appropriate): (a) could this day get any worse? (b) Aaaaagggggggggggghhhh! (c) I'm gonna kick that dog! (d) all these troubles are making me full of joy!
So are you thinking (a), (b), (c) or (d)? How many of us naturally think (d)? But that's what God wants us to do; '...when you have many kinds of troubles, you should be full of joy, because you know that these troubles test your faith, and this will give you patience. Let your patience show itself perfectly in what you do. Then you will be perfect and complete and have everything that you need.' (James 1:2 NCV) When God puts it like that, you can see what He's saying, can't you?

SoulFood: 2 Kings 21-23, Luke 1:1-10, Ps 73:1-16, Pr 13:17-19

content.title: Double standards.
content.introtext:
Double standards.
'...You are like tombs that are painted white...' Matthew 23:27 NCV

When you read about the life of Jesus in the first four books of the New Testament- Matthew, Mark, Luke and John- you often come across a group of people called the Pharisees. They were a powerful group of Jewish religious leaders. They didn't believe Jesus was the Son of God, instead they were convinced He was a devious impostor. They followed Jesus around everywhere, constantly trying to trick Him, so they could arrest Him. But their questioning of Jesus suddenly came to an end one day when Jesus asked them a question they were unable to answer. After that they were too scared to ask any more! Read about it in Matthew 22:41-46.
Jesus wasn't impressed with their behaviour at all. He said to them, 'Pharisees! You are hypocrites! You are like tombs that are painted white. Outside, those tombs look fine, but inside, they are full of the bones of dead people and all kinds of unclean things.' (Matthew 23:27 NCV)
How sad! The Bible tells us that, '...People look at the outside of a person, but the Lord looks at the heart...' (1 Samuel 16:7 NCV) Jesus knew that the Pharisees made themselves look great to people watching, but inside their thoughts and attitudes were all wrong. Jesus let the Pharisees know they were getting it wrong, big time, with their double standards! Don't you make the same mistake!

SoulFood: 2 Kings 24-25, Luke 1:11-25, Ps 73:17-28, Pr 13:20

content.title: The meaning of life
content.introtext:
The meaning of life
'...I urge you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received...' Ephesians 4:1 NIV

Paul says, 'I urge you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received.' What would that life look like?
Well, that life isn't about keeping score. It's not about how many friends you have on Facebook, and it's not about who you've dated, are dating or haven't dated but would like to! It isn't about what sport you play or how well you did or didn't play last week. It's not about your shoes or your hair or the colour of your skin, or where you live or go to school. In fact, it's not about grades, money, clothes or even about whether that university accepts you or not. Life isn't about if you have lots of friends, or if you are alone, and it's not about how accepted or unaccepted you are. Life just isn't about that.
But life is about choosing to love, not hate. It's about trust, contentment and compassion. It's about sticking up for your friends and praying for your enemies. Life is about avoiding jealousy, overcoming ignorance and encouraging others. It's about what you say and what you mean. It's about seeing people for who they are and not what they have. Most of all, it's about choosing to use your life to touch someone else's in a way that could never have been achieved otherwise. These choices are what life's about.

SoulFood: Hosea 1-5, Luke 1:26-38, Ps 139:1-6, Pr 13:21-23

content.title: How Much?
content.introtext:
How Much?
'...you are precious...I love you...' Isaiah 43:4 NIV

'How much are the puppies?' the boy asked the pet shop owner. 'Anything from $75 to $125,' he replied. 'Can I have a look at them?' One puppy was lagging behind the rest and straight away the boy asked, 'What's wrong with that one?' The pup didn't have a hip socket. It would always limp.
'That's the one I want to buy,' said the boy. 'You don't want to buy that little dog', said the shopkeeper. 'If you really want him, I'll just give him to you.' The boy looked sad. 'I don't want you to give him to me. That little dog is worth every bit as much as all the other dogs and I'll pay full price'. The shopkeeper insisted, 'You really don't want to buy this one. He's never going to be able to play like the other puppies.' The boy stood back from the counter and revealed his own badly twisted leg, supported by a metal brace, 'Well I don't run so well myself, and this little puppy will need someone who understands!'
We can sometimes think we are useless, not worth as much as everyone else. But Jesus knows differently: 'But God shows His great love for us in this way: Christ died for us while were still sinners.' (Romans 5:8 NCV) Psalm 139:2-3 NCV says 'You know my thoughts... You know where I go... You know everything I do...' We can sometimes think that no-one understands us, but God does!

SoulFood: Hosea 6-10, Luke 1:39-56, Ps 139:7-12, Pr 13:24

content.title: Just say No!
content.introtext:
Just say No!
'...put all evil things out of your life...' Colossians 3:5 NCV

Ever had one of those stuffed toys where you squeeze the paw and it barks, moos or whatever - depends on the animal I guess :) Anyway, one that says "Jesus says no!" might be a real asset with our daily decision making. The only way we are going to 'Put all evil things out of our lives' is by saying, 'Jesus says no!' and making good choices that let nothing evil into our lives. And if anything is in there already or sneaks in through a window, 'put these things out of your life.' (Colossians 3:8 NCV)
The best way to keep bad things out of your life is by filling your life up with good things. Here are four good things the Bible teaches us to do to start us off: (1) stop craving things you don't need. Instead enjoy what you've got (2) if you're not giving generously to God's work, start now! Make a habit of giving away a percentage of whatever comes your way. 'Give freely and become more wealthy; be stingy and lose everything.' (Proverbs 11:24-25 NLT) Yes, even give a bit of your pocket money-even 50c of that five bucks from your Nana! (3) trust God completely, with everything. God guarantees to 'supply all your needs.' (Philippians 4:19 NLT)
Go ahead, do it! Obey God, be patient, and watch what happens.

SoulFood: Hosea 11-14, Luke 1:57-66, Ps 139:13-24, Pr 13:25

content.title: It's kickin' off in here!
content.introtext:
It's kickin' off in here!
'...fight hard for the faith...' Jude 3:3 NCV

Is God really telling us to fight? And not just fight, but fight hard? Well, before you go punching someone's lights out, listen up! God isn't telling you to 'kick off' every time someone disagrees with what you believe. Nor is He telling you to 'beat the living daylights' out of any of your mates who try and talk you out of going to Church! And He's definitely not asking you to have a slanging match with the next person who calls you a 'Bible Basher'!
If someone is overweight, then they might be encouraged to 'fight the flab'. This doesn't mean they are being asked to beat themselves up literally, does it? What they're saying is use all your inner strength and willpower to keep those kilos from piling on. Eat all the right foods and take the right exercise to make this possible.
In a similar way, when God tells us, 'Fight hard for the faith,' He is asking us to do everything we can to keep our focus and attention on Jesus. Don't compromise what the Bible tells you. Believe it and live by it! Fighting involves: (1) Training: Don't get discouraged and give up. (2)Readiness: There's no time off being a Christian! (3) Action: Fight to win! 'I do not mean that I am already as God wants me to be... but I continue trying to reach it and make it mine...' (Philippians 3:12 NCV)

SoulFood: 1 Kings 17:1-7, 1 Kings 18:41-46, Mark 4:35-41

content.title: Don't be a Drifter
content.introtext:
Don't be a Drifter
'...fight hard for the faith...' Jude 3:3 NCV

There's nothing like the feeling of just lying back on an inflatable lilo as it bobs up and down on the gentle waves. Mmmm, the sun shining down, just close your eyes for a minute and reeeelax. Then AAAAH! You open your eyes and you've drifted out to sea on the tide! One minute you're catching the rays, bobbing around the waves, and now you're way out at sea fighting for your life! Maybe you think you'd never be stupid enough to do that but you could still be a drifter. If you've ever day-dreamed, drifted away in your thoughts when you should have been paying attention in class or in a meeting, or during the pastor's talk on a Sunday, then listen up today.
Drifting can be a dangerous habit, because it makes you think everything is ok until it's too late! Drift off in class and it's no problem until you're sitting with that exam paper in front of you and you don't know the answers! Hebrews 2:1 says, 'We must pay more careful attention, therefore, to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away.' God's telling us that it's important we pay attention to the truth about Him, otherwise we'll drift away and believe lies. Paying careful attention is hard work! Every day pray: 'Today God, help me live so close to You, that whoever comes into contact with me, comes into contact with You!'

SoulFood: Jer 1-3, Luke 1:67-80, Ps 144:1-8, Pr 14:1-4

content.title: Keep it real!
content.introtext:
Keep it real!
'I thank my God every time I remember you.' Philippians 1:3 NIV

Revision! Uggh! Exams! Aargh! Trying to recall, names, dates, places, symbols, formulas, equations! Remembering things can be so difficult! But when life gets really difficult, it's important to remember good things. Paul was a prisoner in Rome when he wrote to the Church at Philippi. But he didn't write to have a moan or to ask for a cake with a file in! 'I thank my God every time I remember you.' Paul's letter was really cheerful! 'Be full of joy in the Lord always. I will say again, be full of joy.' (Philippians 4:4 NCV) How encouraging it must have been for the Philippians to receive a letter like that! Hearing how he was praying for them!
Paul got it right. When life's full of more downs than ups, it's good to stop and think about all the good people God has brought into your life, who have encouraged you and supported you and then, take some time to let them know you're thanking God for them! But don't just wait 'til life gets tough! Let those who have encouraged you always be a part of your life. P-ray for them and let them know you're thinking of them, A-ct on the good stuff they've taught you, R-emember them often, T-hank God for bringing them into your life and ask Him to help you become a great encouragement to someone too!

SoulFood: Jer 4-6, Luke 2:1-7, Ps 144:9-15, Pr 14:5-8

content.title: Just do it!
content.introtext:
Just do it!
'...God made us to do good works, which God planned in advance for us to live our lives doing.' Ephesians 2:10 NCV

Being a Christian is about having a living relationship with Jesus that affects the way we live life every day. As we listen to Him and follow in His footsteps our lives start to look radically different from the people around us. Mother Teresa's life is an example of that. This was written on a sign on the wall of her children's home in Calcutta:
'People are often unreasonable, illogical, and self-centred; forgive them anyway. If you are kind, people may accuse you of selfish, ulterior motives; be kind anyway. If you are successful, you will win some false friends and some true enemies; succeed anyway. If you are honest and frank, people may cheat you; be honest and frank anyway. What you spend years building, someone could destroy overnight; build anyway. If you find happiness, they may be jealous; be happy anyway. The good you do today, people will often forget tomorrow; do good anyway. Give the world the best you have, and it may never be enough; give the world the best you've got anyway. You see, in the final analysis, it is between you and God; it was never between you and them anyway.'
'God made you to do good works, which God planned in advance for you' to live your life doing. Don't worry about what everyone else is doing or not doing; you just go ahead and do the good works He's planned you to do.

SoulFood: Jer 7-9, Luke 2:8-20, Ps 8, Pr 14:9-12
