content.title: Words need to be spoken
content.introtext:
Words need to be spoken

'Anxiety in the heart of man causes depression, but a good word makes it glad.' Proverbs 12:25 NKJ

Words. They are everywhere. It's hard to imagine the world without them, isn't it? The world would just cease to function. Not many things in this life are as powerful as the right words spoken at the right time. But that works backwards too; words that should've been said but never were can be a heavy burden to live with. How many people are overcome with emotion at the funeral of a relative because they realise there are so many things they wished they'd said but no longer have the chance?
The great king Solomon was a master of words and his dad David wasn't too bad either! In one of his books (Ecclesiastes) Solomon really spends a lot of time wondering what life is really all about. He wrestles with all sorts of mind-boggling questions. He comes to this conclusion: 'There is...a time to speak.' (Ecclesiastes 3:1; 3:7) But as we all know, time waits for no man, and when it's over, it's over. So make sure you don't find yourself standing in the future carrying a sackful of unspoken words someone close to you desperately needed to hear. Again Solomon said, 'Pleasant words are a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.' (Proverbs 16:24 NIV) He's dead right, you know. So ask God right now to help you find the courage, and the opportunity, to say what you have to say.
SoulFood: Num 19-21, Mark 6:30-44, Ps 37:16-24, Pr 11:4

content.title: How to defeat your giant
content.introtext:
How to defeat your giant


'...the battle is the Lord's...' 1 Samuel 17:47 NKJ

It's amazing that we get to use the name 'Christian' to describe ourselves. You know what that means right? It means follower of Christ! So walk tall today and live a life worthy of the One whose name you carry. And don't be surprised when the giants of this world see you walking tall and try to knock you down. Maybe you'll find yourself facing fear, lust, pride, envy or anger, resentment or addiction. Whatever, you must realise:
(1) Giants start small. Goliath wasn't always a giant; he was fed every day until he became one. Our giants are usually little sins we feed until they grow so big and ugly we struggle to kick them out of our lives.
(2) Giants are bullies. Your giant will bully you for as long as you keep his existence a secret. But bullies hate people who have friends-especially powerful friends like Jesus! David told Goliath, '...this is the Lord's battle, and He will give you to us!' (1 Samuel 17:47 NLT)
(3) Giants need confronting head-on. The Bible says: 'As Goliath moved closer to attack, David quickly ran...to meet him.' (1 Samuel 17:48 NLT) Don't run away, don't try to negotiate or make excuses. Use the trusty weapon God has given you: His Word. And above all, don't look at God in the light of your giant, look at your giant in the light of God.
SoulFood: Num 16-18, Mark 6:14-29, Ps 37: 8-15, Pr 11:3

content.title: You'll get through this storm
content.introtext:
You'll get through this storm

'Don't be afraid,' He said. 'Take courage! I am here!' Mark 6:50 NLT

What's the weather like where you are today? No, don't look out of the window! What are the conditions in your heart? Listen: 'Late that night, the disciples were in their boat in the middle of the lake, and Jesus was alone on land. He saw that they were in serious trouble, rowing hard and struggling against the wind and waves. About three o'clock in the morning Jesus came toward them, walking on the water. He intended to go past them, but when they saw Him walking on the water, they cried out in terror, thinking He was a ghost... But Jesus spoke to them at once. "Don't be afraid," He said. "Take courage! I am here!" Then He climbed into the boat, and the wind stopped. They were totally amazed...' (Mark 6:47-51 NLT)
Often it's when our life is at its most stormy that God teaches us the biggest lessons. Dave Dravecky was a top sportsman whose baseball career was ended by cancer 20 years ago. He lost his career but thankfully he kept his life! Here's what he has to say: 'Looking back... I have learned that the wilderness is part of the landscape of faith, and every bit as essential as the mountaintop. On the mountaintop we are overwhelmed by God's presence. In the wilderness we are overwhelmed by His absence. Both places should bring us to our knees; the one, in utter awe; the other, in utter dependence.' So fix your eyes on Jesus and don't worry about the weather.
SoulFood: 2 Kings 5:1-27, Matt 6:19-34, Acts 5:1-11

content.title: On guard!
content.introtext:
On guard!


'It is better to trust in the Lord than to put confidence in man.' Psalm 118:8 KJV

Jesus said, 'Can all your worries add a single moment to your life?' (Matthew 6:27 NLT) Of course not! Worry changes nothing. When was the last time you solved a problem by worrying about it? Imagine somebody saying, 'I got behind on my bills so I decided to worry my way out of debt. And you know, it worked!' You can't add one day to your life or one bit of life to your day by worrying; all worry will do is bring you wrinkles and grey hairs!
Listen to these two Scriptures: 'Those who trust in the Lord are like Mount Zion, which cannot be shaken but endures forever.' (Psalm 125:1 NIV); 'You will keep in perfect peace him whose mind is steadfast, because he trusts in You.' (Isaiah 26:3 NIV) We don't get up in the morning and decide, 'Today I'm going to doubt God', yet when we worry that's what we do.
Paul writes, '...His peace will guard your hearts and minds...' (Philippians 4:7 NLT) Paul uses a military word here-guard. The Philippians lived under Roman occupation and were used to seeing the centurions guarding their town. What security! Before an enemy could get to them they first had to get past the rock-hard Roman guards. And you know what? God gives you the same guarantee! His peace is not wishy washy-it is solid. Your heart and mind are completely safe if you'll let His peace stand guard. Why don't you ask Him for His peace right now?
SoulFood: Num 14-15, Mark 6:1-13, Ps 37:1-7, Pr 11:1-2

content.title: The right choice!
content.introtext:
The right choice!

'…I have come that they may have life…to the full.' John 10:10 NIV

When Jesus says, 'I have come that they may have life…to the full', He isn't talking about taking us on holiday to Disneyland or offering us a swanky pad, a faster car, the latest gadgets, fashion frenzy or a bank account that never runs dry. He isn't even offering a life free from pain or grief. He's inviting us into life as it was meant to be lived, with Him. Life with Jesus is like the difference between watching the latest movie on a black and white 10cm screen TV or on a cinema screen with surround sound. It's the difference between being robbed and being given a shed-load of the best presents ever! Jesus said, 'The thief comes to steal and kill and destroy. I have come that they may have life and have it to the full.' It's the difference between losing your life and gaining your life. John 3:16 says, 'For God so greatly loved and dearly prized the world that He [even] gave up His only begotten (unique) Son, so that whoever believes in (trusts in, clings to, relies on) Him shall not perish (come to destruction, be lost) but have eternal (everlasting) life.' (AMP) Because of Jesus we can live forever. We don't have to fear anything. We can go to Heaven and get the best out of life now. Have you made the right choice for your life?

Soulfood: Num 11-13, Mark 5:31-43, Ps 2, Pr 10:30-32

content.title: Growing our faith
content.introtext:
Growing our faith

'…faith is…the conviction of things not seen.' Hebrews 11:1 NAS

So what's the best way to grow in our faith? We can learn to trust God through the lives of other people. Reading the life stories of Christians can be a fantastic way to get to know God better. Chasing the Dragon by Jackie Pullinger or The Cross and the Switchblade by David Wilkerson are two powerful stories that reveal a lot about the life of faith in God. Ask your parents or older people in your church how they have learned to trust God over the years—you might be surprised by the stories they can tell you. But most of all, we learn to trust in God by simply doing it: by regularly stepping out in obedience and discovering that He's totally trustworthy. That happens when you take a risk with giving away your money, when you take a risk on sharing your faith with a friend or take a risk giving up your summer holiday for mission with people you don't know. Building faith is like building muscle. You strengthen and tone your muscles at the gym by repeatedly working and stretching them. In the same way, faith must be stretched. Sometimes that's uncomfortable. Obeying when God hasn't revealed the steps or the final destination can be challenging. But when we walk by faith He gets the glory, because we know we couldn't have done it without Him. So, take a leap of faith.

Soulfood: Num 8-10, Mark 5:21-30, Ps 35, Pr 10:28-29

content.title: Take a leap of faith
content.introtext:
Take a leap of faith

'…You give them something to eat.' Matthew 14:16 NKJ

Imagine this: you're in a popular band and the lead singer decides you're going to do a random freebie gig out in the sticks. You set off, stage and lighting arrives. Word spreads and people appear in masses. The show begins. It's amazing: the crowd are pumped, the beat goes on and you keep on playing. It's getting late, you're in a field in the middle of nowhere with a crowd of thousands but there's no burger vans, kebab heaven or fish & chip shop anywhere! During the next musical interlude you say, 'Look guys, as good as this is, we're going to have to stop. Look at all these people, look where we are; we need to send them away so they can get some food. They'll be starving soon.' The lead singer says, 'Go on then, you feed them,' and you laugh: 'Good one, mate, very funny.' But He's serious. He's expecting you to feed them all! Now you've got some idea of what the disciples felt like. A crowd of over 5000 hungry people. Surely sending them home seemed like the best plan? But Jesus used the moment to teach them something. The disciples had a choice: put their faith in Jesus or pack it in! They choose to act on their faith and saw over 5000 people being fed from one tiny packed lunch. A miracle! Something they'd have never seen if they'd packed it in. Faith without action isn't much good at all!

Soulfood: Num 7, Mark 5:11-20, Ps 94:12-23, Pr 10:27

content.title: The Thomas effect
content.introtext:
The Thomas effect

'…Anyone who doubts is like a wave in the sea, blown up and down by the wind.' James 1:6 NCV

Doubts! We all have them! God says 'Anyone who doubts is like a wave in the sea, blown up and down by the wind.' Does this mean that God is dissing us if we doubt? No. Have you ever watched waves roll up the beach on a beach? They crash down and creep up the sand, then suck back out, then they're back in again, then they're back out again. They're restless, they never settle. That's what we're like when we doubt; we're unsettled, restless all the time. It's not a comfortable feeling and God doesn't want us to be suffering like this. He's doesn't diss us for doubting. He encourages us to get rid of them. Thomas, one of Jesus' disciples was one serious doubter; that's where we get the phrase 'Doubting Thomas' from. So what did Jesus do? Tell him to get lost, 'don't hang around me if you can't trust me, Tom'? No way. Jesus did everything needed to help Thomas get rid of all his restless doubt and replace it with guaranteed hope, positivity, certainty, security in God. 'Then He said to Thomas, put your finger here, see My hands reach out your hand and put it into My side. Stop doubting and believe.' Thomas answered, 'My Lord and my God.''(John 20:27-28 NIV) Let Jesus in on your doubts. What He did for Thomas He will do for you.

Soulfood: Num 4:34-6:27, Mark 5:1-10, Ps 94:1-11, Pr 10:24-26

content.title: Let God do the 'heavy lifting'
content.introtext:
Let God do the 'heavy lifting'

'…it is God who works in you…' Philippians 2:13 NKJ

In our culture, the pressure to succeed can be huge. It hits us from every direction: from parents, teachers, friends and relatives, from the television and other media. But the life God wants us to live for Him is different from this. In fact, we can learn a lot from the humble straw! Imagine you've just got a freshly-poured thickshake. You grab a straw and stick it in. Now, how does this little piece of thin plastic move the thickest toughest drink known to man from the cup into your mouth? It doesn't. You do all the hard work. The straw is just the conduit. A conduit is a channel through which things (like the milkshake) move from one point to another, and you are God's conduit! You are designed to be a free-flowing channel for Jesus Christ Himself, bringing the influence and benefits of God's Kingdom wherever we go. It is God who does the hard work. You are just the conduit. The problems start when we forget this and allow ourselves to feel the pressure of making things happen in our own strength. We must be full of the Word of God, and most importantly, spend time in intimacy with the Lord in order to be God's conduit. So, today try and be more like the straw and let 'God work in you' more and more. Learn to let Him do the heavy lifting.

Soulfood: Num 3:1-4:33, Mark 4:26-41, Ps 144:9-15, Pr 10: 22-23

content.title: Liar, Liar
content.introtext:
Liar, Liar

'…those who deal truthfully are His delight.' Proverbs 12:22 NKJ

It's alright to tell a little white lie isn't it? 'The Lord detests lying lips.' (Proverbs 12:22 NIV) After all, it's not a real lie, is it? 'The Lord hates...a lying tongue.' (Proverbs 6:16-17 NLT) It's OK, everyone tells little white lies! 'You must...speak truthfully.' (Ephesians 4:25 NIV) It's impossible to be truthful all the time! 'Do not lie to each other.' (Colossians 3:9 NIV) In fact you need to lie sometimes, so you don't hurt people's feelings, right? 'Do not tell lies.' (Exodus 20:16 CEV) There's no excuse for lying, no reasons that make it acceptable. God doesn't mince His words about this. He tells us that lying is something the devil does: 'the devil...there is no truth in him...he is a liar and the father of all lies.' (John 8:44 NKJ) God lets us know that '...those who deal truthfully are His delight.' So be committed to telling the truth, it's an investment into the future: 'Truthful words stand the test of time, but lies are soon exposed.' (Proverbs 12:19 NLT) One more thing: when you avoid lying, you actually make your own life easier. Lying is hard work: you have to keep track of everything you say; otherwise you'll trip yourself up! People will know you're lying! Lying is destructive: it trashes trust, ruins relationships and creates conflict. Live truthfully and know that God delights over you.

Soulfood: 2 Kings 6:1-7, Matt 14:22-33

content.title: Gifted
content.introtext:
Gifted

'Having then gifts…let us use them…' Romans 12:6 NKJ

God has given us all gifts and talents—yes, even you! He wants you to discover them and use them because He has given you them for a reason. 'Do what you're called to do,' He says. Trouble is we can spend more time trying to be like other people instead, ending up like this crazy bunch of animals in Dr Charles Swindoll's story: 'Once upon a time, the animals decided that they should do something 'to help'. So they organised a school. The curriculum: running, climbing, swimming, and flying. The duck was excellent at swimming…and very poor in running…so he dropped swimming to practice running. This hurt his webbed feet so badly that he couldn't even swim that well anymore! The rabbit stayed at the top of his class in running, but developed a nervous twitch in his leg muscles because he had so much 'catch-up' work to do in swimming. The squirrel was excellent in climbing, but he 'was frustrated' in flying class because his teacher made him start from the ground up instead of from the treetop down…so he only got a 'C' in climbing and a 'D' in running.' Why didn't they just stick to what they were good at instead of trying to do everything? Stop concentrating on what you're not good at and start getting better at what you can do well. Enjoy being you—and excel at it!

Soulfood: Num 1-2, Mark 4:13-25, Ps 144:1-8, Pr 10:19-21

content.title: Friends
content.introtext:
Friends

'…the Spirit…makes intercession for us…' Romans 8:26 NKJ

We don't have to learn or be taught how to talk to our friends. It just happens. A little 'hi' some time ago and a friendship was born. The more you chat, the more you learn each other's likes and dislikes, hopes and dreams. Your conversations become longer, more enjoyable, sometimes intense, even heartbreaking as you share disappointments and difficulties. You begin to trust and confide. You stop worrying when you disagree—it makes you, not breaks you. You mess up, it becomes easier to say 'sorry', to forgive. When friendships keep growing like this you make not just friends but best friends! You know, that's all that prayer is—a friendship with God. You begin by saying,'hi,' you keep on communicating and soon you discover that you have the bestest of best friends. Friends make conversation easy. You don't worry about what to say next. Sometimes friends know what you're going to say before you even say it! God is the greatest at doing that; listen: 'The Holy Spirit prays for us with groanings that cannot be expressed in words. And the Father who knows all hearts knows what the Spirit is saying, for the Spirit pleads for us believers in harmony with God's own will.' (Romans 8: 26-27 NLT) God's Spirit in us speaks to God for us, making chatting to Him the easiest thing in the world. Don't over complicate it or underestimate it. Discover your bestest best friend—pray!

Soulfood: Jam 3-5, Mark 4:1-12, Ps 7:10-17, Pr 10:17-18

content.title: Questions, Questions!
content.introtext:
Questions, Questions!

'…don't worry about…what to say…' Matthew 10:19 NLT

When people know you are a Christian, they can bombard you with their thoughts and opinions. They lob really tough questions and crazy theories at you that totally wreck your head! Usually this brings about one of four reactions: (1) you give up (you back off being a Christian altogether because you don't want the agro); (2) you shut up (you keep your head down and your faith to yourself); (3) you punch up (answering everyone in 'attack mode', verbally lashing out) or (4) you break up (fall apart under the pressure and end up feeling guilty for not knowing how to answer them). Jesus had questions thrown at Him all the time. The people asking the questions didn't really want an answer; they wanted to trick Him, trap Him, and make Him look like an idiot. He knew the same thing would happen to His disciples and gave them some advice: '…don't worry about …what to say.' Jesus never worried about how to answer His interrogators; He doesn't want you to worry either! Jesus didn't answer every question put to Him; sometimes He answered their question with a question back to them, or with a story which left people wondering what on earth He meant. Don't worry about people's questions or theories. Instead spend more time getting to know Jesus better so you never give up, shut up, punch up, or break up!

Soulfood: Jam 1-2, Mark 3:20-35, Ps 7:1-9, Pr 10:16

content.title: Family guy?
content.introtext:
Family guy?

'…for this purpose I have been sent.' Luke 4:43 NKJ

They say, 'You can pick your mates, but you can't pick your relatives!' Do you ever wish that wasn't true? Would you make any changes to your family if you could? Jesus knew how tough family can be—at times His family thought He was off His head! 'When His family heard this, they went to get Him because they thought He was out of His mind.' (Mark 3:21 NCV) It seems like Jesus' family just didn't get Him at times like this. So how did He handle His relatives? What's certain is that He kept loving His family despite the fact they didn't seem to understand Him. He didn't mouth off at them when they insulted Him or go into a major sulk and refuse to speak to them. But neither did He spend His whole life trying to please them or let their behaviour control Him. In fact, throughout His life He was single-minded in his obedience to his heavenly Father. The Bible is clear that we need to obey our parents (see for example, Ephesians 6:1-3) and this should be our starting point. But it's very likely that you will come into conflict at some point with people who are very close to you but who don't share your faith, or who are Christians but don't agree with where you feel God is leading you. At these times, we need to stick close to Jesus and take good advice from wise leaders in the church.

Soulfood: Dan 11-12, Mark 3:7-19, Ps 16, Pr 10:15

content.title: SWEET!
content.introtext:
SWEET!

'The Lord is on my side; I will not fear…' Psalm 118:6 NKJ

Get this: 'The Lord is on your side!' God—the One who holds the universe in His hand, and then some—is on your side! How cool is that! Which means that just like David, who wrote Psalm 118, you can say, 'What have I to fear?' Sweet! Do you really believe that? It's so easy to think: 'God won't 'watch my back'…I'm too bad for God to even want to hang out with me.' Or 'I've messed up too much…I'm rubbish…no one wants me…I'm useless, no-one picks me—God wouldn't want me on His team.' We might get mixed up sometimes but God doesn't, so what He says goes! If He says 'He's on your side,' then it's true! He is! You don't have to be scared of anything or anyone because God is there with you, looking out for you, wanting to help you! Now hang on a minute! Before you get carried away—this doesn't mean that you can go through life doing what you like, doing whatever, to whoever, wherever. You can't walk around singing, 'You can't touch me, God is on my side'. But when you follow God you can walk around knowing that whatever's happening, there's no need to be afraid, you can and you will get through it. So look up, walk tall, live confidently, knowing the Lord is on your side!

Soulfood: Dan 8-10, Mark 3:1-6, Ps 103:13-22, Pr 10:14

content.title: Training session
content.introtext:
Training session

'…a father corrects a child in whom he delights.' Proverbs 3:12 NLT

Ever feel like you're 'getting it in the neck' from everyone? Teachers: Blah! Blah! Blah! Parents: Nag! Nag! Nag! Police: Yada! Yada! Yada! And you're like, 'Whatever!' None of us enjoy getting 'disciplined'. It just does your head in! It can feel like people are against us wanting to bring us down. The word discipline doesn't mean to be unnecessarily mean, cruel and downright evil. It actually means to teach and to train. God knows that in order for us to become all we were created by Him to be, we need teaching and training. That's why 'the Lord disciplines those He loves.' (Hebrews 12:6 NLT) Discipline sounds negative to us because some people who have disciplined us in the past haven't always done in it in a good or a loving way. But Hebrews 12: 10-11 NLT says: 'God's discipline is always good for us…no discipline is enjoyable while it is happening—it is painful! But afterward there will be…right living for those who are trained in this way.' God is love. So when He disciplines you it's not because He enjoys inflicting pain but because He is hugely concerned about you. He completely 100% loves you! Be encouraged today, accept God's discipline, knowing He loves you so much that He wants to spend time teaching and training you to receive all His benefits.

Soulfood: Dan 5-7, Mark 2:23-28, Ps 103:1-12, Pr 10:13

content.title: Spot the deliberate mistake (3)
content.introtext:
Spot the deliberate mistake (3)

'Words of the wise…should be heard…' Ecclesiastes 9:17 NKJ

Fear of making mistakes keep us from reaching our potential. Fear stops us from asking for help or owning up when we don't have all the answers. Fear stops us speaking out in case we get shot down. To be successful you need to be brave enough to listen. When you don't, it can be disastrous. In It's Your Ship, Michael Abrashoff writes: 'The moment I heard about it [the tragic sinking of a Japanese fishing boat off Honolulu by the submarine USS Greenville], I was reminded that, as is often the case with accidents, someone senses possible danger but doesn't actually speak up. As the Greenville investigation unfolded, I read in a New York Times article that the submarine's crew 'respected the Commanding Officer too much to question his judgement.' If that's respect, then I want none of it. You need to have people that can tap you on your shoulder and say, 'Is this the best way?' or 'Slow down', or 'Think about this' or 'Is what we are doing worth killing or injuring somebody?' 'History records countless incidents in which ship captains or organisation leaders permitted a climate of intimidation to pervade the workplace, silencing subordinates whose warnings could have prevented disaster. Even when the reluctance to speak up stems from admiration for the Commanding Officer's skill and experience, a climate to respectfully question decisions must be created in order to foster double-checking.'

Soulfood: 2 Kings 6:8-23, Matt 5:43-48, Luke 6:27-36

content.title: Spot the deliberate mistake (2)
content.introtext:
Spot the deliberate mistake (2)

'Words of the wise…should be heard…' Ecclesiastes 9:17 NKJ

A story about a rich and powerful man made the headlines. Perhaps you read it? The man had a weakness for the opposite sex, and one day, after his afternoon nap, he strolled across the roof of his penthouse and stopped to perve at a chick having a bath. He made up his mind there and then to have her no matter what the cost. One affair, one murder, one dead baby later, the guy came to his senses. His reputation, his public standing, his character were just totalled. His name? King David of Israel (2 Samuel 11). Some mistakes have dire consequences. David allowed lust and passion to burn him up, completely disrespecting God's law, destroying Uriah (the husband of the woman David takes) and implicating Bathsheba (the woman having the bath) in the process. It's as if he turns off the part of his brain that thinks two steps ahead. Surely he knows it will all come back to bite him, and yet he goes ahead with his big seduction routine anyway. Aren't we a bit like that at times? OK, so maybe we're not committing a murder-adultery cocktail, but we can, in our own way, turn our brains off when it comes to thinking about the consequences of our actions. Gossiping, sleeping around, taking drugs, whatever—it all starts when we flick the switch marked 'consequences' in our brains to 'off'.

Soulfood: Dan 3-4, Mark 2:18-22, Ps 130, Pr 10:12

content.title: Spot the deliberate mistake (1)
content.introtext:
Spot the deliberate mistake (1)

'Words of the wise…should be heard…' Ecclesiastes 9:17 NKJ

Perhaps you got a shiny new guitar on your birthday. Perhaps you've perfected some of your better guitar hero poses in the mirror. Perhaps you've styled yourself somewhere between Skyhooks and Midnight Oil, for that retro feel. Who knows, maybe you've even rehearsed your acceptance speech for 'Sexiest Guitar Solo Ever on the Airwaves' for next year's ARIA awards. Now, all you have to do is get a sound out of it that doesn't seem like cat's intestines being plucked by a gorilla. Yep, that's right, no matter how promising we look, we're all still a 'work in progress'; whether it's learning guitar or learning to be humble, the principle is the same: we learn by our mistakes. Two top tips: First, recognise the bung notes. If you insist there's nothing wrong with your out-of-tune scales, you're only fooling your own ears. Everyone knows when you hit a bung note. Likewise everyone knows your weaknesses, so don't try and hide them. Learn from them! Second, remember that practice makes perfect. Paul McCartney didn't fall out of his mother's womb playing Hey Jude, he persevered through all his years of bung notes. Likewise, learn to see failure as part of the road to success. Those who are willing to learn from their mistakes don't have to keep repeating them. So there you are: happy plucking!

Soulfood: Dan 1-2, Mark 2:13-17, Ps 127, Pr 10:11

content.title: Heartache
content.introtext:
Heartache

'…Let not your heart be troubled…' John 14:27 NKJ

Have you heard about that boat trip Jesus went on with His pals? The one where the sea got so rough, the waves weren't just rocking the boat, they were crashing over the sides and the boat was filling with water? (Check it out in Mark 4.) They weren't just worried about puking up with sea-sickness but petrified they were actually going to die. Well, everyone except Jesus that is. His pals; most of whom were used to life on the waves were reduced to quivering wrecks in one short trip. But Jesus was so chilled out He fell asleep. The disciples thought that Jesus didn't care about them: 'Teacher, don't you care that we're going to drown?' And you can't blame them for thinking that can you? They're in the middle of a massive crisis and Jesus is having a power nap! But the disciples were wrong. Jesus cared more about them than they realised, He sorted everything: 'He got up, rebuked the wind and said to the waves, 'Quiet! Be still!' Then the wind died down and it was completely calm.' (Mark 4:39-40 NIV) We don't have a clue what life will throw at us tomorrow, next week, next month, or next year. It could be calm and tranquil or it could be whipping up a storm. The thing is, Jesus does know what's going to happen and whatever it is, Jesus says, 'Don't let this throw you…Trust me.'

Soulfood: Phil 1-4, Mark 2:1-12, Ps 43, Pr 10:10

content.title: Forgiveness
content.introtext:
Forgiveness

'…forgive whatever grievances you may have…' Colossians 3:13 NIV

When someone messes us up the last thing we want to say to them is, 'I forgive you.' It feels like we're doing them a favour or we're 'letting them off the hook'. But this is just warped thinking. Forgiveness is a gift from God for you. Forgiveness isn't about doing someone else a favour; it's about setting you free! 'If you forgive others for their sins, your Father in Heaven will also forgive you for your sins. But if you don't…your Father in Heaven will not forgive your sins.' (Matthew 6:14-15 NCV) When we forgive, God is able to set us free from being trapped in our own sin. Forgiveness isn't about letting them off the hook; it's about you becoming more like Jesus. To the people who crucified Him, Jesus said, 'Father forgive them because they do not know what they are doing.' When we forgive, we act like Jesus, we become more like Jesus. 'When a person changes and follows the Lord...we all show the Lord's glory and we are being changed to be like Him.' (2 Corinthians 3:16-18 NCV) Are you carrying a grudge? Why? It doesn't make sense. Why would you pick up something each day that weighs you down and carry it around with you? When we're given a gift, we're given a choice—we can accept and make use of it, or we can stash it under our bed and forget about it. Open up God's gift of forgiveness and use it.

Soulfood: Lev 26-27, Mark 1:40-45, Ps 56, Pr 10:8-9

content.title: What's the time?
content.introtext:
What's the time?

'...teach us to number our days.' Psalm 90:12 NKJ

When we're young it feels like the world is our oyster. We've got all the time in the world. Psalm 90 (the oldest Psalm) was written by Moses and He asks God to '...teach us to number our days, that we may gain a heart of wisdom.' Psalm 90:12 NKJ It's possible Moses wrote this psalm when all he could see was sand. For 40 years Moses was with the people of Israel, living in a desert. God promised them good things for their lives, but instead they ignored God and did their own thing. As a result the majority of them never left the desert; they never got to see God's better way for their lives. They lived and died in a desert, over six hundred thousand of them. They wasted their time doing their own thing, becoming right miserable losers! You may not be living in a desert, but how many times already have you wasted your time or been told by someone else that you're wasting theirs? How many times have you wished time away, wanting to throw off your teenage years because you're sick of people treating you like a little kid? Moses saw firsthand the horror of people wasting the time they have. Today ask God to teach you to make the most of your time, so that you can grow in wisdom. Let your life be a life of significance; not a waste!

Soulfood: Lev 23:26-25:55, Mark 1:35-39, Ps 50:16-23, Pr 10:4-7

content.title: Do you know Him?
content.introtext:
Do you know Him?

'…without Me you can do nothing.' John 15:5 NKJ

'Without Me you can do nothing,' said Jesus, letting us know that the only way to live life right, is through knowing Him. This can seem maddeningly confusing at worst and a little irritating at best! But when we get to know who Jesus is, it begins to make sense. Preacher SM Lockridge's once gave a six-and-a-half minute description of Jesus. Listen to some of the things he said (search on YouTube for the whole thing. It's worth it!): 'He's…the King of Kings…the Lord of Lords…the greatest phenomenon that has ever crossed the horizon of this world…He's the centrepiece of civilisation...He's the only one qualified to be an all-sufficient Saviour...He strengthens and sustains…He guards and He guides…He heals the sick…He forgives sinners…He blesses the young…He's the key to knowledge…His life is matchless…His goodness is limitless…His love never changes…His word is enough…His grace is sufficient…He's indescribable, He's incomprehensible, He's invincible, He's irresistible…You can't out live Him and you can't live without Him…Death couldn't handle Him and the grave couldn't hold Him…Do you know Him?' The more you get to know Jesus, the more incredible He becomes, the more you know you need Him and the more thankful you become in knowing that 'without Jesus you can do nothing.'

Soulfood: Lev 21:1-23:25, Mark 1:29-34, Ps 50:1-15, Pr 10:3

content.title: Big dreams (3)
content.introtext:
Big dreams (3)

'For the vision…will surely come…' Habakkuk 2:3 KJV

All this 'new beginning' talk is like a New Year's resolution—great for a few days but hard to keep going. Let's not be like your mum, who starts a new diet every other month and swears that no carbohydrate will pass her lips until she's lost 3 dress sizes. Or your Dad with his 'I'm quitting even if I have to set light to these nicotine patches to do it'. Let's start acting on the vision that God has given us. Let God's will be done on earth as it is in heaven today, courtesy of our fresh faith-like approach to life. Unlike Mum who in a few days will be having a chocolate withdrawal, we're going to have the will power of a saint. Why? Because, '…But we are not of those who shrink back and are destroyed, but of those who believe and are saved.' (Hebrews 10:39 NIV) Yes, and when Dad is sniffing the inside of a used ash tray for the smell of tobacco, we will pray for strength: 'Let me live that I may praise you, and may your laws sustain me.' (Psalm 119: 175 NIV) Whatever up and downs the rest of life has planned for you, 'Never be lazy, but work hard and serve the Lord enthusiastically…' (Romans 12:11 NLT)

Soulfood: 2 Chron 7:12-16, Matt 6:5-15, Luke 18:1-8

content.title: Big dreams (2)
content.introtext:
Big dreams (2)

'For the vision…will surely come…' Habakkuk 2:3 KJV

Whether your dream is to kick-start a credible youth service in your church or to impress Marcia Hines with your bump 'n grind rendition of 'Millennium Prayer' (best seek advice from your minister on that one!) you're going to need plenty of iron in your soul. Every dream will face the pin-prick test sooner or later. But it's not the pain, it's the praise that will decide whether you survive. Early church hero Paul dreamed of spreading God's peace around the ancient world. After 16 months of being chained in a Roman dungeon, you'd expect him to be all 'woe is me', but this guy's grin is still going strong. Listen: 'Rejoice in the Lord always and again I say, rejoice.' (Philippians 4:4 NAS) How did he keep his smile when the world was telling him to frown? Extra brownie points if you answered: vision. Vision says: It's not over till God says it's over. Circumstances and people don't have the last word: God does! He is 'the author and finisher of our faith …' (Hebrews 12:2 NKJ). With God, quitting is not an option. When you quit without his permission you're 'AWOL'—absent without leave—you abandon His protection and provision. Vision also says: Nothing can defeat you without your permission. You can't control what happens to you, but you can control what you say and do. Take control; hold onto vision.

Soulfood: Lev 18-20, Mark 1:21-28, Ps 25:16-22, Pr 10:2

content.title: Big dreams (1)
content.introtext:
Big dreams (1)

'For the vision…will surely come…' Habakkuk 2:3 KJV

What kind of aspirations has God planted in your heart? If you're not sure, then ask him: 'Make plans by seeking advice…' (Proverbs 20:18 NIV) If you want to know why you're here on this sphere, ask him. God has all your answers. God has all your purposes. God has all your dreams. Plus, here's the 'win-win' situation, not only will He give you wild dreams to chase, He'll give you all you need to fulfil them. Yes, there'll be set-backs and obstacles, it won't all be plain-sailing. (Hey, even Rocky has to do the hard yards of running up all those steps to his theme tune, before he gets his world title, so why should you get off lightly?) But if you stick it out, with God's help, you'll change history. Winston Churchill did it: when it looked like the war was lost, Britain's leader looked over the mountain, beyond the now and into the future, rallying his nation with these words, 'Never give up! Never give up! Never, never, never, give up!' Now there was a man of vision, a man of purpose, certain of his impending victory despite the overwhelming odds. Whatever righteous cause God entrusts to you, never, never, never give up!

Soulfood: Lev 15-17, Mark 1:14-20, Ps 25:8-15, Pr 10:1

content.title: Tough love
content.introtext:
Tough love

'…Arise and walk…' Matthew 9:5 NKJ

'Arise and walk', Jesus said to a man who was paralysed. Can you imagine what must have been going through this guy's mind? There He was, being carried on a mat down the street by his mates who put him down right by this guy Jesus. By now everyone wanted to meet Jesus who was getting a reputation for doing miraculous stuff. The place was packed and Jesus looked at him, didn't mention his paralysis at all but said, 'Cheer up, mate. I forgive your sins.' This caused some religious people to have a go at Jesus, because they didn't like what He was saying. The paralysed guy was stuck in the middle of it all. Jesus turned to him and said, 'Get up. Take your bed and go home.' Talk about pressure! Everyone's now looking at him: what can he do? He knows he's paralysed and can't move! Where's the sympathy and understanding from Jesus, eh? Where's the love? How tough is Jesus on this poor guy? Even so, this guy chose to trust Jesus, and guess what? He stood up! He was healed. He didn't just walk out that room, he ran! Sometimes, what Jesus asks us to do can seem too hard, too tough. It can even seem like Jesus doesn't care about us, doesn't understand our situation. But if you trust Him the results will blow your mind.

Soulfood: Lev 13:38-14:57, Mark 1:9-13, Ps 25:1-7, Pr 9:17-18

content.title: Loving God, loving others
content.introtext:
Loving God, loving others

'…which is the greatest commandment?...' Matthew 22:36 NIV

So how do you know when you've arrived as a top-notch premier league Christian? Is it when you can raise your arms higher than anyone else during the worship time? Is it when you've mastered the art of pronouncing those long names in difficult Bible readings? Or is it when you have a variation of a 'WWJD' bracelet around your wrist? You get the vibe off Jesus that the things that require the least fuss and attention to us are the things that God smiles on the most. Someone once asked Jesus, 'Which is the greatest commandment?' He answered, 'Love the Lord…and…love your neighbour as yourself.' (Matthew 22:37-39) Don't you just love the simplicity of Jesus? We make 'religion' so hard and complicated, when really it's all about loving God and loving others. When it comes to singing, it's not about who's making the sweetest sound, it's about who you're singing to. When it comes to Bible study, it's not about who knows the most Greek words, it's about the words shaping your life. When it comes to 'WWJD' wristbands, it's not about who has the funkiest collection, it's about applying the 'What Would Jesus Do' principle to your everyday choices. How do you know when you're getting there? Simple: when you're loving God and loving others.

Soulfood: Lev 11:1-13:37, Mark 1:1-8, Ps 32, Pr 9:10-16

content.title: Learn by your mistakes
content.introtext:
Learn by your mistakes

'Words of wisdom spoken softly make much...sense…' Ecclesiastes 9:17 CEV

One day, King Zedekiah said to the prophet Jeremiah, 'I will ask you something. Hide nothing from me.' (Jeremiah 38:14 NKJ) Could you face that kind of honesty? Would you dare ask someone to go through your life and give them permission to ask some tough questions? Lots of Christians do this sort of thing all the time. It's called having an 'accountability partner'. This is when a strictly no-fun Christian ties you to a chair and beats confessions out of you with a sharp bamboo cane. Errr, actually, it's nothing scary at all: it's about meeting with someone more mature in the faith than you and being totally honest about your successes and failures. It takes a special somebody to be able to challenge you on your slip-ups and it's only a special few who can take the probing without wanting to worm their way out one way or another. Those who have accountability partners, however, find the support is the key to their proven track record. Too often, we only want to hear how great we are, but if we are just 'works in progress', it can only help to hear where we need to pull our socks up. It's all part of becoming beautiful: 'Do not let your adornment be merely outward…rather let it be the hidden person of the heart, with the incorruptible beauty of a gentle and quiet spirit.' (1 Peter 3:3-4 NKJ)

Soulfood: Lev 8-10, Matt 28:16-20, Ps 72:12-20, Pr 9:7-9

content.title: Are you Leggin it'?
content.introtext:
Are you Leggin it'?

'…Jonah arose to flee to Tarshish…' Jonah 1:3 NKJ

There's a guy in the Bible called Jonah. He could also be called Mr Stubborn or Mr Opinionated! Jonah despised the city of Nineveh. He took an instant dislike to anyone who came from there. But God had asked Him to go there, so he 'legged it!' He took a boat trip 4000 km in the opposite direction: 'Jonah ran away from the Lord and…found a ship bound for…Tarshish…' (Jonah 1:3 NIV) So God used a storm at sea, a bunch of burly sailors and a massive fish to bring him back. It's only when he got spewed up on a beach after spending 3 days in the belly of the Loch Ness monster's cousin that Jonah decided being 'Mr Stubborn' wasn't such a good idea! Before Jesus died, people asked Him for a miraculous sign that showed He truly came from God. (Matthew 12:39) He told them the only sign they would get would be that of Jonah. Are you running away from God? Or waiting for the miraculous sign? God's already given it—Jesus rose from the dead after 3 days in the tomb! Instead of running away, Jonah eventually did what God asked. In Nineveh his life (and the lives of the Ninevehites) was transformed as he dropped the 'Mr Opinionated' act. Are you sometimes like Jonah? Stubborn: digging your toes in, running away from God, doing your own thing instead? Opinionated: judging people; being mean, nasty, disrespectful, racist or abusive, just because you think you're right? God loved Jonah so He never gave up on him. Because he was pig-headed, Jonah had to learn the hard way to accept God's love and trust Him. God loves you so He'll never give up on you but do you have to learn the way? Take on the Resurrection life and do it God's way!

Soulfood: Lev 5-7, Matt 28:11-15, Ps 72:1-11, Pr 9:1-6

content.title: 'Happy Easter!'
content.introtext:
'Happy Easter!'

'…He who raised Christ from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies…' Romans 8:11 NIV

Today you have to let go of what you've done to others. The things we've done to others can weigh us down like a ton of bricks—the guilt can really drag you down, even if they say it's fine now. It's a bit like living in A Christmas Carol, with the ghost of your past not letting you move on in life. How do you live with the things you've done? Take Saul (Paul) as an example, and you'll soon feel better about yourself! You can definitely learn from him, he was someone who had really messed up—he'd torn Christians from their families and dragged them away to be beaten and killed. Then he converted to Christianity himself, and went around preaching to and meeting the widows and kids of the guys he'd done over. How did he deal with that guilt? He had two choices, and so do we—either try to carry it around, and probably collapse in the process, or find someone with shoulders big enough to take it from us. What did Paul do? Enter Jesus, who has the biggest shoulders you could ever hope for. Paul handed it to Him, and thanked God for it. Check out Romans 7:24-25. God showed him mercy, and he let go of the hurts he'd caused, knowing God could heal them. Trust God to do the same for you, and let it go.

Easter Sunday Soulfood: 1 Cor 15, Matt 28:1- 10

content.title: I get knocked down but I get up again!
content.introtext:
I get knocked down but I get up again!

'…I will build you up again, and you will be rebuilt…' Jeremiah 31:4 NCV

You check your jeans pockets before you shove 'em in the wash and discover two crumpled-up items. One a flyer, the other a $50 note. One you'll keep and one you'll throw away. Why? After all they're both just crumpled up rubbish, right? Wrong! One makes you think, 'Bin it!' because it's just a manky bit of paper that you don't need any more. The other makes you smile and think, 'Good one!' because you'd forgotten all about that money. One of them is valuable to you. When things go wrong, and they sometimes do, we can begin to feel like that flyer we found crushed in the corner of our jeans pocket. It started out ok; colourful, shiny, useful, but then it got pushed and pulled in every direction, the info on it wasn't as clear as it used to be and it looked dull and boring. It became a lost cause. When things go wrong, and they sometimes will; you need to think of yourself like that money you found crumpled up in the pocket of your jeans, not the tatty flyer. Even if it had gone through the whole wash cycle it would never lose its worth, never lose its value. You may feel battered, broken, bruised, useless! But you will always remain priceless to God and He promises, 'I'll start over with you and build you up again.'

Easter Saturday Soulfood: Num 21:4-9, Matt 27:51-66, Ps 69:7- 21, Deut 21:22-23

content.title: Rejected (3)
content.introtext:
Rejected (3)

'Jesus…asked, 'Are you also going to leave?'' John 6:67 NLT

Being abandoned, ditched, dropped, jilted, neglected, rejected can mess with our heads so much. When stuff like this happens, we tend to handle it by turning into one of three characters: The Boxer: We mouth off big time! Never throwing the towel in, we fight to the finish! The Actor: We pretend it doesn't matter, act like it makes no difference to us: 'I'm perfectly fine, thank you!' The Assassin: We plot revenge; 'I don't get mad, I get even!' Mouthing off, pretending we're fine, or plotting revenge will only leave us getting more hurt and probably hurt others in the process. So what should we do? Have you heard of the game Truth or Dare? You choose between Truth and Dare. Pick truth and you have to answer in total honesty any question that your friends ask you. Choose dare and you have to participate in a challenge set to you by your friends. But have you ever played Truth AND Dare? It's not so much a game but a way of life that God wants us to live; especially when we are feeling rejected. Jesus knows how that feels: He went to the Cross not only rejected by His friends but knowing that God Himself would turn away as He took on the sin of the world. TRUTH: Know God's truth about you. Jesus died for you. God says: '…you are precious to me. You are honoured, and I love you.' (Isaiah 43:4 NLT) DARE: to act on God's truth and not on your feelings! Live, knowing you're precious!

Good Friday Soulfood: Gen 22:1-18, Matt 26:69-27:50, Ps 22, Is 53

content.title: Rejected (2)
content.introtext:
Rejected (2)

'Jesus…asked, 'Are you also going to leave?'' John 6:67 NLT

Q: When negative experiences happen, what's your greatest enemy? A: Your own head! We worry and let our thoughts dictate the pace. Jesus was about to face His greatest trial, so He went out into the Garden of Gethsemane to pray. 'Not My will,' He said to His Father (and ours), 'but yours!' We need to let God in on our thoughts, let God control our thinking. If we don't, our thoughts run riot in our heads making us fearful, depressed, alone. Romans 12:2 NKJ says, '…be transformed by the renewing of your minds.' Get God stuff in your head: When you say, 'I can't solve this!' God tells you, 'I will direct your path.' (Proverbs 3:6) When you say, 'It's impossible!', God tells you, 'Everything is possible.' (Luke 18:27) When you say, 'I feel all alone!', God tells you, 'Never will I leave you.' (Hebrews 13:5) When you say, 'I can't do it!', God tells you, 'I can do everything through Him who gives me strength.' (Philippians 4:13) When you say, 'I don't deserve forgiveness!', God tells you, 'I have forgiven you.' (1 John 1:9, Romans 8:1) When you say, 'I'm afraid!', God tells you, 'Do not fear for I am with you, I will strengthen you and help you.' (Isaiah 41:10) When you say, 'No-one really loves me!', God tells you 'I love you.' (John 3:16) When you say, 'I don't know how to go on!', God tells you 'I will show you.' (Psalm 32:8)

Soulfood: Lev 1-4, Matt 26:47-68, Ps 31, Pr 8:34-36

content.title: Rejected (1)
content.introtext:
Rejected (1)

'Jesus…asked, 'Are you also going to leave?'' John 6:67 NLT

Have you ever been dumped by a boyfriend or girlfriend? Rejected by your mates? Abandoned by your parents? If yes to any of these, you wouldn't be human if you didn't feel hurt. Sometimes the pain and sadness lasts for years. What's weird is that even if nothing like this has ever happened to us, we could still worry about it: fearful that one day someone will dump us, reject us or abandon us. No-one wants to be left alone. At some point we all experience the heartbreak of losing someone we love, or being disappointed in people. It's why God tells us over and over, 'Fear not for I am with you.' (Isaiah 43:5 NKJ) Jesus knows what it's like to be rejected by friends, and not just once! A whole bunch of his friends told Him to get lost. 'At this point many of His disciples turned away and deserted Him.' (John 6:66 NLT) So how did He cope? He didn't deny his emotions. He said: 'Are you also going to leave?' (John 6:67 NLT) It's all there: the pain of loss, wondering what's going to happen next. Remember the pain you feel is ok. Those who say, 'You shouldn't feel this way,' are well-meaning but wrong. Acknowledging pain initiates the feeling-dealing-healing process. You can't heal what you won't feel or deal with. So, embrace your feelings, draw on God's grace, and move through the healing process.

Soulfood: 2 Thess 1-3, Matt 26:30-46, Ps 6, Pr 8:32-33

content.title: New vision
content.introtext:
New vision

'I will give you My message in the form of a vision...' Habakkuk 2:2 CEV

You know when you put your Nan's coke-bottle specs on for a laugh? The world seems a stranger place. Everything seems not only blurred but out of proportion and your head gets that dull aching feeling. When you don't have perfect vision, the world takes on a shadowy edge. The Bible says the same about our lives: 'Where there is no vision, the people are unrestrained…' (Proverbs 29:18 NAS) Now we're not talking about getting your eyes checked here, we're talking about a vision for your life, a dream for your future, your God-destiny, if you like. Did you know that you are a VIP? One of God's special detached agents on a mission that only you can do? (Yes, that's right, you!) Even before you were a twinkle in your mum's eye, God had dreamed up things for you to do here on earth. The good news is you can avoid the dull aching feeling you get when you can't see where you're going. It's your mission (should you choose to accept it) to check in with Kingdom HQ for your next briefing. Here's a report from a God-agent: 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart…in all your ways acknowledge Him, and He will make your paths straight. Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the Lord and shun evil.' (Proverbs 3:5-7 NIV)

content.title: Getting fruity?
content.introtext:
Getting fruity?

'…the fruit of the Spirit…' Galatians 5:22 NIV

So, why does the Bible have a 'fruit' fetish? You can't turn a page in the New Testament without some green-fingered old beardy asking if you're bearing fruit. Is it because Mars bars and chips weren't invented then or is there a purpose in using 'fruit' as an analogy? Well, think about it, our nutrient-rich friends are bursting with goodness (something us God folk should be too). James was a bit fruity for God; that's why he writes, 'How can you show me your faith if you don't have good deeds? I will show you my faith by my good deeds.' (James 2:18 NLT) This verse sums up James' rant about not just talking a good game, but actually living out your faith or showing everyone your Vitamin C-hristianity. Now, where do apples come from? Do they just roll off a conveyor belt in a factory somewhere in the Goulburn Valley? No. They grow naturally, in the right season and from a healthy tree. Good fruit reflects a good tree. It's the same with us: when we're cutting it for God we're showing our ripe fruit, we're reflecting a good tree, we're shimmering for Jesus. Finally, what does this fruit taste like? Paul lists nine different kinds of spiritual fruit: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self control. Start going about showing that lot off and you'll soon make your mates spiritually hungry for something you've got but they haven't: Vitamin JC.

Soulfood: Esther 5-10, Matt 26:1-17, Ps 18:1-29,Pr 26:24-27

content.title: Acorns become oaks
content.introtext:
Acorns become oaks

'Do not despise these small beginnings...' Zechariah 4:10 NLT

Don't be put off just because you haven't had the best start in life. All great things have to start somewhere. Something as large as an oak tree once started out as a tiny acorn. Take Jesus. He didn't exactly have a head start in life, did He? Think about it, He was conceived outside marriage, grew in the womb of a teenage mother (Mary was probably a year 9 at the time of her pregnancy), born in conditions of poverty (a donkey's drinking trough for his cot; that's the definition of 'hard up'). Before He even cut his first tooth, an entire army was on the hunt for his blood. Or what about David, the man known as Israel's greatest ever king? A scrawny little kid whose best friends were sheep. His family were considered insignificant; and he was the 'runt of the litter'. When he should have been given a break (after doing in Goliath for the king, for instance) he found himself instead the victim of King Saul's jealous rages. For a while he couldn't even tune his harp without Saul throwing a spear in his direction. Or Joseph: sold into slavery by his own nearest and dearest. Put into prison for refusing to sleep with the boss's missus. Who'd have thought they'd amount to anything? But they did and their lives counted for God. Many of us struggle with feelings of inadequacy or insignificance. But think of these guys and be encouraged.

Palm Sunday Soulfood: Ps 118:19-29, Matt 21:1-16

content.title: In good spirit
content.introtext:
In good spirit

'…be filled with the Spirit. Ephesians 5:18 NIV

Mortifying, isn't it? Seeing people intoxicated over the festive season, a grown man dancing around with his tie wrapped around his forehead, his wife drooling 'I love you' in his ear, and loudly telling everyone else what's wrong with the world. It's a stupid thing to be 'under the influence'; it makes you say and do things you wouldn't normally do. But being 'under the influence' of God, that's something else! When you're 'filled with the Spirit' you swagger about, you feel like dancing, you get loved-up for God and you want to put the world to rights. Ever noticed how some Christians can be loopy for Jesus? They seem to have their God stuff so much more sorted than you. Well, that's because they're intoxicated with God. Through planned Bible and prayer time, they're constantly filling themselves with the Spirit of God. Those tricky obstacles that come our way ready to throw us off-course can so easily be overcome when we're tuned into the Spirit. Paul knew this well. He wrote to the Galatians: 'Walk by the Spirit, and you will not carry out the desire of the flesh.' (Galatians 5:16 NAS) Walking by the Spirit means continually refilling yourself with God. A car doesn't run on a tank of petrol forever, it needs refilling regularly. When life causes us to run dry, we need to go back to the fuel pump: the Holy Spirit.

Soulfood: Esther 1-4, Matt 25:41-46, Ps 69:19-36, Pr 8:30-31

content.title: The road to God
content.introtext:
The road to God

'...I am the way…' John 14:6 NKJ

Does every religion lead to God? Judaism sees salvation happening on Judgment Day after a life of morality. Hindus look forward to the end of a series of reincarnations of the soul. The Buddhist guide through life is the Four Noble Truths and the Noble Eight-fold Path. Muslims earn their way to Allah through the Five Pillars of Faith. Many philosophers deem life after death as hidden and unknown: 'a great leap in the dark'. Some people clump Christ with Moses, Mohammad, Confucius, and other spiritual leaders. But what did Jesus say about Himself? 'I am the way, and the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me.' (John 14:6 NKJ) No one? No one gets to God except through Jesus? Some would object, saying, 'All roads lead to heaven.' But how can they? Buddhists look toward Nirvana, achieved after no less than 547 reincarnations. Christians believe in one life, one death, and an eternity of enjoying God. Humanists don't acknowledge a creator of life. Jesus claims to be the source of life. Spiritualists read your palms. Christians consult the Bible. Hindus perceive a plural and impersonal God. Christ-followers believe '…there is only one God.' (1 Corinthians 8:4 NLT) Every non-Christian religion says, 'You can save yourself.' Jesus says: 'My death on the cross saves you.' All roads don't lead to Melbourne, all ships don't sail to Hobart and all flights don't land in Sydney. Every path does not lead to God; Jesus is the road to God.

Soulfood: Job 40-42, Matt 25:31-40, Ps 69:1-18, Pr 8:27-29

content.title: Your money or your life
content.introtext:
Your money or your life

'…You cannot serve both God and Money.' Matthew 6:24 NIV

The Bible is full of stories with unexpected twists. Case study: Exodus 32. All the Israelites have witnessed a serious case of God kicking Pharaoh's butt and yet here they are by Exodus 32 giving thanks and praise to a gold cow! If the Israelites had a brain between them at this point, it would probably fit comfortably into a salt shaker. C'mon, how does a chunk of metal with udders compare to the almighty Creator of the universe? Those old beardy Israelites sure had it all wrong…not like us wonderfully wise Christians today, eh? I wonder what those old Israelite dudes would make of the little rectangles of precious plastic we feed into holes in the wall. This is about money, of course. That's our main rival to God, isn't it? We make such a big deal about earning, spending and saving we may as well be giving it our full worship. We see money as the keys to comfort, the tickets to happiness and the vouchers to security. But happiness isn't found in the 'ker-ching' of a cash till. Listen: 'Don't be obsessed with getting more material things. Be relaxed with what you have. Since God assured us, 'Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you.' (Hebrews 13:5 NIV) What's your big deal about: God or money?

Soulfood: Job 38-39, Matt 25:22-30, Ps 38:13-22, Pr 8:24-26

content.title: God's megaphone
content.introtext:
God's megaphone

'...This is the way; walk in it.' Isaiah 30:21 NIV

Pain speaks volumes. Headaches tell us we need to lie down in a dark room; backaches tell us we need to lift safely; stomach-aches tell us to step away from the Doritos. Yes, pain tells us something's not right. Pain captures our attention. It can be the same with our lives, sometimes pain is necessary for change. The pain of depression can lead us to seek help. The pain of loss can help us re-evaluate what matters most in life. The pain of emptiness can bring us back to God. CS Lewis wrote, 'Pain is God's megaphone'. Maybe, this year has been tough for you, life seems a bit pointless and you've been left wondering, 'Where is God in all of this?' The Bible says, '...don't be surprised at the fiery trials you are going through… Instead, be very glad—for these trials make you partners with Christ in his suffering, so that you will have the wonderful joy of seeing his glory when it is revealed to all the world.' (1 Peter 4:12-13 NLT) Pain is never easy! Actually, life isn't easy, but one thing we can count on is God hasn't just left us to it. God is on the job: 'And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose.' (Romans 8:28 NIV) Sometimes God has to use his megaphone to shout: 'This is the way; walk in it.' (Isaiah 30:21 NIV)

Soulfood: Job 35-37, Matt 25:14-21, Ps 38:1-12, Pr 8:22-23

content.title: Going solo
content.introtext:
Going solo

'And Elisha…saw him no more…' 2 Kings 2:12 NKJ

Some dynamic duos are just destined to be: Batman and Robin, Laurel and Hardy, Mickey and Minnie Mouse. The Bible also points out a perfect pairing in Elijah and Elisha. This couple were inseparable until one day '…a chariot of fire…separated the two…Elijah went…into heaven. And Elisha…saw him no more…' (2 Kings 2:11-12 NKJ) Elisha, the right-hand man, is suddenly without a boss to shadow. There are times in life when we must go on alone, and draw from God the strength to do it. Alone at the River Jordan, Elisha '…took up the mantle of Elijah…struck the water…the water…divided…and Elisha crossed over.' (2 Kings 2:13-14 NKJ) Crossing the Jordan was Elisha's first steps alone—except he wasn't really alone, God was with him. Those looking on were soon saying, 'The spirit of Elijah lives in Elisha!' Later, in 2 Kings 2:19-22 we see that 'spirit of Elijah' when God used Elisha to get rid of the pollution in a town's water supply. Any worries Elisha had about filling Elijah-sized shoes in the miracle stakes were quashed right then. Another time (2 Kings 2:23) near Bethel, Elisha is publicly dissed but God gets the last word in via a full-on bear attack! (Really, read it for yourself.) The point is, time and time again, Elisha didn't need Elijah, because he had God. Likewise, you're not alone either if you have God.

Soulfood: Job 32-34, Matt 25:1-13, Ps 55:12-23, Pr 8:19-21

content.title: Lost
content.introtext:
Lost

'I will arise and go to my father…' Luke 15:18 NKJ

Look up the story of the lost son in Luke 15:11-32. Read it? Good. Now the father in the story would do anything to have his kid back with him, but he doesn't send a search party to kidnap him back. No, the choice has to be the son's. God doesn't force His agenda on us, as if we're His prisoners of war, or helpless subjects of a dictatorship. He empowers us to make our own choice. The son realised living in a pig-pen is no life at all. He came to his own realisation. What about you? You were born for a palace, not a pig-pen; have you realised that yet? Have you also realised the grass isn't always greener? The son should never have been in the pig-pen in the first place. His choices landed him there. Dad seemed too boring, home seemed like a bunch of rules, all work and no play. Surely, he thought, there's a better life on the outside, far away from dad's estate. That's what had driven our prodigal 1000 kilometres from being able to borrow dad's car or celebrating in style on his birthday. What about you? Does it feel like you're 1000 km away from where you should be right now? The reality is you're just a prayer away from God's outstretched arms.

Soulfood: Job 29-31, Matt 24:36-51, Ps 55:1-11, Pr 8:17-18

content.title: Devilishly naughty
content.introtext:
Devilishly naughty

'…submit to God. Resist the devil…' James 4:7 NKJ

The devil? He only exists in the minds of mullet-wearing metal-heads or crops up on the shoulders of cartoon figures complete with comedy pitch-fork, doesn't he?! It's time our mind gave the devil a complete make-over. Maybe it's easier to think in terms of 'temptation'; we've all been there, right? Those little moral dilemmas: 'I could download this track and pay the music company their $1.99…' or 'I could click on this illegal site and it's mine for nothing'? When it comes to temptation, nobody is so super-spiritual that they're immune. 1 Corinthians 10:12 NIV says, 'So, if you think you are standing firm, be careful that you don't fall!' Face facts: the very thing you're a sucker for wants to make a sucker out of you. The good news is that you can ask God for help. The Bible says '...God is faithful; He will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear. But when you are tempted, He will also provide a way out so that you can stand up under it.' (1 Corinthians 10:13 NIV)

Soulfood: 2 Kings 4:42-44, Mark 6:30-44

content.title: You could be Joseph
content.introtext:
You could be Joseph

'...God has made me forget…' Genesis 41:51 NKJ

So you find it hard to forgive your sister because she didn't return your CDs or you want to play soccer with your little brother's head because he lost your phone. But imagine if they sold you as a slave for the price of a double latté! You'd be well within your rights to throw yourself a pity-party. Unless, that is, you're like Joseph. He's the guy who refused to sit around and mope in his prison chains. Instead he stuck so close to God he could practically pinch him. That's the kind of attitude God loves to smile down on and that's why God elevated 'Mr Dreamcoat' from prisoner to Prime Minister in the space of 13 years. But how did Joseph get through his dark years? For starters, he didn't pretend it never happened. He must've spent many nights in God-led therapy, since he called one of his sons Manasseh (which means 'God has made me forget'). Every time Joseph called his son's name he was reminded how God had helped him move on from the hurt. His other son was named Ephraim (which means 'God made me fruitful in the land of my afflictions'). Every time he thought about Ephraim he was reminded how circumstances intended for his harm turned around for his good. Joseph teaches us that God-praise outweighs self-pity any day.

Soulfood: Job 24-28, Matt 24:26-35, Ps 13, Pr 8:14-16

content.title: Room for improvement
content.introtext:
Room for improvement

'I press on toward the goal…' Philippians 3:14 NIV

Paul writes: '…I do not consider myself yet to have taken hold of it. But…I press on toward the goal…' (Philippians 3:13-14 NIV) Paul must be in the top few influential Christians of all time. And yet here he is admitting that there's room for improvement in his life. What about you? You know when you get that annoying teacher's gem on your school report, 'Could try harder', well, in what ways could you try harder? Rate yourself in this 'room for improvement checklist' (a = always, b = sometimes, c = could try harder) (1) I'm patient (2) I'm self-controlled (3) I put others before myself (4) I'm a cheerful giver (5) I read my Bible (6) I pray by myself and with others (7) I'm happy with a lot or a little (8) I'm respectful (9) I choose forgiveness over hurt or revenge (10) I follow God no matter what. So how did you go? This isn't an exercise in bigging yourself up or battering yourself down, it's an opportunity to be like Paul by recognising how far you've come and then setting yourself some goals to become more Christ-like. Why don't you keep a copy of this checklist in your Bible, and keep coming back to it every few months? You might be pleasantly surprised at the results as Jesus paints His masterpiece within you.

Soulfood: Job 21-23, Matt 24:15-25, Ps 116:12-19, Pr 8:10-13

content.title: Ready, set, go
content.introtext:
Ready, set, go

'Be dressed ready for service…' Luke 12:35 NIV

Whilst most of us would still be fiddling with the odour-eaters in our running shoes, Usain Bolt has already won the race, whistled his national anthem and cartwheeled all the way back to Jamaica. How? Because he's the fastest man on the planet; the guy has speed written into his DNA. The Bible often has Usain Bolt moments: again and again we read words like straightaway, immediately, and suddenly, giving us reminders that God often moves with speed written in His DNA. Maybe it feels like you're going through a 'God in slow-mo' patch right now. You've been praying for something again and again, but nothing seems to be happening. Well, perhaps you're just a prayer away from one of God's 'suddenly' moments. John 5 might be just what you need to hear. For absolutely yonks, a paralysed man was sitting next to a pool that bubbled from time to time with the right properties for healing, but nobody would help him at the right moments. How frustrating! Enter stage left Jesus, and we get a completely different scene. No longer is the man sitting a metre or so from his solution; he's face-to-face with it. A 38-year wait ends with a suddenly of God. What about you? Are you waiting for God's suddenly in your life? Take heart, sometimes God moves swifter than Usain Bolt. What counts is being ready.

Soulfood: Job 18-20, Matt 24:1-14, Ps 116:1-11, Pr 8:8-9

content.title: Work on the inner you
content.introtext:
Work on the inner you

'…the inward man is being renewed day by day.' 2 Corinthians 4:16 NKJ

Remember that summer when you were desperate to cram yourself into your old togs? It was goodbye cheesy Doritos, hello celery, right? To get that beautiful beach bod, you knew you had to watch what you pushed into your mouth. Well, it's the same with inner beauty. To be sizzling on the inside you need to watch what goes into your mind. If you keep allowing your mind to pig-out on junk like gossip, back-biting, slanging and banging, it won't be long before you start to look spiritually flabby. So, how do you stay buff on the inside? First of all, we need to check out which areas we've let get a bit out of shape. This might mean spending some alone—time with God and asking him to pin-point some areas of 'bulge'. Confession is like a detox—good for clearing out those sin-toxins. Second, we need to change our habits. A healthy eating plan involves changing habits, not cutting out food full-stop. Nobody is asking you to be Mother Teresa, but changing some of your habits will help you. Could you cut out a few episodes of your favourite sit-com and pray instead? Probably. Finally, feed on something healthy. An orange has more vitamin C than a crème egg; the Bible has more nourishment than any magazine. You do the maths.

Soulfood: Job 15-17, Matt 23:23-39, Ps 19, Pr 8:6-7

content.title: Don't judge a book by its cover
content.introtext:
Don't judge a book by its cover

'…man looks at the outward appearance...' 1 Samuel 16:7 NKJ

How often do you judge people by the way they look? They're carrying a big battered Bible, so they must be holy. They've got nice hair and the latest fashion, so they must be rich. They've got a sad face, so they must be no fun. You may not even know you're doing it—but we all do! The prophet Samuel was just the same. One day God sent him to find Israel's next king. Samuel saw a guy who looked the part and thought, 'This must be the one.' Uh-uh. God measures differently to us: '…man looks at the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart.' Short weedy, red-faced David was the one God had His eye on to do huge things. So if you're feeling a bit down because of the way you look, don't. God can do huge things with you. And in the same way, don't judge other people just by the way they look; give them a chance, and try to see the good things inside them that God sees. For all you know, they could be the next David: shepherd boy turned king. Or think about Paul; people of his day saw him as a person who was 'unimpressive…his speaking amounts to nothing.' (2 Corinthians 10:10 NIV) But God not only used his words in a massive chunk of the Bible but used the force of his tough life to change history.

Soulfood: Job 11-14, Matt 23:13-22, Ps 11, Pr 8:4-5

content.title: Makeover time
content.introtext:
Makeover time

'…the Lord looks at the heart.' 1 Samuel 16:7 NKJ

Tweezers, waxes, creams, hair dye, scissors, 'brand name' clothes, whole new look—probably the things you think of when you hear the word 'makeover'. If you're a bloke, you're probably ducking for cover already! But that's not what we're talking about today. Every human being is actually two people in one: the outer person (the body, reputation, and personality) and the inner person (the character, spirit and soul). The outer you is visible to everyone, and although you may get a huge zit that not even the best concealer will cover, you can still pretty much 'makeover' the outer you so it looks good to everyone else around you. The inner you is invisible though, and you can hide it from everyone if you want—apart from God, that is! We may be able to hide what we're really feeling and thinking, how we're really doing from those around us, but we can't hide it from God. And here's the thing: the inner you won't ever cease to exist. So even though as you get older, your skin will get wrinkly, your hair will go grey, your bones will get brittle and you'll lose brain cells every day after you hit 30, your spirit will still be going strong. So make sure you exercise it, work it out and keep your spiritual insides trim.

Soulfood: Job 8-10, Matt 23:1-12, Ps 115, Pr 8:1-3

content.title: Wonderful well or shonky sieve?
content.introtext:
Wonderful well or shonky sieve?

'My peope...forsaken me, the spring of living water, and have dug...broken cisterns that cannot hold water.' Jeremiah 2:13 NIV

A cistern is like a well. What do wells need to do? Hold water. So when the people dug cisterns that were like sieves, that was a bit useless really! Sometimes, if we've not got God right in the middle of our lives, we can be running about doing so much other stuff that we become a bit like those wells - letting the water drain away when we need it to live. We all want to feel loved, and successful, and special, and sometimes we look for these things in the weirdest places, forgetting about God completely. You won't find happiness at the bottom of four cans of V, you won't find love having sex with your boyfriend or girlfriend, you won't find success sounding off about that new kid to all your mates, and you won't find fulfilment by nicking money from your mum's purse. All those things are like holes in your well. But when you put God in the centre of everything, you'll find He can give you whatever you need. You need to work at giving yourself strong, God-centred 'walls' to your well. '...blessed are those who trust in the Lord and have made the Lord their hope and confidence. They are like trees planted along a riverbank with roots that reach deep into the water... They never stop producing fruit.' (Jeremiah 17:7-8 NLT) Respect God, trust Him and honour Him in everything and you'll find those holes are soon blocked up, and you'll be a wonderful well, not a shonky sieve.

Soulfood: Is 61:1-9, Luke 4:16-30

content.title: Get passionate
content.introtext:
Get passionate

'So we built the wall…' Nehemiah 4:6 NKJ

We're back with Nehemiah and his wall today. Remember how impressed the bullies were with the speed he rebuilt the walls of Jerusalem (and that's a lot of walls!) yesterday? Question: So how on earth did he do it? Answer: Passion! Nehemiah gave up a high-profile job, overcame relentless opposition, and worked passionately. What can we learn about passion today? (1) Passion is your first step to achievement. Your desire, not your high school results or your DNA, determines your destiny. The greater your desire, the greater your potential. (2) Passion will increase your willpower. Only when you want something badly enough are you willing to pay the price to achieve it. (3) Passion will change you. When your desires are in harmony with God's will and you follow them with a passion, you can't help but become a more productive person. (4) Passion will make possible the impossible. Sometimes, even the experts get it wrong—so watch out! In 1895 Lord Kelvin said, 'Heavier-than-air flying machines are not possible.' In 1905 the US President said, 'Sensible and responsible women do not want to vote.' In 1923 Robert Millikan, a Nobel Prize winner in Physics, said, 'There's no likelihood man can ever tap the power of the atom.' Hmmm, I think they all got it a bit wrong somehow! Jesus said, '…with God all things are possible.' (Mark 10:27 NKJ) When you become passionate about God's purposes, He'll show you what's possible.

Soulfood: Job 5-7, Matt 22:34-46, Ps 26, Pr 7:26-27
