content.title: Beat the bullies, crush the critics
content.introtext:
Beat the bullies, crush the critics

'I sent messengers…with this reply: 'I am carrying on a great project and cannot go down…' Nehemiah 6:2-3 NIV

Nehemiah teaches us three things to help prepare us for bullies and critics: (1) Expect it. When you're watching a race, where do you focus? On the front runners! 'Criticism is something you can avoid easily: by saying nothing, doing nothing, and being nothing.' But those three options don't work for God's kids. Don't stoop to the level of those having a go at you; rise above it. (2) Evaluate it. 'I knew they were scheming to hurt me,' Nehemiah said. When people say, 'I'm going to tell you something for your own good,' often they've nothing good to tell you whatsoever. When you're criticised, ask yourself who criticised you? 'Faithful are the wounds of a friend, but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.' (Proverbs 27:6 NKJ) Has that person earned the right to speak into your life? (3) Outlive it. Even Nehemiah's mates wanted him to give in and run away to hide but he wouldn't, and he carried on building his wall. When it was finished in super-speedy time, even the bad guys turned round and said that he must have had God's help! (Check out Nehemiah 6 for the whole story.) Sometimes you're in more danger from the advice of your friends than you are from the criticism of your enemies. That's when you must know who you are and what God's called you to do. It's the only way to outlive the criticism!

Soulfood: Job 1-4, Matt 22:23-33, Ps 24, Pr 7:24-25

content.title: 'Come and see'
content.introtext:
'Come and see'

'…They came and saw…and remained with Him…' John 1:39 NKJ

The country's most famous evangelist is in town and you've gone to hear him speak. But all he talks about is someone better who's coming soon. So what do you do? Stay where you are or go to try and find the guy he's talking about? Well, duh! Can you blame Andrew and his mates for going off to hunt out Jesus, and find out if He really was as incredible as John the Baptist was saying? They knew the only way to find out was to spend time with the man Himself, find out what floated His boat, what made Him tick—so they did. When they found Him, His response was to tell them to 'come and see'. So what exactly did He want them to see? (1) See how He handles power. Not once did Jesus use His power to impress others or enrich Himself in any way. (2) See how He handles people. He didn't see them as interruptions, irritations or obstacles on His path to personal fulfilment. No. '…when He saw the multitudes, He was moved with compassion…' (Matthew 9:36 NKJ) (3) See how He handles priorities. '…vast crowds came to hear him… But Jesus often withdrew to the wilderness for prayer.' (Luke 5:15-16 NLT) Did He know something we don't? No commitment is harder to keep, or more important, than spending time in prayer each day.

Soulfood: I Thess 1-5, Matt 22:15-22, Ps 135, Pr 7:21-23

content.title: Don't be a clown - practice those circus skills!
content.introtext:
Don't be a clown-practice those circus skills!

'But those who fail to develop…are shortsighted or blind…' 2 Peter 1:9 NLT

Brian Dyson once said this to a bunch of young students: 'Imagine life as a game in which you are juggling five balls in the air. You name them: work, family, health, friends and spirit. You will soon understand that work is a rubber ball. If you drop it, it will bounce back. But the other four balls are made of glass. If you drop any of these they will be irrevocably scuffed, marked damaged or even shattered. They will never be the same. You must understand that and strive for balance in your life.' You may feel like some of those things aren't relevant to you right now but it's really important to start to get the balance sorted now, even if some of them are still in the future. You need to focus on keeping your relationships with your family and friends healthy, making sure you're in good shape physically, and most importantly, keep your spiritual life fresh and on track. Work, although it can bounce, is still important (after all, God's first task for Adam at creation was to look after the land so He must see work as pretty important). Don't spend all your time with your mates, and forget about the rest! And don't spend all your time locked in the house listening to worship music. God says balance is good. Check out the rest of 2 Peter 1:5-9 for more balls that need to be kept in balance.

Soulfood: Gen 50, Haggai 1-2, Matt 22:1-14, Ps 27, Pr 7:10-20

content.title: Face your fears (2) 'If-only-itis'?
content.introtext:
Face your fears (2) 'If-only-itis'?

'Be not afraid of their faces...' Jeremiah 1:8 NKJ

Do you find yourself constantly comparing yourself to other people? Have you got a case of 'if-only-itis'? You always see where everyone else gets it right but not where you do? You only see where you get it wrong? You wish you were more like your best mate. Or maybe you always see the glass half empty, 'They'll never want to talk to me', or 'I could never do that' or 'Why would they go out with me when they could have someone better?' If that's you, stop! Rewind! Try to look at yourself with a God-mirror. Isaiah 43:4 NCV says 'Because you are precious to me, because I give you honour and love you, I will give…nations to save your life.' That's you He's talking about there. Say to yourself: 'They're what God made them and I'm what God made me. I'm unique—in a good way. Yes, I make mistakes, but I'm not a mistake. With God's grace, I can work on loving myself, on being the capable person He's made me to be'. Accept that it's a process. You don't have to get it right straight away—after all, you're only human! But if God says you can do it, you can, so face your fears. Do what you've been afraid to do. God's promise of '…I am with you…' (Jeremiah 1:19 NLT) was all Jeremiah needed, and it's all you need too.

Soulfood: Gen 47-49, Matt 21:33-46, Ps 112, Pr 7:6-9

content.title: Face your fears (1) 'What if …?
content.introtext:
Face your fears (1) 'What if …'?

'Be not afraid of their faces...' Jeremiah 1:8 NKJ

Face your fears (1) 'what if …'? Your bus was late, so you got home late, so your dinner was late, so you got ready late, so you left the house late, so you've arrived late to your new youth group, choir practice, footie team, party… you get the picture. You're by yourself, and you look through a crack in the door and see that everyone is there already. You're about to walk in, but then fear kicks in. Are they talking about you? You start to sweat and panic; there's no way you can go in there and face them all. What if they all turn around to look at you, thinking goodness knows what? What if you get embarrassed and they all think you're stupid? What if they laugh at you? So many 'what ifs'. So you turn around and go home, missing out on what could have been a fantastic night. Stop! Rewind! Go back to when you got to the door, and stop saying 'What if …?' Instead, say 'So what if …?' Know that with God on your side, with His grace, you can handle anything. You may not especially like it, but you can do it and you'll survive to face another day. When Jeremiah wanted to get away from a whole bunch of people, God stepped in, and told Jerry not to be afraid, because He would be with him every step of the way. The same is true for you; so don't run away.

Soulfood: Gen 44-46, Matt 21:18-32, Ps 106:24-48, Pr 7:3-5

content.title: 'No strings attached' love
content.introtext:
'No strings attached' love

'Can anything ever separate us from Christ's love?' Romans 8:35 NLT

Think back to the playground at primary school. You're there, happily playing, thinking everything is great. Then you see your best friend playing with someone else, so you go over to join in but they stick their tongues out at you, and say, 'I'm not playing with you, I'm not your friend anymore,' and you run off in tears. Ring any bells? Do you remember anything like that? Human beings can be a bit fickle; we fall out with other people for the stupidest reasons (not sharing toys, looking at a boyfriend the wrong way) or even for serious reasons, like betrayal or physical hurt. Because that's our experience in life, our minds can't quite cope with the 'no strings attached' kind of love that God offers us. We don't get that there's no small print. We're always waiting for the catch, for God to turn round and say, 'Sorry mate, I've had enough of you. I don't want to know you anymore.' But get this: '...I am convinced that nothing can ever separate us from God's love.' (Romans 8:38 NLT) How incredible is that? God will never stop loving you. No matter what. He knows exactly what you're like, and He loves you so much. There's nothing that God can't get over; so accept his no-strings-attached love today.

Soulfood: Joel 2:23-32, Acts 2:1-21

content.title: The perfect package
content.introtext:
The perfect package

'…Having believed, you were marked…with a seal…' Ephesians 1:13 NIV

God has the perfect package lined up for you: When you believe, and become His child—that makes Him your Dad. You get His DNA, His seal on your life and the security of your future with Him. As a child of God, you get the seal of His Spirit on your life: 'Having believed, you were marked…with a seal, the promised Holy Spirit.' (Ephesians 1:13 NIV) Max Lucado writes: 'For a short time in college I worked in a vacuum-cleaner plant. We assembled the appliance from plug to hose. The last step on the assembly line was 'sealing and shipping'. By this point the company had invested hours and dollars in the machine. So they took extra care to protect it. They mummified it in bubble wrap, secured it with styrofoam, wrapped the box with tough-to-tear tape, stamped the destination on the box, and belted it inside the truck. That vacuum was secure.' But compared to God's care for His saints, the machine might as well have been dumped into the back of a rusty ute. God vacuum-seals us with His strongest force: His Spirit. He clothes His children in a suit of spiritual armour, encircles us with angels and lives within us. Not even the President of the United States is that well protected! But you are. That's how much God cares for you! How amazing is that?

Soulfood: Gen 42-43, Matt 21:12-17, Ps 106:1-23, Pr 7:1-2

content.title: Believe it
content.introtext:
Believe it

'…we have…believed the love that God has for us…' 1 John 4:16 NKJ

'Dear child: I knew you before time began. I know how many hairs are on your head. You're created in my image and I'm just rapt by the family resemblance. I have plans for you. I've given you gifts to help you bring those plans to fulfilment and what I give, nobody can take away. But don't abandon my gifts, leaving them to spoil in a corner. Exercise them, and stir them up daily. I've started a good work in you and I'm going to finish it. I always complete what I begin. 'My commitment to you is unending. In this life you will have challenges, but cheer up, I've robbed Satan of his power to control you and I've smashed the power of this world to destroy you. When you're in trouble, remember I'm with you. Hand Me your burdens so I can help and keep you going. When you're stressed out and worn down by the pressures of life, lean on Me. I'll be your rock, your fortress, your deliverer and your strength. Even though you fail from time to time, you won't be discarded because I am upholding you. 'But a word of caution: don't take advice from those who are spiritually blind or hang out with sceptics. Dig deep and take delight in My Word and, like a big oak tree growing by a river, you'll prosper in all you do. Love, God. 'PS, I'd love to hear from you.'

Soulfood: Gen 40-41, Matt 21:1-11, Ps 136:13-26, Pr 6:32-35

content.title: Be a baby again
content.introtext:
Be a baby again

'…everyone who believes in Him will have eternal life.' John 3:15 NLT

It's easy to sometimes read the Bible and get a bit confused, isn't it? That's where stories like this one about Nicodemus are great; here was a teacher and even he didn't get it when Jesus told him he had to be 'born again'! It's ok not to get things straight away, but Jesus wants us (like Nic) to stick at it until it makes sense. So what exactly does it mean to be 'born again'? Well, if you've ever seen a newborn baby, you know they don't do much other than eat, sleep, cry and fill nappies! The baby is totally dependent on its parents, and that's what God wants for us. It's as simple as looking to the Father, and looking to His Son, and only then can we truly live. We expect life to be way more complicated than that. I mean, you can't even join a video store without jumping through hoops! Surely, we think, we have to do more stuff to get eternal life? Well, according to Jesus, apparently not. All we have to do is believe. Trust. Just like you trust the air around you has enough oxygen for you to breathe, just like you trust a chair every time you sit down, just like a baby trusts their parents for food. Trust the power of God that you can't see to do what you can't imagine, and you, like Nic, may suddenly 'get it'.

Soulfood: Gen 37-39, Matt 20:29-34, Ps 136:1-12, Pr 6:30-31

content.title: Surviving an 'SOS'
content.introtext:
Surviving an 'SOS'

…pour out your hearts before Him…' Psalm 62:8 NKJ

We all have bad times. And at some point, we'll all have someone close to us who will die, and leave a massive hole in our lives. So what advice does the Bible give us on how to cope? (1) Don't bottle it up. Did you ever close your eyes when you were a kid, and think, 'If I can't see them, they can't see me'. That doesn't work with emotions! They won't go away just because you close your eyes. They're normal, so don't try and hide them away, or pretend they don't exist. God created you to feel—so go with it. The Bible tells us, 'Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.' (Matthew 5:4 NIV) Be honest with God. 'Pour out your heart before Him,' Psalm 62:8 NKJ) and He will comfort you. (2) Let your mates help. Don't go and hide in a corner, like the kid who's been told off and isn't letting anyone near. When tragedy strikes, we all need the encouragement, support (and hugs!) of our friends. And your mates have been called to help—check out Galatians 6:2. (3) Think positively. Cheesy as it sounds and little as you may feel like it, focus on the good memories. Make a list of all the other good things you have in life, and thank God for them. When you focus on the good, it's hard not to start feeling better.

Soulfood: Gen 35-36, Matt 20:17-28, Ps 77, Pr 6:29

content.title: Stewardship (4)-Why bother?
content.introtext:
Stewardship (4)-Why bother?

'...the lord of those servants...settled accounts...' Matthew 25:19 NKJ

So, to recap. God gives us all good things, and we are stewards of them for Him. He gives us what we can cope with, and He will only expect us to do what we can. He wants us to do the right thing, and make these gifts grow-but He won't force us. We get to make our own decisions. This is great, but at the end of the day, why should we bother?
One reason is before us: 'After a long time the lord of those stewards came and settled accounts with them.' (Matt 25:19 NKJ) It may seem like it's been a long time since Jesus was here, and it may feel like it could be forever before He comes back, but He will come back. He hasn't changed His mind or His plan. The first time, Jesus was here to save. The next time, He'll be here to reign; and when He does, He will reward His good stewards. Check this out: 'If the master returns and finds that the servant has done a good job, there will be a reward.' (Luke 12:43 NLT) He's coming back, and He'll be looking for those who have stewarded well. What more reason could you want than to please the King of kings Himself?

So don't get weary or bogged down, but keep your eyes on the prize! Imagine Jesus saying 'Well done!' to you when He returns. Awesome.

Soulfood: Gen 32-34, Matt 20:1-16, Ps 70, Pr 6:26-28

content.title: Stewardship (3)—Who's pulling the strings?
content.introtext:
Stewardship (3)—Who's pulling the strings?

'…Well done, good and faithful servant…' Matthew 25:21 NKJ

The next thing to learn is that God isn't a puppeteer! We're not in some episode of Thunderbirds where God's written the script and is pulling the strings to make sure we do what He wants, when He wants and how He wants, with Him speaking for us. No way! When God gives us good things, whether that's money, gifts, or skills, He won't force us to use them well. It's entirely up to us. We have the freedom to run our own show, to mess it up or make what He's given us grow amazingly. Looking at the parable of the talents again, we see that the first two servants made their money grow, whereas the third wimped out and just buried what he had been given, not doing anything positive with it. He was scared he wouldn't be able to do enough, and the master would be mad; so instead he did diddly squat. Not good enough, the master says. It's easy to read the story and think he was an idiot, but sometimes we may find we're doing that with God too: we're scared to use what He's given us in case we don't get it right. But remember God won't ask you to do anything you can't. By His grace, you can do all things that He asks of you. So don't wait for Him to tap you on the shoulder, set to it yourself.

Soulfood: Gen 30:25-31:55, Matt 19:15-30, Ps 66:13-20, Pr 6:23-25

content.title: Stewardship (2)—personal responsibility
content.introtext:
Stewardship (2)—personal responsibility

'…He gave…to each according to his own ability…' Matthew 25:15 NKJ

Today, let's take a look at the parable of the talents in Matthew 25:14-30. A businessman going on a trip divides up his money among his managers and instructs them to take care of it for him. You'll notice Jesus points out a really key thing: the man distributes to each manager 'according to his own ability'. God knows what you can handle and He won't give you more, so don't ask Him to. The master didn't burden the one-talent guy with a five-talent responsibility, or vice versa. Now we're not saying that those who have lots of stuff are the best stewards, or that those who have less must be poor stewards but God knows each of us intimately, and He deals with us according to that knowledge. You won't have to answer for what God didn't give you or what He gave someone else. You're only responsible for yourself. Whatever God's entrusted to you to manage, He's done so knowing you're capable of handling it. So if you feel your mate's got it all and you're a bit jealous; just remember, they've got all the responsibility as to how they deal with it too, and they'll have to answer to God for what they do. And if it's you that's got it all, don't go bragging to your mates and showing off. Instead, remember your responsibility to do the right thing. Whatever you've got, ask God what He wants you to do with your lot to glorify Him.

Soulfood: Ex 17:8-16, 2 Cor 1:3-7

content.title: Stewardship (1)—it's mine!
content.introtext:
Stewardship (1)—it's mine!

'…What do you have that you did not receive?…' 1 Corinthians 4:7 NIV

So what does this word 'stewardship' mean? 'Hands off!' 'You can't have it!' 'It's mine!' These are all common things you hear kids saying when they're playing. But just have a think: have you said (or even thought) that recently? It's easy to fall into the trap of thinking we have the right to everything we have. Our time is ours, our stuff is ours, we can do what we want with it, right? Uh-uh—wrong! Look at today's verse. Every good thing you have is a gift from God. That's everything: your phone, your iPod, your Wii, your allowance… starting to get it? It's all from God. Yes, you may have saved for it or worked for it but ultimately it's God who has given it to you so you can be a 'steward' or caretaker. 'So what?' I hear you say. 'He's given it to me, so it's mine'. Yep, that's true; but a steward doesn't actually own the property he manages, so he needs to handle things with an eye to pleasing his boss, the owner—in our case, God. He wants us to be sensible and wise with what He's given us, not selfish and boastful like those little kids always screaming, 'Gerroff! It's mine!' But how do we know what God wants us to do with what He's given us? And how come some people get more than others? Don't panic—we've got three more days to make sense of that!

Soulfood: Gen 28:1-30:24, Matt 19:1-14, Ps 66:1-12, Pr 6:20-22

content.title: Mean what you say
content.introtext:
Mean what you say

'…Let your 'Yes' be yes and your 'No,' no…' James 5:12 NIV

Saying what you mean is just the beginning. Meaning what you say is the next step. Don't say one thing, then walk away and do the opposite. When you say 'that's the last time', make sure it is! Start with the small things (like how much time you'll spend on the games console or starting your assignment before the last minute), and you may well find it filters into some of the bigger decisions and actions too. If you're not planning on doing something, don't say you will. And stick to your guns too; if you tell your friend you're not going to let him borrow your bus pass anymore, don't let him. Saying 'Oh ok, just this once', makes him think it's ok to keep coming back and before you know it he'll be walking all over you again. Have you ever heard a mum screaming at a kid, 'If you don't stop that right now you'll have to go to your room'? The kid doesn't stop, so the mum says, 'This is your last warning'. Still the kid doesn't stop—but still the mum doesn't take action. The 'final warnings' just keep on coming. What does the kid do? Whatever they want to, of course. Why? Because empty words have no meaning. If you want people to listen to what you say, respect you, and value your words—then make sure you place value on them too, and follow through on what you say.

Soulfood: Gen 25:19-27:46, Matt 18:21-35, Ps 61, Pr 6:16-19

content.title: Say what you mean
content.introtext:
Say what you mean

'…Let your 'Yes' be yes, and your 'No,' no…' James 5:12 NIV

'Sick. Wicked. Mint. Cool. Sweet. Cheese. Gross.' What do you think when you hear those words? And what do your parents think? I'm guessing completely different things. You think: 'amazing, awesome, fantastic, nice, great, naff, disgusting'. Your parents think: 'ill, evil, a herb that flavours toothpaste, cold, sugar, cheddar, large'. Words can be so easy to misunderstand, and I'm guessing there's plenty of times when your mum has a go at you because she can't understand what you're saying or your dad tries to drop a 'cool' into everyday conversation. Sometimes what we say can be easily confused, especially if we're not in the habit of saying what we mean. The Bible says '…Let your 'Yes' be yes, and your 'No,' no…' Does that mean you have to eat a dictionary before you speak to anyone to make sure you use all the correct grammar? Not at all. But it's really important to actually think about what you're saying to people. Only say 'yes' if you really mean it, not because you've felt pressured into it. Stop and think for a moment before your instant reply to your parents is 'no'. Is there a chance you could you actually do what they're asking? By thinking first, you'll build strong relationships and people will know they can trust your 'Yes' to be yes, and your 'No' to be no.

Soulfood: Gen 24:1-25:18, Matt 18:10-20, Ps 58, Pr 6:12-15

content.title: Barneys are bad!
content.introtext:
Barneys are bad!

'…Let's not have any quarrelling…' Genesis 13:8 NIV

We're not talking about huge purple dinosaurs, but about the kind of barney when it's your face that turns purple from shouting! Abram and Lot could have fallen out badly when it came to parting ways and deciding who'd get what bit of land. But Abram realised that an argument wasn't the way forward so he bit the bullet and did something about it. We can learn a couple of things from old Abe here that help us handle conflict and confrontations in our own relationships. (1) Don't wait for someone else to make the first move. Abe realised that, left unchecked, a problem could arise so he took the initiative and nipped it in the bud. Growth and blessing call for wisdom. So be wise: if you sense a problem between you and someone else, try to make the first move in putting things right. (2) Don't worry about missing out on something; God will make it up to you. Lot chose the best fields when Abe gave him the choice and it might have looked to Abram that he was left with the dud end of the deal. But read on to the end of the story, and you'll see that it all went pear-shaped for Lot, but Abram's decisions blessed all mankind. God's plans for you are bigger than who wins the argument. Try to be a peacemaker and leave the barneys behind you.

Soulfood: Gen 20-23, Matt 18:1-9, Ps 53, Pr 6:9-11

content.title: Good or goody-two-shoes?
content.introtext:
Good or goody-two-shoes?

'Whenever you are able, do good to people who need help.…' Proverbs 3:27 NCV

Dan Clark tells the story of a time when he and his dad were queuing for the circus, behind a really poor family who were so excited it was obvious they had never been to the circus before. You could tell just by looking at them. The attendant asked how many tickets, and the man proudly replied, 'I'd like to buy eight children's tickets and two adults'.' But when the attendant said the price, the man's wife dropped his hand, and her head drooped. The man leaned in and whispered, 'How much…?' The attendant repeated the price. The man obviously didn't have the money—he looked crushed. Behind them, Dan's dad pulled $20 out of his pocket and dropped it on the floor. Then he tapped the man on the shoulder, pointed to the money and said, 'Excuse me, I think this must be yours.' The man knew exactly what was going on. He looked straight into Dan's father's eyes, took his hand, shook it, and with a tear streaming down his face replied, 'Thank you, thank you, sir. This really means a lot to me and my family.' There wasn't enough money for Dan and his dad to go to the circus as well, so they got in the car and drove home. But it didn't matter to them. They'd blessed a whole family, and none of them would ever forget that. That's called doing good. Can you see any good you could do today?

Soulfood: Gen 17-19, Matt 17:14-27, Ps 40:9-17, Pr 6:6-8

content.title: Faith life
content.introtext:
Faith life

'All these great people died in faith...' Hebrews 11:13 NCV

What does it mean to die in faith? Or even to live in faith? It means trusting in God, believing His promises; even if everything around you is pointing in the opposite direction. It means knowing that God is in charge and living like it, even when everyone around you is telling you not to. It means holding on to God's promises, His love for you, and His perfect plan for your life, even when everything feels like it's falling apart. Take a look at Abraham; in faith, he and his very old wife became parents when it really looked like they couldn't! Or Noah; how crazy did it seem to build a mahoosive boat in the middle of dry land? I bet everyone around him was thinking what a nutter he was, but his faith proved right and his family were the only ones still with dry feet when the flood came. But the people of faith didn't always see God's promises fulfilled. Abe didn't see the complete ultimate fulfilment of God's promises for his life but still died believing in God's promises. Follow old Abe's example today: trust God, live your life in a way that shows you have faith in Him, no matter what your circumstances are. Trust that God will do everything in His way, in His time, and for His glory; and then you'll have a faith life.

Soulfood: Gen 13-16, Matt 17:1-13, Ps 40:1-8, Pr 6:1-5

content.title: Turn aside and listen to God
content.introtext:
Turn aside and listen to God

'I must turn aside to see this great sight...' Exodus 3:3 ESV

Moses was just doing his job minding sheep out in the desert when he saw a bush on fire. No big deal at first, until he noticed the bushfire wasn't burning up the bush. Moses said, 'I must turn aside to see this great sight.' In that moment, everything depended on his willingness to interrupt his daily routine and make time for God. Moses could have said, 'I'm busy,' and kept on going. But he didn't; he 'turned aside' and his life changed! God wanted to begin a new nation with Moses leading it. The timing seemed strange. With God, it often does. Forty years previously Moses had been young, the product of the finest education system in the world. He had powerful connections and high hopes. But now he was a nobody, a lowly shepherd in a forgotten desert, rejected by his people and a fugitive on the run. He asked God: 'Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh?' (Exodus 3:11 ESV) Moses was thinking: Nobody knows me. I don't speak too well. And my track record isn't too good. But God said, I know about your past, and it doesn't matter. Your failure and inadequacies are no longer the ultimate truth about you. You are what you are, but you're not yet what you will be; because I will be with you. Do you need direction for your life? Slow down, turn aside, and listen to God. What He has to say is more important than anything else you'll hear.

Soulfood: 1 Sam 3:1-11, Act 9:1-9

content.title: You can't save yourself!
content.introtext:
You can't save yourself!

'…Not of yourselves; it is the gift of God.' Ephesians 2:8 NKJ

Lifeguards know more than how to stand next to the pool chatting people up, or spin their whistle around really fast, or how to give dirty looks to anyone who does a dive bomb. They know how to save people from drowning! If a lifeguard is trying to save you, you need to stop kicking around trying to save yourself. When you're struggling in deep water you tire easily and sink faster. You also drag others down with you. That's why a lifeguard will tell you to stop struggling and trust him. It's true with God too: He doesn't need your help to save you! The Bible says, '...God's mercy is great, and He loved us very much. Though we were spiritually dead because of the things we did against God, he gave us new life with Christ… And he raised us up with Christ and gave us a seat with Him in the heavens…I mean that you have been saved by grace through believing. You did not save yourselves; it was a gift from God. It was not the result of your own efforts, so you cannot brag about it. (Ephesians 2:4-9 NCV) When Nicodemus came to talk to Jesus about salvation he thought Jesus would give him a list of religious do's and don'ts to follow. What this top-dog religious leader failed to grasp is that God is not impressed with our good works; He loves us but in His eyes '…each of our good deeds is merely a filthy rag…' (Isaiah 64:6 CEV) There's a humbling thought! Paul writes: '…His grace…is a free gift…' (Romans 3:24 NCV), and He's offering it to you today. Will you accept it?

Soulfood: Gen 10-12, Matt 16:13-28, Ps 36, Pr 5:21-23

content.title: Thinking of quitting? Don't!
content.introtext:
Thinking of quitting? Don't!

'…Be steadfast…' 1 Corinthians 15:58 NKJ

Heard of Handel? These days his music is what your gran rocks out to on Classic FM but in his day he was like a rock legend! Handel was a musical genius. At 21, he was a musician at the very top of his game. When he turned to composing, he gained immediate fame and soon was appointed Kapellmeister (that's German for the dude in charge of the tunes) to the guy who later became King George I. By the time he was 40, he was world-famous. (This might not seem like much now but in the days before tv or the internet, it was a mega-achievement.) But despite his talent and fame he faced huge difficulties. Rivalry with other composers was fierce. Audiences were fickle; sometimes they didn't turn out for his performances. Several times he found himself on the verge of bankruptcy. He suffered a stroke which left his right arm limp and damaged the use of four fingers on his right hand. Although he recovered, it left him battling depression. Finally, at 56, Handel decided to retire. Discouraged, miserable and consumed with debt, he gave what he considered would be his last concert. Filled with self-pity, he quit. But later that year, something incredible happened. A friend gave Handel a play to read based on the life of Christ. Immediately the floodgates of inspiration opened. For three weeks Handel wrote almost non-stop. In 24 days he had completed the 260-page manuscript of his most famous work: The Messiah. Don't give up!

Soulfood: Gen 7-9, Matt 16:1-12, Ps 33:13-22, Pr 5:15-20

content.title: Have you heard?
content.introtext:
Have you heard?

'…God has come to help his people…' Luke 7:16 NCV

Jesus walks into a village and sees a woman as she wails and staggers alongside the body of her son being carried for burial. Luke says: 'When the Lord saw her, he felt very sorry for her and said, 'Don't cry.' He went up and touched the coffin, and…said, 'Young man, I tell you, get up!' And the son sat up and began to talk. Then Jesus gave him back to his mother. All the people were amazed and began praising God, saying, '…God has come to help his people.'' (Luke 7:13-16 NCV) Many of the Jews believed that God had forgotten about them. The Romans were in charge and life was a nightmare; there was no hope. Then the stories start: 'Have you heard about the man preaching that God loves us? You know he's healing people and giving out free food?' 'Have you heard He makes friends with losers and sinners or about that kid he raised from the dead?' For the religious leaders these stories were full of heresy but for the lost, sick, broken and abused, the stories were bursting with hope. If you're looking to get life sorted, this is the good news: God isn't up above the world, He's in it, getting His hands dirty and looking to the needs of His people!

Soulfood: Gen 4-6, Matt 15:29-39, Ps 33:1-12, Pr 5:7-14

content.title: Impressive stuff
content.introtext:
Impressive stuff

'When Jesus heard this, He was amazed at him…' Luke 7:9 NIV

We know the routine by now. An awkward-looking hopeful stands fidgeting before three judges. The nice judge says nicely, 'So what are you going to sing?' and then smiles. The nervous hopeful whispers the name of a multi-award-winning superstar's most famous and difficult song, opens their mouth and begins to sing. The nice judge listens smiling, the honest and important judge rolls his eyes and the last judge attempts to hide his sniggering. The hopeful leaves rejected and in tears. Another unlikely-looking person wanders in and the judges expect more of the same. But then the new contestant begins to sing with a voice that is beautiful, harmonious, staggeringly good. The judges sit with mouths wide open. They are blown away, impressed and most of all amazed! In today's reading, we discover someone who impressed Jesus so much that Luke says Jesus was amazed. Imagine, Jesus open-mouthed with astonishment! And who pulled this off; who was able to wow God? Not one of the disciples, not a super-religious Bible boffin, but a Roman soldier. Luke puts it this way: 'When Jesus heard this, he was so surprised that he turned and said to the crowd following him, 'In all of Israel I've never found anyone with this much faith!'' (Luke 7:9 CEV) Want to impress Jesus? Simple. Just trust Him.

Soulfood: Gen 1-3, Matt 15:15-28, Ps 28, Pr 5:3-6

content.title: Keep preparing yourself
content.introtext:
Keep preparing yourself

'…I have seen a son of Jesse…who is skilful…' 1 Samuel 16:18 NKJ

David didn't suddenly become an expert with a slingshot when Goliath rocked up, or suddenly know how to play power chords on the harp when King Saul called for a private gig at the palace. He had already taken the long, slow, disciplined route of learning those skills. David had no idea what his future held; he simply got stuck into discovering and developing his gifts. If you think you have learnt all that you need to know, you'll never grow. At the risk of sounding like a 'life coach', which zone do you live in? The 'challenge zone': 'I attempt to do what I haven't done before'? The 'comfort zone': 'I only do what I already know I can do'? Or the 'coasting zone': 'I don't even do what I've done before'? Take up that challenge and you might end up using those skills! David's brothers knew his skills, yet none of them told King Saul about him. When Saul needed a musician: 'A man named Jesse who lives in Bethlehem has a son who can play the harp,' one official said. 'He's a brave warrior, he's good-looking, he can speak well, and the Lord is with him.' (1 Samuel 16:18, CEV) David didn't compete with his brothers or complain about his status as a shepherd. He just kept working on his relationship with God and sharpening his skills. When the time was right, God promoted him. So keep at it; prepare yourself. Ecc 9-12, Matt 15:1-14, Ps 5, Pr 5:1-2

content.title: Five don'ts that make a difference
content.introtext:
Five don'ts that make a difference

'…Get understanding.' Proverbs 4:7 NKJ

Today, five lessons about life that make all the difference: (1) Don't worry, just do your best. God accepts no less, but He demands no more. 'Trust in the Lord, and do good…and He shall give you the desires of your heart.' (Psalm 37:3-4 NKJ) (2) Don't rush it, do it right. 'Good planning and hard work lead to prosperity, but hasty shortcuts lead to poverty.' (Proverbs 21:5 NLT) (3) Don't believe something is impossible without trying it. When you are in God's will, doing things God's way, sensitive to His timing and willing to stick at it, your problems are just a platform for Him to work on your behalf '…we must wait patiently and confidently.' (Romans 8:25 NLT) (4) Don't waste your time. Put first things first and ask yourself, 'What is it that only I can do, or do best?' Only when you've answered that question will you know what you should do. Despite what you're thinking right now, it's probably not got a whole lot to do with Guitar Hero! (5) Don't just talk about it…do it. Lots of people have good intentions but those intentions have to become actions. Get specific about your diet and your devotions, your finances and your family. 'If it's to be, it's up to me.' Write those words on a card and read them regularly. James writes: '…faith by itself, if it does not have works, is dead.' (James 2:17 NKJ)

Soulfood: Ecc 5-8, Matt 14:22-36, Ps 149, Pr 4:25-27

content.title: Loving people
content.introtext:
Loving people

'…Love one another…' John 15:12 NKJ

Hearts, cherubs firing arrows, Valentine's Day, diamond rings, soppy text messages, wedding bells… Maybe these are the sort of things that come to mind when you hear the word 'love'. So what on earth does this verse mean when it tells us to 'love one another'? Does that mean we all have to go around gooey-eyed, hugging and kissing, with a permanent grin on our faces, telling everyone how awesome they are whether we know them or not? Errrrrr, no thank you! But this is a command we've been given from God, and loving others is something we have to do proactively (meaning it has to start with us). Here are 3 hints to help you really love someone: (1) Give them some confidence. You're not the only one who has bad days. Under the 'it's fine' mask that your mates and family wear, you might find they're actually struggling today. So remind them what God says: '…I will never leave you nor forsake you.' (Hebrews 13:5 NKJ) (2) Pump them up. Compliment someone when they least expect it, without expecting them to say something nice in return! Look through your Bible and see how often God tells us how special we are—pass some of that on! (3) Use your ears. Often people just need to be listened to, to feel they're valued. So put those lug-holes on the side of your head to good use!

Valentine's Day Soulfood: Eph 5:21-33, S of S 2:1-7, Ps 45, Prov 5:15-19

content.title: Get to know God better
content.introtext:
Get to know God better

'Can you discover the depths of God?...' Job 11:7 NAS

It's not what you know but who you know. If you know the band, you get backstage passes. Or if your sister has a job at a pizza store, you know when to come in for a special. The Bible also says there are things we can have just because we know God. (1) Blessing. The more you know God and obey His will, the more you'll experience His blessings. 'If you obey all the decrees and commands I am giving you today, all will be well with you and your children…' (Deuteronomy 4:40 NLT) (2) Peace. 'Grace and peace be multiplied to you in the knowledge of God…' (2 Peter 1:2 NAS) The more you know God, the more you'll be at peace. Sure, tough stuff happens, but facing that stuff with God makes a massive difference. (3) Wisdom. Paul prayed that God would give the Ephesians '…a spirit of wisdom and of revelation in the knowledge of Him.' (Ephesians 1:17 NAS) Wisdom is seeing things the right way. Revelation is when God opens your mind and shows you things you otherwise wouldn't know. (4) Freedom. '…when you did not know God, you were slaves...' (Galatians 4:8 NAS) Without the confidence that comes from knowing God, you become a slave to circumstances, emotions, or other people's opinions. Refuse to live that way. Instead, get to know God better.

Soulfood: Ecc 1-4, Matt 14:13-21, Ps 145:14-21, Pr 4:23-24

content.title: We don't get what we deserve (2)
content.introtext:
We don't get what we deserve (2)

'…I go to prepare a place for you.' John 14:2 NKJV

Remember yesterday's reading? Go on then read it again, we're not going anywhere… Now you're back, we want to talk a bit more about the story in Matthew 20. So it's the end of a hot day and all the workers have been paid the same, including the ones who haven't been sweating in the sun all day. The workers who have been slogging away all day complain to the boss because they think the whole deal is just not fair. Here is what the Bible says: 'The owner answered one of them, 'Friend, I didn't cheat you. I paid you exactly what we agreed on. Take your money now and go! What business is it of yours if I want to pay them the same that I paid you? Don't I have the right to do what I want with my own money? Why should you be jealous, if I want to be generous?'' (CEV) It's so easy for us to look at other people and focus on what they've got instead of what God has given us. There is always someone who seems to have got a better deal in life. Like the guy who looks like a film star, plays every instrument in the worship band and invented time travel for his high school Science project. People like that make it easy to not like and be disappointed with yourself! Know what will make your life easier and happier? Stop comparing and complaining. Focus on what you have got, like forgiveness, God's amazing plan for your life, a place in heaven. And that's just the beginning.

Soulfood: Rom 15-16, Matt 14:1-12, Ps 145:1-13, Pr 4:20-22

content.title: We don't get what we deserve (1)
content.introtext:
We don't get what we deserve (1)

'…want to give the man who was hired last the same as I gave you...' Matthew 20:14 NIV

Ever had casual employment? You probably didn't score the greatest job in the world, but while you were plucking dead chickens, stuffing envelopes or picking strawberries, you were undoubtedly looking forward to the end of the week when you will get your hard-earned cash! After all, it was just what you deserve. Jesus told the story of a bloke who hired some workers: some at 6am, some at 9am, some at midday, some at 3pm and some just an hour before quitting time. Amazingly, he paid them all the same wage! Nobody pays a day's wage for one hour's work. Except God. A last-minute convert receives the same grace as a lifetime servant. Have a quick look at Luke 23:40-42 and read about the thief on the cross next to Jesus. Did he deserve to be saved and promised heaven right at the end of his life? Well no. But if God gave us what we deserved, none of us would be saved. Grace means getting the life we don't deserve! The Prodigal Son wasted his possessions. But he returned. And when he did '...his father saw him and had compassion, and ran and...kissed him.' (Luke 15:20 NKJ) The Father loves to bless us, even when we don't deserve it.

Soulfood: Rom 12-14, Matt 13:47-58, Ps 141, Pr 4:18-19

content.title: The 'M' word
content.introtext:
The 'M' word

'…a man shall…be joined to his wife…' Genesis 2:24 NKJ

So it might still be a long way off, but don't pretend you don't spend time thinking about it! Getting hitched, finding 'The One', the 'M' word; marriage! A long time ago God said this about marriage: '…a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and they shall become one flesh.' (Genesis 2:24 NKJ) This verse is read at almost every church wedding. The problem is, a lot of people standing up there at the front and taking those vows haven't really realised what they're promising. Marriage means that all your other relationships (except your relationship with God), now come after your relationship with your wife or husband. Marriage isn't about making space for someone else in your life; it's about re-building your life around them. Here's another thought. When you read the story of Adam and Eve in the book of Genesis, the point is that Eve was specially created because Adam really needed her; he couldn't do it on his own, he was incomplete. Think about this: unless you've found someone to whom you can say, 'I'm incomplete without you', you're probably not ready for marriage. Marriage is a huuuge decision, so don't rush into it through a fog of passion. Allow God to transform your heart into the kind of heart that can offer the sort of love that will help to make your partner whole.

Soulfood: Rom 9:17-11:36, Matt 13:36-46, Ps 138, Pr 4:14-17

content.title: Chain reaction
content.introtext:
Chain reaction

'Then it happened…' 2 Samuel 11:2 NKJ

He was the Jack Bauer of the ancient world. David rocks Goliath, David goes on the run when the king decides he's a threat. It's a right royal thriller—after all, David gets to be king. But then things began to unravel when he let down his guard. The Bible says, 'Then it happened.' What a teaser! David was coasting into middle-age, getting soft, letting other people fight his battles while he stayed home. Maybe, as he was standing on the palace rooftop that night, he wondered, 'Do I still have it?' Then his eyes caught sight of a total babe: Bathsheba. But it's what he didn't see that ruined him. He didn't see that sleeping with her would eventually make him into a murderer. He didn't see that in the years ahead four of his children would die as a result. He didn't see that his action would eventually split his kingdom in half. That's the problem with sin: it always sets off a chain reaction. If you're doing things you shouldn't be doing, watch out! You're not seeing the whole picture. David tried all sorts of things to cover his tracks. They just made things worse and he still got caught! Sin always stirs up a whole load of future trouble that's impossible to see at the time. Seriously, sin is not worth it! Think again before you trigger a chain reaction like David did.

Soulfood: Rom 7:1-9:16, Matt 13:24-35, Ps 134, Pr 4:5-13

content.title: Who comes first?
content.introtext:
Who comes first?

'Seek the Kingdom of God above all else...' Matt 6:33 NLT

Some people seem to have just one ambition in life: to get their own way all the time. And if anyone or anything gets in the way there's trouble. If there's any of that desire in you today, then here's a hard fact for you: get ready to self-destruct. It probably won't happen today or even tomorrow, but some time down the track, meltdown day will arrive. You see, it's impossible to gain true satisfaction in life outside of trusting, long-term relationships. And trusting long-term relationships are never one-sided: there are two people in every friendship, every partnership and every marriage. How can these relationships survive if one side always takes and never gives? How can they last if one side always expects to be satisfied but doesn't offer anything back? There's one sure-fire way to make certain that you don't fall into this trap: give your life to a cause bigger than yourself. Jesus especially loved talking about one subject—the Kingdom of Heaven, also called the Kingdom of God. It's not a kingdom like Britain with Queen Elizabeth or Jordan with King Abdullah. This isn't about geography; the Kingdom is breaking out all over the world! The Kingdom is anywhere that people lay down their own plans and give themselves to God's perfect plans. The Kingdom is life as God always meant it to be. How about putting the Kingdom first today?

Soulfood: Rom 3:21-6:23, Matt 13:10-23, Ps 125, Pr 4:3-4

content.title: To Be With You
content.introtext:
To be with you

'God with us' Matt 1:23 NKJ

We often think we're supposed to offer God our acts of service, which is true, but the gift God wants most is simply to be with us. Think about the disciple, Peter; he's such a great example; so totally human! Peter followed Jesus, learned from Him, praised Him and served Him; but he also doubted Him, misunderstood Him and denied Him. Luke records Jesus' last conversation with Peter. Jesus asked him a deeply personal question: 'Do you love Me?' (John 21:15 CEV) Three times He asked Peter. Three times! Peter didn't quite know what to make of it; he was sooo embarrassed. God created us so that He could be with us. Genesis describes to us how, before sin entered the world, God loved to come and walk with the man and woman He had made, just to be with them. Jesus Himself was also known by the name Immanuel, which means 'God with us'. (Isaiah 7:14, Matt 1:23) The Bible ends with a picture of the new heavens and new earth where God once again is right in the middle of His creation, close enough to '...wipe every tear from their eyes...' (Revelation 21:4 NIV) St Augustine summed it all up like this: 'Love God, and do what you will,' because when you truly love God you'll only want to do the things God loves. Today can you hear Him whispering, 'I'd like to spend some time with you.'?

Soulfood: 1 Kings 3:4-28, James 1:2-8

content.title: Who Says
content.introtext:
Who says?

'…Your word is settled in heaven.' Psalm 119:89 NKJ

Ok, lots of Bible today as we look at our word vs God's Word! You say, 'It's impossible.' God says, 'What is impossible with men is possible with God.' (Luke 18:27 NIV) You say, 'I've had it.' He says, 'But those who wait on the Lord, shall renew their strength…' (Isaiah 40:31 NKJ) You say, 'Nobody loves me.' He says, 'I have loved you with an everlasting love…' (Jeremiah 31:3 NIV) You say, 'I've had enough.' He says, 'My grace is sufficient for you…' (2 Corinthians 12:9 NIV) You say, 'I don't know what to do.' He says, 'He shall direct your paths.' (Proverbs 3:6 NKJ) You say, 'I can't do it.' He says, 'I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.' (Philippians 4:13 NKJ) You say, 'It's not worth it.' He says, '…we will reap a harvest if we do not give up.' (Galatians 6:9 NIV) You say, 'I can't forgive myself.' He says, '…in Christ God forgave you.' (Ephesians 4:32 NIV) You say, 'I'm broke.' He says, '...God shall supply all your need…' (Philippians 4:19 NKJ) You say, 'I'm scared.' He says, '…God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power…' (2 Timothy 1:7 NKJ) You say, 'I can't handle this.' He says, 'Cast your cares on the Lord and He will sustain you…' (Psalms 55:22 NIV) You say, 'I'm stupid.' He says, '…if any of you needs wisdom, you should ask God for it…' (James 1:5 NCV) You say, 'I'm all alone.' He says, '…I will never leave you nor forsake you.' (Hebrews 13:5 NKJ)

Soulfood: Rom 1:1 - 3:20, Matt 13:1-9, Ps 67, Pr 4:1-2

content.title: The great exchange
content.introtext:
The great exchange

'God made him…to be sin for us…' 2 Corinthians 5:21 NIV

Have you ever tried to keep the Ten Commandments? Really tried? Ok, so you probably haven't murdered anyone; but that still leaves nine more to go. What about the 'less serious' ones? 'You must not steal.' (Exodus 20:15 NLT) Have you ever stolen anything? No? Not even a paper clip? How many of your music downloads are legal? All of them? Then there's 'You must not tell lies.' (Exodus 20:16 CEV) You say you haven't? Yeah, right! The bad news is that on your very best day, you still fall far short of God's perfect standards. But there's good news too: '…He was pierced for our rebellion, crushed for our sins. He was beaten so we could be whole…' (Isaiah 53:5 NLT) A Chinese convert to Christianity understood this. Before her baptism the pastor questioned her to ensure she understood the meaning of the cross: 'Did Jesus have any sin?' 'Yes,' she replied. Troubled, he repeated the question. 'Yes, He had sin,' she answered again. The pastor set out to correct her, but she insisted, 'Yes! He had mine.' And she was right! This is the great exchange. At the cross, Jesus was taking your place. What was wrong, He made right. He made beauty out of mess. Aren't you glad?

Soulfood: Is 63-66, Matt 12: 38-50, Ps 120, Pr 3:33-35

content.title: Look Out!
content.introtext:
Look Out!

'…God will help her at break of day.' Psalm 46:5 NIV

Life can be pretty unstable…you know those days when your world suddenly gets turned upside down? And then rolls over, only to go SPLAT? When it does, here are five things from Psalm 46 to look out for: (1) Look out for His supply. 'There is a river whose streams make glad…' (Psalm 46:4 NIV) In Old Testament symbolism, rivers represent the way God meets every need you have. When other sources of supply are drying up, don't fear, look for the river! (2) Look out for His presence. The Bible describes the '…city of God, the holy place where the Most High dwells.' (Psalm 46:4 NIV) God's city is a symbol of His presence, and where He is, then there's peace and order! (3) Look out for His newness. 'God will help [you] at break of day.' (Psalm 46:5 NIV) Daybreak is a symbol of new beginnings; this is to reassure you that problems don't last forever—beyond every time of trouble and testing is a new day. (4) Look out for His works. 'Come…see the works of the Lord…' (Psalm 46:8 NIV) Noticing afresh the amazing things God does every day, the small things as well as the big things, will build your faith muscles back up again. (5) Look out for His peace. Your life is built on the rock solid foundation of His faithfulness, so you can live by the Scripture, 'Be still, and know that I am God…' (Psalm 46:10 NIV)

Soulfood: Is 58-62, Matt 12:22-37, Ps 108, Pr 3:31-32

content.title: November's Prepared, planted, placed, pruned, prospered (2)
content.introtext:
God planted a garden...there He put the man whom He had formed.

Genesis 2:8 NKJV
It's pretty likely that gardening programmes aren't filling up your sky+ hard-drive so lets deal with the basics: what does it mean to plant? Technically it is 'To bury seeds beyond human view so that they germinate and eventually produce fruit.' (you did know that, right?) Now think of the Creator of the universe, as He stoops down and plants blessings and opportunities to grow in your life. Can't see the blessings or opportunities? If you walk out into a field (ok, you might not do that often but use your imagination) and don't see a crop, it doesn't mean the seeds aren't there; God has planted things in your life that will spring out of the mud at different times. Everything God has for you hasn't come up yet, so don't give up, or walk away and say, 'That's all there is'. There are talents in you that haven't been discovered and dreams that haven't been fulfilled. That's what the battle is about! The Devil is fighting you over your destiny. He knows good stuff is planted in you and he's trying to kill the seed. Don't let him. You're not the person you'll be six months or six years from now, because there's a time factor; everything doesn't come to harvest at the same time. You have to have faith and patience; otherwise you'll miss what God has for you.

content.title: The power of encouragement (2)
content.introtext:
The power of encouragement (2)

'Pleasant words are…health to the bones.' Proverbs 16:24 NKJ

One day a principal called in three teachers and said, 'You three are the finest in the system, so we're giving you 90 high-IQ students to see what you can do with them.' At the end of the year the students achieved an amazing 30% more than the other students in the school. The principal called the three teachers in and said, 'I've a confession to make. You didn't have the most promising students: they were run-of-the-mill. We picked them at random.' The teachers naturally decided that their exceptional teaching skills must have been the reason for the students' fantastic results. 'I've another confession,' said the principal. 'You're not the finest teachers in the system; your names were the first three drawn out of the hat.' So why did those students and teachers perform at such a level? Because they were encouraged to believe they could! This idea of believing is right at the heart of what it means to be a Christian. See, your relationship with Jesus is a two-way street. It doesn't mean that you sing songs and say prayers to Him so that He doesn't get insecure about how great He is! He doesn't need to know it—you do! Nobody knows you like Jesus: He sees the amazing potential you have. He put it there before you were even born! He's constantly cheering you on with shouts of 'YES, YOU CAN!' So listen for His voice and believe it!

SoulFood: Is 53-57, Matt 12:15-21, Ps 111, Pr 3:29-30

content.title: The power of encouragement (1)
content.introtext:
The power of encouragement (1)

Pleasant words are…health to the bones.’ Proverbs 16:24 NKJ

Two huge box–office smash hits in the last few years have been the film versions of The Chronicles of Narnia and The Lord of the Rings. Did you know that the authors of the original books—CS Lewis and JRR Tolkien—were both professors at Oxford University and were really good friends? Every week they’d meet for lunch to chat about their writing projects. It was Tolkien who encouraged Lewis, a full–on atheist, to explore Christianity. The result? Lewis gave his life to Jesus! Later, he encouraged Tolkien to continue writing fiction and seek publication. If they hadn’t have kept cheering each other on through thick and thin, the world wouldn’t have some of the greatest stories ever written. Everybody needs to hear words of encouragement. The Bible says, ‘Pleasant words are like a honeycomb, sweetness to the soul and health to the bones.’ (Proverbs 16:24 NKJ) Everyone who receives encouragement, young or old, success or dropout, famous or unknown, is changed by it. Another famous author—Mark Twain—once said, ‘One compliment can keep me going for a whole month.’ A word of encouragement from a teacher can turn the course of a student’s life; a word of encouragement from a boss can inspire a worker to reach their potential; a word of encouragement from a friend can swing a decision from ‘giving in’ to ‘going for it’. So help someone go for it by being an encourager today! SoulFood: Is 49–52, Matt 12:1–14, Ps 107:33–43, Pr 3:27–28

content.title: The 'D' Word
content.introtext:
The ‘D' Word

'...those whom the Lord loves He disciplines...' Hebrews 12:6 NAS

If there's a word that's seriously hard to swallow it's discipline. Sure, your great-granddad who fought in World War 2 probably takes three pills of discipline a day with his afternoon cup of tea, but didn't discipline pass its use-by date centuries ago? Well, maybe discipline is getting out of fashion but we're seriously mistaken if we think we can live without it. The Bible is full of examples of what happens to people when discipline is chucked out the window. Check out old Eli, Israel's High Priest: he had two sons who would've been right at home on some dodgy TV show. We simply read, ‘...He knew that his sons refused to respect Me, and he let them get away with it.' (1 Samuel 3:13 CEV) Perhaps Eli heard about the terrible things his sons were doing and said, ‘Now, boys, you know you shouldn't do that.' And the boys said, ‘Yes, Dad,' then went right back to ripping off the temple worshippers and playing around with the servant girls. They didn't have a bit of self-discipline between them and their dad was worse than useless at pulling them into line. Self-discipline-making the right choices minute by minute, hour by hour, takes time to develop fully. That's why we need people to remind us what self-control means. Seriously, if today you find a bit of tough love coming your way you need to welcome it, not reject it.
SoulFood: Is 45-48, Matt 11:20-30, Ps 107:23-32, Pr 3:25-26

content.title: K1 (Part B)
content.introtext:
…MAKE THE KINGDOM OF GOD YOUR PRIMARY CONCERN.

MATTHEW 6.33 NLT
Here’s some key personal qualities – a checklist for anyone who wants to do great things for God: a) gracious ‘“God blesses those who are merciful…” “Stop judging others, and you will not be judged”’ (Matthew 5:7; Matthew 7:1 NLT) b) restorer ‘When…your brother or sister has something against you…go and make peace with that person…’ (Matthew 5:23-24 NCV) c) teachable ‘Anyone who listens to my teaching and obeys me is wise…’ (Matthew 7:24 NLT) d) creative ‘…overflowing in many expressions of thanks to God’ (2 Corinthians 9:12 NIV) e) courageous ‘Look, I am sending you out as sheep among wolves…don’t be afraid…’ (Matthew 10:16&26 NLT) f) willing ‘Anyone who does the will of my Father in heaven is My brother and sister...’ (Matthew 12:50 NLT) g) surrendered ‘If any of you wants to be My follower, you must put aside your selfish ambition, shoulder your cross, and follow Me’ (Matthew 16:24 NLT) h) repentant ‘…unless you turn from your sins and become as little children, you will never get into the Kingdom of Heaven’ (Matthew 18:3 NLT) i) humble ‘But those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted’ (Matthew 23:12 NLT) j) servant ‘But among you it should be quite different. Whoever wants to be a leader among you must be your servant’ (Matthew 20:26 NLT). If you’re willing to make Jesus Lord of your life, make His Word the last word on all issues, and seek the fullness of His Spirit – you can live this lifestyle too!

content.title: Flick the switch!
content.introtext:
'Your Word is a lamp to my feet and a light to my path.' Psalm 119:105 NKJ

Anyone who's been camping knows the feeling: you wake up in the middle of the night desperate for the loo. You lie in your tent and try to ignore the feeling but as time ticks by, you have to get up. Grumbling, you rummage for your trusty torch and start to trek across the site. It's pitch black, but as you flick the switch on your torch, a beam lights up the ground in front of you. Listen: 'Your Word is a lamp to my feet and a light to my path.' The Bible is the Word of God in printed form. When you open it up and read it, like that torch, you flick the light on in your life. It can answer a problem, give direction for your life and help you get to know God better. It's your trusty God-torch! He gives you His Word and Spirit to help you stick to the right path and go in the right direction.

The Bible uses the example of darkness and light over and over again to describe the difference between people who have found God (or been found by Him-depending on how you look at it) and those who haven't. The Apostle Paul said to his mates in Corinth: '...God, who said, "Let light shine out of darkness," made His light shine in our hearts...' (2 Corinthians 4:6 NIV) Maybe today you could pray for your friends who have not yet had their lives brightened by God, that they would suddenly see what it's all about.



SoulFood: Lev 23:26-25:55, Luke 21:29-38, Ps 50:16-23, Pr 10: 4-7

content.title: Looking forward to death
content.introtext:
'Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death...' Psalm 23:4 NKJ

A bit of a morbid thought, but imagine the doc tells you that you've just 24 hours to live. What do you do?

Do you pick a playlist of tracks to accompany your coffin down the aisle? Do you get a second opinion from another doc? Do you update Facebook telling everyone you love them and you'll miss them?

The last thing you'd want to do is look forward to the day of death, right? But bizarrely enough, a Christian can look forward to death. We don't have to be scared even though we will all 'walk through the valley of the shadow of death'. Why? Because death is not the end; it's only the beginning.

What we believe is this: '...since we died with Christ, we know we will also share His new life. We are sure of this because Christ rose from the dead, and He will never die again. Death no longer has any power over Him.' (Romans 6:8-9 NLT)

If the shadow of death seems ghostly dark, please know that you won't be alone for the journey. Jesus will take your hand and lead you home.



SoulFood: Num 1-2, Mark 1:1-13, Ps 144:1-8, Pr 10:19-21

content.title: Come dine with me
content.introtext:
'You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies...' Psalm 23:5 NKJ

Although we tend to forget it, there's more to dinner than grub. It's about sharing hearts and lives.

John 21 sees Jesus and Peter having a celestial perfect-party moment. Our Pete should be the last person at Jesus' dinner soire; after all, he has just let Jesus down three times in public. Loving people would be a whole lot easier if they weren't so unlovable, right? Like you buy a chocolate bar from the guy at work fundraising to send his kids to camp and he looks at you like dog droppings as you wait for your change. content.title: Money matters (1)
content.introtext:
'Honour the Lord...with the best part of everything...' Proverbs 3:9 NLT

True, money is a passport to your life, as it can get you into pleasure island; but equally, money is a passport to other people's lives, as your cash can be the difference between life and death (seriously, your spare cents can be a lifeline to children living in poverty around the world). So, isn't it about time we started to manage the money? With God's help and some common-sense suggestions you can start making your cents work for good.

First, compare the market. If you spend $29.95 on a CD from a record shop that you could've bought for $19.95 at a supermarket, that's ten bucks in the record shop's pocket, that could've gone to the Salvos or an aid organisation to help rescue a child from a desperate situation. Second, you have the spending power. Top brands use clever marketing to suggest to you that your life would be so much better with their shoes or their jeans. The bottom line is they're not interested in how good you look; they just want your cash. Take back the power: ask yourself, 'Do I really need this...or could I put my money to better use elsewhere?'

Third, tomorrow never comes. Don't think: 'I'll start giving money once I've got a good job or once I can afford it'. Get into the habit now. If you're generous with a little; God will trust you to be generous with a lot. Give God your first and best.



SoulFood: Phil 1-4, Luke 22:14-23, Ps 43, Pr 10:10

content.title: Money matters (2)
content.introtext:
'Honour the Lord...with the best part of everything...' Proverbs 3:9 NLT

Following on from yesterday's look at managing money for good, today we're going to look at how to make money. Ok, so you're somewhere between selling the 'perfume' you attempted to make from rose petals aged five, and getting a full-time job-the point is you're never too young to be entrepreneurial for God.

Remember how Jesus praised the poor old widow for giving all she had, even though it was only spare change? Well guess what? Even though you might not own a flash department store, any bit of spare change is welcome in God's economy. Some ideas:

(1) A carwash service: There may be people you know whose lives are too hectic and busy to take care of their car. Explain that you want to raise money for a disaster relief fund and offer a car shampoo and wax service. (2) A dog walking service: If you're not scared of the four-legged gnashers, how about giving some tired mongrel owner a break by offering to take their pet walkies? Any hard cash could be sent straight to your church's mission pot. Or (3) A painting service: Don the overalls and busy your brushstrokes over the church fence. All for a worthwhile fee, of course.

Be creative with your ideas and remember don't place yourself in situations of unnecessary risk and always tell your parent or guardian what you're doing first. But forget about your personal gain-make money for mission your main motive.



SoulFood: Dan 1-2, Luke 22:24-38, Ps 127, Pr 10:11

content.title: Problem solved
content.introtext:
'God...is the...controller of all things.' 1 Timothy 6:15 PHPS

We all get that fluttery feeling in our stomachs-it might be confirmation that last night's turkey twizzlers did actually need a further ten minutes in the oven or it might mean you're suffering with a bad case of worry. So how do you stop that seasick sensation? First, always ensure your food is piping hot. Second, get a grip on your anxiety.

Scribble down your problem on paper. What exactly are you worrying about? Be specific. Then put your brain in gear. Write down alternative solutions to your problem. Weigh each solution up-ask yourself 'What've I got to lose?' and 'What've I got to gain?' Face up to your fear. Now you have it on paper, face each possible outcome and prepare yourself what it would mean if the worst did happen.

Commit yourself to improving the situation. Is there something you could do, practically, that would help ensure the best possible outcome? Most importantly give it over to God. Pray for wisdom. Bend your ear to what He's saying through the Word. After all, He is 'the...controller of all things'. Shape your problems into praises and watch your problem perspective-shift. '...if any of you needs wisdom, you should ask God for it. He is generous and enjoys giving to all people, so He will give you wisdom. But...you must...not doubt.' (James 1:5-6 NCV)



SoulFood: Dan 3-4, Luke 22:39-46, Ps 130, Pr 10:12
